Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our Half Yearly Results Presentation.
This is our agenda for today.
I'm going to give a short introduction, and then Julia will present a financial review of the first half year.
Cressida Hogg, who's our managing partner of the Infrastructure business, will then give you an overview of this important part of 3i's investment activity.
And finally, I'll review our strategic progress and cover the outlook and priorities for the next six months.
As I said in the statement this morning, we've increased momentum throughout the business.
Our portfolio has delivered a good performance, achieving a gross portfolio return of 8.
7% for the six months until the 30th of September.
Total return was lower at 3.
8%, although NAV growth over the last 12 months is over 15%.
We've made good progress in terms of strategic development, and we now have three strong platforms for growth.
In my last few presentations to you, I've talked about planning and organizing for growth.
We've now moved into the delivery phase.
And I'll give you more detail on this later.
But before that, Julia will review our financial performance.
Well, I think what we're looking to do overall is deliver 15% returns to shareholders.
That will come in a combination of forms, will come from the earnings growth on the portfolio.

We typically do see a step-up when we sell assets open above the carrying value, so that gives an additional boost to return; and of course, from the income streams from managing third-party assets, which clearly will start to rise as we incorporate the Debt Management business.
I think if you look at this half year's performance, I mean, the way I try and look at this is to sort of x out multiple movement, both up and down, whether year and a half, half-year period.
And so I think what they're all about in terms of the overall consistency with that delivery of that trend.
I think we're learning to live with an environment where everything a financial company does is immediately reported in the press.
So you have a pretty good view on the pipeline of potential realizations that are coming forward.

What I can say is when we look at the assets that have been talked about, a number of our big industrial companies, particularly in Continental Europe, we expect to achieve extremely attractive prices for these assets because they are really high quality businesses.
One of the businesses that's being talked about that I referred to, NORMA, is just a sensational business.
That has a potential to be a very, very strong IPO candidate, not just a potential trade sale.
It's a very attractive business.
And the reason it's attractive is because it's got great exposure to developing markets.

One of the things that we'd be pushing across all of our industrial portfolio is where they haven't already got strong market access in India, China or South America, really helping them to move that forward.
And that's what makes these assets very attractive.
I mean, one of the themes that we've been focused on is how do we access that developing market growth.
And I think there are two ways to do that.

One is to invest directly in Asian companies, which clearly we're doing as in GBK, but the other is to make sure our great European businesses are also accessing that growth, and therefore we can benefit in that one as well.
So if I take your question on provisions and impairments, first, I mean, clearly, you're right.
If you compare the numbers to last year, then it doesn't look like a particularly good shift.
What it would say is clearly last year had almost the benefit of the previous year where we've had some very, very significant provisions and impairment.
So I'd say last year was unusually low.
And this year, the provision level is 1.
1% of opening portfolio value.
That's an unusual sort of amount.
In terms of the underlying movement sort of in there, it's a small number of assets.
There's no particular themes that I can draw out for you that's spread across the business lines, that's spread across sectors and spread across geographies.
The specific factors to particular investments and don't actually indicate any underlying trend for the overall portfolio.
And then in terms of cash for the period, I mean, clearly there are, as Michael has said, there was a number of transactions that are being well trailed in the market.
Without trying to give you a specific number where we expect cash to be because we would like actually to be investing in the second half.
So it's realistic to assume that there will be some significant realizations coming through.
But in terms of where net debt's going to be, I would hope that we would actually be putting in some decent amount of investment in the second half.
Some of that will come down to timing.
Where we're talking about smaller numbers of large transactions, we can get quite different numbers coming over the year.
So I would hope that we would have investment, but clearly this number of realizations going through.
Bruce Hamilton, Morgan Stanley.
I mean, obviously, the earnings growth was a very good number in the period of up 8%.
And I guess some didn't move.
Given that, to achieve sort of 3.
8% sort of return to shareholders, which is more of 5% if I x out the FX monies.
On the plate, it doesn't look that impressive.

I guess looking forward, if realizations will improve, should we also assume that the earnings growth will moderate? I mean, what would you expect as a more "normal" level of earnings growth? Or is sort of 15% per year something you think is achievable? Danny Garrod from Barclays Capital.

First, just following on from the set of provisions and impairment side, am I right in the detail of the text you do highlighted as health deterioration on the growth side of the portfolio, the percentage being down versus September versus March.
I wonder if you could give some specificity on  what's going on there? And secondly, you mentioned about expectation of H2 OpEx being higher than H1.

Could you give a bit of color what's flat of the H1 or what's expected in H2, given the H1 is strongly below the run rate, shall we say, of last year? So the MWM transaction is expected to bring in about GBP 180 million.
So as Michael said on his slide, that's GBP 224 million.
Thank you, Julia, and good morning.
3i has grown and established a profitable Infrastructure business from small beginnings.

We started investing in infrastructure-type assets through our private equity business that set up Infrastructure as a separate business line in 2005, as the market increasingly began to view infrastructure as a distinct asset class in its own right.
Since then, we've used 3i's investment expertise and capital to make infrastructure investments and to see two external funds, which now have combined assets under management of approximately GBP 1.
This slide gives more detail on our two infrastructure investment vehicles.
3i Infrastructure PLC, in which we have a 33% holding, is a listed investment company, with a market cap and net assets of just under GBP 1 billion.
Its overall objective is to provide shareholders with a total return, net of costs, of 12% per annum when fully invested, with 5% distributors of yield.
The company's focus is on core infrastructure, which we define as assets with stable contracted revenues or some sort of regulatory protection, principally in the transportation and utility space.
It also has exposure to social infrastructure assets and to the Indian infrastructure market, through a commitment of 3i India Infrastructure Fund.
3i Infrastructure's portfolio provides a high degree of inflation linkage, strong income generation, and opportunities for capital growth.
The company last week announced a new investment in Eversholt Rail Group and now has an investment portfolio of 15 assets worth around GBP 800 million and remaining cash balances of GBP 138 million.
The 3i India Infrastructure Funds, in which both 3i Group and 3i Infrastructure have a GBP 250 million commitment, is a GBP 1.
2 billion LP fund established to access the growing infrastructure market in India.
It focuses on the port, airport, road and power sectors.
And its objective is to deliver an 18% net returns to its investors.

Following the announcement of a new investment in GBK Energy on Monday, the fund is now over 50% invested in four assets, including two power generation developers, a port, and a road constructor and operator.
Our two external funds have now established a very strong track record and a good reputation in the market.
With its focus on mature infrastructure assets in developed economies, 3i Infrastructure has built a robust cash-generated portfolio, which has delivered a 9.
5% annualized growth in returns since inception during a period of great market volatility.
Importantly, it has also delivered its 5% yield objective in every year since inception.

And our India funds, with its focus on early-stage infrastructure assets in one fastest-growing economies in the world, is now valued at 56% above cost and has delivered a gross ROI since inception of nearly 20% so far, in line with its long-term return objectives.
Many of our LPs have singled this fund out as one of their best performing investments.
Julia has just taken you through 3i's return model, and this slide shows how the total return to infrastructure is generated.
3i does not invest in infrastructure assets directly, but through 3i Infrastructure and through the India Fund.
These two contribute to do gross portfolio return in the same way as any other asset, through the realized and unrealized value movements and through dividends and capital returns.
3i also generates advisory and performance fees from 3i infrastructure and management fees and carry from the India Fund.
This income is partly offset by the carry payables of the investment team and by the cost of running the business line, which consist mostly of staff costs.
Being part of 3i has been key to the success of the Infrastructure business line.

3i's brand and investment track record are recognized beyond private equity, and its people and network provide unparalleled access to opportunities, as well as to investments in portfolio management expertise.
This is a strong platform from which to expand our business going forward.
I now wanted to give you a little more detail on 3i Infrastructure's new investment in Eversholt Rail Group, as it provides a flavor of the type of asset that we invest in.
Eversholt is one of the three leading rail rolling stock companies or ROSCOs in the U.
3i infrastructure, in a consortium with Morgan Stanley Infrastructure Partners and Star Capital Partners, is acquiring 100% of the equity.
3i infrastructure will be contributing up to GBP 176 million in equity instruments to finance the purchase, which in total values Eversholt's assets at around GBP 2.
Eversholt currently owns 29% of the British Royal Fleet.
Its 19 fleets at least to seven train operating companies or TOCs.
And its primary revenue stream consists of lease payments.
The company has strong infrastructure characteristics and fits in 3i Infrastructure's investment mandate as a mature cash-generative assets with stable contracted revenues for the following reasons.

First, the market fundamentals are strong because the fleet is fully utilized following a decade of passenger growth, and the government is unlikely to procure many new trains in the near term due to budgetary constraints.
Second, Eversholt itself has strong fundamentals, with high-quality cash flows that are contracted for the medium-term.
Third, Eversholt has high margins with a low cost base.
And finally, Eversholt has a defensive diversified fleet portfolio with an impressive operational history.
In summary, Eversholt offers an exposure to a profitable transport asset with stable contracted revenues, a strong market position, and defensive characteristics.
Now I'd like to look forward to the market opportunity in our key geographical regions: Europe, North America and India.
The market opportunity in Europe and North America is driven by similar factors.
The focus on deficit reduction will drive an increased flow of government disposals and potentially PFI opportunities.
The recent government auction of HS1 in the U.
is a case in point.
The flow of non-core disposals by corporate and financial institutions is continuing and our recent investment in Eversholt, which we purchased from HSBC is an example of this.
The cyclical recovery has de-risked some assets with a higher GDP correlation, making them more attractive to infrastructure investors like ourselves.
And finally, there are policy drivers that may result in new opportunities, such as the use of infrastructure spending for economic stimulus and the incentivization of the green economy.
Our current pipeline includes opportunities in all these categories.
The opportunity in India will continue to be driven by the growing infrastructure deficit.
A combination of GDP growth and expanding population and increasing organization, means that the Indian government is struggling to keep up with the demand for new build infrastructure.
There is significant political momentum to tackle this however.
The Indian government is putting a strong emphasis on private sector participation and partnership in building out infrastructure assets.
Through the India Fund, we are progressing a very attractive pipeline of opportunities, and some of these have reached the advanced stage.
Just with the OpEx point.
Actually, some of our costs are activity-related.
So as activity levels are building up in terms of investment and improvement in WIP, then I'm expecting to see some cost coming through that.
Effectively, what I'm saying to do is just don't double the number for the first half.
There'll be a small increase on the first half.
But overall, we're on a continuing downward trajectory.
Charles, one of the things that we've always seen in this business going through economic cycles is that the demand for growth capital picks up as you start to come out of the downturn.
So through the bottom of the market you don't actually see a lot of demand, and then you see demand pick up.

What's been unusual this time as we've started to see economic recovery, there's been a real reticence among businesses to actually invest, whether it's in a fixed plant and equipment, going out and buying new businesses.
Now it's hard to say whether that trend is going to continue.
But it certainly surprised us that we haven't seen a stronger growth capital pickup, given where we are in the economic cycle.
And it maybe that the way that the banks have behaved has resulted in people being extremely nervous about entering into any new commitments going forward.
There is certainly an element of that.
But I would have to say, I just think that this position, this growth in demand for growth capital has simply been deferred.

And certainly, if we look at the work in progress that we're seeing and we're tracking this on a daily basis, we are seeing the early stage work in progress around growth capital is starting to pick up.
But I think it's too early to say whether that is an evidence of a trend.
But I think it's being deferred in the cycle and certainly happening later than we saw in previous cycles.
Are there any further questions? Well, if there aren't, as Patrick said, we wanted to conclude by 10:02.
And amazingly, we've done exactly that.
So thank you all very much for coming.
Julia, Cressida and I and Patrick are available all day for any other questions that you've got.
And we look forward to seeing you over the next six months in our various one-on-one meetings.
So thank you, all, for coming.
Thanks, Cressida.
I'd now like to update you on our strategic progress and then talk about the outlook and our priorities for the second half.
The four key elements of our strategy, as set out on this slide, are also described in detail on our IR website as well as in our annual report.
And today, I want to mainly focus on two aspects of this strategy, investing and growing the business.
Let me start with investment.
High-quality new investment is important to future value growth.
But the environment for making good investments has been challenging.
Let me explain what I mean by challenging.
Volume of private equity activity across Europe has been very low.
The number of transactions for both growth and buyouts is a third the level than it was in 2007.
But the funds available for investment continue to be very high, with the consequence that most transactions in Europe have been very high prices so we have an overhang of capital in our industry.

Now in this environment, we've taken a measured and highly selective approach to the market and focused only on making investments where we feel we can make a significant impact on the performance of a particular company.
Trescal is a very good example of such a situation.
It's a classic mid-market buyout in terms of size and profile.
Trescal is a French-based International business, providing calibration services for a wide range of industrial companies.
It has revenue of EUR 110 million and operates 60 laboratories in 11 countries.

We were able to invest through our strong relationship with the management, our experience having made several successful investments in the sector and the involvement of [indiscernible] from our business leaders network.
The investment case is based on four components.
Firstly, Trescal is in a growing sector, as many of its customers are looking to outsource testing and measurement.
Secondly, because capital investment is required in building a company like Trescal, there are significant barriers to entry.
Thirdly, through our active partnership analysis, we and management believe there's considerable opportunity for operational improvement.
And finally, given its market position and a highly fragmented sector, there's a real opportunity for buy and build.
Now increasing the level of investment is only one way to grow 3i's value.
In addition, we must also continue to take every opportunity to grow the value of our existing portfolio.
Earnings growth in our portfolio is being good.
And one of the ways that our portfolio companies have been delivering this is to find opportunities in developing markets.
MWM is a very good example of this.
MWM is a GBP 360 million euro buyout from Deutsche AG in 2007.
And it's a leading manufacturer of engines that are used to produce power.
Now a typical use for an MWM engine is generating power from landfill gas sites, so there's huge demand for these products in the developing world.
Our investment case was based on growth and significant operational improvement.

And key to delivering this was the introduction of Peter Grosch, again from 3i's Business Leaders Network to lead a program of significant cultural change, alongside a number of 3i active partnership initiatives to improve MWM's strategic position and operational effectiveness.
Performance of the business has dramatically improved, and its market position has been strengthened.
And this made it a really attractive acquisition target.
And last month, we announced that Caterpillar had agreed to purchase MWM for EUR 580 million.
Now this sale which is subject to various regulatory approvals will deliver 2.
2x money multiple and proceeds of EUR 224 million for 3i Group, as well as an IRR of 25% for 3i and the investors in our Eurofund V.

In addition to making high-quality investments such as Trescal and MWM and doing everything we can to help these businesses grow their earnings and improve their strategic positioning, we've also been investing in 3i itself.
Our Infrastructure business is a great example of this.
But another strategic investment is our Debt Management business.
This started in 2005 with a small in-house team.
The team provides banking expertise to our deal teams and to our portfolio.
In addition, it invests in high-quality debt instruments in non-3i investments.
This team's been a major source of strength to 3i throughout the credit crisis and has added considerable value to our investment teams and our portfolio of companies.
Given this positive experience, we saw a real strategic opportunity to expand our debt investment and management activities.
The acquisition of MIM from Mizuho was therefore a natural step.
MIM manages GBP 3.
7 billion of assets in eight funds of corporate, senior and subordinated debt.
The rationale for the deal was straightforward.
MIM builds on 3i's existing debt management capabilities.
MIM also brings an experienced team of 28 people to 3i, including Jeremy Ghose.
Jeremy will join our leadership team and head up the Debt Management business.
This move creates a platform to manage multiple funds and provides the potential to diversify into other debt products, as well as the capacity to grow using 3i's balance sheet.
Strategically, the Debt Management business is important because like infrastructure, it provides the opportunity for a good source of low volatility returns with a significant yield component.
This next slide shows you the shape of the business once the MIM acquisition is complete, which we expect to be at the end of January 2011.
Our Private Equity business is clearly the largest, with assets under management of GBP 7.
In September, we announced the decision to combine our Buyout and Growth Capital businesses to form a single Private Equity business.

The rationale for this change was to ensure that we had the right model for a changing market and is based on ensuring we continue to develop our business model to maintain a sustainable competitive advantage.
Our Buyout and Growth Capital businesses have the same mid-market focus, targeting companies with an enterprise value in the range of EUR 100 million to EUR 1 billion.
They have the same investment and management processes, and our teams adopt the same approach to achieving influence through being active members of the portfolio company boards.
They share the same active partnership approach to driving value, both use the group's network and sector expertise and both draw on our Business Leaders Network members.
Now another important driver of this decision was our view on what the next generation of private equity funds might look like.

Our view was that there's an evolution towards more regionally-based funds and that most LPs are more focused on making geographic allocations than the distinction between majority and minority private equity investments.
We've also been preparing for the next generation of leadership in our investment business, and I'll say more on that in a minute.
This change has been welcomed by professional advisors, management teams, our Business Leaders Network and our own people.
The feedback that we've had is it will make 3i easier to understand and easier to deal with.
And this is critical in a highly competitive market.
We've been actively communicating with our LP investors in both our buyout and growth funds.
And we are, of course, committed to managing these funds on the same basis through to the end of their investing periods.
Now following these changes this autumn, we're in a six-month consultation period with our Eurofund V Advisory Board.
Those discussions are constructive and include the possibility of potentially extending the fund for one year beyond November 2011.
Notwithstanding the six-month consultation period, we expect matters to be resolved by the end of the calendar year.
So the bottom line is the fund continues as normal.
We've also recently promoted three people to the leadership team, Menno Antal, Alan Giddins and Cressida Hogg, who you already heard from.
Menno has been a senior partner in the Buyout business and will take over leadership of the buyout fund and have geographical responsibility for Northern Europe.
Alan Giddins, who is also a senior partner in Buyouts and has also led our business services sector across the whole company, will have, responsibility for the U.
and all our sector activities.
We now have three strong platforms for growth, which can leverage our resources and expertise.
The growth of our Debt Management and Infrastructure businesses brings several benefits to 3i, not least in lowering potential volatility through generating increased revenue profits.
And I want to give you a brief update on six of our largest investments.
There are some really common themes as to how they have generated growth and value in a recession.
These are international development, improved strategy and positioning, operational effectiveness and also following a buy and build strategy.
There are more details of these and other companies in your packs and on the IR website.
But let me introduce these companies.
ACR is the pan-Asian reinsurer that we invested in, in 2006.
Today, it has premiums of USD $500 million and customers across 50 countries.
NORMA is a leading manufacturer of joining technology products and solutions.
It operates across 80 countries, and since we invested, has opened new plants in China, Thailand, Mexico, Russia and Serbia.
EBITDA has tripled during our investment period.
Foster + Partners is one of the world's most innovative architectural practices, and since our investment has continued to expand internationally and has now delivered projects in 50 countries.
EBITDA has grown 68% since our investment in 2007.
Mmora is a leading funeral service provider in Spain and Portugal.
Through acquisitions, growth and operational improvement, EBITDA is up 21% from the time of our investment in 2008.
Mayborn may be well known to you through the its Tommee Tippee brand.
And this business has grown internationally from virtually nothing when we invested, to 55% of sales today.
And the last of these six companies is Quintiles, the global market leader in outsourced clinical trial.
We've supported what was already an outstanding company to grow further in Asia and Europe.
But let me return to the common themes.
In five out of these six, we supported their international development.

In all of them, our sector knowledge and ability to identify great people from our Business Leaders Network has either helped the company directly or given 3i particular insight into the opportunities.

In all of them, our active partnership initiative is generating operational improvements, improving their strategic positions and building robust growth through acquisitions that are enhancing returns.
Together, these companies have a combined value of GBP 724 million.
And more and more of our portfolio companies we're making these initiatives deliver value for us.
Today, we focus on the first two elements of our strategy, investing and growing 3i.
In order to achieve these, it's absolutely critical that we do all that we can to ensure that 3i's reputation not only remains good, but that we build on it.
Our success internationally owes much to the strength of our brand.
As you heard from Cressida, 3i's brand has been central to developing a strong position in the infrastructure market.

3i's reputation as a responsible investor is a core part of our brand and we'll be placing an increased emphasis on corporate responsibility, not just to the group level but also in all our portfolio companies.
At our results presentation in May, I mentioned the One 3i approach that we've been driving through the business.

The point of this was to increase our effectiveness, especially in terms of how we source opportunities, how we convert these opportunities into investments and then how we create value once invested.
This underpins all the other elements of our strategy.
And of course, the real test of whether this strategy delivers value will be our long-term financial performance and reputation.
So let me turn to the outlook and our priorities for the second half.
Predicting the macroeconomic outlook remains a challenge.
The important thing is that 3i is in a strong position to take advantage of either a sustained improvement or given our financial strength, to deal with further turbulence.
Thank you, Julia, and good morning.

Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our Half Yearly Results Presentation.
This is our agenda for today.
I'm going to give a short introduction, and then Julia will present a financial review of the first half year.
Cressida Hogg, who's our managing partner of the Infrastructure business, will then give you an overview of this important part of 3i's investment activity.
And finally, I'll review our strategic progress and cover the outlook and priorities for the next six months.
As I said in the statement this morning, we've increased momentum throughout the business.
Our portfolio has delivered a good performance, achieving a gross portfolio return of 8.
7% for the six months until the 30th of September.
Total return was lower at 3.
8%, although NAV growth over the last 12 months is over 15%.
We've made good progress in terms of strategic development, and we now have three strong platforms for growth.
In my last few presentations to you, I've talked about planning and organizing for growth.
We've now moved into the delivery phase.
And I'll give you more detail on this later.
But before that, Julia will review our financial performance.
Thank you, Michael, and good morning, everybody.
Let me start my financial update by taking you through the highlights of the six months to September.
Investment at GBP 327 million was still at a relatively modest level, although it was significantly up from last year.
Our portfolio has performed well, with an improvement in earnings used for evaluation purposes of 8% in the six months.
This is a key driver of the 8.
7% gross portfolio return in the six months, despite lower multiples used to value the portfolio.
The benefits of the tough decisions we've taken in our own business is reflected in our operating costs, which have continued to fall.
Our total return on opening shareholders funds at 3.
8% was an encouraging result.
And consequently, the board has an approved an interim dividend of 1.
2p per share, as we've taken the opportunity to reset our dividend at a higher level.
NAV per share grew by 9p in the period to GBP 3.
Importantly, as Michael said, this is a 15% increase on a year ago.
And we have finished the period with liquidity of more than GBP 2 billion and net debt of only GBP 352 million.
Let me give you some more detail on the investment of GBP 327 million.
We have invested GBP 58 million in two new businesses: Trescal, which is a European calibration service provider; and Vedici, the fifth-largest acute healthcare company in France.
In this very competitive market, both experience and will provide opportunities to buy and build.
More than the third in investment was made expanding the investment in our existing portfolio.
We continue to provide acquisition funding as we see our portfolio companies able to do transactions which are not subject to the same high prices we see elsewhere.
And we've also taken the opportunity in two cases to buy senior debt and pick at discounted values.
Realizations of GBP 293 million were achieved as an 11% uplift over opening book value.
The most significant individual transaction was the sale by Inspectorate of its global Commodity Testing and Inspection division.
As a result, we received proceeds of GBP 121 million and retained a top 30 investment, which is valued at GBP 42 million, which is now called ESG and is focused on environmental and food testing.
Despite the prevalence of secondary transactions in the market, almost all of our realizations with the non-financial buyers.
Looking then at the breakdown of our total return.
Gross portfolio return is the return we generate directly from our portfolio.
The GBP 307 million represents an 8.
7% return on opening portfolio value for the six-month period.
It is driven by period performance in the portfolio, giving rise to unrealized profits of GBP 196 million.
All our core business lines generated an 8% return in the six-month period.
We then get to net portfolio return by reflecting the income and costs associated with the Asset Management business.
So the GBP 236 million represents the gross portfolio return diluted by carry payable and operating expenses and enhanced by carry receivable and fund fee income.
Finally, total return takes account of the effects of our balance sheet structure.
So the GBP 117 million of return is achieved after deducting our cost of finance as well as a net exchange loss of GBP 29 million.
So turning then to the valuation of our portfolio and its effect on our returns in the period.
You will see from this slide that most of the return in this period comes from the highest-quality factors, uplifts to sale and portfolio earnings growth.
This builds on the momentum in the second half of last year and represents a very different picture from that of 12 months ago.
The uplift on assets, which are in the process of being sold, was GBP 66 million in the six-month period.
It includes the sale to Caterpillar of MWM, which is a German-headquartered global business supplying alternative engines.
This transaction is expected is complete by the end of the year.
So this slide gives you some more detail on the earnings and multiple movements that we've used in our valuations exercise.
As I've said before, the most striking aspect is the improvement in the quality of value growth.
Looking at the first line in the table, earnings used for the valuations grew by 8% in the first half, accounting for GBP 273 million of growth.
This follows a 5% increase in the second half of last year and compared to a 13% decline in the comparative period.
This growth reflects the tough actions that our portfolio companies have been taking in the face of the considerable economic uncertainty that Michael has talked about in his statement this morning.
Markets were volatile in the six months.
And overall, the market month pulls in the sectors and geographies in which we are invested fell during the period.
Consequently, the multiples we used in the valuations declined by 5%.
This compares to a 10% increase in the second half of last year and a 21% increase in the comparative period.
As usual, we've provided you with further analysis regarding our valuations in the appendices to your presentation.
Before talking about the balance sheet, let me make a few comments on other components of total return.
Fund fee income generated is marginally up on the same period last year.
This is principally due to the launch of the growth capital fund at the end of March.
As I mentioned earlier, we have taken tough actions ourselves to improve cost efficiency.
Operating costs were down to GBP 89 million for the six-month period.
I do expect cost to be marginally higher in the second half, although the year-on-year trajectory remains down.
A GBP 29 million exchange loss was incurred in the first six months due to the strengthening of sterling.
The earning hedging in operation in the six-month period was that affected by our core currency borrowings.
As we've noted in our statement this morning, the board has recently decided to extend the hedging policy to include the use of derivatives.
This is a limited extension and will not exceed 30% of the corresponding portfolio value.
Implementation will be phased throughout the second half of this year.
Turning then to the balance sheet.
We've continued to adopt a conservative approach to our balance sheet management.
We set ourselves a limit on net debt of GBP 1 billion.
We have also set an objective of reducing our gross debt and managing maturities so that over time, maturities in any one year will be no more than GBP 300 million.

Consistent with that strategy, gross debt has been reduced by GBP 354 million through a series of actions, significantly, the repayments of GBP 195 million of the convertible bond and GBP 89 million of commercial paper.
And we've continued with this activity since September.
There was an increase in net debt as a result of net cash outflow in the period due to operating activity.
However, the net debt of GBP 352 million is comfortably within our GBP 1 billion limit.
And the group's liquidity position remains very strong at GBP 2.
1 billion, meaning, we are well positioned for investment.
So in summary and to complete my review of the financial performance, we have seen good portfolio performance, driven by earnings improvements.

We have a continued focus on conservative balance sheet management, and we remain well positioned to manage against continuing uncertainty in the market and take advantage of investment opportunities.
I'm now going to hand over to Cressida, who's going to update you on our Infrastructure business.
Thank you, Julia, and good morning.
3i has grown and established a profitable Infrastructure business from small beginnings.

We started investing in infrastructure-type assets through our private equity business that set up Infrastructure as a separate business line in 2005, as the market increasingly began to view infrastructure as a distinct asset class in its own right.
Since then, we've used 3i's investment expertise and capital to make infrastructure investments and to see two external funds, which now have combined assets under management of approximately GBP 1.
This slide gives more detail on our two infrastructure investment vehicles.
3i Infrastructure PLC, in which we have a 33% holding, is a listed investment company, with a market cap and net assets of just under GBP 1 billion.
Its overall objective is to provide shareholders with a total return, net of costs, of 12% per annum when fully invested, with 5% distributors of yield.
The company's focus is on core infrastructure, which we define as assets with stable contracted revenues or some sort of regulatory protection, principally in the transportation and utility space.
It also has exposure to social infrastructure assets and to the Indian infrastructure market, through a commitment of 3i India Infrastructure Fund.
3i Infrastructure's portfolio provides a high degree of inflation linkage, strong income generation, and opportunities for capital growth.
The company last week announced a new investment in Eversholt Rail Group and now has an investment portfolio of 15 assets worth around GBP 800 million and remaining cash balances of GBP 138 million.
The 3i India Infrastructure Fund, in which both 3i Group and 3i Infrastructure have a GBP 250 million commitment, is a GBP 1.
2 billion LP fund established to access the growing infrastructure market in India.
It focuses on the port, airport, road and power sectors.
And its objective is to deliver an 18% net returns to its investors.

Following the announcement of a new investment in GBK Energy on Monday, the fund is now over 50% invested in four assets, including two power generation developers, a port, and a road constructor and operator.
Our two external funds have now established a very strong track record and a good reputation in the market.
With its focus on mature infrastructure assets in developed economies, 3i Infrastructure has built a robust cash-generative portfolio, which has delivered a 9.
5% annualized growth in returns since inception during a period of great market volatility.
Importantly, it has also delivered its 5% yield objective in every year since inception.

And our India funds, with its focus on early-stage infrastructure assets in one fastest-growing economies in the world, is now valued at 56% above cost and has delivered a gross ROI since inception of nearly 20% so far, in line with its long-term return objectives.
Many of our LPs have singled this fund out as one of their best performing investments.
Julia has just taken you through 3i's return model, and this slide shows how the total return to infrastructure is generated.
3i does not invest in infrastructure assets directly, but through 3i Infrastructure and through the India Fund.
These two contribute to do gross portfolio return in the same way as any other asset, through the realized and unrealized value movements and through dividends and capital returns.
3i also generates advisory and performance fees from 3i infrastructure and management fees and carry from the India Fund.
This income is partly offset by the carry payables of the investment team and by the cost of running the business line, which consist mostly of staff costs.
Being part of 3i has been key to the success of the Infrastructure business line.

3i's brand and investment track record are recognized beyond private equity, and its people and network provide unparalleled access to opportunities, as well as to investments in portfolio management expertise.
This is a strong platform from which to expand our business going forward.
I now wanted to give you a little more detail on 3i Infrastructure's new investment in Eversholt Rail Group, as it provides a flavor of the type of asset that we invest in.
Eversholt is one of the three leading rail rolling stock companies or ROSCOs in the U.
3i infrastructure, in a consortium with Morgan Stanley Infrastructure Partners and Star Capital Partners, is acquiring 100% of the equity.
3i infrastructure will be contributing up to GBP 176 million in equity instruments to finance the purchase, which in total values Eversholt's assets at around GBP 2.
Eversholt currently owns 29% of the British Rail Fleet.
Its 19 fleets are leased to seven train operating companies or TOCs.
And its primary revenue stream consists of lease payments.
The company has strong infrastructure characteristics and fits in 3i Infrastructure's investment mandate as a mature cash-generative asset with stable contracted revenues for the following reasons.

First, the market fundamentals are strong because the fleet is fully utilized following a decade of passenger growth, and the government is unlikely to procure many new trains in the near term due to budgetary constraints.
Second, Eversholt itself has strong fundamentals, with high-quality cash flows that are contracted for the medium-term.
Third, Eversholt has high margins with a low cost base.
And finally, Eversholt has a defensive diversified fleet portfolio with an impressive operational history.
In summary, Eversholt offers an exposure to a profitable transport asset with stable contracted revenues, a strong market position, and defensive characteristics.
Now I'd like to look forward to the market opportunity in our key geographical regions: Europe, North America and India.
The market opportunity in Europe and North America is driven by similar factors.
The focus on deficit reduction will drive an increased flow of government disposals and potentially PFI opportunities.
The recent government auction of HS1 in the U.
is a case in point.
The flow of non-core disposals by corporate and financial institutions is continuing and our recent investment in Eversholt, which we purchased from HSBC is an example of this.
The cyclical recovery has de-risked some assets with a higher GDP correlation, making them more attractive to infrastructure investors like ourselves.
And finally, there are policy drivers that may result in new opportunities, such as the use of infrastructure spending for economic stimulus and the incentivization of the green economy.
Our current pipeline includes opportunities in all these categories.
The opportunity in India will continue to be driven by the growing infrastructure deficit.
A combination of GDP growth and expanding population and increasing organization, means that the Indian government is struggling to keep up with the demand for new build infrastructure.
There is significant political momentum to tackle this however.
The Indian government is putting a strong emphasis on private sector participation and partnership in building out infrastructure assets.
Through the India Fund, we are progressing a very attractive pipeline of opportunities, and some of these have reached the advanced stage.
Bruce Hamilton, Morgan Stanley.
If I look at the -- the earnings growth was a very good number in the period of up 8%.
And I guess some didn't move.
Given that, to achieve sort of 3.
8% sort of return to shareholders, which is more of 5% if I x out the FX monies.
On the face, it doesn't look that impressive.

I guess looking forward, realizations will improve, but should we also assume that the earnings growth will moderate? I mean, what would you expect as a more "normal" level of earnings growth? Or is sort of 15% per year something you think is achievable? In terms of the health of the portfolio, I mean, the general trend actually is positive.
We're seeing month-by-month continued overall trends.

The provisions numbers are slightly skewed because you get an individual company that has got specific issues relating to that company that will go through the provision that will make a difference to that figure.
So you can't necessarily draw conclusions across the portfolio from those individual numbers.

One company in the growth portfolio that was a sizable chunk of that provision number, actually, could come back very strongly, so we could end up at the 31st of March actually in effect reversing out some of that provision.
But we have a set policy that if the company is performing in a particular way, we will make a provision.
But the key message is the underlying health of the portfolio is continuing to show steady improvement.
Well, I think what we're looking to do overall is deliver 15% returns to shareholders.
That will come in a combination of forms, will come from the earnings growth on the portfolio.

We typically do see a step-up when we sell assets open above the carrying value, so that gives an additional boost to return; and of course, from the income streams from managing third-party assets, which clearly will start to rise as we incorporate the Debt Management business.
I think if you look at this half year's performance, I mean, the way I try and look at this is to sort of x out multiple movement, both up and down, whether year and a half, half-year period.
And so I think what they're all about in terms of the overall consistency with that delivery of that trend.
So to take your question on provisions and impairments, first, I mean, clearly, you're right.
If you compare the numbers to last year, then it doesn't look like a particularly good shift.
What it would say is clearly last year had almost the benefit of the previous year where we've had some very, very significant provisions and impairment.
So I'd say last year was unusually low.
And this year, the provision level is 1.
1% of opening portfolio value.
That's an unusual sort of amount.
In terms of the underlying movement sort of in there, it's a small number of assets.
There's no particular themes that I can draw out for you that's spread across the business lines, that's spread across sectors and spread across geographies.
The specific factors to particular investments and don't actually indicate any underlying trend for the overall portfolio.
And then in terms of cash for the period, I mean, clearly there are, as Michael has said, there was a number of transactions that are being well trailed in the market.
Without trying to give you a specific number where we expect cash to be because we would like actually to be investing in the second half.
So it's realistic to assume that there will be some significant realizations coming through.
But in terms of where net debt's going to be, I would hope that we would actually be putting in some decent amount of investment in the second half.
Some of that will come down to timing.
Where we're talking about smaller numbers of large transactions, we can get quite different numbers coming over the year.
So I would hope that we would have investment, but clearly this number of realizations going through.
If I talk about the first half in particular, one of the things I talked about is the conservative balance sheet management and trying to extend our maturities and manage those maturities.
So one of the factors that you have in this period is the consequence of us refinancing in effect the convertible bond ahead of time.
So you remember we took advantage of the small window of opportunity in March to raise the GBP 350 million fixed rate bond that we have.
So you've got the interest cost of that coming in overlapping with the convertible bond in the period.
It's a consequence of actually our conservative balance sheet management.
The important thing is by next year, that overlap will have phased out.
And then I don't really want to go to the joys of IS39 accounting.
But one of the consequences of that in trying to manage the overlap I've talked about, we've been buying back our convertible bond in the market.
The convertible bond has an amortization charge that comes through the total return statement.
The consequence of buying it back early means that we've accelerated some of that amortization into the first half, so there's GBP 8 million of accelerated amortization sitting in those numbers.
The way I'm looking at is really looking through to next year, when all of these factors should have washed out, when we'll have a fixed interest cost of about GBP 50 million.
And that will be about half of our interest costs going forward.
Just with the OpEx point.
Actually, some of our costs are activity-related.
So as activity levels are building up in terms of investment and improvement in WIP, then I'm expecting to see some cost coming through there.
Effectively, what I'm saying to do is just don't double the number for the first half.
There'll be a small increase on the first half.
But overall, we're on a continuing downward trajectory.
That's the most significant transaction coming through.
[indiscernible] Firstly, provisions and impairments.
These have increased again.
I think over the last two halves, they were actually positive, if I remember correctly.
Can you just give us a bit more color on that? How many assets are involved? And then the other question was on cash.
I mean, there are quite a number of sales that you've announced over the last few months.
If you project the cash that you're expecting to come in, how much is actually due to come in and be completed? Where will that then leave net debt? Danny Garrod from Barclays Capital.

First, just following on from the set of provisions and impairment side, am I right in the detail of the text you do highlighted as health deterioration on the growth side of the portfolio, the percentage being down versus September versus March.
I wonder if you could give some specificity on what's going on there? And secondly, you mentioned about expectation of H2 OpEx being higher than H1.
Could you give a bit of color what's flat of the H1 or what's expected in H2, given the H1 is strongly below the run rate, shall we say, of last year? Thank you, Michael, and good morning, everybody.
Let me start my financial update by taking you through the highlights of the six months to September.
Investment at GBP 327 million was still at a relatively modest level, although it was significantly up from last year.
Our portfolio has performed well, with an improvement in earnings used for evaluation purposes of 8% in the six months.
This is a key driver of the 8.
7% gross portfolio return in the six months, despite lower multiples used to value the portfolio.
The benefits of the tough decisions we've taken in our own business is reflected in our operating costs, which have continued to fall.
Our total return on opening shareholders funds at 3.
8% was an encouraging result.
And consequently, the board has an approved an interim dividend of 1.
2p per share, as we've taken the opportunity to reset our dividend at a higher level.
NAV per share grew by 9p in the period to GBP 3.
Importantly, as Michael said, this is a 15% increase on a year ago.
And we have finished the period with liquidity of more than GBP 2 billion and net debt of only GBP 352 million.
Let me give you some more detail on the investment of GBP 327 million.
We have invested GBP 58 million in two new businesses: Trescal, which is a European calibration service provider; and Vedici, the fifth-largest acute healthcare company in France.
In this very competitive market, both experience and will provide opportunities to buy and build.
More than the third in investment was made expanding the investment in our existing portfolio.
We continue to provide acquisition funding as we see our portfolio companies able to do transactions which are not subject to the same high prices we see elsewhere.
And we've also taken the opportunity in two cases to buy senior debt and pick at discounted values.
Realizations of GBP 293 million were achieved as an 11% uplift over opening book value.
The most significant individual transaction was the sale by Inspectorate of its global Commodity Testing and Inspection division.
As a result, we received proceeds of GBP 121 million and retained a top 30 investment, which is valued at GBP 42 million, which is now called ESG and is focused on environmental and food testing.
Despite the prevalence of secondary transactions in the market, almost all of our realizations with the non-financial buyers.
Looking then at the breakdown of our total return.
Gross portfolio return is the return we generate directly from our portfolio.
The GBP 307 million represents an 8.
7% return on opening portfolio value for the six-month period.
It is driven by period performance in the portfolio, giving rise to unrealized profits of GBP 196 million.
All our core business lines generated an 8% return in the six-month period.
We then get to net portfolio return by reflecting the income and costs associated with the Asset Management business.
So the GBP 236 million represents the gross portfolio return diluted by carry payable and operating expenses and enhanced by carry receivable and fund fee income.
Finally, total return takes account of the effects of our balance sheet structure.
So the GBP 117 million of return is achieved after deducting our cost of finance as well as a net exchange loss of GBP 29 million.
So turning then to the valuation of our portfolio and its effect on our returns in the period.
You will see from this slide that most of the return in this period comes from the highest-quality factors, uplifts to sale and portfolio earnings growth.
This builds on the momentum in the second half of last year and represents a very different picture from that of 12 months ago.
The uplift on assets, which are in the process of being sold, was GBP 66 million in the six-month period.
It includes the sale to Caterpillar of MWM, which is a German-headquartered global business supplying alternative engines.
This transaction is expected is complete by the end of the year.
So this slide gives you some more detail on the earnings and multiple movements that we've used in our valuations exercise.
As I've said before, the most striking aspect is the improvement in the quality of value growth.
Looking at the first line in the table, earnings used for the valuations grew by 8% in the first half, accounting for GBP 273 million of growth.
This follows a 5% increase in the second half of last year and compared to a 13% decline in the comparative period.
This growth reflects the tough actions that our portfolio companies have been taking in the face of the considerable economic uncertainty that Michael has talked about in his statement this morning.
Markets were volatile in the six months.
And overall, the market month pulls in the sectors and geographies in which we are invested fell during the period.
Consequently, the multiples we used in the valuations declined by 5%.
This compares to a 10% increase in the second half of last year and a 21% increase in the comparative period.
As usual, we've provided you with further analysis regarding our valuations in the appendices to your presentation.
Before talking about the balance sheet, let me make a few comments on other components of total return.
Fund fee income generated is marginally up on the same period last year.
This is principally due to the launch of the growth capital fund at the end of March.
As I mentioned earlier, we have taken tough actions ourselves to improve cost efficiency.
Operating costs were down to GBP 89 million for the six-month period.
I do expect cost to be marginally higher in the second half, although the year-on-year trajectory remains down.
A GBP 29 million exchange loss was incurred in the first six months due to the strengthening of sterling.
The earning hedging in operation in the six-month period was that affected by our core currency borrowings.
As we've noted in our statement this morning, the board has recently decided to extend the hedging policy to include the use of derivatives.
This is a limited extension and will not exceed 30% of the corresponding portfolio value.
Implementation will be phased throughout the second half of this year.
Turning then to the balance sheet.
We've continued to adopt a conservative approach to our balance sheet management.
We set ourselves a limit on net debt of GBP 1 billion.
We have also set an objective of reducing our gross debt and managing maturities so that over time, maturities in any one year will be no more than GBP 300 million.

Consistent with that strategy, gross debt has been reduced by GBP 354 million through a series of actions, significantly, the repayments of GBP 195 million of the convertible bond and GBP 89 million of commercial paper.
And we've continued with this activity since September.
There was an increase in net debt as a result of net cash outflow in the period due to operating activity.
However, the net debt of GBP 352 million is comfortably within our GBP 1 billion limit.
And the group's liquidity position remains very strong at GBP 2.
1 billion, meaning, we are well positioned for investment.
So in summary and to complete my review of the financial performance, we have seen good portfolio performance, driven by earnings improvements.

We have a continued focus on conservative balance sheet management, and we remain well positioned to manage against continuing uncertainty in the market and take advantage of investment opportunities.
I'm now going to hand over to Cressida, who's going to update you on our Infrastructure business.
Thanks, Cressida.
I'd now like to update you on our strategic progress and then talk about the outlook and our priorities for the second half.
The four key elements of our strategy, as set out on this slide, are also described in detail on our IR website as well as in our annual report.
And today, I want to mainly focus on two aspects of this strategy, investing and growing the business.
Let me start with investment.
High-quality new investment is important to future value growth.
But the environment for making good investments has been challenging.
Let me explain what I mean by challenging.
Volume of private equity activity across Europe has been very low.
The number of transactions for both growth and buyouts is a third the level than it was in 2007.
But the funds available for investment continue to be very high, with the consequence that most transactions in Europe have been very high prices so we have an overhang of capital in our industry.

Now in this environment, we've taken a measured and highly selective approach to the market and focused only on making investments where we feel we can make a significant impact on the performance of a particular company.
Trescal is a very good example of such a situation.
It's a classic mid-market buyout in terms of size and profile.
Trescal is a French-based International business, providing calibration services for a wide range of industrial companies.
It has revenue of EUR 110 million and operates 60 laboratories in 11 countries.

We were able to invest through our strong relationship with the management, our experience having made several successful investments in the sector and the involvement of [indiscernible] from our business leaders network.
The investment case is based on four components.
Firstly, Trescal is in a growing sector, as many of its customers are looking to outsource testing and measurement.
Secondly, because capital investment is required in building a company like Trescal, there are significant barriers to entry.
Thirdly, through our active partnership analysis, we and management believe there's considerable opportunity for operational improvement.
And finally, given its market position and a highly fragmented sector, there's a real opportunity for buy and build.
Now increasing the level of investment is only one way to grow 3i's value.
In addition, we must also continue to take every opportunity to grow the value of our existing portfolio.
Earnings growth in our portfolio is being good.
And one of the ways that our portfolio companies have been delivering this is to find opportunities in developing markets.
MWM is a very good example of this.
MWM is a GBP 360 million euro buyout from Deutsche AG in 2007.
And it's a leading manufacturer of engines that are used to produce power.
Now a typical use for an MWM engine is generating power from landfill gas sites, so there's huge demand for these products in the developing world.
Our investment case was based on growth and significant operational improvement.

And key to delivering this was the introduction of Peter Grosch, again from 3i's Business Leaders Network to lead a program of significant cultural change, alongside a number of 3i active partnership initiatives to improve MWM's strategic position and operational effectiveness.
Performance of the business has dramatically improved, and its market position has been strengthened.
And this made it a really attractive acquisition target.
And last month, we announced that Caterpillar had agreed to purchase MWM for EUR 580 million.
Now this sale which is subject to various regulatory approvals will deliver 2.
2x money multiple and proceeds of EUR 224 million for 3i Group, as well as an IRR of 25% for 3i and the investors in our Eurofund V.

In addition to making high-quality investments such as Trescal and MWM and doing everything we can to help these businesses grow their earnings and improve their strategic positioning, we've also been investing in 3i itself.
Our Infrastructure business is a great example of this.
But another strategic investment is our Debt Management business.
This started in 2005 with a small in-house team.
The team provides banking expertise to our deal teams and to our portfolio.
In addition, it invests in high-quality debt instruments in non-3i investments.
This team's been a major source of strength to 3i throughout the credit crisis and has added considerable value to our investment teams and our portfolio of companies.
Given this positive experience, we saw a real strategic opportunity to expand our debt investment and management activities.
The acquisition of MIM from Mizuho was therefore a natural step.
MIM manages GBP 3.
7 billion of assets in eight funds of corporate, senior and subordinated debt.
The rationale for the deal was straightforward.
MIM builds on 3i's existing debt management capabilities.
MIM also brings an experienced team of 28 people to 3i, including Jeremy Ghose.
Jeremy will join our leadership team and head up the Debt Management business.
This move creates a platform to manage multiple funds and provides the potential to diversify into other debt products, as well as the capacity to grow using 3i's balance sheet.
Strategically, the Debt Management business is important because like infrastructure, it provides the opportunity for a good source of low volatility returns with a significant yield component.
This next slide shows you the shape of the business once the MIM acquisition is complete, which we expect to be at the end of January 2011.
Our Private Equity business is clearly the largest, with assets under management of GBP 7.
In September, we announced the decision to combine our Buyout and Growth Capital businesses to form a single Private Equity business.

The rationale for this change was to ensure that we had the right model for a changing market and is based on ensuring we continue to develop our business model to maintain a sustainable competitive advantage.
Our Buyout and Growth Capital businesses have the same mid-market focus, targeting companies with an enterprise value in the range of EUR 100 million to EUR 1 billion.
They have the same investment and management processes, and our teams adopt the same approach to achieving influence through being active members of the portfolio company boards.
They share the same active partnership approach to driving value, both use the group's network and sector expertise and both draw on our Business Leaders Network members.
Now another important driver of this decision was our view on what the next generation of private equity funds might look like.

Our view was that there's an evolution towards more regionally-based funds and that most LPs are more focused on making geographic allocations than the distinction between majority and minority private equity investments.
We've also been preparing for the next generation of leadership in our investment business, and I'll say more on that in a minute.
This change has been welcomed by professional advisors, management teams, our Business Leaders Network and our own people.
The feedback that we've had is it will make 3i easier to understand and easier to deal with.
And this is critical in a highly competitive market.
We've been actively communicating with our LP investors in both our buyout and growth funds.
And we are, of course, committed to managing these funds on the same basis through to the end of their investing periods.
Now following these changes this autumn, we're in a six-month consultation period with our Eurofund V Advisory Board.
Those discussions are constructive and include the possibility of potentially extending the fund for one year beyond November 2011.
Notwithstanding the six-month consultation period, we expect matters to be resolved by the end of the calendar year.
So the bottom line is the fund continues as normal.
We've also recently promoted three people to the leadership team, Menno Antal, Alan Giddins and Cressida Hogg, who you already heard from.
Menno has been a senior partner in the Buyout business and will take over leadership of the buyout fund and have geographical responsibility for Northern Europe.
Alan Giddins, who is also a senior partner in Buyouts and has also led our business services sector across the whole company, will have, responsibility for the U.
and all our sector activities.
We now have three strong platforms for growth, which can leverage our resources and expertise.
The growth of our Debt Management and Infrastructure businesses brings several benefits to 3i, not least in lowering potential volatility through generating increased revenue profits.
And I want to give you a brief update on six of our largest investments.
There are some really common themes as to how they have generated growth and value in a recession.
These are international development, improved strategy and positioning, operational effectiveness and also following a buy and build strategy.
There are more details of these and other companies in your packs and on the IR website.
But let me introduce these companies.
ACR is the pan-Asian reinsurer that we invested in, in 2006.
Today, it has premiums of USD $500 million and customers across 50 countries.
NORMA is a leading manufacturer of joining technology products and solutions.
It operates across 80 countries, and since we invested, has opened new plants in China, Thailand, Mexico, Russia and Serbia.
EBITDA has tripled during our investment period.
Foster + Partners is one of the world's most innovative architectural practices, and since our investment has continued to expand internationally and has now delivered projects in 50 countries.
EBITDA has grown 68% since our investment in 2007.
Mmora is a leading funeral service provider in Spain and Portugal.
Through acquisitions, growth and operational improvement, EBITDA is up 21% from the time of our investment in 2008.
Mayborn may be well known to you through the its Tommee Tippee brand.
And this business has grown internationally from virtually nothing when we invested, to 55% of sales today.
And the last of these six companies is Quintiles, the global market leader in outsourced clinical trial.
We've supported what was already an outstanding company to grow further in Asia and Europe.
But let me return to the common themes.
In five out of these six, we supported their international development.

In all of them, our sector knowledge and ability to identify great people from our Business Leaders Network has either helped the company directly or given 3i particular insight into the opportunities.

In all of them, our active partnership initiative is generating operational improvements, improving their strategic positions and building robust growth through acquisitions that are enhancing returns.
Together, these companies have a combined value of GBP 724 million.
And more and more of our portfolio companies we're making these initiatives deliver value for us.
Today, we focus on the first two elements of our strategy, investing and growing 3i.
In order to achieve these, it's absolutely critical that we do all that we can to ensure that 3i's reputation not only remains good, but that we build on it.
Our success internationally owes much to the strength of our brand.
As you heard from Cressida, 3i's brand has been central to developing a strong position in the infrastructure market.

3i's reputation as a responsible investor is a core part of our brand and we'll be placing an increased emphasis on corporate responsibility, not just to the group level but also in all our portfolio companies.
At our results presentation in May, I mentioned the One 3i approach that we've been driving through the business.

The point of this was to increase our effectiveness, especially in terms of how we source opportunities, how we convert these opportunities into investments and then how we create value once invested.
This underpins all the other elements of our strategy.
And of course, the real test of whether this strategy delivers value will be our long-term financial performance and reputation.
So let me turn to the outlook and our priorities for the second half.
Predicting the macroeconomic outlook remains a challenge.
The important thing is that 3i is in a strong position to take advantage of either a sustained improvement or given our financial strength, to deal with further turbulence.
The outlook for our Private Equity business is improving.
Pricing will remain full.
And I think that this will continue for another 12 to 18 months.
But despite this, we can find good investments, as we've demonstrated with Trescal and Vedici.
As Cressida said, conditions in the infrastructure market in Europe and in India look favorable.
And as demonstrated by the two investments we've announced in the last week.
The outlook for the Debt Management business is also positive, with the opportunity to grow assets under management through new funds and further acquisitions.
The combination of the MIM team's track record and capabilities and 3i's brand and financial strength position us well to take advantage of these opportunities.
So overall, the outlook for 3i is good, and we've therefore taken the opportunity to increase our dividend by 20%.
In the short term, our priorities are to continue to deliver good financial performance, to integrate MIM, and to increase momentum in our investment activity.

So in conclusion, our key themes for today are: we've increased the momentum throughout the business; our portfolio has also delivered a good performance; we've made good progress in terms of strategic development; and we now have three strong platforms for growth.
As I also said at the beginning, we've moved from planning and organizing growth to delivering growth.
Julia, Cressida and I would now be happy to take any questions that you've got.
[Operator Instructions] Is there anything else due to come through in the next few weeks? Thanks, Patrick.

Were there any reasons for that? And how do you see that going forward? Charles, one of the things that we've always seen in this business going through economic cycles is that the demand for growth capital picks up as you start to come out of the downturn.
So through the bottom of the market you don't actually see a lot of demand, and then you see demand pick up.

What's been unusual this time as we've started to see economic recovery, there's been a real reticence among businesses to actually invest, whether it's in a fixed plant and equipment, going out and buying new businesses.
Now it's hard to say whether that trend is going to continue.
But it certainly surprised us that we haven't seen a stronger growth capital pickup, given where we are in the economic cycle.
And it maybe that the way that the banks have behaved has resulted in people being extremely nervous about entering into any new commitments going forward.
There is certainly an element of that.
But I would have to say, I just think that this position, this growth in demand for growth capital has simply been deferred.

And certainly, if we look at the work in progress that we're seeing and we're tracking this on a daily basis, we are seeing the early stage work in progress around growth capital is starting to pick up.
But I think it's too early to say whether that is an evidence of a trend.
But I think it's being deferred in the cycle and certainly happening later than we saw in previous cycles.

Turning to our strategy, on the right side of the slides, I've set out our key competitive advantages, and on the left, the deal criteria, which are based on these advantages.
Our target market is investments with an enterprise value of up to EUR 500 million.
We consider this to be the midmarket where local relationships are of high importance, and where our companies are focused on international growth which plays to our strengths.
Our key competitive advantage is the global presence that we have, with local offices that are deeply rooted in their respective business communities.
I believe this is unique in the European midmarket, particularly when combined with our presence and experience of markets such as India, China and most recently, Brazil.
Our global network help us to assess the international growth opportunity of a given investment, and subsequently, determine a strategy to ensure its execution.

Well the board's considered whether it's appropriate to conduct buybacks in the current market, and felt that given the uncertainties around refinancing and our need to continue to rollover some parts of our gross borrowings, it was just too uncertain of an environment to embark on that.
What we also need to do is to make sure that we continue to meet our fiduciary responsibilities in respect of the funds that we manage.
We raise these funds and we charge fees on the basis that we will invest in assets over a given timeframe.
And it's very important that we continue to do that.
