Thank you, Michael, and good morning, everyone.
As Michael has said, our returns for the 6 months of 30 September reflect the market conditions in a period of considerable political, economic, and financial uncertainty and volatility.
We are not immune to that, seeing its effect in evaluation of our portfolio and of our pension fund.
However, our balance sheet means that we're able to withstand these headwinds from a position of strength.
This slide shows you the key elements of our returns.
The gross portfolio return reflects the returns generated by our direct investments in the portfolio.
Net portfolio return reflects the financial impact of running our asset management business.
And finally, total return includes the financial effects of our balance sheet.
I will take you through each of these components in more detail in the next few slides.
And as I do so, you'll see some new disclosure regarding the performance of our business lines.
Having confirmed our model for returns in May, we're now reporting net portfolio returns by business.
In addition, I'll also provide you some detail on our valuations in the period.

Our private equity business will always be the most significant component of our gross portfolio return, as our business model assumes that we'll allocate a much more significant proportion of our own capital to private equity than either infrastructure or debt management.
The private equity returns include GBP 25 million of realized profits on gross proceeds of GBP 523 million, which had lower uplifts than normal.
However, this is due to the timing, with the significant proportion of the value being reflected in uplifts to sale as at the 31 March 2011.
The top 5 disposals were all at very good money multiples, ranging from 2.
The net GBP 414 million of unrealized write-downs reflect a deterioration in market multiples and some contraction in the earnings that we use for valuations.
And I'll come on to talk about this in more detail shortly.

The gross portfolio return in our infrastructure business principally comprises the quoted movement and dividend income from our 35% stake in 3i Infrastructure plc, offset by unrealized value movements on investments in our Indian Infrastructure Fund.

Through our infrastructure share price has performed very well in the last 6 months, increasing by 3% to 121p at the 30th of September, and offsetting some currency-led value declines in the Indian portfolio.
We increased our investments in through our Infrastructure plc by GBP 33 million, exercising the warrants that we received when the company was first listed.
As expected, Debt Management has minimal effect at the gross portfolio return level, as we've invested only 1% of the capital at work in this business.
We'd expect this to grow in importance as we invest in new funds, such as the recently announced Credit Opportunities Fund.
Turning then to the valuation of the portfolio, which gives rise to the GBP 441 million negative movements in the period.
Clearly, market conditions have deteriorated significantly and rapidly since I spoke to you in May.
And our portfolio is not immune to the effects of that, directly in terms of multiples but also in some cases, in performance.
I'm going to comment on earnings and multiples in more detail shortly, so I'm just going to use this slide to talk about a couple of the other components.
Impairments of GBP 66 million relate to a number of asset, and are a function of the earnings multiple movements that I'm going to describe.
Provisions are low at GBP 43 million.
The uplift to imminent sale relates to the disposal of MWM.
You may recall that we announced this disposal last year.
I'm pleased to say that we have received proceeds of GBP 197 million at the start of November.

Finally, the movements on the quoted portfolio, which now accounts for 15% of the total, relates to our residual holding in NORMA, which is a business that IPO-ed in April, as well as our 3i Infrastructure plc shares and Adani Power.
As expected, stock market declines in the period flowed through to the multiples that we use to value the portfolio.
The overall fall was 8%.
On the face of it, this is lower than headline falls in, say, the FTSE 100 of 13%.
However, it is in line with the movements in the underlying sectors and the geographies in which we have invested.
You can see here the portfolio diversification.
So for example, we have limited exposure in European financials, which had a significant impact on total market movements, and our value exposure to consumer is much more heavily weighted to Asia.
The weighted average EBITDA multiple fell to 8.
8x at the 31st of March.
We talk about earnings growth in 2 ways.
Firstly, in explaining the movements and earnings that we use for valuation purposes; and secondly, for considering the performance of the portfolio as a whole.
So looking first at the earnings that we use for valuation purposes, which results in a negative GBP 52 million unrealized value movement.
64% of the portfolio is valued on an earnings basis.
And we calculate the movement on those companies that were valued in this way at the start and at the end of the period.
Our valuation policy is to use the last 12 months' management accounts up to the preceding quarter, so in this case, to the 30th of June.
But if it is apparent that the current year forecast, in other words to the 31st of December, is showing reducing earnings, then we anticipate that decline and use those forecasts.
The number of companies in this position has increased in this period to 23%, reflecting the market conditions.
And as a result, the earnings used for valuation purposes showed a contraction of 1%.
Looking at earnings as a whole, in aggregate, the earnings in our private equity portfolio grew by 1% in the 6 months, but the weighted average growth in earnings was 8%.
It is in that context that we believe the portfolio performance has been solid despite the tough economic conditions.
And this slide shows you some new disclosure about earnings performance of the private equity portfolio, breaking down the last 12 months of earnings performance by value and number of companies.
This slide then shows you the effects of those valuations on the total portfolio value.
We began the period with a portfolio of GBP 3.
9 billion, investments of GBP 448 million was measured, and Menno will talk in more detail about some of the new investments in private equity.
Taking account of unrealized losses, divestments and FX, the portfolio value at the end of the period was reduced to GBP 3.
For the first time, we're providing a breakdown of our net portfolio return by business line.
As you'll recall, we set our 15% targets for each of private equity, infrastructure and debt management, on our bridge over 5 years.
We believe providing this framework allows for a more detailed discussion about the drivers of performance, how we allocate our capital, and how new strategic initiatives are assessed.
So taking each business in turn.
Private equities performance is driven by its gross portfolio return, but the cross-cycle target is 20%.
We are a significant balance sheet investor here, 82% of our portfolio and 64% of the private equity assets under management.
And so we expect there to be a dilution from gross to net returns.
Therefore, in a period where market conditions have had a marked effect on the gross portfolio returns, the business will not achieve its 15% target.
Its return is a negative 11%.
Fee income in the period is in line with expectations and reflects fees from Eurofunds IV and V, as well as the Growth Capital Fund.
Net carry is a positive, as it reflects the reversal of previous accruals following the reduction in portfolio valuing.
Over time, we expect net carry to be a cost as we pay carry on total investments but received carry only on the third-party money that we manage.
The cost of GBP 74 million  include the new Brazil team and are flat year-on-year, including this additional resource.
In infrastructure, we have said we expect to be managing 75% third-party money and 25% of our own capital.
As of the 30th of September, this ratio was 69:31, reflecting our additional investment of GBP 33 million in the period for 3i Infrastructure plc.
As a result, we expect lower gross returns for this business to be enhanced by fees and carry more than covering costs.
We still expect this to be the case in the longer term.
Today, 3i capital represents only 1% of the assets under management in Debt Management, although our aim is to invest 10% capital in this business line.
Consequently, we expect fee income to be the most significant driver of this business.
Fees for the period are ahead of our expectations as performance has improved in the funds that we acquired at the end of last year.
Cost of the business include acquisition accounting adjustments of GBP 2 million.
So bringing together the performance of all our businesses into the group's returns, let me comment on a few aspects of total return.
Total operating expenses for the period were GBP 98 million, which include GBP 8 million relating to Brazil and the new debt management team.
Importantly, after taking account of fee income, our net expenses reduced from GBP 59 million to GBP 55 million, as the fees from the Debt Management business more than covered its additional costs.

Net interest payable reduced to GBP 52 million, as we reduced gross debt following the maturity of the remainder of the convertible bond, other planned maturities, and the repurchase of EUR 95 million of the June 2012 FRN.
The actuarial loss of GBP 49 million relates mainly to our U.
defined benefits team and reflects a combination of factors.
The market has  again had an impact, with the value of assets in the scheme and the discount rate used to value the liabilities both falling.
In addition, we have now agreed the latest triennial funding valuation with the scheme's trustees.
We have agreed some additional funding contributions.
GBP 60 million of this was paid in September and a further amount, which is expected to be about GBP 36 million, will be paid in April 2012.
The accounting for this is not straightforward, but the actuarial loss reflects the effect of both payments.

We've also agreed a contingent asset arrangement with the trustees without any cash or strategic cost to the group, allowing flexibility to proceed with the de-risking investment strategy for the fund.
NAV was 294p at the 30th of September, falling from 351p at the 31st of March.
35p was attributable to the fall in portfolio value, 5p to the actuarial loss of the pension, and the remainder due to operating and interest costs.
We have continued to adopt a conservative balance sheet strategy throughout the period, reducing gross debt and managing our cash requirements carefully.

We hold high levels of liquidity to ensure that we can meet our fund commitments, the ongoing funding requirements of the portfolio, our debt maturities, and to take advantage of investment opportunities where appropriate.
This is particularly important in these economic conditions when our ability to refinance debt may be more constrained or more costly and realizations are more uncertain.
You can see from this slide that we finished the period of investment assets of GBP 3.
4 billion and gross debt of GBP 1.
Net debt was more or less unchanged at GBP 531 million and remains within the GBP 1 billion net debt limit that we've set ourselves.
Gearing has increased to 19% as a result of the fall in the portfolio value.
Liquidity remains strong at GBP 1.
7 billion and is made up of cash at GBP 1.
2 billion, and undrawn committed facilities of GBP 0.
Our gross debt has fallen from GBP 2 billion to GBP 1.
7 billion as debt has matured.
We have successfully continued in our strategy of extending term and reducing absolute maturities in any one year.

We noted in June that we had refinanced our principal revolving credit facility, extending the maturities to June 2016, increasing the amount from GBP 300 million to GBP 450 million, and significantly reducing the costs.
I'm pleased to confirm that we have now also extended the 2012 bilateral facility, also to 2016, and have reduced its amount from GBP 100 million to GBP 50 million.
Before handing over to Menno, I wanted to elaborate further on Michael's comments regarding changes we've announced to our distribution policy.
Subject of course to shareholder approval, we have today announced our intention to pay a dividend for the year of 8.
7p being declared as an interim dividend today.
The cash cost of the dividend is GBP 77 million, which is about the level of cash cost before the rights issue in 2009.
A proportion of this dividend will be funded out of capital profits, but we've looked at the long-term average of our realization levels and are comfortable that it is sustainable at this level.
As the asset management part of our business grows, we expect the dividend to be funded out of those revenue profits.
So to conclude.
Our returns for the 6 months of 30 September reflect the market conditions in a period of considerable financial uncertainty and volatility.
We are not immune to that, seeing its affecting the valuation of our portfolio and our pension fund.
In this market, the most important thing we can do is manage the business cautiously and conservatively, taking steps to increase our margin of safety wherever we can.
We have continued to do this throughout the period, meaning we were able to withstand the economic headwinds from a position of strength.
I'd now like to hand over to Menno.
I mean, we certainly have flagged today that we expect the environment for realizations, over the next 6 to 12 months, to be particularly challenging.
As Menno outlined, the activity level, both realizations and new investments in private equity is back at the 2003, 2004 level.
You could even see that actually falling back further than that.
It really does depend on how the Eurozone crisis impacts on the banking market.
Right now, the banks are closed for business.
So that will have an impact, both on the ability to fund new investments and also on other people's ability to buy investments in our portfolio.
So we have had, in the last 6 months, one process where we backed out of it because the funding climate had got more challenging.
And as I said in my statement, we were very fortunate.
We got most of the realizations of this period in the early part of the period when the markets were pretty much functional.
So we are anticipating a slower period.
Given the sheer scale of our portfolio, there will always be some level of churn, and we do have some visibility on some realizations coming through.
But we are flagging it's going to be a difficult environment.

And the other side of that means that we're going to be highly selective in investment, making sure we're only paying the right value for businesses and making sure that, that value reflects the uncertainties in the market.
If I pick up the net portfolio return question, yes, you're right.
There are different factors happening for both divisions.
If you look at Debt Management, I would say that absolutely is in sort of a -- not quite a startup phase, but we're in the early development of that strategic initiative.
And the amount of capital that we have invested there is actually only GBP 18 million at the moment.
So it's extremely sensitive to any changes in the numbers that we have there.
In the period that we've seen, the gross portfolio return for Debt Management was negative as we had some mark-to-market movements on the equity investments that we have there.
And given the low level of capital that we have at work, things like the GBP 2 million of acquisition accounting adjustments actually have quite a significant impact.
It would be very, very easy to actually produce a completely stellar return for Debt Management, given that amount of capital we've got at the moment.
So very much look at that in terms of early days of strategic development.
But the trajectory for us, in terms of the model that we expect to have, is enhancement from our gross portfolio return, to our net portfolio return, to get an overall 15% return.
For Infrastructure, there are 1 or 2 particular things that play in the 6-month period.
I mean, overall, the business is performing extremely well.
The gross portfolio return has got the quoted impact of the Adani Power shares that I've talked about.

And a little bit complicated to understand, but because we expect to manage more third-party money than our own money, in contrast to private equity, if you have a negative gross portfolio return, there is a reversal in the carry accrual that actually ends up being a cost.
So you've got a knock-on effect to that gross portfolio and impact.

Overall, we expect that the Infrastructure business, which has performed very well, as you can see reflected in the confidence of our own Infrastructure plc share price, to absolutely deliver the 15% that we're looking for.
Thank you, Julia, and good morning, everyone.
My name is Menno Antal.
I'm an engineer by education and complemented by an MBA from IMD.
Before joining 3i, I worked for 10 years at Heineken in different international, operational, commercial, and general management roles.
I joined 3i in 2000 to help build the Benelux office in Amsterdam, of which I became a Managing Director in 2003.
In 2009, I took over responsibility for Germany, followed by the Nordic region in 2010.
I also became part of the leadership team in 2010.

What I would like to do in this presentation is to provide a brief update on the European private equity markets and to explain our strategy within these markets, particularly against a market backdrop that continues to present challenges, then to take you through the recent investment activities to demonstrate actually why I believe we will be successful in delivering good returns in the medium term.
Through this presentation, I'd also like to give you a clear understanding of the changes of the private equity business as announced by Michael earlier.
Let me begin with the European private equity markets.
The investment activities have come off significantly since '07, '08.
Even if the large cap markets has suffered most, the mid-market has also been impacted, and investment levels are now comparable to the years of 2003 and 2004.
In 2010 and first half of 2011, we saw an upward trend in activity levels.
However, since the beginning of August, the euro crisis has had a significant impact on the market.
The third quarter, to the end of September, is showing a 41% decline in investment activity on the previous quarter.
It's our expectation that these conditions will prevail well into 2012.
However, there are clear regional differences across the European market.
We have an excellent investment track record over the past 10 years, in Germany, the Benelux, France and the Nordic region.

3i is very well-positioned in these markets and we continue to see attractive investment opportunities, given the quality of the companies that we're seeing, the strength of the management teams, and our ability to help these businesses achieve their international potential.
, we obviously have a very strong position.
In the short term, we expect the current economic conditions to continue in the U.
, and combined with the intense competition we are seeing for good-quality assets, means that we will remain highly selective.
That said, I'm confident that we will find attractive opportunities in this market.
The Spanish and Italian markets show even greater challenges.
Making new investments in these markets does not look attractive in the near term.
However, we have a very good market position in Spain, and a high-quality team to create value from the existing large portfolio.
Turning to our strategy.
On the right side of the slides, I've set out our key competitive advantages, and on the left, the deal criteria which are based on these advantages.
Our target market is investments with an enterprise value of up to EUR 500 million.
We consider this to be the mid-market, where local relationships are of high importance, and where companies are focused on international growth, which plays to our strengths.
Our key competitive advantage is the global presence that we have, with local offices that are deeply rooted in their respective business communities.
I believe this is unique in the European mid-market, particularly when combined with our presence and experience of markets such as India, China, and most recently, Brazil.
Our global network helps us to assess the international growth opportunity of a given investment and subsequently determine a strategy to ensure its execution.
Another key advantage is our sector knowledge, and the people and network we've built around the sectors.

This not only makes us proactive in our investment approach, but also the long-term track records that we have built in these sectors provides the opportunity to work with best-in-class chairmen and operators, giving us real credibility with management teams when we are pursuing a deal.

As you would expect, and entirely consistent with the private equity investment model, we focus on bringing operational improvements to each of our investments through our Active Partnership program, which is crucial to driving value, particularly in this current environment.
The case that I'll discuss in a moment will give you a clear sense of what I mean.
But first, let me take you through our recent investment activity.
We have made 13 new investments since the rights issue in 2009, to which we have rigorously applied the investment disciplines that I have just described.
In your presentation packs you will find an overview of each of these investments.
Performance is very promising, with 85% of these companies performing in line or ahead of plan, and we have clear visibility of those companies that are not performing to plan.
Turning to the 3 most recent buyouts, set out on this slide, let me provide some greater detail to demonstrate how we apply our investment criteria to each new investment.
SMT is a European/U.
testing and inspections business.
We know this sector well and our cross-Atlantic consolidation strategy plays to our strengths here.
As part of the strategy, we see a strong pipeline of acquisition opportunities in both Europe and the U.
Trading performance is strong with current organic growth of 25%.
This now translates into a purchase price of less than 8x 2011 EBITDA, down from 9.
Another recent investment is Action, a Dutch discount retailer we were able to acquire in an off-market transaction from the founders.
We regard the business as noncyclical and highly defensive given its discount offering.
The company has delivered 21% growth on average each of the past 5 years, and we see a continuation of that growth again this year.
Now you can see that the international booked has not picked.
[ph] And we have indeed not built our base business assumptions on an international rollout.

However, despite the strong growth we are seeing in Action's domestic market, we intend to pursue a strategy to internationalize the business, to accelerate growth, and maximize the potential of this investment.
Let me now turn to Hilite in some more detail.
Hilite is a classic 3i buyout.
This is a EUR 190 million acquisition of a non-core German subsidiary of a U.
company, through our German and U.

We won this deal on the back of our track records in the automotive and engineering sector, based on what we achieved with investment such as MWM, Hyva, and NORMA, all investments which have delivered fabulous returns over the last 12 to 18 months.
Hilite is a leading global supplier of fuel efficiency and emissions reductions components, with annual sales of around EUR 300 million, and a very positive sales outlook.
The majority of its sales for the next 4 years have already been contracted.

Management was attracted to 3i's track record in the automotive industry, our ability to further internationalize businesses, along with our active partnership approach to drive further efficiencies from across the business.
We regard this as one of the most exciting segments of the automotive industry.
Hilite is the innovation leader, and we see real potential to grow the business internationally, particularly in China.
Since the investment, we've been able to strengthen management, bringing the former chairman of NORMA and former executives from Siemens and GE to the company.
Now based on current performance, we completed the deal at 5.
4x 2011 EBITDA, which makes it very attractively priced.
Many of you will be familiar with the following, which sets out our private equity track record over the last 10 years.
The total equity value at exit the state of net realized losses, I believe that our recent investment -- apologies for that.
I therefore believe that this is a good proxy for the track record of the private equity business, despite the impact of performance of  recent vintages.
An enormous amount of work has been done to mitigate portfolio risk.
We have reinforced our investment procedures, financial risk and government processes to apply realistic investment parameters that recognize current operating environment in which we are investing.
We've also reduced the leverage across the buyout portfolio from around 6x EBITDA to 4.
4x, with over 85% of the portfolio not having any maturities due before 2014.

The further changes that we are bringing to our business today, built on the initiatives we have implemented under Michael's leadership, these changes will strengthen our position for both today's and tomorrow's markets.

In summary, with the changes that we have made to the team over the past year, including today, we have in place a high-quality team, which is determined to succeed and to deliver really good returns.
I believe our recent investments demonstrate that even in the current markets, we are able to find exciting investment opportunities, with significant growth strategies.
I would now like to hand back to Michael.
The chart on Page 34, I think it was -- in Menno's part of the presentation, showed where the value had come from the exited investments.
I just wondered whether you had the money multiple for those investments in the IRR.
3i Infrastructure, I think, is a great performing business.
I mean, fundamentally, it does what it says on the 10.
It provides very, very stable, secure return with a high yield component.
It's a key part of our infrastructure strategy.
And what we've said in all of our business lines, is we will have a mix of our own balance sheet capital and third-party capital.
And the way in which we do that in, say, private equity, is we raise funds with limited partners.
The way we do that in Infrastructure is we have a listed permanent capital vehicle that we hold a stake in.
So it's a fundamental part of our strategy.
So we have absolutely no intention of selling that stake or distributing it in specie.

And we were in a closed period, so we haven't been able to go back and really understand what their thinking was.
But certainly, as part of this roadshow, we will be having that discussion.
But we've got no intention of selling our stake.
Well, if there are no further questions, thank you very much for coming along today.
If you do think of any other questions during the course of the day, Julia and Menno and I will be very happy to answer them.
But thank you very much for coming.

So to be clear, my comments around using capital profits was to acknowledge that if you look at our cash flow in any one year at the moment, then clearly there's an element of funding dividend out of capital cash flows.
In terms of the reserves that we will use to pay the dividend, for now, until the new investment trust rules come into operation, then we will be using our revenue reserve.

There is ample in the revenue reserve, taking account of the dividend that we've announced today and assuming no further revenue profits generated, then we have at least 2 years' cover in our revenue reserve.
But we are absolutely expecting the changes to come through by the next financial period, which will give us much greater flexibility in terms of our ability to pay out of our reserves.

Good morning, everyone and welcome, again.
My job is very simple and that's just simply to let you know that if the fire alarm goes for any reason, you need to move out from the back please.
And also, if you could, please turn your mobiles and any other devices off that might interfere with the microphones because this morning's presentation is being webcast.
So without further ado, I'd like to introduce Chief Executive Michael Queen.

Well, the board has considered whether it's appropriate to conduct buybacks in the current market and felt that, given the uncertainties around refinancing and our need to continue to roll over certain parts of our gross borrowings, that it was just too uncertain an environment to embark on that.
What we also need to do is to make sure that we continue to meet our fiduciary responsibilities in respect to the funds that we manage.
We raise these funds and we charge fees on the basis that we will invest in assets over a given timeframe.
And it's very important that we continue to do that.
And clearly, 3i's investment in those assets, it's important to meet that because we intend to continue to raise funds going forward.
So while mathematically, if the shares trade at a discount to net assets, it's unassailable logic that buying those shares on that basis would boost the NAV per share.
It's not necessarily in the long-term interest of shareholders for us to do that.
And that's what the board has taken into account in coming out with a decision today, that in the current time we would not undertake buybacks.
Now that's not to say that, that will be the position forever.
We don't have a principled objection to buybacks.
We absolutely see buybacks as an appropriate form of the cycle.
But given the risks in the macro environment today, we are not going to be doing that in the near term.
Henry Freeman from Liberum Capital again.

So under that environment, we would expect to see provisions increasing.

Absent that, and let's assume governments do get their act together and we do see some form stabilization, I wouldn't, in the current environment, expect to see a significant increase in the level of provisioning that we're seeing.
There will always be some provisioning, but I don't think it's going to be a dramatic increase on what we've got we got at the moment.
Well, good morning, everyone.
Let me take you through the agenda for today's briefing.

I'm going to start by giving an overview of the group performance, as well as more detail on the private equity changes that we've announced this morning, and the result of the board's dividend policy review.
Julia will follow with the detailed financial results.
I'll then ask Menno Antal to give a bit more color on how the private equity business line is performing.
Finally, I'll return to say a few words on the outlook before we open the floor to questions.
There's no doubt that the last 6 months have presented an extremely difficult operating environment.
For financial markets, it's been a period of considerable uncertainty, and fears regarding the future of the Eurozone have severely damaged business confidence in many of our markets.

3i has not been immune to this turmoil, and as you'll see in more detail as Julia takes you through the financials, our half year performance has been significantly affected by the macroeconomic environment, particularly the impact of falling stock markets on multiples.
We can take some comfort in the underlying performance of our investments.
On a value-weighted basis, our portfolio earnings have increased 8% in the 6 months, with our more valuable investments tending to be the better performers throughout the period.
However, as I've raised repeatedly through these presentations, our performance has continued to be impacted by the high prices paid and high leverage of assets invested in 2007 and 2008.
On the macroeconomic level, parallels can be drawn between what we're going through now and the first stage of the financial crisis in 2008.
However, from a 3i Group perspective, there's a marked contrast between then and now.
The steps we've taken to strengthen our balance sheet were a precaution against exactly the kind of market conditions we're seeing today.
We've also significantly reduced the leverage at the portfolio level.
As an example, the average debt multiple in our buyout portfolio now stands at 4.
4x, down from almost 6x, which gives greater headroom to cope with any temporary fluctuations in performance.
We've reduced net debt at the 3i Group level too, from a peak of GBP 1.
9 billion  in 2009 to just over GBP 0.
5 billion today, giving us a stronger position as we enter an increasingly uncertain period for realizations in refinancings.
The quality of our asset management and investment capabilities has also been strengthened as evidenced by the performance of recent new investments.
The teams are very focused on maintaining their investment discipline and managing the portfolio to maximize value.
Another area where we've changed 3i is the cost base.
By adjusting our operational and financial structure, and maintaining a focus on our core competencies, we've reduced operating expenses by 1/3 over the past 3 years.
Last year, we announced the combination of our European growth and buyout teams to form a single European private equity team.

As we reach the end of the Eurofund V investment period, we are now further reshaping this combined business to reflect the current market condition and the likely new investment environment over the next few years.
In addition, we're integrating our U.
team to create a developed markets private equity team.
This will allow operating efficiencies to be achieved, which in turn, enables a reduction of operating expenses by at least GBP 15 million a year from financial year 2012-13.
These steps reflect the natural progression of our private equity business.
The team will be well positioned to take advantage of attractive investment opportunities as they arise and will have the full support of the 3i balance sheet.
In developing markets private equity, we strengthened our China team with the appointment of Paul Su.
We've also received an allocation to invest in local currency from the Chinese government.
And in Brazil, we've established an advisory board to support the local team in So Paulo.
The changes in the private equity business also require some changes to the leadership team and a realignment of leadership roles.
As we've already announced, Simon Borrows has joined as Chief Investment Officer, while his predecessor, Ian Nolan, is leaving 3i.
Menno Antal and Alan Giddins will jointly lead our developed markets private equity business, covering Europe and the U.
, and Guy Zarzavatdjian will take over responsibility for developing markets in addition to his current responsibility for the Growth Capital Fund.
Bob Stefanowski will step down from the leadership team to focus on 2 of our larger portfolio companies.
In our Infrastructure and Debt Management business lines, performance has been robust, and we're pursuing a number of initiatives.
The European infrastructure assets have performed well, and during the period, 3i Infrastructure's consortium was announced as a preferred bidder on the U.
's Thameslink rail project.
In India, we've launched the second India Infrastructure Fund, which we expect to complete during 2012.
In debt management, the CLO funds are performing ahead of our original business plan, generating good advisory and performance fees.
During this period, we've launched a new Credit Opportunities Fund, initially funded by 3i, which will aim to take advantage of the dislocation that we see in credit markets.
I now want to turn towards our current priorities.

3i's first priority is to maximize the value of our existing investments by supporting them through current economic conditions so that they're well positioned to take advantage of growth opportunities that will follow.
We're also focused on maintaining investment discipline across our business lines.
All the deals we do must be reviewed in the light of constantly changing economic conditions, and we need to ensure that we pay the right price at the right time.
It's also vitally important that we continue with the conservative balance sheet strategy we followed since 2009.
Doing so will give greater security to all our stakeholders in this uncertain environment.
A key part of our strategy is to grow the business in a measured way.
Some good examples of this are the second Indian infrastructure fund raising and the Credit Opportunities Fund that I've already mentioned.
Together, these priorities feed into the delivery of our strategic model, and allow us to provide shareholders with more stable and consistent returns over the economic cycle.

Now having introduced our model for returns in May and completed our review of the European private equity business, the board has now decided the appropriate proportion of those returns that should take the form of dividend.
I'm pleased to announce that, subject to shareholder approval, we're raising the full year dividend to 8.
1p per share, and this is an increase of 125% on the previous year, of which we're declaring an interim dividend of 2.
From this higher base, we expect to grow the dividend progressively, in line with the performance of the business and its balance sheet strength.

The board has also considered undertaking share buybacks and, while accepting the principle of buybacks, has concluded that such purchases are not appropriate at the current time, particularly given the extreme uncertainty in financial markets and low levels of business and consumer confidence.
And now before I pass to Julia, let me give you the key metrics for the period.
As I've said, our gross return has been primarily driven by market conditions, most notably the decline in multiples used for valuation purposes.
Although as a whole, our investments have displayed resilient underlying performance, the general softening of market conditions has led to a negative gross investment return of 8.
After cost and financing, this results in a negative total return of 15.
Despite the tough environment, we achieved a good level of realizations at GBP 532 million, although most of these were in the first half of this 6-month period.
Investment during this period was GBP 448 million.
Our gross debt currently stands at GBP 1.
7 billion, and taking into account our cash balances, we have net debt of GBP 531 million.
Our liquidity, which includes cash and undrawn facilities, is GBP 1.
Julia will now take you through these numbers, along with the other financials, in more detail.

And that's why we've seen strong business performance in the Benelux, in Nordic and in Germany, where many of the businesses we've invested have that profile.
So it's that, the balance between domestic sales and export in which is probably the biggest single factor.

is now becoming much less a part of our asset base.

and we've done some great deals here, as I mentioned, Go Outdoors.

portfolio specific company or can you just comment on to the rate of crossing terms order other investment in the  U.

, please? You anticipate much closer to the 1 billion at into next year significant step up? Philip, I think estimating the demand and supply of capital is always going to be more of an outer science.
Our view is that at the margin, it's going to get better.

One of the things I didn't talk about though was what corporate behavior will be because corporate has got more cash than they've ever had at any point, and I've been surprised how little M&A activities they driven through corporate so you got all of that factor in as well.
What we're focused in on though is those sectors and geographies where we believe we have real insights into individual businesses.
And if you look at some of the deals that we've done in the last 12 months, they're very, very good examples of this.
So the Digi, the chain of private hospitals that we bought in France, it's a very good example.

Because we previously owned a similar chain in the Nordic region called Ambea, where over a number of years, we basically acquired a series of similar businesses, integrated them, improved the trading performance of all these businesses and saw a very substantial uplift in value.

So in the Digi our plan is to acquire a great platform to grow that business through a combination of improved operating performance, but also acquiring smaller, local businesses that we can add into it.
And you'll see some of our investment goes into supporting inquisitive growth.
So very common part of our investment is now.
Other business that we invested in last year for the first time was a business called Fresco, a fruit juice business.
They've made a major acquisition using capital from 3i over the last 12 months and will continue to do so.
Another business that we talked about before Labco, a laboratories business in France.
They've made about 25 acquisitions over the last couple of years as we consolidate that highly fragmented sector.

So a combination of sector insight, helping businesses internationalize, move into Asian markets, improving their operating performance and identifying platforms for growth that we can then make acquisitions through are part of our investment thesis.
So Private Equity is no longer about hoping for multiple arbitrage, leveraging something out and then selling a few years later at a higher price.
A lot of hard work that goes into improving the performance of these businesses.
Well, good morning, everyone.
Today, we're going to set out the results of the group and how each of our businesses are performing.
I want to use this results presentation to explain how our strategy is developing and give you a financial framework to assess both these results and our future performance updates.

After this brief introduction, Julia will provide a detailed financial review and I'll then set out the market background and give you more detail on our strategy and financial objectives for the future.
These are the key messages that run through these results.
The underlying performance of each business line is positive and we've come very long way in 2 years.
Strategically, the acquisition of MIM to form a Debt Management business line is an important step forward on our growth agenda.
3i Debt Management will provide yield and lower volatility earnings.
We've also reviewed our approach to investment in asset management.
We've improved where necessary, for example, in bringing together our Buyout and Growth Capital business so that they might operate more effectively in the market.
And I'm pleased that the benefits of this move are already showing through in an increase in investment activity.
This year, we completed 10 high-quality transactions across our network, investing 1.
5 billion in total.
The final message reflects our commitment to manage 3i, with both strong liquidity and low leverage, and you'll see that we're continued to bring down absolute levels of borrowing.
Before handing over to Julia, I want to summarize the progress we've made over the past 2 years.

Firstly, the financial security of the company needed to be reestablished and the steps that we took in early 2009 to restructure and derisk the balance sheet helped us to achieve this sooner than expected.
Secondly, we needed to protect value in the portfolio and then ensure businesses were achieving their full potential.
Thirdly, we've made important management and cultural changes to create a winning model.
And finally, we're now moving back to a growth agenda.
So let me now turn to this year's financial highlights.
Julia's going to take you through these numbers in more detail, but let me focus on 2 aspects of these results.
Total return of 10.
6% or 324 million was achieved despite an impairment in value of 198 million in respect of a large U.
asset which is now valued at zero.
While this write-down is disappointing, the overall results highlight the resilience of the business.
And this performance was underpinned by portfolio earnings growth of 13% and good uplifts on the sale of assets of 26%.
And it's this underlying strength that gives us confidence to recommend an increase of 20% in the dividend.

I'm now going to hand over to Julia who will take us through the detail behind these numbers but when I come back, I'll set out a very important series of ways in which we're challenging ourselves to deliver returns.
In terms of your capital question.
I think it's a very good point.
And what we have seen, particularly in Europe is growth-orientated businesses have been relatively reluctant to actually press the button on expansion.
I mean there's been a lot of diversion in a lot of diversion actually taking new steps forward.
What we have seen to in the last 3 to 4 months is that attitude changing.
And already in the new financial year, we've actually completed another 2 growth capital transactions, 1 in the U.
in Go Outdoors which is a U.
retail concept which we're very excited about and we think it's got every category killer, and also we've invested in a French-based international freight forwarding and management business.
And the pipeline for growth capital investments is actually the strongest it's been for a number of years.
So I think it was around reticence to commit to growth by businesses, but that now seems to be baby and we are seeing some very good opportunities.

Well, thank you, Michael, and good morning, everyone.
I'd now like to take you through our results for the period of the 31st of March 2011.
Let me begin with the financial highlights in some more detail.
Michael said at the outset we closed the year with a total return of 324 million, a return on opening shareholders funds of 10.
This translates into an increase of 30p in net asset value from 321p to 351p per share.
1% gross portfolio return was driven by strong earnings growth and a good level of realized profits, combined with uplift to imminent sales.
We continue to take advantage of open markets realizations, generating uplifts of 26% over opening valuations.
And we've also seen a 14% increase in fee income over the period.
There was a significant increase in asset bundle management.
This is mainly due to the growth of our Debt Management business following the acquisition of Mizuho Securities and Debt business.
and this added for some 3.
4 billion passed our assets under management.
Investments of 719 million is significantly ahead of last year's historically low levels.
And although realizations are considerably lower at 609 million than last year, this figure does not include the sale of Heber and the IPO of NORMA.
Together these transactions delivered the further 255 million to the group in April, an evidence of our success in our portfolio.
The net effect of this investments activity means we finished the year with strong liquidity of 1.
8 billion and net debt of 522 million.
We remain positive about the outlook for 3i and the strength of our business, our portfolio and our brand.
Reinforcing this, we declared a dividend of 2.
4p, a total increase of 20% in the year.
Turning then to returns, and just to remind you how our returns are made up.
Gross portfolio return shows the returns from those assets in which 3i invests directly.
And I'll come on to talk in more detail about how each of our business lines have performed this year.
In total, the group generated a gross portfolio return of 601 million or 17.
1% return on opening portfolio value.
Next portfolio return includes the benefits of our Asset Management business to increase the fees and we carried that we generate to managing investments on behalf of others.
The increase in fees in the year primarily reflects the first full year of the Growth Capital Fund.
Net portfolio return also increased the costs of running our investment in Asset Management businesses.
Those operating expenses continued to fall in the year despite adding the costs of the new Debt Management team.
Finally, to get to total return, we take account of the cost of our own balance sheet funding and other factors such as the pension and foreign exchange.
As I indicated in November, interest cost has been higher in the year as we reshaped the maturity profile of our debt in line with our conservative balance sheet approach.
In particular, the 127 million net interest cost reflects our decision to issue a 7-year bond in March 2010.
This is to take advantage of the market opportunity, but it was somewhat ahead of the convertible bond maturity that we have this month.
We have mitigated this overlap by buying in the convertible bond throughout the year where it was available.
We've now extended our balance sheet hedging policy to include foreign currency swaps, as well as core currency borrowing.
At the year-end, we hedged 68% of our Euro portfolio and 46% of our dollar portfolio.
The unhedged elements of the portfolio resulted in a net exchange movement of 17 million.
Finally, the accounting valuation of our U.
-defined benefits pension scheme resulted in an actuarial gain of 20 million.
We're in discussion with the trustees of this scheme regarding its latest trend in evaluation.
Now that the scheme is close to new members and to future accrual for existing members, we're taking further steps to derisk the scheme to reduce the effects of the scheme on our returns.
Taking all of these aspects into account, we've closed the year with a total return of 10.
6% or 324 million.
This translates to an NAV of 351p, an increase of 30p since March 2010.
Looking at those components of return in terms of NAV progression, this slide shows you how we've increased NAV from 321p at the start of the year to 351p at the end.
Gross portfolio return from our direct investments contributed 63p.
The net effect of the benefits of Asset Management, offset by the cost of running the business, reduced NAV by 16p.
And the cost of the balance sheet, a further 13p.
Dividends paid to shareholders, which here does not include the dividend we've announced today, amount to 3p, all in all resulting in an NAV of 351p at the end of the year.
So let me now take you through the components of the gross portfolio return in more detail.
This slide shows you the composition of our gross portfolio return and the contributions made by each business line.
As we'd expect, given the nature and the relative size of its direct portfolio, the most significant contributor is our Private Equity business.
This generated a return of 16% or 462 million.
Realizations are lower, as I've already mentioned, but with good uplifts of 20%.

Unrealized returns of 277 million were driven by good earnings performance across much of the portfolio, although these were partially offset by significant impairments and the portfolio to value this portfolio.
I'll come back to talk about this unrealized value growth into more detail in the next few slides.

Portfolio income of 123 million in our Private Equity business and in buyouts in particular principally comprises the capitalized interest, and so does not generate cash yield until the underlying investment is sold.
That said, a number of our growth capital investments have paid dividends in the year.

Turning then to our Infrastructure business, the gross portfolio return of 45 million or 11% from our Infrastructure business affects the movement in our 33% holding in 3i Infrastructure Plc and value movements on investments held through it 3i India Infrastructure Fund.
As Cressida Hogg reported last week, the underlying performance of Infrastructure portfolio is robust with good new investments in the year.
Our Infrastructure business we also benefit from dividend income from 3i Infrastructure Plc of 16 million.
Finally, our Debt Management business, before I comment on its returns for this year, let me just remind you what this business line is now made up of.
Our approach to strategic development is to build from our strengths and our expertise.
We have had a well-established banking team within our Private Equity business through a number of years.
That team has been instrumental in managing our banking relationships through the period from 2007 to today.
In 2007, that team sets up a debt warehouse investing in European mid-market credit.
In other words, in the title businesses we were very familiar with.
As our knowledge developed, we looked for opportunities to expand this platform.
Our acquisition of Mizuho's European Debt business brought a team of 28 people, led by Jeremy Ghose and has significantly enhanced our capacity for growth.
We now manage 8 funds and are looking for further opportunities to build on our expertise.
At the same time, we've taken advanced market conditions to unwind substantially the original debt warehouse.

This disposal generated proceeds of 145 million, realized profits of 24 million and an uplift of 20%, which you can see here is the most significant aspect of Debt Management's gross portfolio return this year.
With the European acquisition only completed in February, its effect in the results is actually minimal.
I'll now take you through our valuations for the year in more detail and how that 325 million of total unrealized value growth arises.
Strong earnings growth in the portfolio is reflected in the earnings growth movement of 295 million and in the uplift to imminent sales of 240 million, a total contribution of 535 million.
This highlights the strong underlying performance of much of the portfolio, a trend which is being consistent throughout the year.
In particular, we have seen some excellent performance in our northern European portfolio, and those companies which are expanding their businesses to take advantage of Asian growth.
Also consistent with the half year, we continue to see a reduction in multiples used to value the portfolio, and this resulted in a negative value movement of 76 million.
Clearly, a disappointing aspect of this year's performance is the 196 million impairment compared to last year's reversal of 47 million.
The impairment includes a significant movement of 198 million in respect of a single U.
We have taken a more cautious view on its earnings, and as a result, made a significant revision to the comparable multiples set.
It's a combination of these factors that has given rise to the impairment, which has taken the value of the asset to null.

Our change in view is attributable to both sector and to company-specific factors it does not reflect the view that it affects the broader portfolio where we continue to see good underlying performance.
Provisions of 71 million account for about 2% of opening portfolio value.
And they relate to 7 assets in a variety of sexes and geographies.
Together, they do not show a particular concentration risk.
Positively, it includes a reversal of 18 million in relation to an additional asset, which is showing signs of good earnings recovery of the significant intervention on our part.
This company now moves back to an earnings basis evaluation.

The positive contribution of 4 million from those assets valued on a DCF basis relates to the investments made through our Indian Infrastructure Fund and to a small number of private equity businesses.

Finally, although the total unrealized value movements is lower in absolute terms than last year, the contribution of strong earnings growth from the portfolio and uplift to imminent sales is much more significant, and is an indicator of our confidence in the underlying performance of the portfolio.
Picking up on this point in more detail, you can see from this slide how the earnings growth and multiple movements have trended in the last 2 years.
These numbers relate to those companies that are valued on an earnings basis at the beginning and at the end of the year.
As I've already said, we continue to see strong earnings growth in much of our portfolio, notwithstanding some impairments.
Earnings growth of 13% contributed 295 million to returns compared to a decline of 8% in the prior year.
That growth has also continued consistently throughout the year.
Around 3 quarters of this portfolio contributes a positive earnings growth during the year and more than 40% of the portfolio showed earnings growth of more than 30%.
And of course we're working very hard the company showed earnings decreases to get them back on plan.
Much of this portfolio, 84% of it, has been valued using the management accounts to the 31st of December 2010.
However, we also review the latest management accounts available, and if they or the current year forecasts indicate a downturn in performance, we take that into account in our valuation.
This year, 12% of companies were in this category, which is stable compared to last year and is a market improvement in 2009 were 39% of the portfolio was valued on a current year forecast basis.
Turning to multiples, equity markets remain volatile in the 12-month period in 31st of March 2011.
Overall, we've seen a 7% decline in the multiples used to value the majority of the portfolio.
The multiples we choose are based on comparable sets of multiples for each company.
We consider factors such as geography, sector, size and earnings performance.
We also compare the end result, in this case the 7% full, to the equivalent indices in the sectors and the geographies in which we invest.
And those indices showed very similar movements in the year.
The weighted average multiples used to value the portfolio fell to 8.
8 before discount compared to 9.
5 in March 2010.
As a result of this reduction, value growth decreased by 76 million.

So as we start the half year, those elements of the valuation which directly reflect the performance of the investments, have remained strong in the second half, and notwithstanding a small number of asset-specific reductions.
The unrealized value growth on our portfolio is obviously a key driver of our returns and also of a balance sheet portfolio value.
This slide shows you the progression of the portfolio value during the year.
The opening portfolio was 3.
This increased by 719 million of investments and the positive contribution from the revaluation of 325 million.
After taking account the divestments and other movements, the closing portfolio value was 4 billion at the 31st of March 2011.
Let me just spend a few minutes elaborating on that 719 million of investment in the year.

This is a significant increase following a period of low activity levels, and is consistent with the recovery in activity levels seen in the European private equity market, which Michael will talk in more detail about shortly.
We have maintained a highly selective approach to new investment, looking for investments where we believe our sector expertise and our international network could make a difference.
However, the competitive environment remains, which has meant a number of transactions have had a very long lead time.
You can see from this slide we invested 270 million in private equity.
This is in 6 new deals, most of which were undrawn Europe from 5 mandates.

We also invested in 3 new deals in our Indian Infrastructure Fund and I would encourage you to look at the results in the presentation given by Cressida and the infrastructure team last week, which gives you plenty of detail on the progress being made there.
In addition to making new investments, we continue to support our existing portfolio, providing 80 million of capital to fund new acquisitions and capital expenditure.
As we noted in the half year, we also invested 110 million in buying discount at existing businesses.
And the cost of equity cures and capital restructurings were low at 16 million.
Capitalized interest of 158 million relates largely to the buyout portfolio.

So what effect has that and the realizations had on the makeup of our portfolio? This slide sets out the portfolio by business, geography, sector and vintage, and it's helpful in understanding the shape of our business today.
I am not going to spend any time going through this in detail, but it is clear from the analysis that the portfolio remains well diversified.
Now I'd like to turn to the rest of the balance sheet.
We've continued to adopt the conservative approach to our balance sheet management and remain committed to our limit on net debt of 1 billion.
We've also continued to make progress in reducing our gross debt.
This has fallen significantly in the period from 2.
5 billion to 2 billion, as we abort on the convertible bond, bought back some of our 2012 maturities and took a positive decision not to refinance other debt which has fallen due in the year.
There was an increase in net debt and gearing as a result of net cash outflow during the period.
However, net debt of 522 billion is comfortably within our 1 million limit.
The group's liquidity position remains very strong at 1.
8 billion, meaning we're well-placed to take advantage of investment and strategic opportunities as they arise.
The macroeconomic environment is still uncertain whilst this prevails, our strategy is to continue to manage the balance sheet on a conservative basis.
We recognize that this has a negative effect on our returns in the short-term.
We continually look for opportunities to mitigate this while maintaining flexibility for funding.
As Michael will explain shortly, it is very much our intention to deploy capital wisely and in a way that is consistent with our model for returns.
Thus in summary, we have continued to diversify the business across 3 core businesses and has been an increase of activity across all of them.
Notwithstanding a small number of asset-specific write-downs that has been geared underlying performance in the portfolio, the stronger earnings performance across many of our portfolio companies.
And the business is very well-funded, with strong liquidity to take advantage of new investment opportunities to support future growth.
So thank you, and I will now hand back to Michael.

I mean we're seeing -- the private equity the second secondary private equity market, I think, it's certainly likely to be a major part of all private equity activity over the next 4 or 5 years and certainly in the last year, we've seen it.

That's more predominant in half of the European transactions.
In India, clearly, it's a very different market and there are no secondary transactions in that market.
It was in the other area where there's quite a few transactions.
But if we look forward and we look at the number of companies across Europe that are now owned by private equity firms, it's about 2,000 companies.
And all of those companies have to be sold in the next 4 or 5 years.
So in terms of the proportion of M&A activity, the private equity sales will contribute, it's going to be growing compared to what we've seen historically.
So I think everybody is likely to see more secondary activity than you've seen historically.
Where that trend will end, it's hard to say.
What's important about secondary transactions though, is you've got to be very clear about what you're going to do with that business.
So the assets that we've acquired, we have a very clear value strategy on how the 3i model will move that business on and generate additional returns.
What we're not looking to do is buy from somebody who operates a similar model to us because they've probably done all of the things that we were going to do.
So we're going to have a clear value creation strategy in place.
We have received 325 million of additional realization so far.

In this next section, I want to give you some background on the market, remind you of our wider strategy and introduce a model for how we generate returns before closing with a few comments on the outlook.
Let's look at our markets.
The private equity market continues to be impacted by excess capital that was raised in the peak years of 2006 to 2008, and hasn't yet been spent due to low investment over the past couple of years.

We are, however, seeing investment rates begin to pick up, driven by 2 factors: First the return of confidence; and secondly, the pressure on funds to invest as they move towards the end of their investment periods.
The short-term impact of this has been increased competition, which is pushing asset prices up.
However, private equity fund raising remains at historically low levels.
Therefore, as investment increases and new fund raising remains low, they expects excess capital to be used up and the investment environment to improve.
As a permanent capital vehicle, 3i is well-positioned to take advantage of this market dynamic.
Turning to the infrastructure market, pressures on public finances will increase deal flow as governments increasingly looked to the private sector as a source of finding.
Such opportunities play to the strengths of 3i's brand, our reputations as responsible investor and our ability to invest for the long term through 3i Infrastructure Plc.
In India, economic development continues to drive a huge demand for India.
It's estimated that over the next 5 years, $1 trillion will be invested in the sector.
3i is already recognized as a market leader in Indian infrastructure investment, which positions us well to take advantage of new opportunities through our existing and follow on funds.

With respect to Debt Management, we believe that the combined effect of Bill III and liquidity pressures in the banking sector will create attractive opportunities to invest the same factors are also likely to present further acquisition opportunities in both Europe and the U.
Let me remind you of the shape of 3i today.
We now have 3 businesses, Private Equity, Infrastructure and Debt.
Each business has its own return characteristics and is funded differently from mix of 3i's own balance sheet and external funds.
Each is differentiated in their respective markets by the strength of 3i's brand.
The benefit from 3i's institutional model and the breadth of our international network.
Our permanent capital and strong balance sheet provide a competitive advantage, flexibility in how we manage our business.
And a major benefit from managing multiple asset classes is that different risk return profiles that they have.
By investing across all 3 business lines, we can improve the quality of overall returns.
This next chart shows the progress that the group's made over the past 2 years.
We've added an additional 30p to our net asset value this year, giving an annualized return of 13% over the 2 years.
And I want to build on this progress as we move forward.
Over the past 2 years, we've developed a clear set of priorities to deliver future growth.
It's consistent with our return objectives.
These priorities form the basis for the strategy summarized on this slide.
By building on the 3i brand and growing our reputation as a respected and responsible investor, we will invest in 3i itself, our business lines and Investment portfolios to deliver growth.
We must ensure that we maintain a consistent approach to the way that we do business to drive performance, build best practice and achieve our objective of delivering consistent returns.

As an experienced international investment company, managing multiple sources of capital across different asset classes, I believe that we're well-positioned to deliver this strategy for our shareholders and investors.
And let me expand on 2 of these areas of strategy, investment and growth of the business.
Starting with investment, 3i and its funds have committed 1.
5 billion to 10 new companies over the year.
These include Eversholt, the U.
train leasing company, the Digi [ph], a private health care provider in France, and BBG, 1 of India's largest facilities management service providers.
And the 1 thing that all of these investments have in common is that they're in sectors and countries we know well.

While our rate of investment has increased significantly over the previous year we've ensured that we retained our measured and highly selective approach in what has remained a very competitive market.
The second aspect of our strategy has been particularly relevant this year is our commitment to grow the business.

Our Debt Management acquisition in September, which completed in February, has added to our existing Debt Management capabilities and reinforced 3i's strategy of growing in areas consistent with our investment expertise.
Our new business line 3i Debt Management, complements the existing private equity and infrastructure businesses, and provides a source of growing and lower volatility returns.
We've also recently announced the recruitment of an experienced team in Brazil.
Led by Marcelo DiLorenzo, the team' has established track record will give us access to opportunities in 1 of the world's fastest-growing regions.
What's more, the global nature of 3i's portfolio means that 20% of our companies already have an exposure to Latin America.
And having a team on the ground in that region will provide the support that these companies need to grow.
In Asia, we're looking to raise a second Indian Infrastructure Fund to build on the performance of the first fund.
And I hope this demonstrates the ambition that we have to grow our business.
We're actively pursuing further opportunities to complement our existing business and build on 3i's brand, reputation and expertise.
Let me now turn to our model for returns.
This is the framework that I'm using as a management tool to guide 3i's growth.
I want to spend a few moments on this next slide to explain the model.
3i now operates in 3 distinct asset classes across the risk return spectrum: Private equity, infrastructure and debt.
And although the gross returns of these investments vary, we designed a funding structure that should ease the each business line contributes equally to our long term objective of 15%.
This return objective is demanding.
And we're looking at it as an average over any given 5-year period.
For those business lines with lower gross return characteristics, namely infrastructure and debt, we have a higher proportion of third-party funds under management, and so receive higher fee income.
By their nature, these asset classes also benefit from more stable earnings, allowing us to deliver a greater consistency of returns.
Let me now show you in more detail how our current business lines fit with this model.
Let's firstly take private equity.
That is the business line that contributes the highest gross return to our portfolio to around 20%.
It's also the business line to which we commit the highest proportion of our own funds, at least a 50/50 split with external investors.
Overall, the net effect of costs, fees and carried interest gives us a long term net return objective of 15%.
Moving on to infrastructure, as a lower risk asset class, our gross return objective for infrastructure is lower than private equity at 12%.
However, since 3i managers are higher proportion of third-party capital, we see a net benefit from fee income, which contributes to an overall net return objective of 15%.

And finally, turning to our new Debt Management business line, this has the highest proportion of external funds under management, and so shows the largest positive impact of external management and performance fees.
So again, a 15% return is achieved.
And so I hope you can now see how our 3 business lines work together to achieve our return objectives.
So for shareholders, our net return objective of 15% should translate into a return on equity, also of 15%.
And this is the model that I'm using to challenge each of our businesses to deliver over the long term.
And of course in each individual period, the results are likely to vary from these objectives.
But hopefully, this framework should help shareholders understand more clearly the progress that we're making.
This model also serves the dual purpose of being a tool to evaluate new areas of investment.
Any new business opportunities will be tested against this framework, and will need to fit with our strategy, our return objectives and enhance the overall 3i business model.
And I wanted to look forward to the outlook for 3i.
In the near term, the global economic climate raises considerable uncertainty but is likely to show overall growth.
However, the regional differences will be significant.
in this environment, we will continue to focus on stock selection, and we expect it to increase investment.
However, this will be well-controlled and focus on regions and sectors where we have a competitive advantage.
3i will also continue to pursue its strategy of investing in its business and reputation.
The multi-business line structure that we now operate is designed to provide higher quality and more stable earnings for our investors.
3i is facing the future with confidence.
And I hope our new framework for returns clarifies our business and provides a yardstick for future performance.
Before we turn to Q&A, let me pick up on the key messages that I hope you take from this meeting.
Firstly, we're seeing very good underlying performance of our business lines.
We've taken 1 notable hit to performance this year in our Private Equity business.
But this aside, all 3 business lines are performing in line with our long term return objectives.
We've also made good strategic and operational progress.
The creation of 3i Debt Management will not only diversify returns for our investors, but will also provide greater yield and more stable earnings.
In addition, the operational review of our asset management techniques will ensure that we're managing our portfolio optimally and have learned from the challenges of recent years.

To provide greater insight into our businesses, we'll be holding an Investor Day on the 23rd of June, where all our senior business line leaders will be presenting an in-depth review of their businesses and key assets.
We've continued to be highly selective with respect to new investment.
However, we're well-positioned to take advantage of the good quality investment opportunities that are emerging given that we're well-funded and with a strong balance sheet.
Growth from here will be from a solid, financial base and we'll be well-controlled to ensure that we maintain our financial discipline.
Finally, I've introduce to you a model for returns that I intend to use to guide our performance and against which all new business opportunities will be assessed.
This will help to ensure that we're delivering increasing value for our shareholders and the investors in our funds.
We'll be now very happy to take questions.
