In terms of where that fund is marked at the moment, when you get the report and accounts, it was probably in all the disclosures we gave today.
There was a table showing for all of our funds and what the multiples are.
And the multiple on that -- on Eurofund V at the moment is standing at north 0.
I can't remember offhand, I'm sorry, Bruce, what the exact IRR on that is.
But you'd be able to see in that table where all of our funds are performing.
We're giving more disclosure on that this year.
But clearly you're adding in one side of the equation.
What we're really looking to see in the next 6 months is further investments as well.
So you've got the numbers for the realization side of the equation.
Well, thank you, Michael, and good morning, everyone.
I'd now like to take you through our results for the period to the 31st of March 2011.
Let me begin with the financial highlights in some more detail.
Michael said at the outset, we closed the year with a total return of 324 million, a return on opening shareholders funds of 10.
This translates into an increase of 30p in net asset value from 321p to 351p per share.
1% gross portfolio return was driven by strong earnings growth and a good level of realized profits, combined with uplift to imminent sales.
We continue to take advantage of open markets for realizations, generating uplifts of 26% over opening valuations.
And we've also seen a 14% increase in fee income over the period.
There was a significant increase in asset under management.
This is mainly due to the growth of our Debt Management business, following the acquisition of Mizuho's European debt business.
And this adds some 3.
4 billion to our assets under management.
Investments of 719 million is significantly ahead of last year's historically low levels.
And although realizations are considerably lower at 609 million than last year, this figure does not include the sale of Hyva and the IPO of NORMA.
Together, these transactions delivered a further 255 million to the Group in April, an evidence of our success in our portfolio.
The net effect of this investment activity means we finished the year with strong liquidity of 1.
8 billion and net debt of 522 million.
We remain positive about the outlook for 3i and the strength of our business, our portfolio and our brand.
Reinforcing this, we declared a dividend of 2.
4p, a total increase of 20% in the year.
Turning then to returns, and just to remind you how our returns are made up.
Gross portfolio return shows the returns from those assets in which 3i invests directly.
And I'll come on to talk in more detail about how each of our business lines have performed this year.
In total, the Group generated a gross portfolio return of 601 million or 17.
1% return on opening portfolio value.
Next portfolio return includes the benefits of our asset management business, so it includes the fees and the carry that we generate through managing investments on behalf of others.
The increase in fees in the year primarily reflects the first full year of the growth capital fund.
Net portfolio return also increased the costs of running our investment in asset management businesses.
Those operating expenses continued to fall in the year, despite adding the costs of the new Debt Management team.
Finally, to get the total return, we take account of the costs of our own balance sheet funding and other factors, such as the pension and foreign exchange.
As I indicated in November, interest cost has been higher in the year as we reshaped the maturity profile of our debt in line with our conservative balance sheet approach.
In particular, the 127 million net interest cost reflects our decision to issue a 7-year bond in March 2010.
This is to take advantage of a market opportunity, but it was somewhat ahead of the convertible bond maturity that we have this month.
We have mitigated this overlap by buying in the convertible bond throughout the year where it was available.
We've now extended our balance sheet hedging policy to include foreign currency swaps, as well as core currency borrowing.
At the year end, we'd hedged 68% of our euro portfolio and 46% of our dollar portfolio.
The unhedged element to the portfolio resulted in a net exchange movement of 17 million.
Finally, the accounting valuation of our U.
-defined benefits pension scheme resulted in an actuarial gain of 20 million.
We're in discussion with the trustees of this scheme, regarding its latest triennial valuation.
Now that the scheme has closed to new members and to future accrual for existing members, we're taking further steps to de-risk the scheme to reduce the effects of the scheme on our returns.
Taking all of these aspects into account, we've closed the year with a total return of 10.
6% or 324 million.
This translates to an NAV of 351p, an increase of 30p since March 2010.
Looking at those components of return in terms of NAV progression, this slide shows you how we've increased NAV from 321p at the start of the year to 351p at the end.
Gross portfolio return from our direct investments contributed 63p.
The net effect of the benefits of Asset Management, offset by the cost of running the business, reduced NAV by 16p, and the cost of the balance sheet, a further 13p.
Dividends paid to shareholders, which of course here do not include the dividend we've announced today, amount to 3p, all in all resulting in an NAV of 351p at the end of the year.
So let me now take you through the components of the gross portfolio return in more detail.
This slide shows you the composition of our gross portfolio return and the contributions made by each business line.
As we'd expect, given the nature and the relative size of its direct portfolio, the most significant contributor is our private equity business.
This generated a return of 16% or 462 million.
Realizations are lower, as I've already mentioned, but we're at good uplifts of 20%.

Unrealized returns of 277 million were driven by good earnings performance across much of the portfolio, although these were partially offset by significant impairments and a fall in multiples used to value this portfolio.
I'll come on to talk about this unrealized value growth in some more detail in the next few slides.

Portfolio income of 123 million in our private equity business and in buyouts, in particular, principally comprises the capitalized interest, and so does not generate cash yield until the underlying investment is sold.
That said, a number of our growth capital investments have paid dividends in the year.
Turning then to our infrastructure business.

The gross portfolio return of 45 million or 11% from our infrastructure business reflects the quoted [ph] movement in our 33% holding in 3i Infrastructure plc and value movements on investments held through 3i India Infrastructure Fund.
As Cressida Hogg reported last week, the underlying performance of the infrastructure portfolio is robust, with good new investments in the year.
In our infrastructure business, we also benefit from dividend income from 3i Infrastructure plc of 16 million.
Finally, our Debt Management business.
Before I comment on its returns for this year, let me just remind you what this business line is now made up of.
Our approach to strategic development is to build from our strengths and our expertise.
We have had a well-established banking team within our private equity business for a number of years.
That team has been instrumental in managing our banking relationships through the period from 2007 to today.
In 2007, that team set up a debt warehouse investing in European mid-market credit.
In other words, in the type of businesses we were very familiar with.
As our knowledge developed, we looked for opportunities to expand this platform.
Our acquisition of Mizuho's European debt business brought a team of 28 people, led by Jeremy Ghose and has significantly enhanced our capacity for growth.
We now manage 8 funds and are looking for further opportunities to build on our expertise.
At the same time, we've taken advantage of market conditions to unwind substantially the original debt warehouse.

This disposal generated proceeds of 145 million, realized profits of 24 million and an uplift of 20%, which you can see here is the most significant aspect of Debt Management's gross portfolio return this year.
With the European acquisition only completed in February, its effect on the results this year is actually minimal.
I'd now like to take you through our valuations for the year in more detail and how that 325 million of total unrealized value growth arises.
Strong earnings growth in the portfolio is reflected in the earnings growth movement of 295 million and in the uplift to imminent sale of 240 million, a total contribution of 535 million.
This highlights the strong underlying performance of much of the portfolio, a trend which is being consistent throughout the year.
In particular, we have seen some excellent performance in our Northern European portfolio, and those companies which are expanding their businesses to take advantage of Asian growth.
Also consistent with the half year, we've continued to see a reduction in multiples used to value the portfolio.
And this resulted in a negative value movement of 76 million.
Clearly, a disappointing aspect of this year's performance is the 196 million impairment compared to last year's reversal of 47 million.
The impairment includes a significant movement of 198 million in respect of a single U.
We have taken a more cautious view on its earnings, and as a result, made a significant revision to the comparable multiples set.
It's a combination of these factors that has given rise to the impairment, which has taken the value of the asset to nil.
Our change in view is attributable to both sector and to company-specific factors.
It does not reflect the view that affects the broader portfolio where we continue to see good underlying performance.
Provisions of 71 million account for about 2% of opening portfolio value.
And they relate to 7 assets in a variety of sectors and geographies.
Together, they do not show a particular concentration risk.
Positively, it includes a reversal of 18 million in relation to an additional asset, which is showing signs of good earnings recovery after significant intervention on our part.
This company now moves back to an earnings basis evaluation.

The positive contribution of 54 million from those assets valued on a DCF basis relates to the investments made through our Indian Infrastructure Fund and to a small number of private equity businesses.

Finally, although the total unrealized value movements is lower in absolute terms than last year, the contribution of strong earnings growth in the portfolio and uplift to imminent sale is much more significant and is an indicator of our confidence in the underlying performance of the portfolio.
Picking up on this point in more detail, you can see from this slide how the earnings growth and multiple movements have trended in the last 2 years.
These numbers relate to those companies that are valued on an earnings basis at the beginning and at the end of the year.
As I've already said, we continue to see strong earnings growth in much of our portfolio, notwithstanding some impairments.
Earnings growth of 13% contributed 295 million to returns compared to a decline of 8% in the prior year.
That growth has also continued consistently throughout the year.
Around 3 quarters of this portfolio contributes a positive earnings growth during the year, and more than 40% of the portfolio showed earnings growth of more than 20%.
And of course, we're working very hard with the companies that showed earnings decreases to get them back on plan.
Much of this portfolio, 84% of it, has been valued using the management accounts to the 31st of December 2010.
However, we also review the latest management accounts available, and if they or the current year forecasts indicate a downturn in performance, we take that into account in our valuation.
This year, 12% of companies were in this category, which is stable compared to last year and has marked improvement on 2009 where 39% of the portfolio was valued on a current year forecast basis.
Turning to multiples.
Equity markets remain volatile in the 12-month period to the 31st of March 2011.
Overall, we've seen a 7% decline in the multiples used to value the majority of the portfolio.
The multiples we choose are based on comparable sets of multiples for each company.
We consider factors such as geography, sector, size and earnings performance.
We also compare the end result, in this case the 7% fall, to the equivalent indices in the sectors and the geographies in which we invest.
And those indices showed very similar movements in the year.
The weighted average multiples used to value the portfolio fell to 8.
8 before discount compared to 9.
5 in March 2010.
As a result of this reduction, value growth decreased by 76 million.

So as we start the half year, those elements of the valuation, which directly reflect the performance of the investments, have remained strong in the second half, and notwithstanding a small number of asset-specific reductions.
The unrealized value growth on our portfolio is obviously a key driver of our returns and also of a balance sheet portfolio value.
This slide shows you the progression of the portfolio value during the year.
The opening portfolio was 3.
This increased by 719 million of investments and the positive contribution from the revaluation of 325 million.
After taking account of divestments and other movements, the closing portfolio value was 4 billion at the 31st of March 2011.
Let me just spend a few minutes elaborating on that 719 million of investment in the year.

This is a significant increase, following a period of low activity levels, and is consistent with the recovery in activity levels seen in the European private equity market, which Michael will talk in more detail about shortly.
We have maintained a highly selective approach to new investment, looking for investments where we believed our sector expertise and our international network could make a difference.
However, the competitive environment remains, which has meant a number of transactions have had a very long lead time.
You can see from this slide, we invested 270 million in private equity.
This is in 6 new deals, most of which were under our Eurofund V mandates.

We also invested in 3 new deals in our Indian Infrastructure Fund, and I would encourage you to look at the results in the presentation given by Cressida and the infrastructure team last week, which gives you plenty of detail on the progress being made there.
In addition to making new investments, we've continued to support our existing portfolio, providing 80 million of capital to fund new acquisitions and capital expenditure.
As we announced at the half year, we also invested 110 million in buying debt at a discount at existing businesses.
And the cost of equity cures and capital restructurings were low at 16 million.
Capitalized interest of 158 million relates largely to the buyout portfolio.
So what effect has that and the realizations had on the makeup of our portfolio? This slide sets out the portfolio by business, geography, sector and vintage.
And it's helpful in understanding the shape of our business today.
I'm not going to spend any time going through this in detail, but it is clear from the analysis that the portfolio remains well diversified.
I'd now like to turn to the rest of the balance sheet.
We've continued to adopt the conservative approach to our balance sheet management and remain committed to our limit on net debt of 1 billion.
We've also continued to make progress in reducing our gross debt.
This has fallen significantly in the period from 2.
5 billion to 2 billion, as we have bought in the convertible bond, bought back some of our 2012 maturities and took a positive decision not to refinance other debt, which has fallen due in the year.
There was an increase in net debt and gearing as a result of net cash outflow in the period.
However, net debt of 522 million is comfortably within our 1 billion limit.

The Group's liquidity position remains very strong 
at 1.
8 billion, meaning we're well placed to take advantage of investment and strategic opportunities as they arise.
The macroeconomic environment is still uncertain whilst this prevails, our strategy is to continue to manage the balance sheet on a conservative basis.
We recognize that this has a negative effect on our returns in the short term.
We continually look for opportunities to mitigate this while maintaining flexibility for funding.
As Michael will explain shortly, it is very much our intention to deploy capital wisely, and in a way, that is consistent with our model for returns.
Thus in summary, we have continued to diversify the business across 3 core businesses and has been an increase in activity across all of them.
Notwithstanding a small number of asset-specific write-downs, there has been good underlying performance in the portfolio, with stronger earnings performance across many of our portfolio companies.
And the business is very well funded, with strong liquidity to take advantage of new investment opportunities to support future growth.
So thank you, and I will now hand back to Michael.
Thanks, Julia.

In this next section, I want to give you some background on the market, remind you of our wider strategy and introduce a model for how we generate returns, before closing with a few comments on the outlook.
Let's look at our markets.
The private equity market continues to be impacted by excess capital that was raised in the peak years of 2006 to 2008, and hasn't yet been spent due to low investment over the past couple of years.

We are, however, seeing investment rates begin to pick up, driven by 2 factors: firstly, a return of confidence; and secondly, the pressure on funds to invest as they move towards the end of their investment periods.
The short-term impact of this has been increased competition, which is pushing asset prices up.
However, private equity fund raising remains at historically low levels.
Therefore, as investment increases and new fund raising remains low, I expect excess capital to be used up and the investment environment to improve.
As a permanent capital vehicle, 3i is well positioned to take advantage of this market dynamic.
Turning to the infrastructure market.
Pressures on public finances will increase deal flow as governments increasingly looked to the private sector as a source of funding.
Such opportunities play to the strengths of 3i's brand, our reputation as a responsible investor and our ability to invest for the long term through 3i Infrastructure plc.
In India, economic development continues to drive a huge demand for India.
It's estimated that over the next 5 years, $1 trillion will be invested in the sector.
3i is already recognized as a market leader in Indian infrastructure investment, which positions us well to take advantage of new opportunities through our existing and follow-on funds.
With respect to Debt Management, we believe that the combined effect of Basel III [ph] and liquidity pressures in the banking sector will create attractive opportunities to invest.
These same factors are also likely to present further acquisition opportunities in both Europe and the U.
Let me remind you of the shape of 3i today.
We now have 3 businesses: private equity, infrastructure and debt.
Each business has its own return characteristics and is funded differently through a mix of 3i's own balance sheet and external funds.
Each is differentiated in their respective markets by the strength of 3i's brand.
They benefit from 3i's institutional model and the breadth of our international network.
Our permanent capital and strong balance sheet provide a competitive advantage and flexibility in how we manage our business.
And a major benefit from managing multiple asset classes is the different risk return profiles that they have.
By investing across all 3 business lines, we can improve the quality of overall returns.
This next chart shows the progress that the Group's made over the past 2 years.
We've added an additional 30p to our net asset value this year, giving an annualized return of 13% over the 2 years.
And I want to build on this progress as we move forward.
Over the past 2 years, we've developed a clear set of priorities to deliver future growth.
It's consistent with our return objectives.
These priorities form the basis for the strategy summarized on this slide.
By building on the 3i brand and growing our reputation as a respected and responsible investor, we will invest in 3i itself, our business lines and investment portfolios to deliver growth.
We must ensure that we maintain a consistent approach to the way that we do business to drive performance, build best practice and achieve our objective of delivering consistent returns.

As an experienced international investment company, managing multiple sources of capital across different asset classes, I believe that we're well positioned to deliver this strategy for our shareholders and investors.
And let me expand on 2 of these areas of strategy: investment and growth of the business.
Starting with investment, 3i and its funds have committed 1.
5 billion to 10 new companies over the year.
These include: Eversholt, the U.
train leasing company, Vedici, a private healthcare provider in France, and BVG, one of India's largest facilities management service providers.
And the one thing that all of these investments have in common is that they're in sectors and countries that we know well.
While our rates of investment has increased significantly on the previous year, we've ensured that we retain our measured and highly selective approach in what has remained a very competitive market.
The second aspect of our strategy that's been particularly relevant this year is our commitment to grow the business.

Our Debt Management acquisition in September, which completed in February, has added to our existing Debt Management capabilities and reinforced 3i's strategy of growing in areas consistent with our investment expertise.
Our new business line, 3i Debt Management, complements the existing private equity and infrastructure businesses, and provides a source of growing and lower volatility returns.

We've also recently announced the recruitment of an experienced team in Brazil, led by Marcelo Di Lorenzo, the team's established track record will give us access to opportunities in one of the world's fastest-growing regions.
What's more, the global nature of 3i's portfolio means that 20% of our companies already have an exposure to Latin America.
And having a team on the ground in that region will provide the support that these companies need to grow.
In Asia, we're looking to raise a second Indian Infrastructure Fund to build on the performance of the first fund.
And I hope this demonstrates the ambition that we have to grow our business.
We're actively pursuing further opportunities to complement our existing business and build on 3i's brand, reputation and expertise.
Let me now turn to our model for returns.
This is the framework that I'm using as a management tool to guide 3i's growth.
I want to spend a few moments on this next slide to explain the model.
3i now operates in 3 distinct asset classes across the risk/return spectrum: private equity, infrastructure and debt.
And although the gross returns of these investments vary, we've designed a funding structure, such that each business line contributes equally to our long term return objective of 15%.
This return objective is demanding.
And we're looking at it as an average over any given 5-year period.

For those business lines with lower gross return characteristics, namely infrastructure and debt, we have a higher proportion of the third-party funds under management, and so receive higher fee income.
By their nature, these asset classes also benefit from more stable earnings, allowing us to deliver a greater consistency of returns.
Let me now show you in more detail how our current business lines fit with this model.
Let's firstly take private equity.
This is the business line that contributes the highest gross return to our portfolio to around 20%.
It's also the business line to which we commit the highest proportion of our own funds, at least a 50/50 split with external investors.
Overall, the net effect of costs, fees and carried interest gives us a long term net return objective of 15%.
Moving on to infrastructure.
As a lower risk asset class, our gross return objective for infrastructure is lower than private equity at 12%.
However, since 3i managers' a higher proportion of third-party capital, we see a net benefit from fee income, which contributes to an overall net return objective of 15%.

And finally, turning to our new Debt Management business line, this has the highest proportion of external funds under management, and so shows the largest positive impact of external management and performance fees.
So again, a 15% return is achieved.
And so I hope you can now see how our 3 business lines work together to achieve our return objectives.
So for shareholders, our net return objective of 15% should translate into a return on equity, also of 15%.
And this is the model that I'm using to challenge each of our businesses to deliver over the long term.
Of course in each individual period, the results are likely to vary from these objectives.
But hopefully, this framework should help shareholders understand more clearly the progress that we're making.
This model also serves the dual purpose of being a tool to evaluate new areas of investment.
Any new business opportunities will be tested against this framework and will need to fit with our strategy, our return objectives and enhance the overall 3i business model.
And I wanted to look forward to the outlook for 3i.
In the near term, the global economic climate faces considerable uncertainty, but is likely to show overall growth.
However, the regional differences will be significant.
In this environment, we will continue to focus on stock selection, and we expect to increase investment.
However, this will be well controlled and focus on regions and sectors where we have a competitive advantage.
3i will also continue to pursue its strategy of investing in its business and reputation.
The multi-business line structure that we now operate is designed to provide higher quality and more stable earnings for our investors.
3i is facing the future with confidence.
And I hope our new framework for returns clarifies our business and provides a yardstick for future performance.
Before we turn to Q&A, let me pick up on the key messages that I hope you take from this meeting.
Firstly, we're seeing very good underlying performance of our business lines.
We've taken one notable hit to performance this year in our private equity business.
But this aside, all 3 business lines are performing in line with our long term return objectives.
We've also made good strategic and operational progress.
The creation of 3i Debt Management will not only diversify returns for our investors, but will also provide greater yield and more stable earnings.
In addition, the operational review of our asset management techniques will ensure that we're managing our portfolio optimally and have learned from the challenges of recent years.

To provide greater insight into our businesses, we'll be holding an Investor Day on the 23rd of June, where all our senior business line leaders will be presenting an in-depth review of their businesses and key assets.
We've continued to be highly selective, with respect to new investment.
However, we're well positioned to take advantage of the good quality investment opportunities that are emerging, given that we're well funded and with a strong balance sheet.
Growth from here will be from a solid, financial base, and we'll be well controlled to ensure that we maintain our financial discipline.
Finally, I've introduce to you a model for returns that I intend to use to guide our performance and against which all new business opportunities will be assessed.
This will help to ensure that we're delivering increasing value for our shareholders and the investors in our funds.
We'll be now very happy to take questions.
I think, I mean, going forward, we are planning to, as Julia said very clearly, adopt a very conservative funding strategy.
We have a net debt limit at the moment of 1 billion, which clearly has the net asset value growth.
That becomes an even more and more conservative limit.
And obviously, we're nowhere near that as of the 31st of March.
And as you quite rightly point out, the additional realizations that have come in already in the last 6 weeks mean that we're actually -- that net debt figure has come down even further.
We're not assuming that we get any benefit from leverage in the target that we're setting.
So we have not set these targets on the basis of let's increase leverage as a helping hand.
We have leverage in the business and we run cash balances really to give us the flexibility to have capital available to deploy at a moment's notice.
That's what we're focused on around our balance sheet management as opposed to having structural leverage that will enhance our returns.
It's Bruce Hamilton, Morgan Stanley.
Just 2 quick questions please.
Firstly, on the earnings growth, obviously, you've had 18 months of pretty solid earnings growth probably along -- above longer-term averages.

How -- is there still sort of an embedded catch-up there, or should we assume that things probably kind of normalize from here? And then secondly, in terms of your most recent sort of buyout fund, can you remind us how much is invested, so when we might expect you to come back and raise another fund, and where you're currently marked in terms of multiple of invested capital and in terms of IRR? I mean, we're seeing -- I mean, the private equity, the secondary private equity market, I think, is certainly a -- likely to be a major part of all private equity activity over the next 4 or 5 years and certainly in the last year, we've seen it.
So what we actually saw was about half of the transactions that we were involved in were secondary transactions.
That's more predominant in -- half of the European transactions, sorry.
In India, clearly, it's a very different market, and there are no secondary transactions in that market.
It was the other area where we did quite a few transactions.

But if we look forward and we look at the number of companies across Europe that are now owned by private equity firms, it's about 2,000 companies, and all of those companies have to be sold in the next 4 or 5 years.
So in terms of the proportion of M&A activity, the private equity sales will contribute, it's going to be growing compared to what we've seen historically.
So I think everybody is likely to see more secondary activity than you've seen historically.
Where that trend will end, it's hard to say.
What's important about secondary transactions though, is you've got to be very clear about what you're going to do with that business.
So the assets that we've acquired, we have a very clear value strategy on how the 3i model will move that business on and generate additional returns.
What we're not looking to do is buy from somebody who operates a similar model to us because they've probably done all of the things that we were going to do.
So we've got to have a clear value creation strategy in place.
Taking your first question about earnings growth, yes, clearly we've seen some extremely strong earnings growth in this period, and we do expect to see strong earnings growth continue.
In terms of the catch-up that we've talked about previously, I think you should assume that most of that has now normalized.
I think the thing that you should focus on thinking about next year is clearly we've done 6 new investments in the Private Equity business.
Some of these, we've had for a very short period of time, the early -- the indications of those businesses is that they are strong and that they are good investments.
So whilst we are continuing to realize companies that are delivering strong earnings growth, we are replacing those with good investments as well.
I think the targets, the sort of broad working metrics that we're using are not so much targeting an amount that we will have in each area, but more of the funding balance.
And we really want to test what the growth opportunities in each area and we're very ambitious for each of the areas and all of them can grow.
But the funding balance, I said, at least 50/50 in Private Equity.
In Infrastructure, the broad metric that we're looking at is 25% on balance sheet; 75%, third-party funds.
And in Debt Management, we'd expect about 10% on balance sheet; 90%, third-party funds.
So those are broad working metrics that we're operating with.
Well, thank you all very much for coming.
Julia and I are available for the rest of the day, and indeed, over the next few weeks.
We're going to be talking to many of our shareholders.
So we'd be very happy to take any further questions outside this session.
But thank you very much for coming today.
In terms of the existing funds that we've acquired, we expect that we will be able to achieve those return targets.
But the purpose of establishing the Debt Management business is not to simply stay with the funds that we've got at the moment.
There are opportunities for further consolidation of the sector, and there are certainly very attractive opportunities over the next 2 to 5 years in terms of launching new funds.

And the reason those opportunities exist is because the banks will struggle to fund all of the corporate debt requirement both in North America and in Europe over the next 5 years because of the regulatory capital rules that have been brought in.
And the bank's exposure to some of the southern European sovereign markets will further exacerbate that position.
So Debt Management is an area that we feel very excited about and we think there are very, very strong growth prospects.
So the model is not based on sitting with what we've got at the moment.
It is about growing the business further.
Well, let me try and answer all of those questions.
I mean, in terms of the large U.
asset, of which there's clearly a lot more detail in the statements that we released today, to address your specific point, the underlying performance of that asset, it is a robust business.
It's a business with over 1 billion turnover with over a 16 million operating profit, and its got an order book of over 5 billion.
So on an operational level, the business is performing well.
But it's a business that serves the U.
public sector.
And therefore, it's faced the headwinds of U.
public sector cuts.
And as a result of what we see as the lower growth trajectory of that business, we've used a lower earnings multiple to value it.

So that, combined with flat or slightly decreasing earnings, together with a very highly leveraged structure that was put in place at the time of our own original investment, means that the write-down that we're talking about is, as you put it, Andrew, a mathematical result of our valuation policy.
And we've taken that asset down to zero.
We're working very hard with the company.
We've changed the Chairman and the Chief Executive.
We've reorganized the business to face the new market conditions.
So is it possible that the value of that business will come back in due course? The answer to that is, we would hope to see some value recovery and we're certainly working towards that.

In terms of your second question, around the share of rewards between employees of a financial business and the shareholders of the financial business, I think actually 3i has managed over the years to strike quite a good balance and that our teams recognize they benefit from the brand, the permanent capital, our market reach, to be able to access great investment opportunities whether in any of our business lines.
And therefore, the sharing of rewards between the employees and the shareholders, I think, is in a form that is unlikely to be shifted dramatically.
And we're certainly not seeing the pressure that you talk about for a particular move in that direction.
In terms of the share price right now compared to the NAV, I mean, again, mathematically, you're absolutely right.
You were absolutely right on the figure.
And I'm sure you hear lots of chief executives who bemoan where their share price is.
There aren't that many FTSE100 chief executives whose share price is trading at a 17% discount to hard assets.
So I think my grievance around might be slightly more credible.

I think though the critical thing for us is one, deliver on the return on equity targets; and two, actually use the framework I've described today to help more people understand 3i, what our business model is and how we're going to deliver returns.
And I think if we get that right, I think the share price will take care of itself.
So what we're focused on as a management team is delivering those return on equity objectives.
And right now, we are seeing plenty of opportunities to deploy capital at the kind of returns I talked about.
And I think that will be in the longer-term interest of shareholders rather than actually reducing the size of the overall business through buybacks.
Iain, in terms of your Growth Capital question, I think -- I mean, I think it's a very good point.
And what we have seen, particularly in Europe, is growth-orientated businesses have been relatively reluctant to actually press the button on expansion.
I mean, there's been a lot of debt aversion and a lot of aversion to actually taking new steps forward.
What we have seen though, in the last 3 to 4 months is that attitude changing.
And already in the new financial year, we've actually completed another 2 Growth Capital transactions: One in the U.
, in GO Outdoors, which is a U.

retail concept, which we're very excited about and we think has got every chance of being a real category killer; and also we've invested in a French-based international freight forwarding and management business.
And the pipeline for Growth Capital investments is actually the strongest it's been for a number of years.
So I think it was around reticence to commit to growth by businesses, but that now seems to be fading, and we are seeing some very good opportunities.

And the second question, just on Debt Management, to what extent is that business able to meet your return targets, assuming the status quo? Or do your targets require on further fundraisings? Can I just ask quickly, in terms of your 3 business areas, so Private Equity, Infrastructure and Debt Management, do you have target allocations? Or in the future, could that change significantly in terms of proportion of portfolio invested in those areas by reference to what it is now? Sure.
I mean, one of the things we said in our preclose statement was that we were seeing a combination of different trading performances by geography and then there were some asset-specific issues.
Within the U.
, we've seen softer trading in a number of our businesses, and that's fully reflected in the results today.
The businesses that have been suffering the most have been -- have tended to be ones that are domestically focused.
We've got other businesses in the U.

We've got a great business based in Yorkshire, an engineering business called AES, which has had a record turnover, record profits, because it's an engineering business, where it's exporting to India, China and the growing markets around the world.
So that's a common thing that we see, where our businesses have got a high export content to developing markets that are performing very, very well.
And that's why we've seen strong business performance in the Benelux, in Nordic and in Germany, where many of the businesses that were invested have that profile.
So it's that -- the balance between domestic sales and exporting, which is probably the biggest single factor.
Well, I mean, we've had -- received 325 million of additional realization so far.
So you're not 1 million miles out if you say it was about 253 million at the moment.
Well, if there's no more -- oh, there are some more questions.
Just picking up your first question about uplifts to sale, yes, you're right.
I mean, the 3 principal transactions in there are Hyva, MWM and the NORMA IPO.
Hyva and NORMA completed in April.
And as I said, it was -- at the beginning of my presentation, that's actually now delivered 255 million of proceeds.
MWM is still going through a competition clearance.
Philip, I think, estimating the demand and supply of capital is always going to be more of an art rather than a science.
So I mean, our view is that at the margin, it is going to get better.

One of the things I didn't talk about though, was what corporate behavior will be because corporates have got more cash than they've ever had at any point, and I've been surprised at how little M&A activities being driven through corporates.
So you got all of that to factor in as well.
What we're focused in on though, are those sectors and geographies where we believe we have real insights into individual businesses.
And if you look at some of the deals that we've done in the last 12 months, they're very, very good examples of this.

So Vedici, the chain of private hospitals that we bought in France, is a very good example, because we previously owned a similar chain in the Nordic region called Ambea, where over a number of years, we basically acquired a series of similar businesses and integrated them, improved the trading performance of all these businesses and saw a very substantial uplift in value.

So in Vedici, our plan is having acquired a great platform to grow that business through a combination of improved operating performance, but also acquiring smaller, local businesses that we can add into it.
And you'll see some of our investment goes into supporting acquisitive growth.
It's a very common part of our investment thesis now.
Another business that we invested in last year for the first time was a business called  Refresco, a fruit juice business.
They've made a major acquisition using capital from 3i over the last 12 months and will continue to do so.
Another business that we've talked about before Labco, a laboratories business in France.
They've made about 25 acquisitions over the last couple of years as we consolidate that highly fragmented sector.

So a combination of sector insight, helping businesses internationalize, move into Asian markets, improving their operating performance and identifying platforms for growth that we can then make acquisitions through a part of our investment thesis.
So Private Equity is no longer about hoping for multiple arbitrage, leveraging something up and then selling a few years later at a higher price.
There's a lot of hard work that goes into improving the performance of these businesses.
Well, good morning, everyone.
Today, we're going to set out the results of the Group and how each of our businesses are performing.
I want to use this results presentation to explain how our strategy is developing and give you a financial framework to assess both these results and our future performance updates.

After this brief introduction, Julia will provide a detailed financial review, and then I'll set out the market background and give you more detail on our strategy and financial objectives for the future.
These are the key messages that run through these results.
The underlying performance of each business line is positive, and we've come a very long way in 2 years.
Strategically, the acquisition of MIM to form a Debt Management business line is an important step forward on our growth agenda.
3i Debt Management will provide yield and lower volatility earnings.
We've also reviewed our approach to investment in asset management.
We've improved where necessary, for example, in bringing together our buyout and growth capital businesses, so that they might operate more effectively in the market.
And I'm pleased that the benefits of this move are already showing through in an increase in investment activity.
This year, we've completed 10 high-quality transactions across our network, investing 1.
5 billion in total.
The final message reflects our commitment to manage 3i, with both strong liquidity and low leverage.
And you'll see that we're continuing to bring down absolute levels of borrowing.
Before handing over to Julia, I want to summarize the progress we've made over the past 2 years.

Firstly, the financial security of the company needed to be reestablished, and the steps that we took in early 2009 to restructure and de-risk the balance sheet helped us to achieve this sooner than expected.
Secondly, we needed to protect the value in the portfolio, and then ensure businesses were achieving their full potential.
Thirdly, we've made important management and cultural changes to create a winning model.
And finally, we're now moving back to a growth agenda.
So let me now turn to this year's financial highlights.
Julia's going to take you through these numbers in more detail, but let me focus on 2 aspects of these results.
Total return of 10.
6% or 324 million was achieved despite an impairment in value of 198 million, in respect of a large U.
asset, which is now valued at zero.
While this write-down is disappointing, the overall results highlight the resilience of the business.
And this performance was underpinned by portfolio earnings growth of 13% and good uplifts on the sale of assets at 26%.
And it's this underlying strength that gives us confidence to recommend an increase of 20% in the dividend.
I'm now going to hand over to Julia, who will take us through the detail behind these numbers.
But when I come back, I'll set out a very important series of ways in which we're challenging ourselves to deliver returns.
It's Monica Tepes at Westhouse Securities.
Looking across the portfolio earnings, if you were to put a profile on it, say, for example, the percentage of earnings that are economically sensitive or the percentage earnings that come from a U.
domestic or other Europe domestic or emerging market demand, just to give an idea of where the sensitivities are.
Taking your first question about earnings growth, yes, clearly we've seen some extremely strong earnings growth in this period, and we do expect to see strong earnings growth continue.
In terms of the catch-up that we've talked about previously, I think you should assume that most of that has now normalized.
I think the thing that you should focus on thinking about next year is clearly we've done 6 new investments in the Private Equity business.
Some of these, we've had for a very short period of time, the early -- the indications of those businesses is that they are strong and that they are good investments.
So whilst we are continuing to realize companies that are delivering strong earnings growth, we are replacing those with good investments as well.

What would the pro forma net debt position be if those 3 assets are included then? I think it's also fair to say, I mean, one of the things we've done around our valuation approach this year is we drew -- when we use last 12 months as a valuation metric, which we're doing in most of the portfolio, we stopped the last 12 months at the 31st of December.
And so in a sense, in previous years, what we've done is we've allowed that to run up to the accounting year-end date.
What we do have though, is very good visibility on that quarter's earnings.
And we can see that those earnings are continuing to grow.
So we've taken a slightly more conservative approach to the earnings that we use in the valuation.
We've got good visibility on earnings growth throughout this year.
So one of the reasons why we are standing up in a very confident way about the portfolio is that we do have that visibility on earnings already flowing through.
In terms of Eurofund V, the investment period for Eurofund V comes to an end in November 2011.
So later on this year.
What that means in practice is that any work in progress that we're working on at November '11 will continue to be invested.
So in reality, it means that the investment will actually stop in that fund probably around February 2012.
So that's over the course of this year.
We will be talking to our LP [Limited Partner] investors about what the next iteration of the fund will look like.
But you will remember from what we said at the half year is that the next fund that we raise in Europe will be a combined buyout and Growth Capital Fund.
And of course, our current Growth Capital Fund doesn't finish its investment period until the end of 2012.
So what we've got to work up is a combined model for that business, and we're giving -- be giving you much more detail around that when we stand up and give our interim results.
In terms of where that fund is marked at the moment, when you get the report and accounts, it was probably in all the disclosures we gave today.
There was a table showing for all of our funds and what the multiples are.
And the multiple on that -- on Eurofund V at the moment is standing at north 0.
I can't remember offhand, I'm sorry, Bruce, what the exact IRR on that is.
But you'd be able to see in that table where all of our funds are performing.
We're giving more disclosure on that this year.
Well, if there's no more -- oh, there are some more questions.
Chris Brown from JPMorgan Cazenove.

It's Philip Middleton from Merrill's.
I'll have to learn to sit near the front in future.
I just wondered on the buyout business, I can see that burning off dry powder argument to a degree.
But on the other hand, best-of-breed competitors are raising funds now, so there's not going to be an extreme change in market conditions.

So how much are you relying on pricing changing in that market? And what else are you doing to try and enable you to generate returns in that business going forward in terms of adding value to your companies and improving your marketing, all those issues? I mean, we're seeing -- I mean, the private equity, the secondary private equity market, I think, is certainly a -- likely to be a major part of all private equity activity over the next 4 or 5 years and certainly in the last year, we've seen it.
So what we actually saw was about half of the transactions that we were involved in were secondary transactions.
That's more predominant in -- half of the European transactions, sorry.
In India, clearly, it's a very different market, and there are no secondary transactions in that market.
It was the other area where we did quite a few transactions.

But if we look forward and we look at the number of companies across Europe that are now owned by private equity firms, it's about 2,000 companies, and all of those companies have to be sold in the next 4 or 5 years.
So in terms of the proportion of M&A activity, the private equity sales will contribute, it's going to be growing compared to what we've seen historically.
So I think everybody is likely to see more secondary activity than you've seen historically.
Where that trend will end, it's hard to say.
What's important about secondary transactions though, is you've got to be very clear about what you're going to do with that business.
So the assets that we've acquired, we have a very clear value strategy on how the 3i model will move that business on and generate additional returns.
What we're not looking to do is buy from somebody who operates a similar model to us because they've probably done all of the things that we were going to do.
So we've got to have a clear value creation strategy in place.
It's Bruce Hamilton, Morgan Stanley.
Just 2 quick questions please.
Firstly, on the earnings growth, obviously, you've had 18 months of pretty solid earnings growth probably along -- above longer-term averages.

How -- is there still sort of an embedded catch-up there, or should we assume that things probably kind of normalize from here? And then secondly, in terms of your most recent sort of buyout fund, can you remind us how much is invested, so when we might expect you to come back and raise another fund, and where you're currently marked in terms of multiple of invested capital and in terms of IRR? Well, thank you, Michael, and good morning, everyone.
I'd now like to take you through our results for the period to the 31st of March 2011.
Let me begin with the financial highlights in some more detail.
Michael said at the outset, we closed the year with a total return of 324 million, a return on opening shareholders funds of 10.
This translates into an increase of 30p in net asset value from 321p to 351p per share.
1% gross portfolio return was driven by strong earnings growth and a good level of realized profits, combined with uplifts to imminent sales.
We continue to take advantage of open markets for realizations, generating uplifts of 26% over opening valuations.
And we've also seen a 14% increase in fee income over the period.
There was a significant increase in assets under management.
This is mainly due to the growth of our Debt Management business, following the acquisition of Mizuho's European debt business.
And this adds some 3.
4 billion to our assets under management.
Investments of 719 million is significantly ahead of last year's historically low levels.
And although realizations are considerably lower at 609 million than last year, this figure does not include the sale of Hyva and the IPO of NORMA.
Together, these transactions delivered a further 255 million to the Group in April, an evidence of our success in our portfolio.
The net effect of this investment activity means we finished the year with strong liquidity of 1.
8 billion and net debt of 522 million.
We remain positive about the outlook for 3i and the strength of our business, our portfolio and our brand.
Reinforcing this, we declared a dividend of 2.
4p, a total increase of 20% in the year.
Turning then to returns, and just to remind you how our returns are made up.
Gross portfolio return shows the returns from those assets in which 3i invests directly.
And I'll come on to talk in more detail about how each of our business lines have performed this year.
In total, the Group generated a gross portfolio return of 601 million or 17.
1% return on opening portfolio value.
Net portfolio return includes the benefits of our asset management business, so it includes the fees and the carry that we generate through managing investments on behalf of others.
The increase in fees in the year primarily reflects the first full year of the growth capital fund.
Net portfolio return also includes the costs of running our investment in asset management businesses.
Those operating expenses continued to fall in the year, despite adding the costs of the new Debt Management team.
Finally, to get the total return, we take account of the costs of our own balance sheet funding and other factors, such as the pension and foreign exchange.
As I indicated in November, interest cost has been higher in the year as we reshaped the maturity profile of our debt in line with our conservative balance sheet approach.
In particular, the 127 million net interest cost reflects our decision to issue a 7-year bond in March 2010.
This is to take advantage of a market opportunity, but it was somewhat ahead of the convertible bond maturity that we have this month.
We have mitigated this overlap by buying in the convertible bond throughout the year where it was available.
We've now extended our balance sheet hedging policy to include foreign currency swaps, as well as core currency borrowing.
At the year end, we'd hedged 68% of our euro portfolio and 46% of our dollar portfolio.
The unhedged element to the portfolio resulted in a net exchange movement of 17 million.
Finally, the accounting valuation of our U.
-defined benefits pension scheme resulted in an actuarial gain of 20 million.
We're in discussion with the trustees of this scheme, regarding its latest triennial valuation.
Now that the scheme has closed to new members and to future accrual for existing members, we're taking further steps to de-risk the scheme to reduce the effects of the scheme on our returns.
Taking all of these aspects into account, we've closed the year with a total return of 10.
6% or 324 million.
This translates to an NAV of 351p, an increase of 30p since March 2010.
Looking at those components of return in terms of NAV progression, this slide shows you how we've increased NAV from 321p at the start of the year to 351p at the end.
Gross portfolio return from our direct investments contributed 63p.
The net effect of the benefits of Asset Management, offset by the cost of running the business, reduced NAV by 16p, and the cost of the balance sheet, a further 13p.
Dividends paid to shareholders, which of course here do not include the dividend we've announced today, amount to 3p, all in all resulting in an NAV of 351p at the end of the year.
So let me now take you through the components of the gross portfolio return in more detail.
This slide shows you the composition of our gross portfolio return and the contributions made by each business line.
As we'd expect, given the nature and the relative size of its direct portfolio, the most significant contributor is our private equity business.
This generated a return of 16% or 462 million.
Realizations are lower, as I've already mentioned, but we're at good uplifts of 20%.

Unrealized returns of 277 million were driven by good earnings performance across much of the portfolio, although these were partially offset by significant impairments and a fall in multiples used to value this portfolio.
I'll come on to talk about this unrealized value growth in some more detail in the next few slides.

Portfolio income of 123 million in our private equity business and in buyouts, in particular, principally comprises the capitalized interest, and so does not generate cash yield until the underlying investment is sold.
That said, a number of our growth capital investments have paid dividends in the year.
Turning then to our infrastructure business.

The gross portfolio return of 45 million or 11% from our infrastructure business reflects the quoted movement in our 33% holding in 3i Infrastructure plc and value movements on investments held through 3i India Infrastructure Fund.
As Cressida Hogg reported last week, the underlying performance of the infrastructure portfolio is robust, with good new investments in the year.
In our infrastructure business, we also benefit from dividend income from 3i Infrastructure plc of 16 million.
Finally, our Debt Management business.
Before I comment on its returns for this year, let me just remind you what this business line is now made up of.
Our approach to strategic development is to build from our strengths and our expertise.
We have had a well-established banking team within our private equity business for a number of years.
That team has been instrumental in managing our banking relationships through the period from 2007 to today.
In 2007, that team set up a debt warehouse investing in European mid-market credit.
In other words, in the type of businesses we were very familiar with.
As our knowledge developed, we looked for opportunities to expand this platform.
Our acquisition of Mizuho's European debt business brought a team of 28 people, led by Jeremy Ghose and has significantly enhanced our capacity for growth.
We now manage 8 funds and are looking for further opportunities to build on our expertise.
At the same time, we've taken advantage of market conditions to unwind substantially the original debt warehouse.

This disposal generated proceeds of 145 million, realized profits of 24 million and an uplift of 20%, which you can see here is the most significant aspect of Debt Management's gross portfolio return this year.
With the European acquisition only completed in February, its effect on the results this year is actually minimal.
I'd now like to take you through our valuations for the year in more detail and how that 325 million of total unrealized value growth arises.
Strong earnings growth in the portfolio is reflected in the earnings growth movement of 295 million and in the uplift to imminent sale of 240 million, a total contribution of 535 million.
This highlights the strong underlying performance of much of the portfolio, a trend which has been consistent throughout the year.
In particular, we have seen some excellent performance in our Northern European portfolio, and those companies which are expanding their businesses to take advantage of Asian growth.
Also consistent with the half year, we've continued to see a reduction in multiples used to value the portfolio.
And this resulted in a negative value movement of 76 million.
Clearly, a disappointing aspect of this year's performance is the 196 million impairment compared to last year's reversal of 47 million.
The impairment includes a significant movement of 198 million in respect of a single U.
We have taken a more cautious view on its earnings, and as a result, made a significant revision to the comparable multiples set.
It is a combination of these factors that has given rise to the impairment, which has taken the value of the asset to nil.
Our change in view is attributable to both sector and to company-specific factors.
It does not reflect the view that affects the broader portfolio where we continue to see good underlying performance.
Provisions of 71 million account for about 2% of opening portfolio value.
And they relate to 7 assets in a variety of sectors and geographies.
Together, they do not show a particular concentration risk.
Positively, it includes a reversal of 18 million in relation to an additional asset, which is showing signs of good earnings recovery after significant intervention on our part.
This company now moves back to an earnings basis evaluation.

The positive contribution of 54 million from those assets valued on a DCF basis relates to the investments made through our Indian Infrastructure Fund and to a small number of private equity businesses.

Finally, although the total unrealized value movements is lower in absolute terms than last year, the contribution of strong earnings growth in the portfolio and uplift to imminent sale is much more significant and is an indicator of our confidence in the underlying performance of the portfolio.
Picking up on this point in more detail, you can see from this slide how the earnings growth and multiple movements have trended in the last 2 years.
These numbers relate to those companies that are valued on an earnings basis at the beginning and at the end of the year.
As I've already said, we continue to see strong earnings growth in much of our portfolio, notwithstanding some impairments.
Earnings growth of 13% contributed 295 million to returns compared to a decline of 8% in the prior year.
That growth has also continued consistently throughout the year.
Around 3 quarters of this portfolio contributes a positive earnings growth during the year, and more than 40% of the portfolio showed earnings growth of more than 20%.
And of course, we're working very hard with the companies that showed earnings decreases to get them back on plan.
Much of this portfolio, 84% of it, has been valued using the management accounts to the 31st of December 2010.
However, we also review the latest management accounts available, and if they or the current year forecasts indicate a downturn in performance, we take that into account in our valuation.
This year, 12% of companies were in this category, which is stable compared to last year and is a marked improvement on 2009 where 39% of the portfolio was valued on a current year forecast basis.
Turning to multiples.
Equity markets remain volatile in the 12-month period to the 31st of March 2011.
Overall, we've seen a 7% decline in the multiples used to value the majority of the portfolio.
The multiples we choose are based on comparable sets of multiples for each company.
We consider factors such as geography, sector, size and earnings performance.
We also compare the end result, in this case the 7% fall, to the equivalent indices in the sectors and the geographies in which we invest.
And those indices showed very similar movements in the year.
The weighted average multiples used to value the portfolio fell to 8.
8 before discount compared to 9.
5 in March 2010.
As a result of this reduction, value growth decreased by 76 million.

So as we start the half year, those elements of the valuation, which directly reflect the performance of the investments, have remained strong in the second half, and notwithstanding a small number of asset-specific reductions.
The unrealized value growth on our portfolio is obviously a key driver of our returns and also of a balance sheet portfolio value.
This slide shows you the progression of the portfolio value during the year.
The opening portfolio was 3.
This increased by 719 million of investments and the positive contribution from the revaluation of 325 million.
After taking account of divestments and other movements, the closing portfolio value was 4 billion at the 31st of March 2011.
Let me just spend a few minutes elaborating on that 719 million of investment in the year.

This is a significant increase, following a period of low activity levels, and is consistent with the recovery in activity levels seen in the European private equity market, which Michael will talk in more detail about shortly.
We have maintained a highly selective approach to new investment, looking for investments where we believed our sector expertise and our international network could make a difference.
However, the competitive environment remains, which has meant a number of transactions have had a very long lead time.
You can see from this slide, we invested 270 million in private equity.
This is in 6 new deals, most of which were under our Eurofund V mandates.

We also invested in 3 new deals in our Indian Infrastructure Fund, and I would encourage you to look at the results in the presentation given by Cressida and the infrastructure team last week, which gives you plenty of detail on the progress being made there.
In addition to making new investments, we've continued to support our existing portfolio, providing 80 million of capital to fund new acquisitions and capital expenditure.
As we announced at the half year, we also invested 110 million in buying debt at a discount at existing businesses.
And the cost of equity cures and capital restructurings were low at 16 million.
Capitalized interest of 158 million relates largely to the buyout portfolio.
So what effect has that and the realizations had on the makeup of our portfolio? This slide sets out the portfolio by business, geography, sector and vintage.
And it's helpful in understanding the shape of our business today.
I'm not going to spend any time going through this in detail, but it is clear from the analysis that the portfolio remains well diversified.
I'd now like to turn to the rest of the balance sheet.
We've continued to adopt a conservative approach to our balance sheet management and remain committed to our limit on net debt of 1 billion.
We've also continued to make progress in reducing our gross debt.
This has fallen significantly in the period from 2.
5 billion to 2 billion, as we have bought in the convertible bond, bought back some of our 2012 maturities and took a positive decision not to refinance other debt, which has fallen due in the year.
There was an increase in net debt and gearing as a result of net cash outflow in the period.
However, net debt of 522 million is comfortably within our 1 billion limit.

The Group's liquidity position remains very strong 
at 1.
8 billion, meaning we're well placed to take advantage of investment and strategic opportunities as they arise.
The macroeconomic environment is still uncertain.
Whilst this prevails, our strategy is to continue to manage the balance sheet on a conservative basis.
We recognize that this has a negative effect on our returns in the short term.
We continually look for opportunities to mitigate this while maintaining flexibility for funding.
As Michael will explain shortly, it is very much our intention to deploy capital wisely, and in a way, that is consistent with our model for returns.
Thus in summary, we have continued to diversify the business across 3 core businesses and there has been an increase in activity across all of them.
Notwithstanding a small number of asset-specific write-downs, there has been good underlying performance in the portfolio, with stronger earnings performance across many of our portfolio companies.
And the business is very well funded, with strong liquidity to take advantage of new investment opportunities to support future growth.
So thank you, and I will now hand back to Michael.
The best way of looking at that is if you remember the chart that Julia showed with all the different pie charts on, as Julia said, she wasn't going to go into detail in that.
But if you actually look at that chart, it gives you a very, very good overview of where the sectoral concentrations are, where the geographic concentrations are.
And I think one of the reasons why we want to draw people's attention to that is we believe we've got a very, very diversified portfolio.
And what you are seeing now is that as we expand our activities on a global basis, what used to be a historic point of concentration being the U.
is now becoming much less a part of our asset base.
We'll continue to invest in the U.
and we've done some great deals here, as I mentioned, GO Outdoors.
But there isn't any particular area of concentration that I would mention.
But have a look at that chart, and if that doesn't answer your question, then give us a call.
