This year, we've completed 10 high-quality transactions across our network, investing 1.
5 billion in total.
The final message reflects our commitment to manage 3i, with both strong liquidity and low leverage.
And you'll see that we're continuing to bring down absolute levels of borrowing.
Before handing over to Julia, I want to summarize the progress we've made over the past 2 years.

Firstly, the financial security of the company needed to be reestablished, and the steps that we took in early 2009 to restructure and de-risk the balance sheet helped us to achieve this sooner than expected.
Secondly, we needed to protect value in the portfolio, and then ensure businesses were achieving their full potential.
Thirdly, we've made important management and cultural changes to create a winning model.
And finally, we're now moving back to a growth agenda.
So let me now turn to this year's financial highlights.
Julia's going to take you through these numbers in more detail, but let me focus on 2 aspects of these results.
Total return of 10.
6% or 324 million was achieved despite an impairment in value of 198 million, in respect of a large U.
asset, which is now valued at zero.
While this write-down is disappointing, the overall results highlight the resilience of the business.
And this performance was underpinned by portfolio earnings growth of 13% and good uplifts on the sale of assets at 26%.
And it's this underlying strength that gives us confidence to recommend an increase of 20% in the dividend.
I'm now going to hand over to Julia, who will take us through the detail behind these numbers.
But when I come back, I'll set out a very important series of ways in which we're challenging ourselves to deliver returns.
Daniel Garrod from Barclays Capital here.
A couple of quick questions, if I may.
I was wondering if you could give some color on those targets, the Group ROE target of 15% around the sort of the leverage that you intend to employ for the Group.

In particular, currently, I wonder if you could outline sort of 520 million net debt position, but if you included the proceeds that you've outlined from Hyva and NORMA, and perhaps if you could also include MWM, as well that you may get later in the year, what the pro forma net debt position.
I imagine, it would look much closer to sort of zero.

Is that ROE target achievable with that sort of virtually zero net debt position? Or does it require you pushing much closer to your sort of ceiling of 1 billion? Can I just ask quickly, in terms of your 3 business areas, so Private Equity, Infrastructure and Debt Management, do you have target allocations? Or in the future, could that change significantly in terms of proportion of portfolio invested in those areas by reference to what it is now? In terms of the existing funds that we've acquired, we expect that we will be able to achieve those return targets.
But the purpose of establishing the Debt Management business is not to simply stay with the funds that we've got at the moment.
There are opportunities for further consolidation of the sector, and there are certainly very attractive opportunities over the next 2 to 5 years in terms of launching new funds.

And the reason those opportunities exist is because the banks will struggle to fund all of the corporate debt requirement both in North America and in Europe over the next 5 years because of the regulatory capital rules that have been brought in.
And the bank's exposure to some of the southern European sovereign markets will further exacerbate that position.
So Debt Management is an area that we feel very excited about and we think there are very, very strong growth prospects.
So the model is not based on sitting with what we've got at the moment.
It is about growing the business further.
And do you anticipate being much closer to the 1 billion by the end of next year? Is there going to be a significant step-up? Nathan Archer here from Nomura.
For your U.
portfolio, you've obviously taken the one and specific company hit.
Can you just comment onto the read across in terms of your other investment in the U.
, please? Iain, in terms of your Growth Capital question, I think -- I mean, I think it's a very good point.
And what we have seen, particularly in Europe, is growth-orientated businesses have been relatively reluctant to actually press the button on expansion.
I mean, there's been a lot of debt aversion and a lot of aversion to actually taking new steps forward.
What we have seen though, in the last 3 to 4 months is that attitude changing.
And already in the new financial year, we've actually completed another 2 Growth Capital transactions: One in the U.
, in GO Outdoors, which is a U.

retail concept, which we're very excited about and we think has got every chance of being a real category killer; and also we've invested in a French-based international freight forwarding and management business.
And the pipeline for Growth Capital investments is actually the strongest it's been for a number of years.
So I think it was around reticence to commit to growth by businesses, but that now seems to be fading, and we are seeing some very good opportunities.
It's Andrew Bell from Witan Investment Trust.
I've got 3 questions.
The first is with the significant U.

write-down, does it reflect a distressed business or simply is it a mathematical result of applying the right multiple to the business, and that just leaves nothing for the equity at the moment, but it might recover? The second is, other people who manage external funds have found that there's pressure from the fund holders to concentrate the returns on the people working for their funds, so that they're not disadvantaged.

And how are you going to make sure that the benefit, which is part -- an integral part of the returns from the lower return asset categories -- how do you ensure that you capture those benefits for 3i rather than they're being hypothecated as it were towards the people who are focused on those funds? And the third is, this admirable portfolio you've talked to us about, even after today's share price rise, is now still available on about a 17% or 18% discount.
And it'd be helpful if you could give a bit of color on your policy on the share buybacks.
I mean, one of the things we said in our preclose statement was that we were seeing a combination of different trading performances by geography and then there were some asset-specific issues.
Within the U.
, we've seen softer trading in a number of our businesses, and that's fully reflected in the results today.
The businesses that have been suffering the most have been -- have tended to be ones that are domestically focused.
We've got other businesses in the U.

We've got a great business based in Yorkshire, an engineering business called AES, which has had a record turnover, record profits, because it's an engineering business, where it's exporting to India, China and the growing markets around the world.
So that's a common thing that we see, where our businesses have got a high export content to developing markets that are performing very, very well.
And that's why we've seen strong business performance in the Benelux, in Nordic and in Germany, where many of the businesses that were invested have that profile.
So it's that -- the balance between domestic sales and exporting, which is probably the biggest single factor.
But clearly you're adding in one side of the equation.
What we're really looking to see in the next 6 months is further investments as well.
So you've got the numbers for the realization side of the equation.
Just picking up your first question about uplifts to sale, yes, you're right.
I mean, the 3 principal transactions in there are Hyva, MWM and the NORMA IPO.
Hyva and NORMA completed in April.
And as I said, it was -- at the beginning of my presentation, that's actually now delivered 255 million of proceeds.
MWM is still going through competition clearance.
Thanks, Julia.

In this next section, I want to give you some background on the market, remind you of our wider strategy and introduce a model for how we generate returns, before closing with a few comments on the outlook.
Let's look at our markets.
The private equity market continues to be impacted by excess capital that was raised in the peak years of 2006 to 2008, and hasn't yet been spent due to low investment over the past couple of years.

We are, however, seeing investment rates begin to pick up, driven by 2 factors: firstly, a return of confidence; and secondly, the pressure on funds to invest as they move towards the end of their investment periods.
The short-term impact of this has been increased competition, which is pushing asset prices up.
However, private equity fund raising remains at historically low levels.
Therefore, as investment increases and new fund raising remains low, I expect excess capital to be used up and the investment environment to improve.
As a permanent capital vehicle, 3i is well positioned to take advantage of this market dynamic.
Turning to the infrastructure market.
Pressures on public finances will increase deal flow as governments increasingly look to the private sector as a source of funding.
Such opportunities play to the strengths of 3i's brand, our reputation as a responsible investor and our ability to invest for the long term through 3i Infrastructure plc.
In India, economic development continues to drive a huge demand for India.
It's estimated that over the next 5 years, $1 trillion will be invested in the sector.
3i is already recognized as a market leader in Indian infrastructure investment, which positions us well to take advantage of new opportunities through our existing and follow-on funds.
With respect to Debt Management, we believe that the combined effect of Basel III [ph] and liquidity pressures in the banking sector will create attractive opportunities to invest.
These same factors are also likely to present further acquisition opportunities in both Europe and the U.
Let me remind you of the shape of 3i today.
We now have 3 businesses: Private Equity, Infrastructure and Debt.
Each business has its own return characteristics and is funded differently through a mix of 3i's own balance sheet and external funds.
Each is differentiated in their respective markets by the strength of 3i's brand.
They benefit from 3i's institutional model and the breadth of our international network.
Our permanent capital and strong balance sheet provide a competitive advantage and flexibility in how we manage our business.
And a major benefit from managing multiple asset classes is the different risk return profiles that they have.
By investing across all 3 business lines, we can improve the quality of overall returns.
This next chart shows the progress that the Group's made over the past 2 years.
We've added an additional 30p to our net asset value this year, giving an annualized return of 13% over the 2 years.
And I want to build on this progress as we move forward.
Over the past 2 years, we've developed a clear set of priorities to deliver future growth that's consistent with our return objectives.
These priorities form the basis for the strategy summarized on this slide.
By building on the 3i brand and growing our reputation as a respected and responsible investor, we will invest in 3i itself, our business lines and investment portfolios to deliver growth.
We must ensure that we maintain a consistent approach to the way that we do business to drive performance, build best practice and achieve our objective of delivering consistent returns.

As an experienced international investment company, managing multiple sources of capital across different asset classes, I believe that we're well positioned to deliver this strategy for our shareholders and investors.
And let me expand on 2 of these areas of strategy: investment and growth of the business.
Starting with investment, 3i and its funds have committed 1.
5 billion to 10 new companies over the year.
These include: Eversholt, the U.
train leasing company, Vedici, a private healthcare provider in France, and BVG, one of India's largest facilities management service providers.
And the one thing that all of these investments have in common is that they're in sectors and countries that we know well.
While our rates of investment has increased significantly on the previous year, we've ensured that we retain our measured and highly selective approach in what has remained a very competitive market.
The second aspect of our strategy that's been particularly relevant this year is our commitment to grow the business.

Our Debt Management acquisition in September, which completed in February, has added to our existing Debt Management capabilities and reinforced 3i's strategy of growing in areas consistent with our investment expertise.
Our new business line, 3i Debt Management, complements the existing private equity and infrastructure businesses, and provides a source of growing and lower volatility returns.

We've also recently announced the recruitment of an experienced team in Brazil, led by Marcelo Di Lorenzo, the team's established track record will give us access to opportunities in one of the world's fastest-growing regions.
What's more, the global nature of 3i's portfolio means that 20% of our companies already have an exposure to Latin America.
And having a team on the ground in that region will provide the support that these companies need to grow.
In Asia, we're looking to raise a second Indian Infrastructure Fund to build on the performance of the first fund.
And I hope this demonstrates the ambition that we have to grow our business.
We're actively pursuing further opportunities to complement our existing business and build on 3i's brand, reputation and expertise.
Let me now turn to our model for returns.
This is the framework that I'm using as a management tool to guide 3i's growth.
I want to spend a few moments on this next slide to explain the model.
3i now operates in 3 distinct asset classes across the risk/return spectrum: private equity, infrastructure and debt.
And although the gross returns of these investments vary, we've designed a funding structure, such that each business line contributes equally to our long term return objective of 15%.
This return objective is demanding.
And we're looking at it as an average over any given 5-year period.
For those business lines with lower gross return characteristics, namely infrastructure and debt, we have a higher proportion of third-party funds under management, and so receive higher fee income.
By their nature, these asset classes also benefit from more stable earnings, allowing us to deliver a greater consistency of returns.
Let me now show you in more detail how our current business lines fit with this model.
Let's firstly take Private Equity.
This is the business line that contributes the highest gross return to our portfolio to around 20%.
It's also the business line to which we commit the highest proportion of our own funds, at least a 50/50 split with external investors.
Overall, the net effect of costs, fees and carried interest gives us a long term net return objective of 15%.
Moving on to Infrastructure.
As a lower risk asset class, our gross return objective for Infrastructure is lower than Private Equity at 12%.
However, since 3i manages a higher proportion of third-party capital, we see a net benefit from fee income, which contributes to an overall net return objective of 15%.

And finally, turning to our new Debt Management business line, this has the highest proportion of external funds under management, and so shows the largest positive impact of external management and performance fees.
So again, a 15% return is achieved.
And so I hope you can now see how our 3 business lines work together to achieve our return objectives.
So for shareholders, our net return objective of 15% should translate into a return on equity, also of 15%.
And this is the model that I'm using to challenge each of our businesses to deliver over the long term.
Of course in each individual period, the results are likely to vary from these objectives.
But hopefully, this framework should help shareholders understand more clearly the progress that we're making.
This model also serves the dual purpose of being a tool to evaluate new areas of investment.
Any new business opportunities will be tested against this framework and will need to fit with our strategy, our return objectives and enhance the overall 3i business model.
And I wanted to look forward to the outlook for 3i.
In the near term, the global economic climate faces considerable uncertainty, but is likely to show overall growth.
However, the regional differences will be significant.
In this environment, we will continue to focus on stock selection, and we expect to increase investment.
However, this will be well controlled and focused on regions and sectors where we have a competitive advantage.
3i will also continue to pursue its strategy of investing in its business and reputation.
The multi-business line structure that we now operate is designed to provide higher quality and more stable earnings for our investors.
3i is facing the future with confidence.
And I hope our new framework for returns clarifies our business and provides a yardstick for future performance.
Before we turn to Q&A, let me pick up on the key messages that I hope you take from this meeting.
Firstly, we're seeing very good underlying performance of our business lines.
We've taken one notable hit to performance this year in our private equity business.
But this aside, all 3 business lines are performing in line with our long term return objectives.
We've also made good strategic and operational progress.
The creation of 3i Debt Management will not only diversify returns for our investors, but will also provide greater yield and more stable earnings.
In addition, the operational review of our asset management techniques will ensure that we're managing our portfolio optimally and have learned from the challenges of recent years.

To provide greater insight into our businesses, we'll be holding an Investor Day on the 23rd of June, where all our senior business line leaders will be presenting an in-depth review of their businesses and key assets.
We've continued to be highly selective with respect to new investment.
However, we're well positioned to take advantage of the good quality investment opportunities that are emerging, given that we're well funded and with a strong balance sheet.
Growth from here will be from a solid, financial base, and we'll be well controlled to ensure that we maintain our financial discipline.
Finally, I've introduce to you a model for returns that I intend to use to guide our performance and against which all new business opportunities will be assessed.
This will help to ensure that we're delivering increasing value for our shareholders and the investors in our funds.
We'll be now very happy to take questions.
And you'll see from our report and accounts, we actually quantified that in terms of our attribution analysis for those transactions that we've actually sold.
I think the targets, the sort of broad working metrics that we're using are not so much targeting an amount that we will have in each area, but more the funding balance.
And we really want to test what the growth opportunities in each area and we're very ambitious for each of the areas and all of them can grow.
But the funding balance, I said, at least 50/50 in Private Equity.
In Infrastructure, the broad metric that we're looking at is 25% on balance sheet; 75%, third-party funds.
And in Debt Management, we'd expect about 10% on balance sheet; 90%, third-party funds.
So those are broad working metrics that we're operating with.
Well, thank you all very much for coming.
Julia and I are available for the rest of the day, and indeed, over the next few weeks.
We're going to be talking to many of our shareholders.
So we'd be very happy to take any further questions outside this session.
But thank you very much for coming today.
Well, I mean, we've had -- received 325 million of additional realization so far.
So you're not 1 million miles out if you say it was about 253 million at the moment.
It really does depend on the opportunities.
I mean, what we have seen certainly in terms of what we're targeting around realizations, we've got off to a great start in, if you like, front-end loaded our budget on realizations.
That gives us great flexibility if we want to step up investments because we're seeing good opportunities to do so.
But certainly, as you saw from the increased investment during the last financial year, we are looking to see growing levels of investment compared to what we've seen historically.
So what we say is we will operate within that 1 billion net debt limit.
If we go up to it, because we've seen great investment opportunities, well, that's fine.
But equally, as you've seen in the last couple of years, we've operated well below that.
This is Iain Scouller from Oriel Securities.
I've got a couple.
Firstly, on the imminent sale gain number, I mean, that was particularly strong.
I was wondering if you could just give us a bit more color on that.
Presumably that includes things like the 60 million gain ahead of the NORMA IPO.
Then I was wondering if you could talk a bit about the investment rate within the Growth Capital business.
I'm just sort of perplexed, given how low that figure is.
I think it was around about 70 million for the year.
Well, let me try and answer all of those questions.
I mean, in terms of the large U.
asset, of which there's clearly a lot more detail in the statements that we released today, to address your specific point, the underlying performance of that asset, it is a robust business.
It's a business with over 1 billion turnover with over a 16 million operating profit, and its got an order book of over 5 billion.
So on an operational level, the business is performing well.
But it's a business that serves the U.
public sector.
And therefore, it's faced the headwinds of U.
public sector cuts.
And as a result of what we see as the lower growth trajectory of that business, we've used a lower earnings multiple to value it.

So that, combined with flat or slightly decreasing earnings, together with a very highly leveraged structure that was put in place at the time of our own original investment, means that the write-down that we're talking about is, as you put it, Andrew, a mathematical result of our valuation policy.
And we've taken that asset down to zero.
We're working very hard with the company.
We've changed the Chairman and the Chief Executive.
We've reorganized the business to face the new market conditions.
So is it possible that the value of that business will come back in due course? The answer to that is, we would hope to see some value recovery and we're certainly working towards that.

In terms of your second question, around the share of rewards between employees of a financial business and the shareholders of the financial business, I think actually 3i has managed over the years to strike quite a good balance in that our teams recognize they benefit from the brand, the permanent capital, our market reach, to be able to access great investment opportunities whether in any of our business lines.
And therefore, the sharing of rewards between the employees and the shareholders, I think, is in a form that is unlikely to be shifted dramatically.
And we're certainly not seeing the pressure that you talk about for a particular move in that direction.
In terms of the share price right now compared to the NAV, I mean, again, mathematically, you're absolutely right.
You were absolutely right on the figure.
And I'm sure you hear lots of chief executives who bemoan where their share price is.
There aren't that many FTSE100 chief executives whose share price is trading at a 17% discount to hard assets.
So I think my grievance around might be slightly more credible.

I think though the critical thing for us is one, deliver on the return on equity targets; and two, actually use the framework I've described today to help more people understand 3i, what our business model is and how we're going to deliver returns.
And I think if we get that right, I think the share price will take care of itself.
So what we're focused on as a management team is delivering those return on equity objectives.
And right now, we are seeing plenty of opportunities to deploy capital at the kind of returns I talked about.
And I think that will be in the longer-term interest of shareholders rather than actually reducing the size of the overall business through buybacks.
I think, I mean, going forward, we are planning to, as Julia said very clearly, adopt a very conservative funding strategy.
We have a net debt limit at the moment of 1 billion, which clearly as the net asset value grows, that becomes an even more and more conservative limit.
And obviously, we're nowhere near that as of the 31st of March.
And as you quite rightly point out, the additional realizations that have come in already in the last 6 weeks mean that we're actually -- that net debt figure has come down even further.
We're not assuming that we get any benefit from leverage in the target that we're setting.
So we have not set these targets on the basis of let's increase leverage as a helping hand.
We have leverage in the business and we run cash balances really to give us the flexibility to have capital available to deploy at a moment's notice.
That's what we're focused on around our balance sheet management as opposed to having structural leverage that will enhance our returns.
Thank you, Simon, and good morning, everyone.
The results we reported this morning is solid evidence of the progress we're making in the strategic initiatives that Simon has just outlined.
And we've achieved those results against the challenging economic environment in which we all continue to operate.
Fundamental, political, regulatory and financial questions remained unanswered in Europe and beyond.
Equity markets have been up and down during the 6 months.
But in the markets and the sectors where we've operated, they've ended up broadly flat.
M&A activity has been muted.
There have been some signs of improvement more recently, but it will take time for any improvement to have an impact on our activity levels.
And finally, as a sterling investor, currency markets have also proved challenging with weakness in the euro and the rupee being particularly relevant for us.
So against that backdrop, here are our key financial, starting with the returns on our income statement.
The performance for the 6 months reflects a period of considerable change in development in 3i, but we have a degree of stability, returning to the underlying portfolio performance.

Gross portfolio return of GBP 180 million reflects good realizations in the noncore portfolio in the first quarter, better earnings performance in a big part of the Private Equity portfolio compared to last year and that GBP 180 million is a marked improvement on the loss of GBP 329 million in the year to 31st of March.
Fees in the period reduced a GBP 36 million and that reflects the end of the investment period for Eurofund V, our most European buyout bond, but we had another strong period of Debt Management.
Operating costs are GBP 105 million.
That GBP 105 million includes the effect of implementing the changes to the business, which we announced in June.
We estimated then that implementation cost will be about GBP 30 million, and we have provided for GBP 25 million in this period.
We have made tangible progress in a relatively short time since the changes were announced in June.
We are on track to achieve the run rate savings of GBP 40 million that Simon talked about by the end of this financial year.
In a minute, I'll outline the composition of the resulting net portfolio return of GBP 109 million by individual business line.
The total return takes account of the effects of our balance sheet and was a small loss of GBP 5 million compared to a GBP 656 million was at the 31st of March.
We accounted for the payment of the final dividend when it was paid in July and that dividend payment, together with a total return, is rise to an NAV, at GBP 2.
73 at the 31st of September.

So how is that NAV progressed during the period? 
Opening NAV of GBP 2.
79 was reduced by 5p for the final dividend.
Implementation costs and the effects of the gross debt reduction gave rise to further reductions of 3p and 2p, respectively.
Noncash FX, pension and other items was 6p.
As a result, underlying business performance contributed a 10p improvement.
So we closed an NAV of GBP 2.
Now I'd like to talk about that underlying business performance in some more detail.
Each of our Infrastructure, Debt Management and Private Equity businesses have contributed to the total net portfolio return of GBP 109 million as you can see here.
The sharp item you'll notice that the 3 business lines don't actually add up to the total.
The difference is our noncore portfolio, and it's not usually so material.

But in this period, the sale of EUSA Pharma, which is a former bench capital asset generated cash proceeds of GBP 72 million, an uplift of GBP 42 million over the opening book value and a money multiple of 2.
That's an excellent result but I don't expect it to be repeated by the noncore business, which now accounts for only 2% of the portfolio.
As you've seen from Simon's presentation, we've made good progress on implementing changes we announced in June to reduce the complexity of the group and cut our cost base.
Simon just said we announced 160 people would be leaving the business by the end of this financial year.
Headcount at the end of the period was down by 104, so we remain on track to meet our run rate target reduce cost by GBP 40 million as we start the next financial year.
And as you can expect with regards next year to be the same level as last year, so we're talking about GBP 180 million.
All these figures are before adjusting for Debt Management acquisitions in the period, but those incremental costs are more than covered by the fees the new businesses will generate.
So taking each principal business line in turn.
Our Infrastructure team manages GBP 1.
6 billion of assets under management, 30% of that or GBP 471 million is on 3i's balance sheet so the contribution that we get is generated by a blended capital returns and fees, net of cost.
The business has had another solid period, supported by the robust performance of its European portfolio.
However, the solid performance was offset by the performance of the Indian portfolio, where the political, currency and sector conditions are more challenging.

In group terms, this performance translates into an increase of GBP 6 million in the value of our 34% share of 3i Infrastructure plc, unrealized value decreases of GBP 8 million in the Indian portfolio and dividend income of GBP 9 million.
During the period, the group sold its investment in Networks.
We had invested alongside 3i Infrastructure last year to facilitate the completion of the deal.
And by the way, that's a good example of the benefit our permanent capital brings.
So now we sold our position at a gain, GBP 1 million gain, over the opening portfolio value.
Our Debt Management business is capital-light but it's an important fee generator for the group.
It's performed well, again with fees from the original European business remaining ahead of plan, and they are now being supplemented by fees from the funds that we acquired from Invesco in August.
We have further increased assets under management by our strategic partnership with Fraser Sullivan, which you've heard about from Simon.
The return impacts of this last transaction is actually minimal in this period because the deal was only signed on the 28th of September.
Private Equity remains the most important contributor to our performance.
Today, it accounts for 80% of our portfolio and 47% of total assets under management, and that's why progress we have made on the assets management initiatives outlined by Simon are so critical.
Before going through the detail of the related gross portfolio return, I'd like to comment briefly on other aspects of the business' performance.
Fees have stepped down in the first half.
Eurofund V investment period ended in November 2011, just a year ago.
And fees in our paid on invested capital rather than committed capital.
The operating expenses of GBP 73 million include GBP 22 million of the GBP 25 million implementation costs.
Investments of GBP 131 million is lower than last year.
It includes the completions of Gecko, the final reinvestments from Eurofund V and Blue Interactive, the first investment made by our Brazil team.
The M&A market has been quiet through most of the period, and we have stayed cautious about new investment in Europe.
We generated realization proceeds of GBP 165 million at the, at an uplift over opening value of 15.
4%, and that represents an aggregate money multiple of 1.
9x, generating realized profits of GBP 22 million.
We've given much more detail about realizations during the period in our announcement today, and in the appendix to the slides.
In Private Equity, it is worth noting that the disposal of Esmalglass, the Spanish investment, was sold at a small uplift over the March value.
And at a money multiple of 1.
The Spanish portfolio now accounts for just 5% of the group's total.
The next slide gives you a picture of the diversity of the Private Equity portfolio.
From a geographic perspective, our strongest performers continue to be in Northern Europe and in the Americas.
Those regions make up 58% of the portfolio and have generated GBP 52 million of value growth in that period.
There is a small number of assets in Europe, which are more challenging, and we're cautious about the outlook for the French portfolio.
The French portfolio is now valued at GBP 216 million or 7% of the total.
The more recent vintages now account for 30% of the total portfolio.
Performance is not uniformly positive.
But it's in those vintages from 2010 onwards that we've seen some very positive earnings growth, with corresponding uplifts in value in the period.
The 2007 to 2009 vintages were more stable in this period.
Their accounting for 66% of the portfolio and generating a value increase of GBP 53 million.

Now in the past, we provided additional disclosure to give you a view on the trajectory of portfolio performance, taking accounts of commercial considerations and confidentiality obligations, and it's fair to say with varying degrees of success.
This slide gives an indicator of performance on an aggregate basis by comparing earnings performance versus the prior year.
The blue line shows you the percentage by number of companies you have better earnings performance than last year.
So for the portfolio at 30th of September, just over 55% of companies are better, and they account for 70% of the value and that's the steady performance since March.
Breaking this picture down to a company level, this slide gives an indication of the performance of our largest assets.
This is a positive picture, with a significant majority performance ahead of last year.
And you'll see from the additional information in the announcement, 35% of companies had growth of more than 10%, 24% of companies generated growth of more than 20%.
So overall, the performance of the portfolio is better than it has been in our most recent periods.
And that's improved portfolio performance is reflected in the valuations in the first half.
As I mentioned earlier, even though equity markets have been volatile, they actually finished broadly flat in the period.
And the multiples used to value the portfolio were also similarly flat, increasing by only 1%.
For this reporting period, we typically use the last 12 months accounts to June as a basis of valuation, but we use forecast earnings if they're lower than the last 12 months to June.
And 16 companies, 27%, were valued using current year forecast earnings.
Aggregate earnings used to value the portfolio, including those on forecast, grew by 1%.
But on valuated basis, earnings used to value the portfolio, grew by 9%.
And as you might expect, the leverage in the portfolio of using earnings fell to 3.
3x net-debt-to-EBITDA multiple, that's thanks to better performance.
So bringing beast data points together into the makeup of the unrealized value for the GBP 66 million, you can see that the most material component relates to performance.
The positive small movements GBP 4 million in provisions is the net effect of 3 companies, each movements being less than GBP 10 million.
And so that's not indicative of the wider trend.
Finally, the industry metric category includes ATR, our Asian reinsurance business, which continues to be impacted by the effects of the Thai floods at the end of 2011.
Turning then to the balance sheet and, in particular, to the gross debt reduction and the capital allocation model that Simon talked about earlier.
Keeping our strategic review we just completed was to reduce the gross debt by using our cash resources.
We have been reducing debt since its peak of GBP 2.
7 billion in March 2009, but it's the simplification of the business model and more direct central control that mean we can take the next significant steps.
We started the year with GBP 1.
6 billion of gross debt and sets target to reduce its GBP 1.
3 billion by the 30th of September and then reduce it further to GBP 1 billion by June 2013.
Gross deb at the end of the period was GBP 1.
2 billion, so we are ahead of our intermediate target.
We've done that through a combination of scheduled maturities but also by being opportunistic in making some early repayments.
Gross interest for the period of GBP 60 million includes GBP 20 million of accelerated interest costs.

I expect that the full year charge will be marginally less than last financial year and, importantly, that the run rate of net interest payable at the start of next year will be near at GBP 60 million for the full year.
So we are ahead of our original plan.
And I'm confident that we're on track to meet the GBP 1 billion target by June 2013.
This is particularly important.
It's not only important because of the impact on the run rate of interest but also because of its link to our capital allocation and distribution policy.

The target capital allocation framework that we set out in June, which Simon has just restated, means we will deploy more of our capital to shareholder distribution and to investment in our core businesses over time.
The quality of realizations in the period has been good, but as we had expected, lower in absolute terms than in prior years.
That reduction and realizations, together with a significant progress we're making to reduce gross debt means that there is a net outflow of GBP 390 million in the period.
Of course, repayments of gross debt has no impact on net debt or gearing.
Net debt increased only marginally from GBP 464 million to GBP 493 million and gearing went from 18% to 19%, that's another important factor in our capital distribution policy.
To remind you what we set out in May, we rebased our dividend to 8.
1p per share this time last year.

And we defined the basis of aggregate shareholders distributions as 15% to 20% of gross cash proceeds from realizations, provided that gearing is less than 20% and that we're on target to have gross debt less than GBP 1 billion by June 2013.
We also indicated that realizations are likely to be lower in this financial year, and the first half performance is consistent with our lower forecast.
Therefore, it's still the case but it will be next financial year before you should expect any meaningful increase in shareholder distribution.
1p levels set last year should be seen as a base for the dividend.
So we announced today, an interim dividend of 2.
7p per share, with an intention to pay 8.
1p per share as the total dividend for the year.
So before I hand back to Simon to wrap up, I'll just quickly summarize the results for the 6 months of the 30th of September 2012.
This has been a period of very considerable change.
A lot of which is reflected in the numbers and some of which will take longer to prove its potential.
We've made good progress in restructuring the business and we've seen a degree of stability in the underlying performance of the portfolio.

The total return loss of GBP 5 million reflects its better performance from our Private Equity portfolio and steady contributions from Infrastructure and Debt Management, as well as the cost of restructuring.
The balance sheet remains strong, and the progress that we've made in reducing gross debt will improve returns and cash flow from next year.
All of this has created a leaner business and prepares us for increased shareholder distributions as the level of our realizations improved.
I'll now hand back to Simon.
Thanks, Julia.
Before we move on to Q&A, I'd like to conclude the presentation with a few key messages.
As I said earlier, we've had a busy period over the last 6 months, and I think we've made great progress on the restructuring in the business against a very difficult macro conditions.
We're on track to meet the cost and the debt reduction targets that we set out in June.
Our overall financial performance has been stable, with a better performance from Private Equity and steady contributions from Infrastructure and our Debt Management business.
We're focusing on the next stage of our strategic plan, transition and delivery, which covers financial years 2014 and 2015.
Transition and delivery will be about aligning our cost to our income, shifting our capital allocation and growing third-party fee income.
As part of that, I expect our pipeline of realizations in Private Equity to come through over the next 2 years and to support enhanced shareholders distributions.
So those are our key messages and they identify our priorities and how we would like to be measured over the next few years.
With that in mind, we'd now be delighted to take some Q&A.
We got some mics so.

And then on your question about provision impairments, I think as we talked about in the past, our provision numbers should really be low because we make a provision when we actually have a fear that the investment may fail.
So we will anticipate negative performance to reduce forecast earnings.
So I think it will be a bit premature to find some correlation now between that number and the dashboard.

Having said that, I'm confident that the dashboard will absolutely help our ability to anticipate any issues in the value that needs to be dealt with, and that you'd expect that to flow through the valuations in time.
Chris Brown from JPMorgan Cazenove.
First question referring to earnings.
Can you talk about the change between March and June and in June and September? I think there's real potential for our country around Brazil.
We've been approached by a number of LPs who made that inquiry and as we have a well-regarded team in Brazil.
We've made our first investment.

We've got a number of other proposals in the pipeline that are being considered at the moment, and it is a much more resilient economy than we see in Europe at the moment across Continental Europe, in particular, with pretty strong government finances and a very developing consumer society within the country.
So we're looking hard at that.
We don't anticipate anything developing of that type before the second half of next year but it will be a serious consideration going into next year.
Daniel Garrod, Barclays.

First you mentioned the actions you were taking on the realization side to ensure that next year there is a step-up in realizations, so I'm wondering if you could provide any color of that to what degree it is relying on sort of primary markets improving obviously in this sort of period relatively low level of realized profits and realizations overall.

Is it just out sort of a vintage of the portfolio that it's that much more optimal to divest next year? Second question, minimal sort of provisions and impairment going through the unrealized movement this period.

How sort of sustainable do you feel that is? You touched on this implementation at the dashboard, has that helped in any way achieve that, or is it coincidence that you actually have a product of how the portfolio has been performing, you have minimal provisions in impairments? Did you see it contributing to lower provision impairments going forward were the just the dashboard that will contribute to earlier recognition? Yes, I think we saw similar profile with slightly better performance in the our second quarter over the first half.
But clearly, the number of forecast earnings we have did also go up in that period.
There's a timing issue with that, as companies go to that calendar year end.
So yes, it's consistent with the overall shape of the half.
Okay, let me try and tackle those.
In terms of comp, we're it's taking out of trunk of comp through the restructuring, so we're losing 1/3 of our staff so that is really taking down that number.

In terms of the balance, it's going to be very aligned to the returns of the group is making itself so that will determine the size of the overall conversation pool and then the division of that pool will be much between the strong performers and the weaker performers.
So I would anticipate some people earning more than at the moment and some people earning considerably less and the variable pay will be used in that regard.

And when we issue shares as deferred compensation to I'm sure people build a stake in the business, we'll make sure that, that's non-dilutive so any shares issued as part of that will be brought back in, in the market.
I think in terms of realizations given the state of the world, I don't want to be led in anything in that regard.
But all the mix of companies that are being put up to sale, some of them are in response to a purchase to us and it's harder to make a judgment about those sorts of prices.
But the ones that we are managing and our promoting ourselves, we feel very confident about that saleability.
And the last one, ROE.
That was a target from another management team.
I'm still trying to work out the best way to be judged in this business.

I have much greater focus on cash and on cash-in-cash returns and I would expect to talk in detail, about how will be presenting their group going forward once we've 
completed the restructuring so those sorts of returns and measures will be up radical part of that.
Henry Freeman from Investec Securities.
We read in the press of the weekend about a potential raise in for Private Equity in Brazil.
What is the potential obviously you've taken us specifically on management businesses in Infrastructure and Debt Management.
What is the potential for a South American raise? Julia, why don't you do with the multiples question.
And often, the companies that already that are taking forecast earnings often got the lower values and it's a continuation of that strategy but not in all cases.
I think on the portfolio review, I'm comfortable with where the thing is valued.
You've seen from the reallocation total in the release today, that effectively made realizations of the head of the marks we have in our books.
There are a good spread of companies.
I guess the concerning thing is that the overwhelming majority of the investment is in Europe.
We see 2013 being pretty tricky in Europe for all sorts of reasons, and that would affect some of the northern European countries.
And the country we are worried about is France.
So we will see some headwinds in that regard.

But in general, we're very comfortable with the general state of the portfolio but a well-known problem that you all know that but apart from that, the bulk of the value is really in some pretty good companies.
Actually, if you split our multiple movement sort of our first quarter, second quarter, there was more of an uptick in the multiples in the second quarter.
So nothing consistent with the Q3 movement that market has But if you do look at the multiple movements for the 6 months as a whole, actually, markets have been pretty flat over that period of time.
We do spend quite less time trying to go through those comparative sets relating to the geographies that we're in, and I feel pretty comfortable it's pretty much in line.
Let me take the first and Julia can take the second.

I think on realizations, we have a number of initiatives in train where it takes about 6 to 9 months to sell a company from agreeing with management to plan for the exit, appointing advisers and putting together the process that leads to a successful sale.

And we've started that in a number of cases, and we started that with companies that, we then, for varying degrees of time but are all at a point where they can be sold effectively in markets that don't have to be as robust as they are now and give the buyer a further traction to hold those investments going forward, so another leg to the story.
So we've identified those businesses.
You're read about some of them in the press.
We haven't confirmed any of them yet, but those processes are kicking off, and we would expect to see the results of them in calendar 2013.
I think it's a metric that's sort, it's a bit meaningless if you are cash investor in the business, so I place less emphasis on it than perhaps you do.
But we'll be more explicit about the way the judge in May.
Any more questions? Okay.
Well, I'd like to wrap it up.
Thanks for your attendance and mingle at the end if you want to ask anything in private.
Yes, and although you had quite high proportion presumably quite a low proportion of the valuation based on those forward earnings? Henry over here.
And I mean, just bearing in mind sort of cautious comments on Europe, can you give any favor of how you might expect earnings to develop? Iain Scouller from Oriel securities.
I've got a couple.
Firstly on multiples.
You saw GBP 4 million gain between March and September.
Can you just talk about what that meant was between June and September because, I think, over that period the small-cap index up about 10%.
MidCap was up about 7%.

We don't seem to seen much impact from multiples over that period, so maybe business mix or maybe you've taken cost approach? And then the second one is on the portfolio review that you've carried out, Simon.
What would you see are the key strengths and weaknesses of the portfolio particularly with regards to the industry mix and any other factors? Okay, I think everyone's through.
Good morning, everyone, and welcome to 3i's results presentation.
For most of the last 10 years, 3i have relied on using part of the firm's capital gains from investment sales to pay for a significant part of the group's annual running costs.
Well, that was workable in the buoyant years of the mid-northeast.
That approach never made any real financial sense.

And the recent years using capital gains to fund our operating costs has led to a hollowing out of the firm's capital, because high operating cost and interest costs have made a very poor capital returns performance even worse at the bottom line.
We've had a busy 6 months restructuring the group and reversing this approach, as well as introducing a number of new asset management initiatives across our Private Equity business.
The journey has just begun but we've made a strong start in some tough macroeconomic conditions.
And today, I'd like to give you an update on our progress on that redirected journey.
I'd also like to reinforce my confidence in the next steps we're taking on the road to recovery.
Our strategic goal hasn't changed.
We remain focused on managing third-party and proprietary capital across our 3 investment platforms.
Our target is to deliver top quartile returns.
And while each business is at a different point in its development, and faces different specific challenges, our vision and our strategy are clear.
3i have stumbled badly over the past few years, and there was a fair degree of confusion and doubt in the organization when I arrived late last year.

Not only was earning coherent between what the group was trying to do and what it could afford to do, but the investment record in Private Equity was suffering badly from a very mixed portfolio of investments made at the top of the cycling calendar years 2007 and 2008.

The group was also struggling with the challenge of managing a decentralized organization, that had investment teams spread across a lot of different geographies and the lack of control and consistency which that produced.
Putting this right is no quick fix and delivering on our strategic goal will take some time.

But putting our house in order, realizing our existing portfolio of Private Equity investments and recovering our reputation in investment and asset management should deliver significant rewards for shareholders in the coming years.
Before I take you through our actions over the last few months, I'd like to remind you of my assessment of 3i's underperformance, which I set out in June.

3i have spread its resources too thinly and created a very broad international platform, encompassing many different investment teams that was little central control, and results suffered from a high level of inconsistency.

The Private Equity portfolio was, in many cases, not managed as closely or as actively as it should've been and suffered from that material overinvestment in 2007 and 2008 at the very top of the cycle.
3i had lots of different controls and limits but it had no annual vintage limit on its own balance sheet investments.
In other words, there was no cap on how much the investment teams could invest each year.
We have now put in place an annual vintage control policy.

It not only includes the limits of the amount we invest in our balance sheet in a given year but it's also used in conjunction with our annual budgeting process and we'll review it quarterly in the Executive Committee.
And as I said earlier, operating costs were far greater than the group's annual cash income that we generate from management fees and the portfolio itself.
The group did not appear to me to be operating as a normal commercial business and seemed to lack the very disciplines it routinely demanded of its investing companies.
So my priorities for this financial year are to restructure the business and bring a much greater degree of control and focus to our asset management activities.
I want us to work at the same levels of consistency and discipline as the best organizations in our sector.
We have individuals and individual teams that do exactly that, but we don't do it consistently across the group.
The restructuring of the business is on track.
We've already reduced headcount by over 100 people, and we're on track to meet our target reduction of 160 by the end of this financial year.
And we've closed 5 offices.
And with the sale of Birmingham, that will complete in January, we will have met our target of 6 office closures.
We're also well underway to achieving a run rate operating cost savings of GBP 40 million by March next year.
That's against our baseline annualized run rate operating cost of GBP 185 million at March this year.
In June, we also announced 6 asset management improvement initiatives, which had been developed with our Private Equity teams during my 6 months as 3i CIO.
That program of initiatives has been substantially implemented and will have a significant positive impact on the performance to our portfolio over the coming years.
You will recall that they involve changes to our investment review process and exit strategy and planning, as well as a review of our people strategy in terms of governance and resourcing.
The next slide illustrates one of these 6 initiatives, a subject I call the dashboard.
When I joined 3i in October last year, I was concerned that the number of instances where the group only seem to recognize series performance issues and invest companies very late in the day.
I was also surprised that the infrequent flow of realtime financial information on key portfolio of companies to the senior executives of the group.
Again, I felt the group fell some way short of best practice in the Private Equity sector and that could only be partially explained by the size and breadth of the portfolio at 3i.
So using some of my prior experience, I instigated a project with the Private Equity team to bring our monitoring and performance tracking up to best in class.
We brought in Bain and Company and together, we designed the dashboard for each of our material Private Equity investments.
The dashboard focused on strategic financial and operational KPIs, as well as presenting relevant commentary on the specific company and its performance.
It also give an assessment of its cash flow and its debt position.
Each dashboard is now produced within 3 weeks of monthly management accounts and sent around on an email to the Investment Committee and the senior partners in our Private Equity business.
There is then the review meeting when we look of the portfolios performance once a month, and it's now very easy to use the KPI information to set the agenda for that meeting.
So that we focus on the companies with performance issues.
We then agree the actions to take and review the follow-up at the next meeting.
In my view, this initiative is transforming the effectiveness of 3i's monitoring and performance tracking.
So that we now have a system, which is timely and truly best in class.
It's been a busy and stretching 6 months for everyone at 3i.
It's been tough on those people who have been asked to leave, but it's also been very tough on those people who have stayed.
And all of this has been happening against the backdrop of some very unhelpful macroeconomic conditions.
I'm confident we will deliver both the restructuring I've been talking about, as well as the asset management initiatives that will lift our investment performance in due course.
So in my view, it's time for us to focus on the next part of our recovery plan, transition and delivery.
The transition and delivery will span financial years ending March 2014 and March 2015.
And we'll focus on aligning our operating costs to our income.
It will also include a hard look at our capital allocation and the growth in third-party fee income.
The aggressive restructuring steps we are taking this year and next are part of an overall plan to bring our operating costs below our cash income on an annual basis.
We are doing this ahead of time when our third-party private fee -- Private Equity fee income is reducing as the funds themselves run off.
But it's also a time when we are seeing opportunities for growth in third-party fee income from Debt Management and from Infrastructure.
Our goal will be to have a healthy surplus each year.
You will all be familiar with this slide, which I used in June.

It shows, in concept, where we are moving to as a result of our actions and our cost in our reduction in gross debt levels and it highlights the significant potential we have for increasing shareholder distributions, as well as reinvestment in our business.
This sum up, we launched a review of compensation across the group.
Compensation is our largest cost at around 60% of total annual operating costs and was not part of the cost reduction program we announced in June.
Compensation will be a key tool in delivering our new strategic objectives.
And we've got to be absolutely sure that there is a fair balance of returns between employees and shareholders.
We've adopted some key principles as part of that review.
An equitable split of returns between employees and shareholders.
And we acknowledge that due to performance issues, we haven't always have that balance over the last few years.
We plan to align compensation with our strategic objectives and make sure these objectives have an important influence on variable compensation, in particular.
Merits will play a more prominent role in variable compensation decisions, which will have a much greater spread from top to bottom than they have had in the past at 3i.
And we'll make sure there is a clear link between overall compensation and shareholder returns.

That will mean that a greater proportion of our senior staff compensation will be in deferred shares to increase alignment with shareholders and the concept of ownership across the key managers in the group.
We plan to involve shareholders in this group-wide review and use the meetings following these results to gain feedback on these key compensation principles.

Early next year, the board intends to enter a formal shareholder consultation period led by Jonathan, the Chairman of our Remuneration Committee, with a view to seeking any necessary approvals in next summer CGM.
That way, these changes will be locked in for our next financial year.
Turning to the subject of third-party fee income, I'd like to start with Infrastructure.
We have a very strong capability in Infrastructure investing.
And we see good opportunities to grow both assets under management and third-party fee income over the coming years.
We believe there will be increasing opportunities for private investment in government-related assets, as government finances become even more challenged.
And we expect to see opportunities to take over management contracts as some existing Infrastructure funds.
Turning to Debt Management.
The team have enjoyed a busy and successful start to this financial year.
Not only as Jeremy Ghose team acquired management contracts in Europe from Invesco and set the U.
platform with Fraser Sullivan, but they've also successfully launched their first 3i CLO fund in the U.
, adding $450 million of funds under management.
Again, like with Infrastructure, we believe that Debt Management is capable of good growth in third-party fee income in AUM over the medium term.
Fraser Sullivan has an excellent reputation in the U.
debt markets and they are well placed to take advantage of the confident market conditions in the U.
to grow their core CLO business.
We should also be able to develop into adjacent debt markets.
The males will be further bolt-on acquisitions in the U.
, opportunities to accelerate our development of third-party fee income and to grow the AUM further.
However, the debt market in Europe remains fairly muted.
We need to continue to manage our existing funds effectively, as well as focusing on those products and capabilities that will position us well as the European market dynamics change.
This could take a number of routes as the banks pullback.

In terms of Private Equity over the last 6 months, realization levels and investment activity have been low, not least because of acquired M&A markets and the continuing tricky macro conditions across Europe.
However, we've made some good realizations in the first half, including Esmalglass in Spain and we exited EUSA Pharma from our noncore Private Equity portfolio.
In today's world, investment is not just about buying a strong business and loading it up with leverage.
Our investment thesis invariably involves a growth or turnaround transformation, which can involve significant operational change.
And this is the most challenging part of our investment plans.
Things rarely stay right on plan.
They almost always move off either up or down.
When they move the wrong way off plan, we have to move quickly to write the situation, and we now have a much better monitoring tool to do that.
One have moved off plan in recent times, and we know focus on returning both of these to a better trajectory.
But it swings in roundabouts, an action, for example, which is our biggest Private Equity investment has moved ahead far more quickly than we anticipated.
And in these sorts of cases, we've got to remain vigilant to make sure our plan and our management are ambitious enough.
We have a number of specific strategic priorities to keep us fully occupied over the next 18 months and you'll be able to judge our performance against these priorities.
In particular, you'll be able to observe an increased level of realization activity from our Private Equity portfolio.
In turn, that will lead to enhanced shareholder distributions.
We've already set in train preparation, which will underpin this realization activity.
And as I said earlier, this is a journey covering 3 distinct phases, and it's important to me that we increase transparency so that you can track our progress.

So in addition to the specific targets that we set out in June, we will be providing more detail on our cash income and our run rate operating costs from March next year, as well as further disclosure on all realizations, including cash profit and cash-on-cash multiples for realization.
You know the shape of 3i today, but this is how we expect to see the group evolve over the medium term.
Clearly, as I've said, we'll have an emphasis on growth in third-party funds and fee income in both Infrastructure and Debt Management.
Proprietary capital will continue to play a significant role in our Private Equity business, but we will be deploying more of our shareholders' funds in our 2 less cyclical divisions.
In time, we've got to change the way the market looks at 3i.
We sit somewhere between the large-scale asset managers in the U.
such as Blackstone and KPR and the investment trust of SVG and HG Capital.

As we complete our restructuring, our objective is that the market not only values our investments but also values the profits we generate, especially as fund managers across our 3 investment platforms.
I'd now like to pass to Julia who will take you through our interim results.
Bruce Hamilton, Morgan Stanley.
Three sort of follow-up questions.
Firstly, on the cost.
When you talk about comp, should we read that as meaning a further reduction in cost, or is it really more of sort of about alignment and making sure the right people get paid.

Secondly, on realizations, I recognized obvious either companies look like they're ready for sale next financial year, but I mean would you regard the 15% uplift you just enjoyed as being a sort of a good number for next year, or something that you'll be pretty disappointed with, because you can sell assets but what's the price? And then finally, on the return on equity, obviously, you previous sort of targets of 15%.
The cost reduction plan to dig here the balance sheet obviously helped but you're still clearly some way off making your cost of equity.

What do you think is would be a plausible sort of ROE sort of run rate looking 2 years out when you got the business back to towards its full run rate? But I guess I suspect the market will continue to extend the return on equity versus your cost of equity.
So what you mean on managing fully focus on that internally.

Did you think he recognized that will be quite an important output in terms of way valuations or do you think that's the wrong metric? Well, I think, as Simon has just said, we are reasonably cautious about the European environment.
By using the forecast earnings we're trying to anticipate some of that, but we're not taking any further forward at the end of September.
So we will all have to see how the European environment develops over the turn of the calendar year.
Julia, why don't you do with the multiples question, first.
Okay, I think everyone's through.

We then agree the actions to take and review the follow-up at the next meeting.
In my view, this initiative is transforming the effectiveness of 3i's monitoring and performance tracking.
So that we now have a system, which is timely and truly best in class.
It's been a busy and stretching 6 months for everyone at 3i.
It's been tough on those people who have been asked to leave, but it's also been very tough on those people, who have stayed.
And all of this has been happening against the backdrop of some very unhelpful macroeconomic conditions.
I'm confident we will deliver both the restructuring I've been talking about, as well as the asset management initiatives that will lift our investment performance in due course.
So in my view, it's time for us to focus on the next part of our recovery plan, transition and delivery.
The transition and delivery will span financial years ending in March 2014 and March 2015.
And we'll focus on aligning our operating costs to our income.
It will also include a hard look at our capital allocation and the growth in third-party fee income.
The aggressive restructuring steps we are taking this year and next are part of an overall plan to bring our operating costs below our cash income on an annual basis.
We are doing this at a time when our third party private fee -- Private Equity fee income is reducing, as the funds themselves run off.
But it's also a time when we are seeing opportunities for growth in third-party fee income from Debt Management and from Infrastructure.
Our goal will be to have a healthy surplus each year.
You will all be familiar with this slide, which I used in June.
It shows in concept where we are moving to as a result of our actions and our cost in our reduction in gross debt levels.
And it highlights the significant potential we have for increasing shareholder distributions, as well as reinvestment in our business.
This sum up, we launched a review of compensation across the group.
Compensation is our largest cost at around 60% of total annual operating costs and was not part of the cost reduction program we announced in June.
Compensation will be a key tool in delivering our new strategic objectives.
And we've got to be absolutely sure that there is a fair balance of returns between employees and shareholders.
We've adopted some key principles as part of that review.
An equitable split of returns between employees and shareholders.
And we acknowledge that due to performance issues, we haven't always have that balance over the last few years.
We plan to align compensation with our strategic objectives and make sure these objectives have an important influence on variable compensation, in particular.
Merits will play a more prominent role in variable compensation decisions, which will have a much greater spread from top to bottom than they have had in the past at 3i.
And we'll make sure there is a clear link between overall compensation and shareholder returns.

That will mean that a greater proportion of our senior staff compensation will be in deferred shares to increase alignment with shareholders and the concept of ownership across the key managers in the group.
We plan to involve shareholders in this group-wide review and use the meetings following these results to gain feedback on these key compensation principles.

Early next year, the board intends to enter a formal shareholder consultation period led by Jonathan Asquith, the Chairman of our Remuneration Committee, with a view to seeking any necessary approvals at next summer's AGM.
That way, these changes will be locked in for our next financial year.
Turning to the subject of third-party fee income, I'd like to start with Infrastructure.
We have a very strong capability in Infrastructure investing.
And we see good opportunities to grow both assets under management and third-party fee income over the coming years.
We believe there will be increasing opportunities for private investment in government-related assets, as government finances become even more challenged.
And we expect to see opportunities to take over management contracts as some existing Infrastructure funds.
Turning to Debt Management.
The team have enjoyed a busy and successful start to this financial year.
Not only as Jeremy Ghose's team acquired management contracts in Europe from Invesco and set up a U.
platform with Fraser Sullivan, but they've also successfully launched their first 3i CLO fund in the U.
, adding $450 million of funds under management.
Again, like with Infrastructure, we believe that Debt Management is capable of good growth in third-party fee income in AUM over the medium term.
Fraser Sullivan has an excellent reputation in the U.
debt markets, and they are well placed to take advantage of the confident market conditions in the U.
to grow their core CLO business.
We should also be able to develop into adjacent debt markets.
There may also be further bolt-on acquisition opportunities in the U.
, opportunities to accelerate our development of third-party fee income and to grow the AUM further.
However, the debt market in Europe remains fairly muted.
We need to continue to manage our existing funds effectively, as well as focusing on those products and capabilities that will position us well as the European market dynamics change.
This could take a number of routes as the banks pull back.

In terms of Private Equity over the last 6 months, realization levels and investment activity have been low, not least because of the acquired M&A markets and the continuing tricky macro conditions across Europe.
However, we've made some good realizations in the first half, including Esmalglass in Spain, and we exited EUSA Pharma from our noncore Private Equity portfolio.
In today's world, investment is not just about buying a strong business and loading it up with leverage.
Our investment thesis invariably involves a growth or turnaround transformation, which can involve significant operational change.
And this is the most challenging part of our investment plans.
Things rarely stay right on plan.
They almost always move off either up or down.
When they move the wrong way off plan, we have to move quickly to write the situation, and we now have a much better monitoring tool to do that.
OneMed and GEKA have moved off plan in recent times, and we now focus on returning both of these to a better trajectory.
But it swings in roundabouts, an action, for example, which is our biggest Private Equity investment, has moved ahead far more quickly than we anticipated.
And in these sorts of cases, we've got to remain vigilant to make sure our plan and our management are ambitious enough.
We have a number of specific strategic priorities to keep us fully occupied over the next 18 months and you'll be able to judge our performance against these priorities.
In particular, you'll be able to observe an increased level of realization activity from our Private Equity portfolio.
In turn, that will lead to enhanced shareholder distributions.
We've already set in train, preparations, which will underpin this realization activity.
And as I said earlier, this is a journey covering 3 distinct phases, and it's important to me that we increase transparency so that you can track our progress.

So in addition to the specific targets that we set out in June, we will be providing more detail on our cash income and our run rate operating costs from March next year, as well as further disclosure on all realizations, including cash profit and cash-on-cash multiples for each realization.
You know the shape of 3i today, but this is how we expect to see the group evolve over the medium term.
Clearly, as I've said, we'll have an emphasis on growth in third-party funds and fee income in both Infrastructure and Debt Management.
Proprietary capital will continue to play a significant role in our Private Equity business, but we'll be deploying more of our shareholders' funds in our 2 less cyclical divisions.
In time, we've got to change the way the market looks at 3i.
We sit somewhere between the large-scale asset managers in the U.
, such as Blackstone and KKR and the investment trust of H -- SVG and HgCapital.

As we complete our restructuring, our objective is that the market not only values our portfolio of investments, but also values the profits we generate, especially as fund managers across our 3 investment platforms.
I'd now like to pass to Julia, who will take you through our interim results.
Yes, and although you had quite a high proportion of forward earnings you were using, presumably quite a low proportion of the valuation based on those forward earnings? Yes, yes.
And often, the companies that are already on -- that are taking forecast earnings have often got the lower values.
And it's a continuation of that strategy, but not in all cases.
Well, I think, as Simon has just said, we are reasonably cautious about the European environment.
By using the forecast earnings, we're trying to anticipate some of that, but we're not taking any further forward in the end of September.
So we will all have to see how the European environment develops over the turn of the calendar year.
I think it's a metric that's sort of -- it's a bit meaningless, if you are a cash investor in the business.
So I placed less emphasis on it than perhaps you do.
But we'll be more explicit about the way to judge us in May.
Any more questions? Okay.
Well, I'd like to wrap it up.
Thanks for your attendance and mingle at the end if you want to ask anything in private.
Actually, if you split our multiple movement, sort of our first quarter, second quarter, there was more of an uptick in the multiples in the second quarter.
So nothing consistent with the Q3 movement that market has honed in on.
But if you do look at the multiple movement for the 6 months as a whole, actually, markets have been pretty flat over that period of time.
We do spend quite less time trying to go through those comparative sets relating to the sets of geographies that we're in.
And I feel pretty comfortable it's pretty much in line.

And then on your question about provisions and  impairments, I think as we talked about in the past, our provision numbers should really be low because we make a provision when we actually have a fear that the investment may fail.
So we will anticipate negative performance through the use of forecast earnings.
So I think it will be a bit premature to find some correlation now between that number and the dashboard.
Having said that, I'm confident that the dashboard will absolutely help our ability to anticipate any issues in the portfolio that need to be dealt with.
And that we usually expect that to flow through the valuations in time.
Bruce Hamilton, Morgan Stanley.
Three sort of follow-up questions.
Firstly, on the cost.

When you talk about comp, should we read that as a meaning there's a further reduction in cost, or is it really more sort of about alignment and sort of making sure the right people get paid? Secondly, on realizations.
I recognized, obviously, there are companies now that look like they're ready for sale next financial year.

But I mean would you regard the 15% uplift you just enjoyed as being a sort of a good number for next year, or something that you would be pretty disappointed with, because you can sell assets but what's the price? And then finally, on the return on equity, obviously, your previous sort of targets of 15%.
The cost reduction plan, the de-gear of the balance sheet obviously helped, but you're still clearly some way off making your cost of equity.

What do you think is a -- would be a plausible sort of ROE sort of run rate looking 2 years out, when you've got the business back to towards its sort of full run rate? But I guess, I suspect the market will continue, to the extent that they value price to book, they'll look at your return on equity versus your cost of equity.
So what do you mean on managed -- fully focus on that internally.
