Did you think that -- I mean you recognized that it will be quite an important output in terms of way your valuations get to, or do you think that's the wrong metric? Chris Brown from JPMorgan Cazenove.
Just have a question to Adrian really.
But just referring to earnings.
Can you talk about the sort of change between March and June and in June and September? I think there's real potential for our country fund around Brazil.
We've been approached by a number of LPs, who've made that inquiry of us.
We have a well-regarded team in Brazil.
We've made our first investment.

We've got a number of other proposals in the pipeline that are being considered at the moment, and it is a much more resilient economy than we see in Europe at the moment across Continental Europe, in particular, with pretty strong government finances and a very developing consumer society within the country.
So we're looking hard at that.
We don't anticipate anything developing of that type before the second half of next year, but it will be a serious consideration going into next year.
Iain Scouller from Oriel securities.
I've got a couple.
Firstly, on multiples.
I think you saw GBP 4 million gain between March and September.
Can you just talk about what the movement was between June and September, because I think over that period the small-cap index of about 10%; mid cap was up about 7%.

We don't seem to see much of an impact for multiples over that period, so maybe due to business mix or maybe you've taken a cautious approach? And then the second one is on the portfolio review that you've carried out, Simon.
What would you say are the key strengths and weaknesses of the portfolio and particularly, with regards to the industry mix and any other factors? Thank you, Simon, and good morning, everyone.
The results we've reported this morning is solid evidence of the progress we're making in the strategic initiatives that Simon has just outlined.
And we've achieved those results against the challenging economic environment in which we all continue to operate.
Fundamental, political, regulatory and financial questions remained unanswered in Europe and beyond.
Equity markets have been up and down during the 6 months.
But in the markets and the sectors where we've operated, they've ended up broadly flat.
M&A activity has been muted.
There have been some signs of improvement more recently, but it will take time for any improvement to have an impact on our activity levels.
And finally, as a sterling investor, currency markets have also proved challenging with weakness in the euro and the rupee being particularly relevant for us.
So against that backdrop, here are our key financials, starting with the returns on our income statement.
The performance for the 6 months reflects a period of considerable change and development in 3i, but we have a degree of stability, returning to the underlying portfolio of performance.

Gross portfolio return of GBP 180 million reflects good realizations in the noncore portfolio in first quarter, better earnings performance in a big part of the Private Equity portfolio compared to last year.
And that GBP 180 million is a marked improvement on the loss of GBP 329 million in the year, 31st of March.
Fees in the period reduced to GBP 36 million, and that reflects the end of the investment period for Eurofund V, our most European buyout bond, but we had another strong period of Debt Management.
Operating costs are GBP 105 million.
That GBP 105 million includes the effect of implementing the changes to the business, which we announced in June.
We estimated then that implementation cost will be about GBP 30 million, and we have provided for GBP 25 million in this period.
We have made tangible progress in the relatively short time since the changes were announced in June.
We are on track to achieve the run rate savings of GBP 40 million that Simon talked about by the end of this financial year.
In a minute, I'll outline the composition of the resulting net portfolio return of GBP 109 million by individual business line.
The total return takes account of the effects of our balance sheet and was a small loss of GBP 5 million compared to a GBP 656 million loss at the 31st of March.
We accounted for the payment of the final dividend when it was paid in July.
And that dividend payment, together with the total return, is rise to an NAV of GBP 2.
73 at the 30th of September.

So how has that NAV progressed during the period? 
Opening NAV of GBP 2.
79 was reduced by 5p for the final dividend.
Implementation costs and the effects of the gross debt reduction gave rise to further reductions of 3p and 2p, respectively.
Noncash FX, pension and other items was 6p.
As a result, underlying business performance contributed a 10p improvement.
So we closed an NAV of GBP 2.
Now I'd like to talk about that underlying business performance in some more detail.
Each of our Infrastructure, Debt Management and Private Equity businesses have contributed to the total net portfolio return of GBP 109 million as you can see here.
The sharp eyed amongst you will notice that the 3 business lines don't actually add up to the total.
The difference is our noncore portfolio, and it's not usually so material.

But in this period, the sale of EUSA Pharma, which is a former bench capital asset, generated cash proceeds of GBP 72 million, an uplift of GBP 42 million over the opening book value and a money multiple of 2.
That's an excellent result, but I don't expect it to be repeated by the noncore business, which now accounts for only 2% of the portfolio.
As you've seen from Simon's presentation, we've made good progress on implementing changes we announced in June to reduce the complexity of the group and cut our cost base.
Simon just said, we announced 160 people would be leaving the business by the end of this financial year.
Headcount at the end of the period was down by 104, so we remain on track to meet our run rate target in reducing cost by GBP 40 million as we start the next financial year.
And as you can expect to discuss for the next -- for this year to be about the same level as last year, so we're talking about GBP 180 million.
All these figures are before adjusting for Debt Management acquisitions in the period, but those incremental costs are more than covered by the fees the new businesses will generate.
So taking each principal business line in turn.
Our Infrastructure team manages GBP 1.
6 billion of assets under management, 30% of that or GBP 471 million is on 3i's balance sheet, so the contribution that we get is generated by a blended capital returns and fees net of cost.
The business has had another solid period, supported by the robust performance of its European portfolio.
However, this solid performance was offset by the performance of the Indian portfolio, where the political, currency and sector conditions are more challenging.

In group terms, this performance translates into an increase of GBP 6 million in the value of our 34% share of 3i Infrastructure plc, unrealized value decreases of GBP 8 million in the Indian portfolio and dividend income of GBP 9 million.
During the period, the group sold its investments in Lakeside Network.
We had invested alongside 3i Infrastructure last year to facilitate the completion of the deal.
And by the way, that's a good example of the benefit our permanent capital brings.
So now we sold our position at a gain, GBP 1 million gain, over the opening portfolio value.
Our Debt Management business is capital light, but it's an important fee generator for the group.
It has performed well again, with fees from the original European business remaining ahead of plan, and they are now being supplemented by fees from the funds that we acquired from Invesco in August.
We have further increased assets under management by our strategic partnership with Fraser Sullivan, which you heard about from Simon.
The return impacts of this last transaction is actually minimal in this period because the deal was only signed on the 28th of September.
Private Equity remains the most important contributor to our performance.
Today, it accounts for 80% of our portfolio and 47% of total assets under management, and that's why progress we have made on the asset management's initiatives outlined by Simon, are so critical.
Before going through the detail of the related gross portfolio return, I'd like to comment briefly on other aspects of the business' performance.
Fees have stepped down in the first half.
Eurofund V's investment period ended in November 2011, just a year ago and fees in our paid on invested capital rather than committed capital.
The operating expenses is GBP 73 million, include GBP 22 million of the GBP 25 million implementation costs.
Investments of GBP 131 million is lower than last year.
It includes the completions of GEKA, the final reinvestments in Eurofund V and Blue Interactive, the first investment made by our Brazil team.
The M&A market has been quiet through most of the period, and we have stayed cautious about new investment in Europe.
We generated realization proceeds of GBP 165 million at the, at an uplift over opening value of 15.
4%, and that represents an aggregate money multiple of 1.
9x, generating realized profits of GBP 22 million.
We've given much more detail about realizations during the period in our announcement today, and in the appendix to the slides.
In Private Equity, it is worth noting the disposal of Esmalglass, the Spanish investment was sold at a small uplift over the March value and at a money multiple of 1.
The Spanish portfolio now accounts for just 5% of the group's total.
The next slide gives you a picture of the diversity of the Private Equity portfolio.
From a geographic perspective, our strongest performers continue to be in Northern Europe and the Americas.
Those regions make up 58% of the portfolio and have generated GBP 52 million of value growth in the period.
There are small number of assets in Europe, which are more challenging, and we're cautious about the outlook for the French portfolio.
The French portfolio is now valued at GBP 216 million or 7% of the total.
The more recent vintages now account for 30% of the total portfolio.
Performance is not uniformly positive, but it's in those vintages from 2010 onwards that we've seen some very positive earnings growth with corresponding uplifts in value in the period.
The 2007 to 2009 vintages were more stable in this period.
They're accounting for 66% of the portfolio and generating a value increase of GBP 53 million.

Now in the past, we've provided additional disclosure to give you a view on the trajectory of portfolio performance, taking accounts of commercial considerations and confidentiality obligations, and it's fair to say, with varying degrees of success.
This slide gives an indicator performance on an aggregate basis by comparing earnings performance versus the prior year.
Blue line shows you the percentage by number of companies.
You have better earnings performance than last year.
So for the portfolio at 30th of September, just over 55% of companies are better, and they account for 70% of the value, and that's a steady performance since March.
Breaking this picture down to a company level, this slide gives an indication of the performance of our largest assets.
This is a positive picture, with a significant majority performance ahead of last year.
And you'll see from the additional information in the announcement, 35% of companies had growth of more than 10%; 24% of companies generated growth of more than 20%.
So overall, the performance of the portfolio is better than it has been in our most recent periods.
And that improved portfolio performance is reflected in the valuations in the first half.
As I mentioned earlier, even though equity markets have been volatile, they actually finished broadly flat in the period.
And the multiples used to value the portfolio were also similarly flat, increasing by only 1%.
For this reporting period, we typically use the last 12 months accounts to June as a basis of valuation, but we use forecast earnings if they're lower than the last 12 months to June.
And 16 companies, 27%, were valued using current year forecast earnings.
Aggregate earnings used to value the portfolio, including those on forecast, grew by 1%.
But on a valuated basis, earnings used to value the portfolio, grew by 9%.
And as you might expect, the leverage in the portfolio valid using earnings fell to 3.
3x net debt to EBITDA multiple.
That was thanks to this better performance.
So bringing these data points together into the makeup of the unrealized value movement to GBP 66 million, you can see that the most material component relates to performance.
The positive, but small movements of GBP 4 million in provisions is the net effect of 3 companies, each movements being less than GBP 10 million.
And so that's not indicative of the wider trend.
Finally, the industry metric category includes ACR, our Asian reinsurance business, which continues to be impacted by the effects of the Thai floods at the end of 2011.
Turning then to the balance sheet, and in particular, to the gross debt reduction and the capital allocation model that Simon talked about earlier.
Key part of the strategic review we've just completed was to reduce the gross debt by using our cash resources.
We have been reducing gross  debt since its peak of GBP 2.
7 billion in March 2009, but it's the simplification of the business model and more direct central control that mean we can take the next significant steps.
We started the year with GBP 1.
6 billion of gross debt and sets target to reduce its GBP 1.
3 billion by the 30th of September and then reduce it further to GBP 1 billion by June 2013.
Gross debt at the end of the period was GBP 1.
2 billion, so we are ahead of our intermediate target.
We've done that through a combination of scheduled maturities, but also by being opportunistic in making some early repayments.
Gross interest for the period of GBP 60 million includes GBP 20 million of accelerated interest costs.

I expect that the full year charge will be marginally less than last financial year, and importantly, that the run rate of net interest payable at the start of next year will be nearer to GBP 60 million for the full year.
So we are ahead of our original plan.
And I am confident that we're on track to meet the GBP 1 billion target by June 2013.
This is particularly important.
It's not only important because of the impact on the run rate of interest, but also because of its link to our capital allocation and distribution policy.

The target capital allocation framework that we set out in June, which Simon has just restated, means we will deploy more of our capital to shareholder distribution and to investment in our core businesses over time.
The quality of realizations in the period has been good, but as we had expected, lower in absolute terms than in prior years.
That reduction and realizations, together with a significant progress we're making to reduce gross debt, means there was a net cash outflow of GBP 390 million in the period.
Of course, repayments of gross debt has no impact on net debt or gearing.
Net debt increased only marginally from GBP 464 million to GBP 493 million and gearing went from 18% to 19%.
That's another important factor in our capital distribution policy.
To remind you what we set out in May.
We rebased our dividend to 8.
1p per share this time last year.

And we defined the basis of aggregate shareholders distributions as 15% to 20% of gross cash proceeds from realizations, provided that gearing is less than 20%, and that we're on  target to have gross debt less than GBP 1 billion by June 2013.
We also indicated that realizations were likely to be lower in this financial year, and the first half performance is consistent with that lower forecast.
Therefore, it's still the case, but it will be next financial year before you should expect any meaningful increase in shareholder distribution.
1p levels set last year should be seen as a base for the dividend.
So we announced today, an interim dividend of 2.
7p per share, with an intention to pay 8.
1p per share as the total dividend for the year.
So before I hand back to Simon to wrap up, I'll just quickly summarize the results for the 6 months of 30th of September, 2012.
This has been a period of very considerable change.
A lot of which is reflected in the numbers, and some of which will take longer to prove its potential.
We've made good progress in restructuring the business, and we've seen a degree of stability in the underlying performance of the portfolio.

The total return loss of GBP 5 million reflects its better performance from our Private Equity portfolio and steady contributions from Infrastructure and Debt Management, as well as the cost of restructuring.
The balance sheet remains strong, and the progress that we've made in reducing gross debt will improve returns and cash flow from next year.
All of this has created a leaner business and prepares us for increased shareholder distributions as the level of our realizations improved.
I'll now hand back to Simon.
Let me take the first, and Julia can take the second.

I think on realizations, we have a number of initiatives in train where it takes about 6 to 9 months to sell a company from agreeing with management to plan for the exit, appointing advisers and putting together the process that leads to a successful sale.

And we've started that in a number of cases, and we started that with companies that, we then, for varying degrees of time, but are all at a point where they can be sold effectively in markets that don't have to be even as robust as they are now and give the buyer a further traction to hold those investments going forward, so another leg to the story.
So we've identified those businesses.
You've read about some of them in the press.
We haven't confirmed any of them yet, but those processes are kicking off, and we would expect to see the results of them in calendar 2013.
Henry over here.
Daniel Garrod, Barclays.
A couple of questions.
First, you mentioned about sort of action that you were taking on the realization side to ensure that next year, there is a step-up in realizations.

I I'm wondered if you could provide any color on that to what degree it is relying on sort of primary markets improving, so obviously in this sort of period, relatively low level of realized profits and realizations overall.

Is it just down to sort of vintage of the portfolio that it's that much more optimal to divest next year? Second question, minimal sort of provisions and impairment go through the unrealized movement this period.
How sort of sustainable do you feel that is? Has -- you touched on this implementation of the dashboard.

Has that helped in any way achieve that, or is it coincidence -- have you achieved that? You've actually -- productive how the portfolio's been performing, you had minimal provisions and impairments, do you see it contributing to lower provision impairments going forward or is just the dashboard that will contribute to earlier recognition? It's Henry Freeman from Investec Securities.
We read in the press of the weekend about a potential raise in for Private Equity in Brazil.
What is the potential -- obviously, you focused, specifically, on management businesses in Infrastructure and Debt Management.
But what is the potential for a South American raise? Okay, let me try and tackle those.
In terms of comp, it -- we're taking out a trunk of comp through the restructuring, so we're losing 1/3 of our staff, so that is really taking down that number.

In terms of the balance, it's going to be very aligned to the returns of the group is making itself, so that will determine the size of the overall compensation pool, and then the division of that pool will be much darker between the strong performers and the weaker performers.
So I would anticipate some people earning more than they earn at the moment, and some people earning considerably less.
And the variable pay will be used in that regard.
And when we use shares as deferred compensation to -- I'm sure people build up a stake in the business, we'll make sure that, that's non-dilutive.
So any shares that are issued as part of that will be brought back in, in the market.
I think in terms of realizations, given the state of the world, I don't want to be led in anything in that regard.
But all the mix of companies that are being put up for sale, some of them are in response to a purchase to us, and it's harder to make a judgment about those sorts of prices.
But the ones that we are managing and our promoting ourselves, we feel very confident about the saleability.
And the last one, ROE.
That was a target from another management team.
I'm still trying to work out the best way to be judged in this business.

I have much greater focus on cash and on cash-on-cash returns, and I would expect us to talk in detail in May about how we'll be presenting the group going forward once we've completed the restructuring.
So those sorts of returns and measures will be a critical part of that.
Yes, I think we saw a similar profile with slightly better performance in the -- our second quarter of the first half.
But clearly, the number of forecast earnings we have did also go up in that period.
There's a timing issue with that, as companies come closer to that calendar year end.
So yes, it's consistent with the overall shape of the half.
And I mean, just bearing in mind, Simon,  sort of cautious comments on Europe.
Can you give any flavor for how you might expect earnings to develop? Thanks, Julia.
Before we move on to Q&A, I'd like to conclude the presentation with a few key messages.
As I said earlier, we've had a busy period over the last 6 months, and I think we've made great progress on the restructuring in the business against a very difficult macro conditions.
We're on track to meet the cost and the debt reduction targets that we set out in June.
Our overall financial performance has been stable, with a better performance from Private Equity and steady contributions from Infrastructure and our Debt Management business.
We're focusing on the next stage of our strategic plan: transition and delivery, which covers financial years 2014 and 2015.
Transition and delivery will be about aligning our cost to our income, shifting our capital allocation and growing third-party fee income.
As part of that, I expect our pipeline of realizations in Private Equity to come through over the next 2 years and to support enhanced shareholder distributions.
So those are our key messages, and they identify our priorities and how we would like to be measured over the next few years.
With that in mind, we'd now be delighted to take some Q&A.
We got some mics, so.
I think on the portfolio review, I'm comfortable with where the thing is valued.
You've seen from the realization total in the release today that we've effectively made realizations of -- ahead of the marks we had in our book.
There are a good spread of companies.
I guess the concerning thing is that the overwhelming majority of the investment is in Europe.
We see 2013 being pretty tricky in Europe for all sorts of reasons, and that would affect some of the Northern European countries, and the country we are worried about is France.
So we will see some headwinds in that regard.

But in general, we're very comfortable with the general state of the portfolio, but of the well-known problem that you all know about -- but apart from that, the bulk of the value is really in some pretty good companies.
Chris Brown from JPMorgan Cazenove.
Just have a question to Adrian, really.
But just referring to earnings.
Can you talk about the sort of change between March and June and in June and September? Julia, why don't you do with the multiples question, first.
And I mean, just bearing in mind, Simon, sort of cautious comments on Europe.
Can you give any flavor for how you might expect earnings to develop? Thanks, Julia.
Before we move on to Q&A, I'd like to conclude the presentation with a few key messages.
As I said earlier, we've had a busy period over the last 6 months, and I think we've made great progress on the restructuring in the business against the very difficult macro conditions.
We're on track to meet the cost and the debt reduction targets that we set out in June.
Our overall financial performance has been stable, with a better performance from Private Equity and steady contributions from Infrastructure and our Debt Management business.
We're focusing on the next stage of our strategic plan: transition and delivery, which covers financial years 2014 and 2015.
Transition and delivery will be about aligning our cost to our income, shifting our capital allocation and growing third-party fee income.
As part of that, I expect our pipeline of realizations in Private Equity to come through over the next 2 years and to support enhanced shareholder distributions.
So those are our key messages, and they identify our priorities and how we would like to be measured over the next few years.
With that in mind, we'd now be delighted to take some Q&A.
We got some mics, so.
Okay, let me try and tackle those.
In terms of comp, it -- we're taking out a trunk of comp through the restructuring, so we're losing 1/3 of our staff, so that is really taking down that number.

In terms of the balance, it's going to be very aligned to the returns of the group is making itself, so that will determine the size of the overall compensation pool, and then the division of that pool will be much darker between the strong performers and the weaker performers.
So I would anticipate some people earning more than they earn at the moment, and some people earning considerably less.
And the variable pay will be used in that regard.
And when we use shares as deferred compensation to -- I'm sure people build up a stake in the business, we'll make sure that, that's non-dilutive.
So any shares that are issued as part of that will be brought back in, in the market.
I think in terms of realizations, given the state of the world, I don't want to be led in anything in that regard.
But all the mix of companies that are being put up for sale, some of them are in response to a purchase to us, and it's harder to make a judgment about those sorts of prices.
But the ones that we are managing and our promoting ourselves, we feel very confident about the saleability.
And the last one, ROE.
That was a target from another management team.
I'm still trying to work out the best way to be judged in this business.

I have much greater focus on cash and on cash-on-cash returns, and I would expect us to talk in detail in May about how we'll be presenting the group going forward once we've completed the restructuring.
So those sorts of returns and measures will be a critical part of that.
Let me take the first, and Julia can take the second.

I think on realizations, we have a number of initiatives in train where it takes about 6 to 9 months to sell a company from agreeing with management to plan for the exit, appointing advisers and putting together the process that leads to a successful sale.

And we've started that in a number of cases, and we started that with companies that weve owned for varying degrees of time, but are all at the point where they can be sold effectively in markets that don't have to be even as robust as they are now and give the buyer a further traction to hold those investments going forward, so another leg to the story.
So we've identified those businesses.
You've read about some of them in the press.
We haven't confirmed any of them yet, but those processes are kicking off, and we would expect to see the results of them in calendar 2013.
Iain Scouller from Oriel securities.
I've got a couple.
Firstly, on multiples.
I think you saw GBP 4 million gain between March and September.
Can you just talk about what the movement was between June and September, because I think over that period the small-cap index of about 10%; mid cap was up about 7%.

We don't seem to see much of an impact for multiples over that period, so maybe due to business mix or maybe you've taken a cautious approach? And then the second one is on the portfolio review that you've carried out, Simon.

What would you say are the key strengths and weaknesses of the portfolio and particularly with regards to the industry mix and any other factors? Yes, I think we saw a similar profile with slightly better performance in the -- our second quarter of the first half.
But clearly, the number of forecast earnings we have did also go up in that period.
There's a timing issue with that, as companies come closer to that calendar year end.
So yes, it's consistent with the overall shape of the half.
And often, the companies that are already on -- that are taking forecast earnings have often got the lower values.
And it's a continuation of that strategy, but not in all cases.
Daniel Garrod, Barclays.
A couple of questions.
First, you mentioned about sort of action that you were taking on the realization side to ensure that next year there is a step-up in realizations.

I'm wondering if you could provide any color on that to what degree it is relying on sort of primary markets improving, so obviously in this sort of period, relatively low level of realized profits and realizations overall.

Is it just down to sort of vintage of the portfolio that it's that much more optimal to divest next year? Second question, minimal sort of provisions and impairment go through the unrealized movement this period.
How sort of sustainable do you feel that is? Has -- you touched on this implementation of the dashboard.

Has that helped in any way achieve that, or is it coincidence -- have you achieved that? You've actually -- productive how the portfolio's been performing, you had minimal provisions and impairments, do you see it contributing to lower provision impairments going forward, or is just the dashboard that will contribute to earlier recognition? I think it's a metric that's sort of -- it's a bit meaningless, if you are a cash investor in the business.
So I place less emphasis on it than perhaps you do.
But we'll be more explicit about the way to judge us in May.
Any more questions? Okay.
Well, I'd like to wrap it up.
Thanks for your attendance and mingle at the end if you want to ask anything in private.
But I guess, I suspect the market will continue to the extent that they value price to book, they'll look at your return on equity versus your cost of equity.
So what do you mean on managed -- fully focus on that internally.

Did you think that -- I mean you recognized that it will be quite an important output in terms of way your valuations get to, or do you think that's the wrong metric? Actually, if you split our multiple movement, sort of our first quarter, second quarter, there was more of an uptick in the multiples in the second quarter.
So nothing consistent with the Q3 movement that market has honed in on.
But if you do look at the multiple movement for the 6 months as a whole, actually markets have been pretty flat over that period of time.
We do spend quite less time trying to go through those comparative sets relating to the sets of geographies that we're in.
And I feel pretty comfortable it's pretty much in line.
Okay, I think everyone's through.
Good morning, everyone, and welcome to 3i's results presentation.
For most of the last 10 years, 3i had relied on using part of the firm's capital gains from investment sales to pay for a significant part of the group's annual running costs.
While that was workable in the buoyant years of the Mid-Northeast, that approach never made any real financial sense.

And in recent years, using capital gains to fund our operating costs has led to a hollowing out of the firm's capital, because high operating costs and interest costs have made a very poor capital returns performance even worse at the bottom line.
We've had a busy 6 months restructuring the group and reversing this approach, as well as introducing a number of new asset management initiatives across our Private Equity business.
The journey has just begun, but we've made a strong start in some tough macroeconomic conditions.
And today, I'd like to give you an update on our progress on that redirected journey.
I'd also like to reinforce my confidence in the next steps we're taking on the road to recovery.
Our strategic goal hasn't changed.
We remain focused on managing third party and proprietary capital across our 3 investment platforms.
Our target is to deliver top quartile returns.
And while each business is at a different point in its development and faces different specific challenges, our vision and our strategy are clear.
3i had stumbled badly over the past few years, and there was a fair degree of confusion and doubt in the organization when I arrived late last year.

Not only was there an incoherence between what the group was trying to do and what it could afford to do, but the investment record in Private Equity was suffering badly from a very mixed portfolio of investments made at the top of the cycling calendar, years 2007 and 2008.

The group was also struggling with the challenge of managing a decentralized organization, that had investment teams spread across a lot of different geographies and the lack of control and consistency which that produced.
Putting this right is no quick fix and delivering our strategic goal will take some time.

But putting our house in order, realizing our existing portfolio of Private Equity investments and recovering our reputation in investment and asset management should deliver significant rewards for shareholders in the coming years.
Before I take you through our actions over the last few months, I'd like to remind you of my assessment of 3i's underperformance, which I set out in June.
3i had spread its resources too thinly and created a very broad international platform, encompassing many different investment teams.
There was little central control, and results suffered from a high level of inconsistency.

The Private Equity portfolio was, in many cases, not managed as closely or as actively as they should have been and suffered from that material overinvestment in 2007 and 2008 at the very top of the cycle.
3i had lots of different controls and limits, but it had no annual vintage limit on its own balance sheet investments.
In other words, there was no cap on how much the investment teams could invest each year.
We have now put in place an annual vintage control policy.
It not only includes limits on the amount we invest from our balance sheet in a given year, but its also used in conjunction with our annual budgeting process.
And we review it quarterly in the Executive Committee.
And as I said earlier, operating costs were far greater than the group's annual cash income that we generate from management fees and the portfolio itself.
The group did not appear to me to be operating as a normal commercial business and seemed to lack the very disciplines it routinely demanded of its investing companies.
So my priorities for this financial year are to restructure the business and bring a much greater degree of control and focus to our asset management activities.
I want us to work at the same levels of consistency and discipline as the best organizations in our sector.
We have individuals and individual teams that do exactly that, but we don't do it consistently across the group.
The restructuring of the business is on track.
We've already reduced headcount by over 100 people, and we're on track to meet our target reduction of 160 by the end of this financial year.
And we've closed 5 offices.
And with the sale of Birmingham that will complete in January, we will have met our target of 6 office closures.
We're also well on the way to achieving run rate operating cost savings of GBP 40 million by March next year.
That's against our baseline annualized run rate operating cost of GBP 185 million at March this year.
In June, we also announced 6 asset management improvement initiatives which had been developed with our Private Equity teams during my 6 months as 3i CIO.
That program of initiatives has been substantially implemented and will have a significant positive impact on the performance of our portfolio over the coming years.
You will recall that they involve changes to our investment review process and exit strategy and planning, as well as a review of our people strategy in terms of governance and resourcing.
The next slide illustrates one of these 6 initiatives, a subject I call the dashboard.
When I joined 3i in October last year, I was concerned that the number of instances where the group only seemed to recognize serious performance issues in investee companies very late in the day.
I was also surprised that the infrequent flow of realtime financial information on key portfolio of companies to the senior executives of the group.
Again, I felt the group fell somewhere short of best practice in the Private Equity sector, and that could only be partially explained by the size and breadth of the portfolio at 3i.
So using some of my prior experience, I instigated a project with the Private Equity team to bring our monitoring and performance tracking up to best in class.
We brought in Bain & Company and together, we designed a dashboard for each of our material Private Equity investments.
The dashboard focused on strategic financial and operational KPIs, as well as presenting relevant commentary on the specific company and its performance.
It also gave an assessment of its cash flow and its debt position.
Each dashboard is now produced within 3 weeks of monthly management accounts and sent around in an email to the Investment Committee and the senior partners in our Private Equity business.

There is then a review meeting where we look of the portfolio's performance once a month, and it's now very easy to use the KPI information to set the agenda for that meeting so that we focus on the companies with performance issues.
We then agree the actions to take and review the follow-up at the next meeting.
In my view, this initiative is transforming the effectiveness of 3i's monitoring and performance tracking so that we now have a system which is timely and truly best in class.
It's been a busy and stretching 6 months for everyone at 3i.
It's been tough on those people who have been asked to leave, but it's also been very tough on those people who have stayed.
And all of this has been happening against the backdrop of some very unhelpful macroeconomic conditions.
I'm confident we will deliver both the restructuring I've been talking about, as well as the asset management initiatives that will lift our investment performance in due course.
So in my view, it's time for us to focus on the next part of our recovery plan, transition and delivery.
The transition and delivery will span financial years ending in March 2014 and March 2015.
And we'll focus on aligning our operating costs to our income.
It will also include a hard look at our capital allocation and the growth in third-party fee income.
The aggressive restructuring steps we are taking this year and next are part of an overall plan to bring our operating costs below our cash income on an annual basis.
We are doing this at a time when our third party private fee -- Private Equity fee income is reducing, as the funds themselves run off.
But it's also a time when we are seeing opportunities for growth in third-party fee income from Debt Management and from Infrastructure.
Our goal will be to have a healthy surplus each year.
You will all be familiar with this slide, which I used in June.
It shows in concept where we are moving to as a result of our actions and our cost in our reduction in gross debt levels.
And it highlights the significant potential we have for increasing shareholder distributions, as well as reinvestment in our business.
This summer, we launched a review of compensation across the group.
Compensation is our largest cost at around 60% of total annual operating costs and was not part of the cost reduction program we announced in June.
Compensation will be a key tool in delivering our new strategic objectives.
And we've got to be absolutely sure that there is a fair balance of returns between employees and shareholders.
We've adopted some key principles as part of that review.
An equitable split of returns between employees and shareholders.
And we acknowledge that due to performance issues, we haven't always have that balance over the last few years.
We plan to align compensation with our strategic objectives and make sure these objectives have an important influence on variable compensation, in particular.
Merits will play a more prominent role in variable compensation decisions, which will have a much greater spread from top to bottom than they have had in the past at 3i.
And we'll make sure there is a clear link between overall compensation and shareholder returns.

That will mean that a greater proportion of our senior staff compensation will be in deferred shares to increase alignment with shareholders and the concept of ownership across the key managers in the group.
We plan to involve shareholders in this group-wide review and use the meetings following these results to gain feedback on these key compensation principles.

Early next year, the board intends to enter a formal shareholder consultation period led by Jonathan Asquith, the Chairman of our Remuneration Committee, with a view to seeking any necessary approvals at next summer's AGM.
That way, these changes will be locked in for our next financial year.
Turning to the subject of third-party fee income, I'd like to start with Infrastructure.
We have a very strong capability in Infrastructure investing, and we see good opportunities to grow both assets under management and third-party fee income over the coming years.
We believe there will be increasing opportunities for private investment in government-related assets, as government finances become even more challenged.
And we expect to see opportunities to take over management contracts of some existing Infrastructure funds.
Turning to Debt Management.
The team have enjoyed a busy and successful start to this financial year.
Not only has Jeremy Ghose's team acquired management contracts in Europe from Invesco and set up a U.
platform with Fraser Sullivan, but they've also successfully launched their first 3i CLO fund in the U.
, adding $450 million of funds under management.
Again, like with Infrastructure, we believe that Debt Management is capable of good growth in third-party fee income in AUM over the medium term.
Fraser Sullivan has an excellent reputation in the U.
debt markets, and they are well placed to take advantage of the confident market conditions in the U.
to grow their core CLO business.
They should also be able to develop into adjacent debt markets.
There may also be further bolt-on acquisition opportunities in the U.
, opportunities to accelerate our development of third-party fee income and to grow the AUM further.
However, the debt market in Europe remains fairly muted.
We need to continue to manage our existing funds effectively, as well as focusing on those products and capabilities that will position us well as the European market dynamics change.
This could take a number of routes as the banks pull back.

In terms of Private Equity over the last 6 months, realization levels and investment activity have been low, not least because of the acquired M&A markets and the continuing tricky macro conditions across Europe.
However, we've made some good realizations in the first half, including Esmalglass in Spain, and we exited EUSA Pharma from our noncore Private Equity portfolio.
In today's world, investment is not just about buying a strong business and loading it up with leverage.
Our investment thesis invariably involves a growth or turnaround transformation, which can involve significant operational change.
And this is the most challenging part of our investment plans.
Things rarely stay right on plan.
They almost always move off either up or down.
When they move the wrong way off plan, we have to move quickly to right the situation, and we now have a much better monitoring tool to do that.
OneMed and GEKA have moved off plan in recent times, and we now focus on returning both of these to a better trajectory.
But it swings in roundabouts, an action, for example, which is our biggest Private Equity investment, has moved ahead far more quickly than we anticipated.
And in these sorts of cases, we've got to remain vigilant to make sure our plan and our management are ambitious enough.
We have a number of specific strategic priorities to keep us fully occupied over the next 18 months and you'll be able to judge our performance against these priorities.
In particular, you'll be able to observe an increased level of realization activity from our Private Equity portfolio.
In turn, that will lead to enhanced shareholder distributions.
We've already set in train preparations which will underpin this realization activity.
And as I said earlier, this is a journey covering 3 distinct phases, and it's important to me that we increase transparency so that you can track our progress.

So in addition to the specific targets that we set out in June, we will be providing more detail on our cash income and our run rate operating costs from March next year, as well as further disclosure on all realizations, including cash profit and cash-on-cash multiples for each realization.
You know the shape of 3i today, but this is how we expect to see the group evolve over the medium term.
Clearly, as I've said, we'll have an emphasis on growth in third-party funds and fee income in both Infrastructure and Debt Management.
Proprietary capital will continue to play a significant role in our Private Equity business, but we'll be deploying more of our shareholders' funds in our 2 less cyclical divisions.
In time, we've got to change the way the market looks at 3i.
We sit somewhere between the large-scale asset managers in the U.
, such as Blackstone and KKR and the investment trust of H -- SVG and HgCapital.

As we complete our restructuring, our objective is that the market not only values our portfolio of investments, but also values the profits we generate, especially as fund managers across our 3 investment platforms.
I'd now like to pass to Julia, who will take you through our interim results.

And then on your question about provisions and  impairments, I think as we talked about in the past, our provision numbers should really be low because we make a provision when we actually have a fear that the investment may fail.
So we will anticipate negative performance through the use of forecast earnings.
So I think it will be a bit premature to find some correlation now between that number and the dashboard.
Having said that, I'm confident that the dashboard will absolutely help our ability to anticipate any issues in the portfolio that need to be dealt with.
And that we usually expect that to flow through the valuations in time.
It's Henry Freeman from Investec Securities.
We read in the press of the weekend about a potential raise in for Private Equity in Brazil.
What is the potential -- obviously, you focused specifically on management businesses in Infrastructure and Debt Management.
But what is the potential for a South American raise? I think there's real potential for our country fund around Brazil.
We've been approached by a number of LPs who've made that inquiry of us.
We have a well-regarded team in Brazil.
We've made our first investment.

We've got a number of other proposals in the pipeline that are being considered at the moment, and it is a much more resilient economy than we see in Europe at the moment across Continental Europe, in particular with pretty strong government finances and a very developing consumer society within the country.
So we're looking hard at that.
We don't anticipate anything developing of that type before the second half of next year, but it will be a serious consideration going into next year.
Henry over here.
Bruce Hamilton, Morgan Stanley.
Three sort of follow-up questions.
Firstly, on the cost.

When you talk about comp, should we read that as a meaning there's a further reduction in cost, or is it really more sort of about alignment and sort of making sure the right people get paid? Secondly, on realizations.
I recognize obviously there are companies now that look like they're ready for sale next financial year.

But I mean would you regard the 15% uplift you just enjoyed as being a sort of a good number for next year, or something that you would be pretty disappointed with, because you can sell assets but what's the price? And then finally, on the return on equity, obviously your previous sort of targets of 15%.
The cost reduction plan, the de-gear of the balance sheet obviously helped, but you're still clearly some way off making your cost of equity.

What do you think is a -- would be a plausible sort of ROE sort of run rate looking 2 years out, when you've got the business back to towards its sort of full run rate? Thank you, Simon, and good morning, everyone.
The results we've reported this morning is solid evidence of the progress we're making in the strategic initiatives that Simon has just outlined.
And we've achieved those results against the challenging economic environment in which we all continue to operate.
Fundamental, political, regulatory and financial questions remained unanswered in Europe and beyond.
Equity markets have been up and down during the 6 months.
But in the markets and the sectors where we've operated, they've ended up broadly flat.
M&A activity has been muted.
There have been some signs of improvement more recently, but it will take time for any improvement to have an impact on our activity levels.
And finally, as a sterling investor, currency markets have also proved challenging with weakness in the euro and the rupee being particularly relevant for us.
So against that backdrop, here are our key financials, starting with the returns on our income statement.
The performance for the 6 months reflects a period of considerable change and development in 3i, but we have a degree of stability, returning to the underlying portfolio of performance.

Gross portfolio return of GBP 180 million reflects good realizations in the noncore portfolio in first quarter, better earnings performance in a big part of the Private Equity portfolio compared to last year.
And that GBP 180 million is a marked improvement on the loss of GBP 329 million in the year, 31st of March.
Fees in the period reduced to GBP 36 million, and that reflects the end of the investment period for Eurofund V, our most European buyout bond, but we had another strong period of Debt Management.
Operating costs are GBP 105 million.
That GBP 105 million includes the effect of implementing the changes to the business, which we announced in June.
We estimated then that implementation cost will be about GBP 30 million, and we have provided for GBP 25 million in this period.
We have made tangible progress in the relatively short time since the changes were announced in June.
We are on track to achieve the run rate savings of GBP 40 million that Simon talked about by the end of this financial year.
In a minute, I'll outline the composition of the resulting net portfolio return of GBP 109 million by individual business line.
The total return takes account of the effects of our balance sheet and was a small loss of GBP 5 million compared to a GBP 656 million loss at the 31st of March.
We accounted for the payment of the final dividend when it was paid in July.
And that dividend payment, together with the total return, is rise to an NAV of GBP 2.
73 at the 30th of September.

So how has that NAV progressed during the period? 
Opening NAV of GBP 2.
79 was reduced by 5p for the final dividend.
Implementation costs and the effects of the gross debt reduction gave rise to further reductions of 3p and 2p, respectively.
Noncash FX, pension and other items was 6p.
As a result, underlying business performance contributed a 10p improvement.
So we closed an NAV of GBP 2.
Now I'd like to talk about that underlying business performance in some more detail.
Each of our Infrastructure, Debt Management and Private Equity businesses have contributed to the total net portfolio return of GBP 109 million as you can see here.
The sharp eyed amongst you will notice that the 3 business lines don't actually add up to the total.
The difference is our noncore portfolio, and it's not usually so material.

But in this period, the sale of EUSA Pharma, which is a former bench capital asset, generated cash proceeds of GBP 72 million, an uplift of GBP 42 million over the opening book value and a money multiple of 2.
That's an excellent result, but I don't expect it to be repeated by the noncore business, which now accounts for only 2% of the portfolio.
As you've seen from Simon's presentation, we've made good progress on implementing changes we announced in June to reduce the complexity of the group and cut our cost base.
Simon just said we announced 160 people would be leaving the business by the end of this financial year.
Headcount at the end of the period was down by 104, so we remain on track to meet our run rate target in reducing cost by GBP 40 million as we start the next financial year.
And as you can expect to discuss for the next -- for this year to be about the same level as last year, so we're talking about GBP 180 million.
All these figures are before adjusting for Debt Management acquisitions in the period, but those incremental costs are more than covered by the fees the new businesses will generate.
So taking each principal business line in turn.
Our Infrastructure team manages GBP 1.
6 billion of assets under management, 30% of that or GBP 471 million is on 3i's balance sheet, so the contribution that we get is generated by a blend of capital returns and fees net of cost.
The business has had another solid period, supported by the robust performance of its European portfolio.
However, this solid performance was offset by the performance of the Indian portfolio, where the political, currency and sector conditions are more challenging.

In group terms, this performance translates into an increase of GBP 6 million in the value of our 34% share of 3i Infrastructure plc, unrealized value decreases of GBP 8 million in the Indian portfolio and dividend income of GBP 9 million.
During the period, the group sold its investments in Lakeside Network.
We had invested alongside 3i Infrastructure last year to facilitate the completion of the deal.
And by the way, that's a good example of the benefit our permanent capital brings.
So now we sold our position at a gain, GBP 1 million gain, over the opening portfolio value.
Our Debt Management business is capital light, but it's an important fee generator for the group.
It has performed well again, with fees from the original European business remaining ahead of plan, and they are now being supplemented by fees from the funds that we acquired from Invesco in August.
We have further increased assets under management by our strategic partnership with Fraser Sullivan, which you heard about from Simon.
The return impacts of this last transaction is actually minimal in this period because the deal was only signed on the 28th of September.
Private Equity remains the most important contributor to our performance.
Today, it accounts for 80% of our portfolio and 47% of total assets under management, and that's why progress we have made on the asset management's initiatives outlined by Simon, are so critical.
Before going through the detail of the related gross portfolio return, I'd like to comment briefly on other aspects of the business' performance.
Fees have stepped down in the first half.
Eurofund V's investment period ended in November 2011, just a year ago, and fees in our paid on invested capital rather than committed capital.
The operating expenses is GBP 73 million, include GBP 22 million of the GBP 25 million implementation costs.
Investments of GBP 131 million is lower than last year.
It includes the completions of GEKA, the final reinvestments in Eurofund V and Blue Interactive, the first investment made by our Brazil team.
The M&A market has been quiet through most of the period, and we have stayed cautious about new investment in Europe.
We generated realization proceeds of GBP 165 million as an uplift over opening value of 15.
4%, and that represents an aggregate money multiple of 1.
9x, generating realized profits of GBP 22 million.
We've given much more detail about realizations during the period in our announcement today, and in the appendix to the slides.
In Private Equity, it is worth noting the disposal of Esmalglass, the Spanish investment was sold at a small uplift over the March value and at a money multiple of 1.
The Spanish portfolio now accounts for just 5% of the group's total.
The next slide gives you a picture of the diversity of the Private Equity portfolio.
From a geographic perspective, our strongest performers continue to be in Northern Europe and the Americas.
Those regions make up 58% of the portfolio and have generated GBP 52 million of value growth in the period.
There are small number of assets in Europe which are more challenging, and we're cautious about the outlook for the French portfolio.
The French portfolio is now valued at GBP 216 million or 7% of the total.
The more recent vintages now account for 30% of the total portfolio.
Performance is not uniformly positive, but it's in those vintages from 2010 onwards that we've seen some very positive earnings growth with corresponding uplifts in value in the period.
The 2007 to 2009 vintages were more stable in this period.
They're accounting for 66% of the portfolio and generating a value increase of GBP 53 million.

Now in the past, we've provided additional disclosure to give you a view on the trajectory of portfolio performance, taking accounts of commercial considerations and confidentiality obligations, and it's fair to say, with varying degrees of success.
This slide gives an indicator performance on an aggregate basis by comparing earnings performance versus the prior year.
Blue line shows you the percentage by number of companies.
You have better earnings performance than last year.
So for the portfolio at 30th of September, just over 55% of companies are better, and they account for 70% of the value, and that's a steady performance since March.
Breaking this picture down to a company level, this slide gives an indication of the performance of our largest assets.
This is a positive picture, with a significant majority performance ahead of last year.
And you'll see from the additional information in the announcement, 35% of companies had growth of more than 10%; 24% of companies generated growth of more than 20%.
So overall, the performance of the portfolio is better than it has been in our most recent periods.
And that improved portfolio performance is reflected in the valuations in the first half.
As I mentioned earlier, even though equity markets have been volatile, they actually finished broadly flat in the period.
And the multiples used to value the portfolio were also similarly flat, increasing by only 1%.
For this reporting period, we typically use the last 12 months accounts to June as a basis of valuation, but we use forecast earnings if they're lower than the last 12 months to June.
And 16 companies, 27%, were valued using current year forecast earnings.
Aggregate earnings used to value the portfolio, including those on forecast, grew by 1%.
But on a valuated basis, earnings used to value the portfolio, grew by 9%.
And as you might expect, the leverage in the portfolio valid using earnings fell to 3.
3x net debt to EBITDA multiple.
That was thanks to this better performance.
So bringing these data points together into the makeup of the unrealized value movement to GBP 66 million, you can see that the most material component relates to performance.
The positive but small movements of GBP 4 million in provisions is the net effect of 3 companies, each movements being less than GBP 10 million.
And so that's not indicative of the wider trend.
Finally, the industry metric category includes ACR, our Asian reinsurance business, which continues to be impacted by the effects of the Thai floods at the end of 2011.
Turning then to the balance sheet, and in particular to the gross debt reduction and the capital allocation model that Simon talked about earlier.
Key part of the strategic review we've just completed was to reduce the gross debt by using our cash resources.
We have been reducing gross  debt since its peak of GBP 2.
7 billion in March 2009, but it's the simplification of the business model and more direct central control that mean we can take the next significant step.
We started the year with GBP 1.
6 billion of gross debt and sets target to reduce its GBP 1.
3 billion by the 30th of September and then reduce it further to GBP 1 billion by June 2013.
Gross debt at the end of the period was GBP 1.
2 billion, so we are ahead of our intermediate target.
We've done that through a combination of scheduled maturities, but also by being opportunistic in making some early repayments.
Gross interest for the period of GBP 60 million includes GBP 20 million of accelerated interest costs.

I expect that the full year charge will be marginally less than last financial year and importantly, that the run rate of net interest payable at the start of next year will be nearer to GBP 60 million for the full year.
So we are ahead of our original plan, and I am confident that we're on track to meet the GBP 1 billion target by June 2013.
This is particularly important.
It's not only important because of the impact on the run rate of interest, but also because of its link to our capital allocation and distribution policy.

The target capital allocation framework that we set out in June, which Simon has just restated, means we will deploy more of our capital to shareholder distribution and to investment in our core businesses over time.
The quality of realizations in the period has been good but, as we had expected, lower in absolute terms than in prior years.
That reduction and realizations, together with a significant progress we're making to reduce gross debt, means there was a net cash outflow of GBP 390 million in the period.
Of course, repayments of gross debt has no impact on net debt or gearing.
Net debt increased only marginally from GBP 464 million to GBP 493 million and gearing went from 18% to 19%.
That's another important factor in our capital distribution policy.
To remind you what we set out in May.
We rebased our dividend to 8.
1p per share this time last year.

And we defined the basis of aggregate shareholders distributions as 15% to 20% of gross cash proceeds from realizations, provided that gearing is less than 20%, and that we're on target to have gross debt less than GBP 1 billion by June 2013.
We also indicated that realizations were likely to be lower in this financial year, and the first half performance is consistent with that lower forecast.
Therefore it's still the case, but it will be next financial year before you should expect any meaningful increase in shareholder distribution.
1p levels set last year should be seen as a base for the dividend.
So we announced today an interim dividend of 2.
7p per share, with an intention to pay 8.
1p per share as the total dividend for the year.
So before I hand back to Simon to wrap up, I'll just quickly summarize the results for the 6 months of 30th of September, 2012.
This has been a period of very considerable change, a lot of which is reflected in the numbers and some of which will take longer to prove its potential.
We've made good progress in restructuring the business, and we've seen a degree of stability in the underlying performance of the portfolio.

The total return loss of GBP 5 million reflects its better performance from our Private Equity portfolio and steady contributions from Infrastructure and Debt Management, as well as the cost of restructuring.
The balance sheet remains strong, and the progress that we've made in reducing gross debt will improve returns and cash flow from next year.
All of this has created a leaner business and prepares us for increased shareholder distributions as the level of our realizations improved.
I'll now hand back to Simon.

Yes, and although you had quite a high proportion of forward earnings you were using, presumably quite a low proportion of the valuation based on those forward earnings? Well, I think, as Simon has just said, we are reasonably cautious about the European environment.
By using the forecast earnings, we're trying to anticipate some of that, but we're not taking any further forward in the end of September.
So we will all have to see how the European environment develops over the turn of the calendar year.
I think on the portfolio review, I'm comfortable with where the thing is valued.
You've seen from the realization total in the release today that we've effectively made realizations of -- ahead of the marks we had in our book.
There are a good spread of companies.
I guess the concerning thing is that the overwhelming majority of the investment is in Europe.
We see 2013 being pretty tricky in Europe for all sorts of reasons, and that would affect some of the Northern European countries, and the country we are worried about is France.
So we will see some headwinds in that regard.

But in general, we're very comfortable with the general state of the portfolio, but of the well-known problem that you all know about -- but apart from that, the bulk of the value is really in some pretty good companies.
Thank you, Adrian and good morning, everybody.

As I take you through the financial results of the group for the year ended 31st of March 2012, there are 3 key areas that I want to focus on: the performance of our portfolio and how it is developed through the year, the progress we have made regarding our operating cost base and the priority we have given to managing our balance sheet and our ability, as a consequence, to enhance direct returns to shareholders.
A quick summary first of the key financials for the year before moving to the aspects and return detailed.
Gross portfolio return of minus 8.

2% on opening portfolio value is driven by lower-than-normal realized profits, valuation write-downs reflecting lower multiples, some underperformance in the portfolio and a net fall in the portfolio.

Our model has seen dilution from gross portfolio return to net portfolio return as a result of our net operating costs, and I'll need the next slide to talk through how each of our business lines have performed.
When growth returns are below our target levels, there is no gearing benefit from net debt.
And so the total return of minus 19.
5% reflects the dilution of our net interest cost.
It also reflects the impact of the pension fund valuation, which we settled at the half year.
In keeping with the distribution policy we announced in November, the board has confirmed its intention to pay a final dividend of 5.
4p per share subject to shareholder approval, making a total dividend for the year of 8.
1p per share and a cash cost of GBP 75 million.
I will comment on the evolution of our distribution policy later in this presentation.
Our assets under management have reduced in the year Clearly, realizations contributed to this.

However, the more material factor is the effect of the end of Eurofund V investment period when we switched from including the total commitment to the amount invested, and this is offset somewhat by new funds in Debt Management.
Finally, we remain selective with new investments, and I'm pleased to say that investments we've made in recent vintages are showing good performance overall.
And realizations of GBP 771 million provide real evidence of the the strength of our portfolio.
The money multiple of the 10 most material transactions averaged 2.
As I set out in the half year, we've enhanced our disclosure to include net portfolio return by business line.
79% of our balance sheet is invested in the private equity portfolio, and so the performance of that business line is dominated by the gross portfolio returns.
I'll be talking shortly in more detail about the drivers of the GBP 339 million negative return in the year and operating costs more generally.
Our infrastructure business continues to perform well.

The gross portfolio return of GBP 11 million includes an increase of GBP 22 million in the value of our 34% holding in 3i Infrastructure plc as well as GBP 18 million of dividends received on our stake.

As Cressida Hogg explained in detail when announcing the results of 3i last week, strong performance in its European investments have been offset by reduction in the valuation of our investments, which we hold for the India Infrastructure Fund.
This is principally due to currency and specifically the share price performance of the power.
However, the operational performance of the Indian portfolio is in line with expectations.
Importantly from the 3i group perspective, the gross returns from 3iN are enhanced with fee income of GBP 25 million resulting in a 2.
8% return over opening book value.

Group investments in infrastructure included GBP 33 million in the exercise of 3iN's warrants, and it also included GBP 28 million of balance sheet investments in LIN and Nordic electricity and heating distribution network business, which we made alongside 3iN.
Debt Management is our newest business line and performance since the acquisition of the business 12 months ago has been very strong.
The results here reflect the fact that this business line is in development.
So last year's return benefited from the realization at the original debt warehouse.
And when you look at the net portfolio return of the business, it's worth noting that carry on cost lines include GBP 6 million of acquisition accounting adjustments.
Excluding these, the underlying return is GBP 9 million, somewhat better than presented here.
But most significantly, dynamic investment management has meant that fees have accrued more quickly than we had planned.
And as a consequence, cash generated by the business has already covered the original acquisition costs.
continues to look at growth opportunities for the business to provide further fee income and return to the group.
Returning then to the 3 most significant elements of our returns in more detail, namely: portfolio performance, operating costs and the return of our conservative balance sheet strategy.
I want to take you through the performance the portfolio as a whole and then how that's reflected in our valuation.

At the highest level and not surprisingly, our portfolio performance reflects the markets and the macroenvironment in which it operates and the prevailing market conditions that existed when investments were made.
In the private equity portfolio, which accounts for 79% of the total, we have seen strong growth in Northern Europe and the U.
, which is where we have targeted investments made since 2009.
Northern Europe has provided our strongest realizations in the year.
Conversely, we have seen in Spain, the U.
and more recently France, which has impacted performance in the year, and Simon will talk through these aspects in more detail later.
As you'd expect, our infrastructure portfolio has been much less impacted by European macroissues and the portfolio continues to perform well.
As a result, materially all of the reduction in portfolio value is attributable to the private equity business and within that, 2/3 relates to the U.
Spanish and French assets.
In current while we have taken the opportunity to realize investments, we have achieved a good money multiple, 2.
9x on the largest 10 sales, 7 of which were based in Northern Europe.

To give you some quantification then of overall performance, we have seen earnings growth in the portfolio of 9% in the 12 months December 2011 on a value weighted basis, and you can see here how that's spread across the portfolio.
By value, 80% of the portfolio grew its earning and 42% by more than 10% in the year.
The last 2 vintages have performed better than average with value weighted earnings growth of 20% in the year.
Now it's clear from discussions with shareholders and analysts that there is a strong desire for greater deal -- detail on the performance of individual portfolio companies and as a whole.
We have to balance this appetite with our confidentiality obligations to the private companies in which we invest and take account of disclosure restrictions imposed on minority investment positions.
So we're therefore providing some new disclosure in the appendix of this presentation at the individual company level for the top 25 assets, but on an anonymous basis.
These assets account for 66% of the whole portfolio value.
We have provided you revenue data to give a sense of scale and earnings growth data to demonstrate momentum.
I'm sure you'll want to look at these later in detail.
But it shows for example that of the top 25, 20 grew earnings in the year and 9 by more than 10%.
So let me now turn to how that performance is reflected in the valuations in the 31st of March.
At the 31st of March, the earnings used in our valuations typically are based on the management accounts of companies to the 31st of December.
However, where we expect future earnings to be lower than those in December -- the December 2011 management accounts, we use the forecast earnings.
We have used forecast earnings for only 8% of companies in the portfolio at March.
This is an improvement in the position at the 30th of September when 23% of companies was valued on this basis and 31st of March 2011 when the number was 12%.
Of course, multiples are the other significant driver of valuations.
The weighted average EBITDA multiple was 7% lower in the year.
Although the market was volatile in the year, equivalent sectors and geographies follow the net basis by about the same amount.
However, in a number of cases particularly in geographies with more challenging economic conditions, we have also reduced the multiple to a greater degree than the comparable set.
And as result, the weighted average EBITDA multiple for the portfolio valued on an earnings basis was 8.
2x pre-discount and 7.
So the effect of that underlying earnings and multiple movement can be seen here in the earnings multiples and impairment lines.
To be clear, impairments are simply the impact of earnings-based valuation on the debt elements in our capitals structure.
Other factors to note include provisions of GBP 138 million, which relates to 6 companies across a range of geographies and sectors.
2 of the 6 are in Spain, with one significant provision of GBP 83 million relating to Hess, our renewable power service provider.
About half of this write-down on Hess has been recognized at the half year.

The value of the portfolio fell by 20 million in total, but includes the increase of 3iN of GBP 22 million offset by reductions in our investments in Power, which is post the Indian infrastructure portfolio and Capital, a U.
growth capital investment which last year.
The most significant item in the industry metric category relates to our investment in ACR, the Singaporean-based Asian reinsurance business.
This is heavily impacted by the Thai floods at the end of calendar 2011, and this led to value movements of GBP 29 million.
Finally, it's worth noting spread across the categories is GBP 47 million of value movement relating to dividends in the portfolio, and these are included elsewhere in returns as income.
Looking then to the effect of these unrealized value movements have had on the balance sheet value.

We started the year with the portfolio value of GBP 4 billion, new investments of GBP 374 million in the year in 9 companies, further investments of GBP 109 million in the existing portfolio and capitalized interest increased the portfolio by GBP 646 million.
The body of assets sold was GBP 748 million, and the unrealized value movement that I've just been talking about reduced the portfolio by GBP 498 million.
As you know, we partially hedge currency movements, and a weakening of the euro and rupee in particular in the year gave rise to a net FX loss of GBP 49 million in our total return.
The gross impact in the portfolio is a GBP 101 million movement that you can see here.
At the end of the year, we had a portfolio of GBP 3.
2 billion, 79% of which relates to the private equity portfolio.
Of the private equity portfolio by vintage, the proportion of the portfolio relating to investments made after 2009 has now increased from 10% to 28%.
69% is focused on Northern Europe, U.
and Asia where the macro environment is more positive.
And within Southern Europe, the proportion of the private equity portfolio in Spain is now only 7%, down from 11% last year.
At the half year announcement in November, we detailed each business lines' net portfolio return for the first time, allowing visibility across our key business measure.

We announced in March that to provide more transparency regarding the performance of the business, particularly against the volatile market backdrop, we will provide a quarterly NAV update, which will start in July for the quarter ending the 30th of June.
And today, we have included our presentation a press release for the new disclosure that seeks to provide more comprehensive detail and information about our key portfolio companies.

In addition to that as I've already talked about, we are also providing additional commentary regarding our top 10 assets, which account for 43% of the portfolio, to make clear our investment strategy and view on current performance.
Further information regarding earnings growth, net debt levels and refinancing across the portfolio as a multiple of original cost achieved in our largest 10 assets in the period.
We believe that this increased level of disclosure will allow shareholders to be more able -- to more clearly track and understand our progress.
The second area I want to focus on today is costs.

There's been considerable commentary about the operating costs base in recent months, and so I want to give you some more detail on costs, what has been achieved to date in reducing them and what is planned in the next 12 months.
As you can see from this chart, we have made significant progress in reducing our cost base.
The peak run rate during the year ended the 31st of March 2008 was GBP 290 million with 788 people.
By the 31st of March 2012, operating costs are 38% lower and GBP 180 million and headcount has reduced to 435.
And this reduction is despite the addition of 30 people in the Debt Management business and 8 people in Brazil.
In November 2011, we announced the changes to our private equity team and indicated that we expected as result to reduce costs by at least GBP 15 million.

Since completing those changes and taking account the consequent changes to support services and property requirements, we expect the annualized benefit of these measures to be GBP 25 million in 2012.
Finally, the third area I said I'll focus on today is the effect of the conservative balance sheet management strategy on our total return.
