Infrastructure continues to make an important contribution to our annual cash operating profit, as does Debt Management's growth in AUM.
So taking Infrastructure first.
Stable fee income and reduced operating cost base have improved the operational performance of the Infrastructure business.
The European portfolio has supported good performance at 3i Infrastructure plc, and our 34% holding has provided portfolio income of GBP 11 million in the period.

I've talked about the currency effect of the Indian rupee, but the Indian Infrastructure Fund asset valuations also reflects some specific operational and financing issues, and the group's direct holding in the India fund gave rise to a net unrealized value reduction of GBP 24 million.
Our recently completed platform acquisition is an important development, and it will increase AUM by a further GBP 780 million and be added to the GBP 1.
5 billion seen here.
The combined team will be even better placed for fundraising.
Almost all of the capital invested by the group in the first half has been to support the development of the Debt Management business.
The team launched Harvest VII, which is their first new European CLO issued since the inception of the business in 3i, and momentum continues with 3i providing capital for U.
and European warehouses in the expectation of more CLOs to come.
This, together with the Fraser Sullivan acquisition last year, has resulted in an increase of more than 40% of AUM in the last 12 months.
This business supports the improvements in our annual cash operating profit, and it has delivered a net return of 12.
5% in the period before GBP 8 million of acquisition accounting adjustments.
Simon has said the Private Equity business drives the proprietary capital returns.
Strong realizations of GBP 528 million at an uplift of 32% over March 2013 values, and an average cash-to-cash money multiple of 1.
6x show you the improving quality of the portfolio and, of course, supports our dividend policy.

Investments in the period was low with no new investments, but the pipeline is much stronger and our recently announced investments in GIF, JMJ and Scandlines are positive developments, accounting for about GBP 185 million of 3i's capital.

I'm now going to take you through portfolio and valuations, but it is also worth noting that a significant contribution to the marked improvement in net return shown here is also the reduction in the cost base.
We look at the Private Equity portfolio by region, by sector and by vintage.
The strong performance of the post-2010 investments has also improved the diversity of the vintage exposure, and we've realized a significant number of assets from earlier years.
So another key development in the makeup of the portfolio is the number of assets.
We have said we'd like to reduce that overall number, and we've successfully reduced the number of assets in the Private Equity portfolio by 15 in the period from 102 to 87.
The top 25 now represent over 75% of the value.
And you can see that most of these continue to show a positive performance trajectory.
In turn, that underpins stability in valuations.
Now there has been plenty of discussion about some of our largest assets like Action and Element, but it's also worth noting the improvement in performance of GEKA, a 2013 vintage investment.
GEKA has been the subject of lots of focus in the monthly dashboard meetings and the value recovery is now almost back to cost.
Across the whole Private Equity portfolio, the majority of our investments, by value and by number, are growing their earnings, as you can see here.
In fact, the strength of our larger assets has supported value weighted last 12-months earnings growth of 15%.

You can also see indicators of better stability across the portfolio in a number of metrics here: increased earnings, especially in our larger assets; fewer companies valued using forecast earnings; a modest increase in leverage caused in part by the refinancing of Action; and the increase in multiples also reflects increased confidence in the portfolio performance.
In recent periods, some multiples have been held flat against increasing comparable sets.
In this quarter, improved performance in a small number of companies has meant we've lifted that cap to set a multiple that's more in line with the market.
And you can see the effect of that here in the multiple movements of GBP 78 million.
Positive markets have also helped the quarter portfolio, with increases in value in the U.
-listed investments, Quintiles and GAIN in particular.
The negative movement of GBP 11 million in the DCF category relates principally to Indian assets.

And the GBP 13 million loss on movement to imminent sale is on a small number of minority Private Equity assets that are facing performance challenges, with the largest component relating to the Asian portfolio.
But overall, this is a solid performance, with no new provisions and good progression in earnings.
And of course, the valuations are underpinned by the strong uplifts to value in realizations that we've achieved in the period.
So before closing, I just wanted to deal with some more detailed points about the dividends that we declared today.
We have said we intend to pay 20p in total for the year.
In keeping with our previous convention, we've declared 1/3 of that today, with 2.
7p on account of the base and 4p as a special dividend.
My plan is that we pay the base dividend out of revenue reserves when we can and that any special is paid out of capital, and both dividends will be paid together in January 2014.
So as I said at the start, we have produced another set of financials which provide clear evidence that we're delivering on our strategy successfully.
But it's not just these interim results that I'm pleased with; we have also achieved strong realizations and a stable portfolio performance.
We've made good progress towards achieving an annual operating cash profit, and we now have lower interest costs and no gearing at the period end.
All of these factors have led to the activation of our dividend policy, which is allowing our shareholders to participate very directly in the success of the business.
As Simon said in his opening, the business now has real momentum.
So thank you, and we're now happy to take questions.
I mean, I would just add the observation on hedging is this is an accounting adjustment, not a cash adjustment.
When we get a receipt in from a euro realization, we don't change it into sterling straight away because we know that we're probably going to be banking a euro investment.

So our actual real cash damage from an appreciation in sterling is far more modest than the translation number that appears in the account because we are actively managing our receipts of currencies and how we spend that.
So I wouldn't get too carried away about the translation numbers, the same for dollar receipts.
The trickier element is India, which is a segue into that question.
We have seen significant weakness in the rupee.
The group has an exposure through 3iN and its exposure to India.
Have an exposure directly into the 3i India Infrastructure Fund.
One of the first decisions I took when I became CEO was to turn off the fundraising for the second fund.
I feel very pleased about that decision.
And we also have some small private equity investments in India that were made several years ago.
So we're not committing any new capital to India, whether through the fund or through group directly.
And actually the exposure to India, because of the decline in the rupee, has become increasingly modest.
So let's hope we're getting towards the bottom.
And the one reassurance we have is while the PE investments are not of the highest quality, I would have to say, the Infrastructure investments in the main are a pretty decent portfolio.
So we're just going to work those out in a patient way and hopefully recover our dollar cost over time.
Tom? Well, we haven't talked in detail about it, but they have 2 funds with GBP 780 million under management.
So I would have thought you were talking about 1/3 to 1/2 as an initial foray of that sort of number if we're talking about a fundraise, and that will take place sometime over the next 18 months.
Daniel Garrod from Barclays.
First question on your hedging policy.
Obviously, you highlighted clearly that FX has had a negative impact on this NAV.

Has there been a sort of material over the last sort of 12, 18 months reduction in how much you hedged the exposures? And given sort of expectations of perhaps currency instability remaining for some time, are you convinced that sort of a reduced hedge exposure is the right way to go? Are there any plans to increase it back up again if that was the case? Second question is around sort of India exposures that you've highlighted as well.
You obviously previously signaled no new Infrastructure investments in India.

But could you remind us about what you're exposures, overall, currently stand at in terms of the PE portfolio and the Infrastructure? And what are your sort of plans there? Are there any plans to sort of accelerate exits and reduce that? Yes, yes.
So you will have seen in the numbers that the carry payable for the period is higher than it's been in the past.
And actually, that's a good signal.
We've talked about the improvement in the performance of 2010-plus vintages in particular.
And what we're seeing in the first half is a catch-up of some of our carry schemes payable have gone through some performance hurdles.
So to be clear, when we account for our carry, effectively, what we do is we assume that we have realized the whole portfolio at the current carrying value and then calculate the carry based on that.
It isn't the same as the carry that's actually being paid, because the carry paid actually only delivers when the realizations have actually come through.

But there's an element of catch-up in the carry charge in this first half because the strong performance that you've mentioned, Eurofund V, particularly in those latter vintages has taken some of those schemes through the hurdle.
So the carry payable you'll see going forward is now much more a function of not just the realized profits, but the unrealized value growth as well because that's the accrual that's coming through.
I think on the earnings disclosure I gave you, that's showing you the number of companies and it's also showing you the value attributed to those.

And the ones that have got the poorer performance, the reducing earnings growth, in terms of where does it go from here, there's always got to be the caveat of some performance will be at risk in those sorts of companies.
But the focus that we have on managing these on a regular basis with the monthly dashboard mitigates that to a certain extent.
And the valuation methodology also mitigates it to a certain extent because we will use forecast earnings for the current year earnings if we can see those earnings are going down.
And I showed you on an earlier slide the number of companies that we've got valued on that basis.
So it puts some risk buffer into the valuation that comes from those.
But we still have 87 assets in the Private Equity portfolio.
The top 25 are 75% of the value, but that's quite a long tail at the end, some of the more trickier assets that we're trying to work out.
Chris Brown from JPMorgan Chase.
Just a couple of questions.
The new investments you made post the period end, to what extent were they co-investments or were they all 3i's capital? It was fundraising.
I think what we're planning to do is lift our skirts a bit more in that with the final results.
So it may not be the final, final version, but it will be a lot more than you've received to date at the financial results.
Yes, so actually, the hedging story is quite a long one.
It's actually quite related to the strategy.

So when we decided to reduce gross debt, in effect, that was taking away one of the planks of the hedging strategy because our gross debt -- we tried to get currency debt, which is actually a good tenure match for the portfolio.
Quite a considerable time ago, 3i had many investments and there was a regular turnover of assets, investments and realization flows.
So the idea of using a derivative policy to match that was broadly effective.

As we've come down to smaller numbers of assets and we've taken away the desire to have gross debt, the idea of trying to use a portfolio of derivatives to hedge the assets just ceases to be properly effective.
We've got assets that are being held for 3 to 5 years, and we've got a big focus now on cash.
And the liquidity drain that you can have from running a derivative program can be quite onerous in -- particularly in currency markets that we're seeing at the moment.
So I think the most important strategic point is that we are focused on our cash-to-cash returns from our investments.
So Simon has talked about the 2x target, and that is really what we're focused on.

So these interim accounting valuations that we have don't really go to that and -- but running the risk of having a significant liquidity drain associated with the derivative program seemed to be a risk that wasn't really giving us the right degree of reward.
So it has been particularly volatile in this 6-month period.
We've got the closing assets and derivative program going as well, but I think it's something that we will continue to keep under review.

I think the rule of thumb I've tried to give people, and I give it with a degree of caveat because it's dependent on the makeup of the portfolio and the investment and realization flows, but roughly speaking, a 1% move on the euro is about a GBP 10 million movement, and a 1% movement in the dollar is about GBP 7 million movement.
And that's, roughly, actually where it has ended up in this 6-month period.
I think on retention and talent recruitment, the industry -- the private equity industry in particular is still going through a very significant shakeup.
There are real winners and losers evolving  because of the more difficult fundraising environment.
And there's still a relatively low flow of transactions reflecting the broader M&A market.
I think 3i is not only a survivor in that because of its permanent capital and the contributions that come from group, but it's actually going to be a winner in that.
And I think we now have a portfolio of investments which are beginning to generate significant carry for the investments' executives.
So the investments that have principally been made since the beginning of '11 are a very valuable collection of investments.
That is the time when the current Private Equity team came together.
They have been the author of those investments since then.
So I think they are glued pretty heavily into that set of investments because of the success of them, and that's what drives private equity investors.
So I think we have much less concerns about retention than we did before.
They're also receiving 3i Group shares as part of their variable compensation.
Those shares have been doing very well.
They will get the benefit of dividends that are made on those shares.
So I think they will be rewarded in the same way that the shareholders are rewarded as the capital allocation policy changes.

In terms of new talent, we are beginning to see inbound calls from individuals who are talented, but are perhaps in those firms where there is more of a question mark over their survivability and their future.
So that again is another indication of our status in a changing industry.
So I think if we want to, we'll be in a position to obtain new talent.
I don't see us having many gaps across our core Northern European platform at the moment, it has to be said.
And I don't have any real concerns about losing executives that I want to keep as part of that team.
What was the third point, Philip? I think in terms of -- we're not contemplating any new areas at the moment.
We're sticking to the 3 activities that we have.
In terms of Infrastructure, we're very keen to see a doubling of the scale of that business in terms of funds under management over the planned period.
And we've also set a revenue target for the Debt Management business to get to GBP 50 million of fees in that business over the planned period.
So they're really the 2 targets we have for those businesses.
Tom Mills, KBW.

Using the Barclays Infrastructure team as a platform to grow you Infrastructure assets, what should we be thinking about in terms of the size of a potential raise if you were to do on -- is there any kind of guidance you can give us on that? Have you got a mic? It's Philip Middleton at Merrill.
I just wonder if you could say quickly -- you've obviously tied it up a lot about the costs in the balance sheet and such that, which has been tremendous hard work.
Going forward, returns will be driven by the investment teams and your ability to grow and nurture those.
I wonder if you could say a little bit about talent retention and recruitment, and also a bit about how you see the prospects for third-party fundraisings over the next couple of years.
Well, I suggest Julia take the hedging question, and I'll make some comments about India.
And the other question is, is when will you intend to sort of split out the profitability of the aforementioned business? Good morning, everyone.
Sorry to pull the blinds down and stop you looking at the window, but we do want your attention on the presentation.
Welcome to 3i's interim results.
We've had a good first half with solid results on the back of our major restructuring last year.
We're now generating some real momentum in the business.

We've produced an excellent run of realizations, our portfolio is performing well in what remains a tricky macro environment across Europe, and our network of international offices is delivering interesting deal flow away from aggressive and competitive auction processes.
Our operating costs are down and our debt is down, and we are dealing with the group's old leakages more quickly than we had originally planned.
We're also seeing a very strong recovery in the performance of our 2 Private Equity funds, Eurofund V and the Growth Capital Fund.
This morning, I'd like to talk to you about our strategic objectives and our progress so far and our evolving business model.
Then I'll hand over to Julia who will take you through our financial performance in the first half.
Now I'd like to start by reminding you about our strategy.
It's simple and it includes all 3 of 3i's businesses: Private Equity, Infrastructure and Debt Management.

The combination of our complementary asset management capabilities across these 3 platforms, together with our permanent capital, gives our investors a clearly differentiated and attractive value proposition.
Our 3 businesses are each different in terms of what drives them, as well as the returns they deliver.
They complement each other and together, they're capable of providing an interesting balance of both income and capital returns.
You've seen this before, the 3i Value Build.
And the results for this year are confirming each and every step on this slide.
Our multi-year value build is based on a number of different phases of organizational change and strategic delivery.
We've delivered all of the strategic priorities we set for our financial year 2013, and we're already progressing well in transition and delivery, the next phase of our plan.

Our priorities for this year are clear: continue making realizations and to realize fully the benefits from the Private Equity management initiatives; look for new investments in Private Equity using proprietary capital and third-party co-investment; and continue to grow Debt Management and the Infrastructure third-party businesses.
We will also reduce our operating and funding costs even further, and we've already fully implemented our new compensation arrangements across the group.
The momentum from our exit plans has continued into the current year, as you can see, so we've generated very good value uplifts, 32% over the March valuations.

We've not only been selling some decent investments, we've also been spending time tidying up the trickier end of our portfolio, with the goal of reducing the portfolio size and making it more manageable.
As I've told you before, when I review our Private Equity portfolio, I think about it in 4 buckets.
It's been great to see the material growth in value in bucket 1 over the last 16 months, as well as the consistent realization of bucket 2 assets at good multiples.
And we continue to focus on the trickier assets in buckets 3 and 4.
This takes time, but will result in a right-sized and more manageable portfolio.
It's also been pretty satisfying to see a good flow of new investment opportunities coming through our international offices.
We have made 3 attractive investments in the last few months after looking at a good number of opportunities.
These are businesses where we have relevant experience and where we have bought them away from the highly competitive auction processes I mentioned a minute ago.
That way, we avoided the heavy premiums being paid across the market at the moment.
As far as I am concerned, the price we pay for something is likely to be the major determinant of our return on it.
So while I'm not looking to buy cheap assets, I certainly don't expect the PE team to bring me proposals that are priced to perfection as a result of some aggressive auction process.
I would rather be patient than lay down assets with the wrong entry price, and that's particularly true with the economic uncertainties we all still face at this time.
The investing teams in 3i are charged with finding and managing investments, as well as ultimately selling them for a solid return.

But it's the Investment Committee which takes all material decisions around new investment, around financing, key people changes and around exits, as well as acting as an engaged LP in monitoring the portfolio on a monthly basis.

This committee, which I chair, is made up of a majority of individuals outside of the Private Equity investment team and enacts completely independently as a custodian of the group's proprietary capital.
Now turning to Infrastructure.
The division continued to make a good contribution to the group's cash income, and the European portfolio continues to perform well.
But we saw a significant pullback in the valuations of some of our Indian assets, not least because of the challenging overall economic conditions in India and the depreciating rupee.
And Julia will talk more about foreign exchange in a minute.
We've made strong progress in growing the Infrastructure business.
Earlier this week, we completed our acquisition of Barclays Infrastructure Fund Management business.
That acquisition is a significant milestone in the implementation of our strategy.
It adds a further $780 million to our third-party AUM.
The team based in London and Paris currently manages 2 active funds in U.
and European PPP and energy projects, so it clearly complements 3i's existing European Infrastructure product offering, which focuses on core infrastructure.
I have met and spent time with this team.
They are busy, focused people and they will double our investment capacity in Infrastructure, and we intend to leverage our enhanced platform to raise new third-party Infrastructure funds.
We're also growing our Debt Management business.
We have recently completed our first new CLO issue in Europe, and we're seeing good opportunities in the U.
to launch further CLOs through the Fraser and Sullivan platform we acquired last year.

As you can see, we have set the team some demanding strategic objectives, but the business has a very experienced group of credit professionals running it and is well placed to build further in this changing sector.
As a result of our cost-saving progress up to March 2013, we announced in May a material increase in our cost reduction target for this current financial year to March '14.
We've moved our total cost reduction target up to GBP 60 million from the original GBP 45 million we announced in June '12.
That represents a like-for-like reduction of almost 1/3 of the total cost base of GBP 185 million that we started with in March 2012.
As the benefits of the changes we've already implemented take effect and we continue to manage the business tightly, we will see further reductions.

We will be keeping pressure on driving down costs, at the same time that we're making sure that we have the right platform and the right level of support to grow our Infrastructure and Debt Management businesses and to maintain the momentum in our Private Equity business.
And we've delivered another material win on our balance sheet.
As you can see, gross debt is now down to GBP 873 million.
And we closed the first half with net cash of GBP 28 million.
We fully implemented our new compensation arrangements, including more share-based compensation for senior staff.
This is already having a strong impact across the business.
People are much more focused on costs and as a result, our cost base is much more in line with the more efficient companies in our sector.
It's good to see senior staff acting with the same discipline on costs as an owner would.
That means the interest of both our shareholders and our investors are closely aligned.
We're already making strong progress in the current phase of our strategic plan transition and delivery.
The slide shows our key objectives for this year and next.
We are coming from a long way back, but we're making good progress in costs and generating new income.
We're seeing growth in Debt Management and Infrastructure leading to a more balanced contribution across our 3 businesses to third-party fee income.
We're seeing a material shift in capital allocation as we have reduced our costs and our debt.
And as we build third-party AUM, more of our cash is going to reinvestment and to shareholder distributions.
This financial year, we've already met our goals for gearing of less than 20% and gross debt below GBP 1 billion.
And as a result, we intend to propose a total dividend in financial year '14 of 20p per share.
That 20p will include the base dividend of 8.
1p per share.
We expect a lower level of realization activity in the second half, but we expect the balance of further realizations and new investment to support our proposed 20p distribution.
This is a very big change from 18 months ago.
And as a shareholder in the group, I am delighted with this development.
It's been a real team effort, and I would like to offer my thanks to each and everyone of 3i's team.
They've been doing a great job.
Now I'd like to talk to you about 3i's evolving business model.
This is 3i's business.
It's distinctive because of the scale of our proprietary capital that is invested in mid-market private equity.

Our proprietary capital invested alongside LP funds will provide significant upside for the shareholders once we have removed all the unnecessary leakages which the group has suffered from in the past.
I think we've now achieved the right alignment of interest across the group.
We continue to put the group's own capital to work alongside third-party investors, and we've now become a much more proactive owner and manager of our portfolio of assets.
And importantly, the senior and investing executives in the group now receive a significant proportion of 3i Group shares as part of their variable compensation.
They're also being measured in operational effectiveness, as well as their investment performance.
Our clear objectives are both to maximize investment returns on the group's own investments and grow profitably our fund management business.
We will deliver this through the 3i Value Build.
This slide clearly shows the different contributions of our businesses between proprietary and third-party capital.
The Private Equity portfolio accounts for the bulk of that proprietary capital, while Debt Management is the largest contributor to third-party AUM and fees.
So we are now managing the group with much clearer delineation between proprietary capital investing and our fund management activities.
Going forward, you'll be able to track our progress through different KPIs measuring our performance at 3i Group in our usage of proprietary capital and through our fund management activities.
We have a clear target of generating annual income, profits and capital flows that we can use for shareholder returns and for reinvestment.
The first phase of our turnaround plan has gone very well.
I'm particularly pleased by our progress on realizations and the quality of the recent investments in Private Equity.
And as I said earlier, we have a new set of priorities for the current financial year and we've made a good start in meeting these new challenges.
Now I'd like to close by making one final point.
There continues to be a great deal of focus on our NAV as the appropriate proxy for our share price.
But as some of you know, I don't hold with that view.
I believe NAV is a measure which has more relevance for a company or trust that owns listed securities.
The bulk of our proprietary capital, and we have a lot, is invested in mid-market private equity investments, where we are planning to generate real alpha by making at least 2x return on our cost.
But we can't describe the target return to our core [ph] revaluations because these are illiquid private company holdings, and business plans for these investments are only partially executed.
This leads us to be cautious in our valuations at any particular point in time as our average EBITDA multiple and the premium on our recent realizations would indicate.
Our experience over the past 12 months has been that we can obtain significant premier to our book values if we sell assets at the right time, i.
at the culmination of our exit plans, into a supportive financing market and where financial or trade buyers are prepared to pay a premium to win an asset.
We held our Private Equity Investor Day in September, focusing on Action and Element in order to communicate the potential quality and value growth in our keeper-bucket assets.
These are assets, which have much greater potential than 2x.

In the case of Action, there are several high-growth discount stocks listed in Europe and North America with similar growth rates to Action, but none of them trade at 10x EBITDA as we value our stake in Action today.
The same is true for Element in that we are only partway through our plan for Element, so we value our stake at a discount to the listed peers even though the peers are growing much less strongly.

So when people think about our NAV being a useful proxy for 3i's share price, they should remember that it doesn't reflect either the complete execution of our exit plans or the premium that can come from selling an asset well at the right time or, for that matter, the potential value in our fund management platform.
None of this, of course, means that valuations cannot go down as well as up, but that's true of listed stocks as well.
Okay, enough from me.
I'll hand over to Julia.
Yes, I thought I'd get asked that.
We're obviously very keen that we build a vintage of investments under this new team from the beginning of '11.
And I think LPs need to see that team not only making investments and managing them, but realizing them as well.
So my judgment is we're still somewhere away from launching a new Private Equity fund.
I don't think it will happen this year and I don't think it will happen on next financial year, but it could well happen the year after that.
But I'm not seeing it much earlier than that.
It's Anil Sharma from Morgan Stanley.
Just a couple of questions, if I can.
You mentioned earlier that there's good generation in the sort of carry in the performance fees payable.

So I just wanted to -- how should we think about that number in the second half because it's quite sort of material in the first half and then sort of into next year? And then in terms of the Private Equity portfolio, I just wanted to check, there's a slide there where you were talking about the earnings growth of some of the companies, and there's sort of effectively 1/4 of the companies with double-digit earning declines.

I just wanted to -- how should we think about the turnaround of those businesses? Are they sort of structurally challenged and you wouldn't expect a recovery or how should I think about that? And so just a final question, if I may.

Just following on from that second one about the earnings growth, where would you expect your funds' sort of performance to be in sort of 12 months' time? You've obviously increased it dramatically, but realizations are sort of slowing or you're signaling they're going to slow.
So how do you -- where should that performance number be in 12 months? It's Iain Scouller from Oriel Securities.
You also made good progress in terms of growing funds under management, Debt and Infrastructure.

Are there any other sectors that you think you'd like to expand into? And on Debt and Infrastructure, do you have any sort of aspirational targets as to where you'd like to get to in terms of funds under management, i.
for the next few years? They were a mixture, so Scandlines was a Eurofund V follow-on investment.
So that was made through the fund, so it was 3i money and Eurofund V money.
It was a proprietary capital investment, and JMJ was made with one of our managed account, co-investment relationships, so a mixture.
I'd say on that, those bucket 3 assets, those challenged assets, the -- we have changed 13 of the CEOs in those buckets.
So we are very aggressively focusing on those buckets.
They can't avoid the macros, some of those companies.
And despite what we're all reading in the papers and everything else, it's still a low-flow, tricky macro for many medium-sized businesses out there.
And the ones that tend to be vulnerable to that tend to sit in our bucket 3.
So we're putting a lot of effort into getting our cost back.
We're getting near to our cost.

We had a couple of triumphs recently that we announced: one was Bestinvest, which was bought at a very high price at the peak of the market; and the other, Everis, the consultancy in Spain, which NTT has purchased.
So I mean, we are getting some good breaks in that bucket, but we can't avoid the macro.
The macro is tough for some of these companies.
In terms of Eurofund V performance, again, what is interesting is inbound and we've started to get LPs asking us when we're going to raise our next fund.
They're all getting very excited about the turnaround.
I think there's much more material turnaround to come.
So having taken it from a low point of 0.
63 to 1, there's still a lot more to come in that fund.
I think it will have a respectable outcome, very much driven by the latter investments, so the end of 2010 to the end of the fund type investments.
So we're feeling very good about that.
But we want those runs to be on the board for when we start the next fundraising.
If there are no more questions, thanks for your attention.
Appreciate it.
Okay, why don't I take the last bit first.
In terms of those arrangements, firstly, it's not discretionary money.
That money is there if they like the investment in question.
But these 2 institutions have been long-term investors with 3i in a number of structures, and we know each other extremely well, and they've been very active investors with a past.
So we have a high degree of confidence that they like what we like and they rate the current team, which is why they've entered into these framework agreements.
The economics of these framework agreements are equivalent to invested money economics in a more general buyout fund.
So they don't pay commitment fees, but they will pay deal fees, management fees and carry to the team in return for good performance there.
So they're very similar to invested money in a fund.
The taste of the 2 is a little different.
One likes to hit boundaries, fours and sixes in terms of the checks it writes.
And the other ones to have a slice of most of our deals with smaller checks.
So they're complementary in that regard.
They obviously don't want their name disclosed at this point.
But I think it will become evident as we invest who they are.
If we just talk about the zeros, it's quite a numerous -- it's at too numerous bucket I'm afraid.
I do know the exact number, but there's quite a lot of them, and enterprise was the most relevant decent example of that, and I'm sure some of them will be recovering above their base value.
But it will be single digits and millions or tens of millions.
It won't be hundreds of millions.
Thanks, Julia.

So we've had a productive year at 3i, and we're changing into a tightly run business with a target of generating annual income, profits and cash flows to be used for shareholder returns and reinvestment, without the large elements of leakage that we've seen in recent years.

We see the group as having 2 parts: Proprietary capital, which is about generating portfolio income and capital profits; and fund management, which manages both the proprietary capital and third-party capital in return for fee income, carried interest and performance fees.
Going forward, you will be able to track our progress and performance not only as a group, but you'll be able to measure our use of proprietary capital, as well as our performance as a fund manager.
We are convinced that this greater transparency will be crucial in judging how we are doing.
As I said earlier, each of our 3 businesses has different drivers and return characteristics, but together, they provide an attractive balance of income and capital returns.

And the combination of our 3 asset management skills, together with our permanent capital, provides us with a differentiated model just at the time when the private equity sector is going for a very fundamental shakeout.
The first phase of our turnaround plan has gone well, and we've exceeded all of our targets, and we're already seeing the benefits in materially improved financial performance.
And as I said earlier, we have a new set of priorities for this year.
Now I'd try and communicate this plan, and our performance, as clearly and as simply as possible.
But don't be fooled into thinking, all we are doing is just taking out a few costs.
This project is far more complicated than that.
And it's required a lot of careful judgment after some very detailed analysis.
The business is multilayered with important fund and LP commitments over many years.
3i's geographically diverse and employs many senior, experienced and independent-minded investment professionals.
It's got an oversized PE portfolio to match its geographic diversity.
And the asset management initiatives are critical to optimizing value from these and from future investments.
In short, the business requires relentless leadership and cut-through to make sure everybody stays on track, and we avoid the banana skins of the past.
That having been said, I'd like to just close by saying thank you to the team at 3i.
They've responded very well to some tough actions this year.
I really admire the determined way they picked up their game and risen to the challenges that have been put in front of them.

When I first stood up as CEO last June and presented our new strategy, I talked about a few things that I believe underpin strong businesses: A clear vision guiding an ambitious but practical strategy; integrity and respect for individuals, be they colleagues, customers or suppliers; high energy levels and a good work ethic; and clear decisions based on thorough analysis, followed by rapid implementation.
Today's 3i team has embraced this approach with real enthusiasm.
The culture is changing, and we become a better focused, flatter organization with a can-do attitude and high energy levels.
We're doing things smartly again, and I'm excited about the progress we will make over the next few years.
It's going to be rewarding for everyone involved.
Thank you for listening.
And we'd now like to throw it open to Q&A.

If we look at how the market is developing and the pipeline in terms of potential investments, the comments I would make are, over the last 6 months, we've seen a very considerable improvements in pipeline potential investments.
It have been very lean priced for that period, particularly, in terms of quality, as well as quantity.
So we've seen some better prospects in Northern Europe, as well as the U.
and Brazil.
We think these prospects are more interesting for both numerous and quality reasons.
And we've got pretty close on 2 investments in Europe, one we couldn't agree a final price with the vendor so we decided to pull back from that.
It's an engineering business based out of Germany.
And another business in Holland we got overbid at the last stage of an auction with a very aggressive price for another private equity house.
So we are there.
We are in the game.
We have the better with in Brazil and the U.
at the moment.
with it's particularly interesting, and it reflects businesses that we like, which have strong capabilities in both Europe and North America, like HILITE like Element.
These sorts of businesses.
So I don't think we're going to see a prolonged phase where we're doing just selling and not investing.
I don't envisage that at all.
In any event, though, what I'd like to see in terms of the shape of the group is that we have about half the Private Equity investments we have today.
So we're on a bit of a journey to reduce bit oversized portfolio.
We need to be more active in that side of things.
And I think the next few years will help us in that regard.
Good morning, everyone.
It's almost 1 year since I stood up in June 2012 to take you through the future strategy of 3i and our restructuring plan.
I'm pleased to say that we've made very significant and rapid progress in implementing our plan.
Our strong set of results for the year, which show material improvement across the board against 2012, clearly demonstrate the progress that we've made.
We've delivered against all of the priorities we set ourselves for the financial year ending March 2013 and, in particular, we've materially exceeded our cost and debt reduction targets.
We've seen considerable improvement in our Private Equity performance, including an impressive run of cash realizations.
In short, it's been a very good year of recovery for 3i after too many disappointing ones.
So I'd like to start by focusing on our strategic objectives and progress over the last year.
Julia will take you through the groups financial performance, and I will then make some concluding remarks before I'd open to Q&A.
But first, I'd like to remind you about our strategy.
It's simple and embraces all 3 of our businesses: Private Equity, Infrastructure and Debt Management.

The combination of our complementary asset management capabilities across these 3 platforms, together with our permanent capital, gives our investors a differentiated and attractive value proposition.

Our 3 businesses are each different in terms of drivers and return characteristics, but they complement each other, and together, they're capable of providing an interesting balance of income and capital growth.
You will have seen this slide before.
It captures the key return drivers for each of our businesses, as well as demonstrating their cyclicality.

Now I've bought shares in 3i because, after analyzing the fundamentals of the group and its prospects, it was clear to me that the business, if ran well, represented a compelling multiyear value proposition.
I was convinced that this value proposition was underpinned by valuable portfolio of investments and by the prospect of significant cash distributions over time.

Today, everybody at 3i sees the simplicity of growing the earnings of our portfolio, realizing our investments at attractive cash multiples, generating annual cash profits by running our 3 fund management businesses well, using our permanent capital to take advantage of value and growth opportunities, and turning this into cash for the benefit of LPs shareholders.
I hope it all sounds very simple, but it's actually taken quite a lot of hard work and careful thought to begin delivering on this strategy and moving 3i on to the solid footing it's on today.
We've had to put in some fundamental new asset management initiatives in Private Equity.
We've refocused that division and put a real emphasis on exit planning and smart execution.
Across our businesses, we are focusing on growing third-party AUM and growing our income against a rightsized cost base.

We've used our capital to exploit opportunities in the debt management sector, and we've reduced gross debt and our cost of funding, so that more of the cash goes back to shareholders and back to the business to be invested.
Our multiyear value build is based on a number of different phases of organizational change in strategic delivery.
We've delivered all of the strategic priorities we set for the financial year 2013.
And we're already progressing well in transition and delivery, the next phase of our plan.
You will recall that we set ourselves 6 strategic objectives last year.
So I'd now like to take you through our progress against each in a little more detail.
Last June, we said we'd reduce our headcount by 160 by the 31st of March.
In fact, we achieved a net headcount reduction of 168.
That's almost 40% of the group's headcount that we had in March last year.
And we closed the 6 offices we said we would, and we reduced our property expenses even further by making significant rental savings in both London and New York.
We originally targeted annualized cost savings of GBP 40 million by March '13 and, in fact, we cut out GBP 51 million.
That puts us 28% ahead of our target and also represents, coincidentally, a 28% reduction to our opening costs of GBP 185 million.
Over 70% of the staff reduction has come from the back office.
That's 119 out of the 168.
As a result, we have a better balance of investment staff versus back-office support.
And this slide gives you an idea of where the headcount reductions taken place.
Geography has determined that the reductions in the investment teams with finance, admin, property, IT, HR and marketing accounting for 119 staff reductions in the group functions.
And here's a little bit more detail on where we've over-performed in cost reductions.
This slide gives you some examples of how further savings have come about.
In general, we have found additional savings through a sharper focus on cost control and by introducing much stronger approval mechanisms across the group.
We've also delayered to become a simple, less hierarchical organization.
As a result of our progress up to March 2013, we're today announcing a material increase in our cost reduction target for this current financial year to March 2014.
We're moving our total cost reduction target up to GBP 60 million from the original GBP 45 million.
So that represents a like-for-like reduction of almost 1/3 against our cost base of GBP 185 million in March last year.
As the benefits of the changes we've already implemented take place, and we continue to manage the business tightly, we will see further reductions.
And we'll be doing this at the same time that we're making sure that we have the right platform and the right level of support to grow our Debt Management and Infrastructure businesses.
And we've delivered another material win around the balance sheet.
Having set the target of GBP 1 billion of gross debt by June '13, we bought it down to close the GBP 900 million by April.
That's a reduction of 44% from our starting position of over GBP 1.
6 billion in March last year.
And that's a clear reflection of our success in realizing from our Private Equity portfolio.
An important part of restructuring over the last year has been to achieve a greater degree of central control and focus.
And to get there, we've removed organizational complexity and bureaucracy.
By removing committees and hierarchies, we've created a much more efficient organization.
When you combine that simplification with a more energized team, you can create a much more dynamic culture.
And that's exactly what we've done, a simple organization with shorter lines of communication leads to much faster and more consistent decision-making.
And that in turn is driving improved performance.
In June last year, we announced 6 new asset management initiatives in Private Equity.
That program has now been substantially implemented and is beginning to make a huge difference to the quality of our asset management in Private Equity.
You've seen some of this already with our realization successes and the improvement in the overall portfolio value, and we expect to see further benefits over time.
We've also revised our investment review process.
We've combined our separate investment and portfolio committee structures under 1 investment committee, which I chair.
The new investment committee considers all decisions from the original investment ideas, right through the divestments.

We've also involved the investment committee early on in the investment process, and we've involved it in all material decisions in the life of an investment, such as refinancing and senior management changes.
With the geographic breadth and sheer scale of that 3i investment portfolio, I'm convinced these changes are critical.
We've tied up our investment processes with asset management, or management assessment, rather, and we made our approach consistent across all our investment teams.
And we've become much more proactive in replacing underperforming management.
Since September last year, we've replaced 11 chairmen and CEOs after our proper evaluation of their performance.
And as most of you will recall, the introduction of the 3i dashboard last September has transformed how quickly we recognize and react to performance issues within our portfolio of companies.
It's working very well, and it's leading to new improved asset management performance across the entire portfolio.
Since March last year, we've increased the emphasis on developing detailed extra strategies for all our equity private investments.
We review and update those plans twice a year with a view to optimizing cash proceeds for shareholders and LPs.

If an investment is ready to be sold, we'll take advantage of market conditions, but equally, we're prepared to think if there is better value down the road, or that we should -- we're prepared to consider refusing a cheap offer or waiting for better value down the road.
You've recently seen the results of this planning and execution with the sales of Mold-Masters and Civica and with plans for each asset in our Private Equity portfolio.
In some cases, those plans were announced a number of years.
In other cases, we have like companies likely to be sold in the near term.
It's been an excellent year for realizations.
We've generated a total of GBP 575 million.
It's an uplift of 49% over the opening book value and a money multiple of 2.
1x against our initial investment, not a bad performance in my book.
I'd also like to remind you again that I believe cash is the best measure of the performance of our investments.

I also feel that, in many cases, a focus on our current NAV fails to recognize the likely future or auction value for each of the investments we have and that we've set out in our individual exit plans.
And I hope our recent sales are convincing you that we've got this right.
We can achieve good premium offers when the financing markets are robust as they are right now.
We refocused our Private Equity business around Northern Europe, the U.
and Brazil.
We've suspended new investments in Asia and Spain, and we're highly selective in the core regions we are investing in.
It's no secret that this has been a difficult environment for investing.
And while we found some investing opportunities in Brazil, we've struggled to get comfortable with the pricing in Northern Europe, in particular.
So in this environment, we're delighted to be more focused on selling.
As most of you know, it has been a really good selling environment with strong financial markets and plenty of cash-rich private equity and corporate buyers.
And I think it's fair to say that our recent record shows that we are taking good advantage of these conditions.
The next slide I showed you last June, the Private Equity portfolio has treated well in a generally very difficult macro environment.
We've had resilient performances in Northern Europe, the U.
and Brazil, some very tough conditions in Spain, and a rapid deterioration in the environment in France and some very tough conditions in India.
And when I review the Private Equity portfolio, I think about it in 4 buckets.
The keepers, e.
action, element, borne, which offer terrific long-term growth.
Second is the strong performers, which we expect to good -- achieve good sales proceeds, like Civica, like Mold-Masters, which I mentioned just a minute ago.
The third bucket is made up of those investments which have the potential for material value recovery from where they have historically traded, companies such as Azaelus and OneMed.
And finally, what I call the zeros, which account for little of our NAV today, but represent auction value, in the case of the enterprise value, recovers above the level of the debt.
The company enterprise was a good example of this category.
The third bucket is our largest bucket by cost of investments and has significant scope to increase value over time.
As you know, we conducted the group-wide compensation review this year.
At around 60% of operating costs, the payroll is our largest expense.
We've got to make sure we have a legitimate split of returns between shareholders and employees.
That's the only way we can retain both the right talent and create long-term shareholder value.
We have broad shareholders support for our new proposals.
And these new compensation arrangements are to be introduced in June 2013.
Going forward, group compensation will be driven by how we perform against our key strategic objectives.
This will give us a much clearer link between staff compensation and shareholder returns.
In addition, a lot bigger proportion of total compensation will be in deferred shares of 3i Group plc.
For example, senior staff in the group will have a shareholding target, which will be set as a multiple of annual gross salary, so that we can enhance our alignment with shareholders.
We're already making strong progress in the next phase of our strategic plan, transition and delivery.
And this slide shows our key objectives for the year ahead.
We expect cash income to cover operating cost by March 2014 on a run rate basis.
And by the way, 3i has not done that for a very long time, to lead to a more balanced contribution for third-party fee income over time.
In Private Equity, we focus on finding the best way to reestablish our investment track record.
We've done that by investing alongside institutional coinvestors in Brazil and establishing 2 framework agreements for investing in Northern Europe.
One of these agreements is with a leading U.
institution and one is with a very large sovereign wealth fund.
Infrastructure continue to make a strong contribution to the group's cash income last year.
The European portfolio performed well, and the value of the holding in 3i Infrastructure increased by 7%.
We did see some pullback in the valuations of some of our Indian assets, given the challenging supply-side and macroeconomic conditions we face in India.
We've got one of the best teams in the Infrastructure sector, and our pipeline in European opportunities is good going into this financial year.
And we therefore expect to see good growth.
Our Debt Management business has had a very strong year.
They've almost doubled third-party funds under management to GBP 6.
They also acquired a very strong U.
franchise in Fraser Sullivan and issued almost 1 billion of CLOs in the U.
The business has a very experienced group of credit professionals and is well-placed to take advantage of further opportunities as this sector continues to change.
This financial year, we intend to pursue our enhanced capital distribution policy.
We've already met our goals for gearing of less than 20% and gross debt below GBP 1 billion.

We intend to distribute 15% to 20% of gross cash proceeds in the next 12 months, and the GBP 222 million from Mold-Masters is going to be part of this calculation, and all other realizations this year will contribute.
The current total, including Mold-Masters and realizations announced so far, is GBP 422 million.

So our priorities for the year are clear: To realize fully the benefits from the Private Equity asset management initiatives, continue to grow Debt Management and Infrastructure's third-party businesses, a look for new investments in Private Equity using proprietary capital and third-party coinvestors.
We'll further reduce our operating and funding costs and fully implement our new compensation arrangements.
So clearly, it's been a good year for 3i.
And I'd now like to ask Julia to take you through the numbers.
Any other questions? I've got to get to the AGM some going to wrap it up year.
Thanks for coming everyone and we'll take questions later in the day if you want.
And my other question was about the hedging policy.
I mean I know last year was very good on the currency front.
Could you just detail a little bit more how that's change and what the effect of currency exposures are in the NAV level? Daniel Garrod, Barclays.
Couple of questions.
Firstly, the 4 buckets of investments that you referred to.
You've obviously done well, realizing out of the #2 just sort of strong performers.
I wonder if you could go to the fourth bracket that you called the zeros.

How many assets are in that category, and can you provide any sort of color on the experience with enterprise about the possibles sort of hidden value creation in that element of your portfolio? The second question is around the statements this morning of the new committed go investments from a number of institutions.

I wonder if you could provide any more color on that a number of institutions, whether there's any change in fees you obviously mentioned you get fees and carry on this potential new investments, coinvestments, with those institutions.
Is there any change in fee structure of those coinvestments compared to, say, your Eurofund V? It's Iain Scouller from Oriel Securities.
I've got a couple.
Firstly on the unrealized volume movements on Slide 57.
I think the second largest contributor was other plus GBP 73 million.
Now can you just give us a bit of a breakdown on that? And then the second one was on in Infrastructure.
I think you said there was a good business opportunity there.

I was just wondering what the plans are for growing that business, clearly I think conditions probably couldn't be more favorable than they are today for the asset class, so what are the plans to grow assets under management? Thank you.
And yes, what we typically have in the other category are companies, which are valued on a different sort of basis.
So the majority of our portfolio is valued on an earnings basis.
We have some companies, which be involved on industry metrics, for example, Hyperion is an example of that we've seen.
And of course, ACR would be another example.
So it's a multitude of things.
It's Henry Freeman from Investec.
Just following up from the question before on your new 2 strategic coinvestors.

Is this the kind of format that we could expect going forward for particularly Private Equity fund raising or cost fundraising, rather than raising money through traditional LP funds? Yes, I think if you look in the disclosure that we gave you on the valuation of the assets, the 2 principal ones talk about the Civica and Quintiles, neither of which were on an uplift to sail basis at the end of the period.
Quintiles was valued at GBP 103 million that we announced that we've received GBP 50 million of proceeds and residual holding is worth GBP 133 million based on the IPO price.
Share price actually gone up since then but I'm not calculating on a daily basis.
And Civica is the other example, which is in the books at GBP 84 million at the end of March.
And we just disclosed proceeds on that asset of GBP 127 million.
And I think actually that both good examples of what this realization market is like.
We strike a fair value for our assets.
I clearly have cited some of these processes, but that's one factor that we take into account a degree of execution risk.
And it's one of the reasons why we would say that the NAV won't ever really reflect the very, very good M&A conditions that we're currently seeing at the moment.
Thank you, Simon.
So you've just heard about the significant progress that we've been making against the strategic objectives that we set last June.
I'd now like to take you through our financial results and show you the evidence of that progress, and I'd like to take you through the impact that, that progress will have on our financial year '14.
So in headline terms, the change is obvious.
We have made growth portfolio return of GBP 546 million.
That's driven by realizations that we've achieved, a good uplift to that opening value.
The cost of running the business is down to GBP 170 million, and that's including restructuring costs of GBP 30 million.
Our balance sheet today is a lot stronger, with gross debt reduced to GBP 1.
1 billion and gearing down to 11%, and our NAV is much improved at 311p.
So this chart shows you how the NAV has improved.
The opening NAV has been reduced by dividends we paid during the year and by the cost of implementing our new strategy.
But strong realizations, good earnings growth and net fee income have been a big contributor of 41p.
And 20p of that performance relates to cash realized profits.
And now that we report our NAV quarterly, here is the same reconciliation for the fourth quarter.
Here, you can see how the momentum has built in the year with an 8.
7% increase in NAV in the fourth quarter compared to 2.
5% in the preceding 3.
Before I get on the business performance, I'd just like to spend some time taking you through the changes in our cost base that Simon talked about.
Then we'll look at the balance sheet structure, which has also been an important change this year.
Just to recap on the key metrics that Simon talked about earlier.
We said we'd reduced our run rate cost base by GBP 40 million by the 31st of March 2013.
We've beaten our target by 28%, and we've reduced the cost base by GBP 51 million.
We said we've reduced headcount by 160 by the 31st of March 2013.
In fact, we reduced headcount by 168.
We said that actual cost for the year would be about the same level as the year before.
Actual cost is 6% lower.

That includes acquisition, as well as an GBP 8 million accounting benefit that we get from the bonus shares awarded as part of the compensation review, that benefit will unwind over the next 3 to 4 years.
That's very good progress but it's a bit complicated by whether we're talking about including or excluding acquisitions or talking about run rate to actual costs.
At the highest level, we started the year with a run rate cost base of GBP 185 million or 1.
8% of our assets under management.
We've reduced the cost base by delivering annual savings of GBP 51 million.
During the year, we added GBP 7 million to that cost base when the Debt Management business grew by acquiring the Invesco contracts and the Fraser Sullivan platform.
These additional costs I'm talking about are covered by fees.
But here, we're looking at gross costs.
And that means we finished the year at 31st of March 2013, with the cost run rate of GBP 140 million or 1.
And how do we reconcile actual and run rate.
So here's the detailed reconciliation of the components, the adjustments for acquisitions and the full year effect of changes and savings.
One of the changes that we've talked about is the compensation review, and you can see here the change in the makeup of fixed and variable compensation this year compared to last.
Better performance has generated higher variable pay of the general bonus pool which reduced by 50% last year.
And there has been a step change in the amount of shared awards to better align people with shareholders, the GBP 8 million cost of which will be accounted over the next 3 to 4 years.
And so to summarize the new targets.
We said the cost would reduce by GBP 45 million by the end of financial year 2014.
We're now resetting that goal to achieve total run rate savings of GBP 60 million.
We said the implementation costs would be GBP 30 million to achieve run rate savings of GBP 45 million.
And that we'd spend GBP 30 million -- we spent GBP 30 million to achieve savings of GBP 51 million.
We'll now spend another GBP 7 million to deliver the total of GBP 60 million savings that we've targeted.
Turning then to the balance sheet.
As Simon has already set out, we said that we would reduce gross debt to GBP 1 billion by June 2013.
Actual gross debt at the 31st of March was GBP 1.
Since then, we've repaid GBP 164 million of drawings under one of our committed facilities.
So at the end of April, gross debt is GBP 917 million, and that's substantially below the target and were ahead in timing as well.
Our net interest payable is GBP 91 million, that's flat compared to last year.
And interest receivable has reduced as you'd expect with our lower cash balances.

The gross interest payable in financial year 2013 of GBP 97 million was modestly lower than the prior year of GBP 103 million, but significantly, this year's expense included GBP 25 million of accelerated interests cost that are associated with the early repayment of a number of tranches of our debt.
So since we accelerated the reduction of the gross debt position, we start financial year 2014 with a much simple simpler profile.
Our liquidity is made up of cash of GBP 746 million and undrawn committed facilities of GBP 336 million.
That's before reflecting the repayments of the drawings just after the period in, which doesn't change liquidity but switches cash to undrawn.
We've Reviewed the level of equity that we have to hold, taking account of the lumpy nature of investment flows, our fund commitments and the ongoing cost of running the business.
Simon explained the 3i business model is much simpler and there is a lot more central control.
That means the level of liquidity that we hold can be reduced.
But I expect that we will always want to maintain a minimum cash balance of about GBP 500 million.
Our gross debt profile is now very simple.

Starting at the end of the chart and working back, we have a long-dated sterling bonds, which costs about GBP 35 million a year and our quality assets to pension funds who are searching for return and duration.
That's GBP 280 million outstanding on our 2017 eurobond, which costs about GBP 60 million per year depending on FX.

If you take account of commitment fees on the undrawn facilities and other balance sheet-related costs, I am confident that the gross interest cost will be less than GBP 60 million in financial year 2014.
One final point to note on simplification.
We have a more straightforward business model and that means a smaller number of assets, so we're changing the way that we manage currency risk.
Instead of hedging on a portfolio basis, currency risk management is now an explicit part of our investment and divestment decisions.
Altogether, we have a much stronger balance sheet, with net debt reduced to GBP 335 million and gearing down to 11.
Of course, the reduction in net debt reflects the success of the business overall and our Private Equity business, in particular, in delivering strong realizations in the year.
So I'd now like to talk to you about our business performance.
Simon has talked about how each business lines contribute to the group performance, with a different emphasis on capital returns and fee income for each of those business.
Clearly the most significant improvement has been in our Private Equity business.
We've generated very strong realized profits, good earnings growth and a reduction in operating costs.
Infrastructure and Debt Management have provided a stable contribution in the period.
I'm going to talk briefly about those 2 businesses first.
Our Infrastructure business invests in Europe and in India, and we are seeing a stark contrast in the performance in those 2 regions.

So the modest loss of GBP 2 million shown here masks a GBP 24 million gain that we made on our 34% holding on 3i Infrastructure plc, offset by value reductions of GBP 27 million in the Indian portfolio.
From a strategic perspective, Infrastructure business generated good cash return, good portfolio income and fees.
Growing income profitably is the key strategic objective for our Debt Management business, and it's a capital-light business for the group.
We have only invested GBP 46 million in this business in the year, with assets under management almost doubling to GBP 6.
We invested GBP 8 million to bring in the Fraser Sullivan platform, acquired the Invesco contracts and supported the U.
team who have raised almost $1 billion of new capital in second half.
We set the target of growing fee income for the business to GBP 50 million in the next 3 to 5 years.
The fees of GBP 31 million this year are a mixture of existing funds where improved credit performance has generated another GBP 6 million of catch-up fees after last year's GBP 11 million.
New business has down only a further GBP 6 million.
So fees are good news but profitable growth is key.
And the net returns you see here are still modest.
However, there is quite a lot of accounting noise in the operating cost of the business.
So it's worth noting of the GBP 32 million of cost shown here, GBP 8 million relates to acquisition accounting or due diligence costs.
I'd now like to come onto the Private Equity business performance.
Private Equity accounts for 82% of our balance sheet investments, so strong results are a very important contributor to the growth in our NAV.

Our realized profits of GBP 190 million and an uplift over opening value of 49% are evidence that the maturity of the portfolio has developed and that the increased focus on the exit plans is already generating results, and Simon has taken you through the significant assets generating this result.
I'll come onto realized profits in a minute, because there's a few other points I want to note in the overall net return for this business.
Portfolio income has fallen in the period.
That's partly as a result of assets sold but also because of the effect of some restructuring and provisions.
However, the cash element of income was stable at GBP 39 million compared to GBP 40 million in the prior year.
Fee income is also lower as expected in December 2012, and we have the full year effect of Eurofund V, which ended its investment period in November 2011.
Finally, we can also see here the benefit of cost reductions.
The GBP 114 million includes GBP 23 million of restructuring costs.
Altogether, the businesses generated a net portfolio return of GBP 416 million or 15.
8%, and that's a significant improvement from the loss of GBP 441 million in the prior year.
A big driver of that change is due to portfolio valuation.
As you can see here, 81% of the portfolio is in Northern Europe, North America and Brazil, which is where our investment efforts are focused.
There have been no significant changes in sector mix.
And although the new vintages continue to grow as a proportion of the portfolio, we still have a majority, 58% by value, of the 2007, '08 and '09 vintages.

This part of the portfolio is beginning to perform more strongly, and we're now seeing a number of good exits, such as the recently announced Civica and Quintiles transaction, as well as Mold-Masters and Hyperion.
Our continued focus on supporting investments that we made with high leverage and high energy prices remains critical.
We've since seen significant increases in value in some of these businesses and a reduction in leverage, as operational improvements and refinancings come through.
The 20 assets shown here account for 62% of the Private Equity portfolio.
As you can see on the right, the direction of travel is improving but the majority of these companies, particularly the larger investments.
We've excluded 5 large investments from this list for commercial reasons, but they also follow the general trend.
In terms of valuations, there are some consistent themes.
On a valuated basis, earnings in the portfolio grew by 10%.
We use forecast earnings for only 11 companies to reflect an expected downturn in performance, and these accounted for 11% of the portfolio value.
And as you'd expect, we normally adjust valuation earnings for one-off costs of restructuring or acquisitions made in the period.
This time, we have also made an adjustment to earnings used the action, the largest Private Equity asset.
We increased its earnings to reflect the run rate of stores that are opened and operational in its successful rollout program.
Multiples have increased by 7% in the year, but the increase was lower in the fourth quarter, the market movements.
There were a number of factors driving that, including the specific mix of geographies, sectors and size and, in a few cases, a degree of caution about where longer cross-cycle multiples might be.
So how do these all variables translate into movements? Well, it's a significant change in dynamics that compared to last year.
Movements from earnings, performance and multiples of GBP 141 million and GBP 36 million, respectively, are positive.

The uplift to imminent sale includes a number of smaller assets, where deals have been signed and cash is effectively in transit, does not include Civica or Quintiles, both of which happened after our cut-off.
The negative DCF movement relates substantially to the Indian portfolio, and Simon has talked about the various challenges that we're experiencing in that geography.
Altogether, an unrealized profit of GBP 250 million, a very significant improvement on the loss of GBP 488 million of the prior period.
Of course, the critical thing is that unrealized value movements turn into realized profits.
And as Simon detailed earlier, we made good progress on that last year, and we've made a strong start in the first quarter.
And as a result, we're now well positioned to initiate distributions above the core level of dividend.
And we expect to do that later in financial '14.
Subject to shareholder approval, the dividend in financial year '13 will be the core dividend, 8.
We'll pay a final dividend of 5.
4p in July.
So to sum up.
Our results show a marked improvement compared to last year.
They give you solid evidence of the cost reduction and balance sheet simplification.
Importantly, we're seeing signs that the asset management initiatives are driving better performance in Private Equity.
And the growth agenda for Infrastructure and Debt Management is improving the core profitability of the group.
So in all, it's been a really busy year for everyone at 3i, and the numbers clearly show the progress that we're making.
And I'll now hand you back to Simon.
Not unduly.

is particularly half but I think we're, the financing market is pretty good now as well.

I wonder if you can talk through what you see the implications for your business, particularly, project would be if the current conditions of strong realizations, difficult investment continues for a year or 2, because obviously for a time you can carry on selling responsibly, which is what you're doing, you're not worry about the investment levels, at some point you have to worry about and I just wondered how you think about that? I think part of the shakeout going on in Private Equity is a reassessment by more experienced LPs as to how they want to gain exposure to this sector.
And many of the more sophisticated ones are looking at this type of arrangement in preference to being tied up in a general fund for 10 years.
So I do think that, that is part of this shift that is going on in the structural sense across the sector.
I don't think everyone is there.
But I think some of the more sophisticated investors are moving to that as their preferred route for investment.
On infra, again, I think there is -- there's a little bit of investing environment in infra that we are seeing in Private Equity that its becoming a very fashionable and competitive area.
There are lots of people who see the attractions of Infrastructure investment in terms of its yield, profile, in particular, but we are -- we're looking at a number of things.
We're looking at new investments in terms of a stronger whip than we saw last year and some quite big stuff across Europe.
And we're also working looking at buckets of assets that we could perhaps manage on behalf of other people because of the quality and the capabilities that we have within 3i in that sector.
So there's a number of different routes that we're looking at that the moment.
I think on the -- taking the latter one first, on the distribution, Julia's indicated that we're going to focus on that later in the financial year '14.
We have already made in an arithmetic terms EUR 422 million of gross realizations, which the 15% to 20% can be applied to.
If you do the arithmetic on that, it sort of accounts for, I guess, our base level of dividend.
So everything going forward now is going to represent arithmetic that will generate a special distribution.
We have a strong pipeline of realizations in progress and to come.
So I'm optimistic that we will be saying more about that towards the end of the year.
