It's Iain Scouller from Oriel Securities.
I've got a couple.
Firstly, on the unrealized volume movements on Slide 57.
I think the second largest contributor was Other, plus GBP 73 million.
Now can you just give us a bit of a breakdown on that? And then the second one was on Infrastructure.
I think you said there was a good business opportunity there.

I was just wondering what the plans are for growing that business, clearly, I think conditions probably couldn't be more favorable than they are today for that asset class, so what are the plans to grow assets under management? Bill Barnard from SG.
Should I assume your first call from this morning was from Mr.

Bramson to thank you for making him so much money, and in terms of making him some more money, can you sort of give a bit more color around your thoughts on sort of a top-up distribution in terms of the quantum, the relationship, the 15% to 20% and, indeed, any timing sort of this year, next year, et cetera, just sort of key variables we should look around there? Thank you, Simon.
So you've just heard about the significant progress that we've been making against the strategic objectives that we set last June.
I'd now like to take you through our financial results and show you the evidence of that progress, and I'd like to take you through the impact that, that progress will have on our financial year '14.
So in headline terms, the change is obvious.
We have made growth portfolio return of GBP 546 million.
That's driven by realizations that we've achieved, a good uplift to the opening value.
The cost of running the business is down to GBP 170 million, and that's including restructuring costs of GBP 30 million.
Our balance sheet today is a lot stronger, with gross debt reduced to GBP 1.
1 billion and gearing down to 11%, and our NAV is much improved at 311p.
So this chart shows you how the NAV has improved.
The opening NAV has been reduced by dividends we paid during the year and by the cost of implementing our new strategy.
But strong realizations, good earnings growth and net fee income have been a big contributor at 41p, and 20p of that performance relates to cash realized profits.
And now that we report our NAV quarterly, here is the same reconciliation for the fourth quarter.
Here, you can see how the momentum has built in the year with an 8.
7% increase in NAV in the fourth quarter compared to 2.
5% in the preceding 3.
Before I get on to business performance, I'd just like to spend some time taking you through the changes in our cost base that Simon talked about.
Then we'll look at the balance sheet structure, which has also been an important change this year.
Just to recap on the key metrics that Simon talked about earlier.
We said we'd reduce our run rate cost base by GBP 40 million by March 31, 2013.
We've beaten that target by 28%, and we've reduced the cost base by GBP 51 million.
We said we'd reduce headcount by 160 by the 31st of March 2013.
In fact, we reduced headcount by 168.
We said the actual cost for the year would be about the same level as the year before.
Actual cost is 6% lower.

That includes acquisitions, as well as an GBP 8 million accounting benefit that we get from the bonus shares awarded as part of the compensation review, and that benefit will unwind over the next 3 to 4 years.
That's very good progress, but it's a bit complicated by whether we're talking about including or excluding acquisitions or talking about run rate to actual costs.
At the highest level, we started the year with a run rate cost base of GBP 185 million or 1.
8% of our assets under management.
We've reduced the cost base by delivering annual savings of GBP 51 million.
During the year, we added GBP 7 million to that cost base when the Debt Management business grew by acquiring Invesco contracts and the Fraser Sullivan platform.
These additional costs I'm talking about are covered by fees.
But here, we're looking at gross costs.
And that means we finished the year, at March 31, 2013, with a cost run rate of GBP 140 million or 1.
And how do we reconcile actual and run rate? So here's the detailed reconciliation of the components, the adjustments for acquisitions and the full year effect of changes and savings.
One of the changes that we've talked about is the compensation review, and you can see here the change in the makeup of fixed and variable compensation this year compared to last.
Better performance has generated higher variable pay as the general bonus pool which reduced by 50% last year.
And there has been a step change in the amount of share awards to better align people with shareholders, the GBP 8 million cost of which will be accounted for over the next 3 to 4 years.
And so to summarize the new targets.
We said that costs would reduce by GBP 45 million by the end of financial year 2014.
We're now resetting that goal to achieve total run rate savings of GBP 60 million.
We said the implementation costs would be GBP 30 million to achieve run rate savings of GBP 45 million.
And that we'd spend GBP 30 million -- we've spent GBP 30 million to achieve savings of GBP 51 million.
We'll now spend another GBP 7 million to deliver the total of GBP 60 million savings that we've targeted.
Turning then to the balance sheet.
As Simon has already set out, we said that we would reduce gross debt to GBP 1 billion by June 2013.
Actual gross debt at the 31st of March was GBP 1.
Since then, we've repaid GBP 164 million of drawings under one of our committed facilities.
So at the end of April, gross debt is GBP 917 million, and that's substantially below the target and we're ahead in timing as well.
Our net interest payable is GBP 91 million, that's flat compared to last year.
And interest receivable has reduced as you'd expect with our lower cash balances.

The gross interest payable in financial year 2013 of GBP 97 million was modestly lower than the prior year of GBP 103 million, but significantly, this year's expense included GBP 25 million of accelerated interest costs that are associated with the early repayment of a number of tranches of our debt.
So since we accelerated the reduction of the gross debt position, we start financial year 2014 with a much simpler profile.
Our liquidity is made up of cash of GBP 746 million and undrawn committed facilities of GBP 336 million.
That's before reflecting the repayments of the drawings just after the period end, which doesn't change liquidity but switches cash to undrawn.
We've reviewed the level of liquidity that we have to hold, taking account of the lumpy nature of investment flows, our fund commitments and the ongoing costs of running the business.
Simon explained the 3i business model is now much simpler and there is a lot more central control.
That means the level of liquidity that we hold can be reduced.
But I expect that we will always want to maintain a minimum cash balance of about GBP 500 million.
Our gross debt profile is now very simple.

Starting at the end of the chart and working back, we have our long-dated sterling bonds, which costs about GBP 35 million a year and our quality assets, the pension funds who are searching for return and duration.
There's GBP 280 million outstanding on our 2017 eurobond, which costs about GBP 60 million per year depending on FX.

If you take account of commitment fees on the undrawn facilities and other balance sheet-related costs, I am confident that the gross interest cost will be less than GBP 60 million in financial year 2014.
One final point to note on simplification.
We have a more straightforward business model and that means a smaller number of assets, so we're changing the way that we manage currency risk.
Instead of hedging on a portfolio basis, currency risk management is now an explicit part of our investment and divestment decisions.
Altogether, we have a much stronger balance sheet, with net debt reduced to GBP 335 million and gearing down to 11.
Of course, the reduction in net debt reflects the success of the business overall and our Private Equity business in particular, in delivering strong realizations in the year.
So I'd now like to talk through that business performance.
Simon has talked about how each business line contributes to the group performance, with a different emphasis on capital returns and fee income for each of those business.
Clearly the most significant improvement has been in our Private Equity business.
We've generated very strong realized profits, good earnings growth and a reduction in operating costs.
Infrastructure and Debt Management have provided a stable contribution in the period.
I'm going to talk briefly about those 2 businesses first.
Our Infrastructure business invests in Europe and in India, and we've seen a stark contrast in the performance in those 2 regions.

So the modest loss of GBP 2 million shown here masks a GBP 24 million gain that we made on our 34% holding in 3i Infrastructure plc, offset by value reductions of GBP 27 million in the Indian portfolio.
From a strategic perspective, Infrastructure business generated good cash return, through both portfolio income and fees.
Growing income profitably is the key strategic objective for our Debt Management business, and it's a capital-light business for the group.
We have only invested GBP 46 million in this business in the year, with assets under management almost doubling to GBP 6.
We invested GBP 8 million to bring in the Fraser Sullivan platform, acquired the Invesco contracts and supported the U.
team who have raised almost $1 billion of new capital in the second half.
We set Jeremy Ghose the target of growing fee income for the business to GBP 50 million in the next 3 to 5 years.
The fees of GBP 31 million this year are a mixture of existing funds where improved credit performance has generated another GBP 6 million of catch-up fees after last year's GBP 11 million.
New business has then added a further GBP 6 million.
So fees are good news but profitable growth is key.
And the net returns you see here are still modest.
However, there is quite a lot of accounting noise in the operating cost of the business.
So it's worth noting of the GBP 32 million of cost shown here, GBP 8 million relates to acquisition accounting or due diligence costs.
I'd now like to come on to the Private Equity business performance.
Private Equity accounts for 82% of our balance sheet investments, so strong results are a very important contributor to the growth in our NAV.

Our realized profits of GBP 190 million and an uplift over opening value of 49% are evidence that the maturity of the portfolio has developed and that the increased focus on the exit plans is already generating results, and Simon has taken you through the significant assets generating this result.
I'll come on to unrealized profits in a minute, because there's a few other points I want to note in the overall net return for this business.
Portfolio income has fallen in the period.
That's partly as a result of assets sold but also because of the effect of some restructuring and provisions.
However, the cash element of income was stable at GBP 39 million compared to GBP 40 million in the prior year.

Fee income is also lower, as expected
[Audio Gap]
December 2012, and we have the full year effect of Eurofund V, which ended its investment period in November 2011.
Finally, we can also see here the benefit of cost reductions.
The GBP 114 million includes GBP 23 million of restructuring costs.
Altogether, the businesses generated a net portfolio return of GBP 416 million or 15.
8%, and that's a significant improvement from the loss of GBP 441 million in the prior year.
A big driver of that change is due to portfolio valuation.
As you can see here, 81% of the portfolio is in Northern Europe, North America and Brazil, which is where our investment efforts are focused.
There have been no significant changes in sector mix.
And although the newer vintages continue to grow as a proportion of the portfolio, we still have a majority, 58% by value, of the 2007, '08 and '09 vintages.

This part of the portfolio is beginning to perform more strongly, and we're now seeing a number of good exits, such as the recently announced Civica and Quintiles transactions, as well as Mold-Masters and Hyperion.
Our continued focus on supporting investments that were made with high leverage and high energy prices remains critical.
We've seen some significant increases in value in some of these businesses and a reduction in leverage, as operational improvements and refinancings come through.
The 20 assets shown here account for 62% of the Private Equity portfolio.
As you can see on the right, the direction of travel is improving for the majority of these companies, particularly the larger investments.
We've excluded 5 large investments from this list for commercial reasons, but they also follow the general trend.
In terms of valuations, there are some consistent themes.
On a valuated basis, earnings in the portfolio grew by 10%.
We use forecast earnings for only 11 companies to reflect an expected downturn in performance, and these accounted for 11% of the portfolio value.
And as you'd expect, we normally adjust valuation earnings for one-off costs of restructuring or acquisitions made in the period.
This time, we have also made an adjustment to earnings used [indiscernible] Action, the largest Private Equity asset.
We increased its earnings to reflect the run rate of stores that are opened and operational in its successful rollout program.
Multiples have increased by 7% in the year, but the increase was lower in the fourth quarter, the market movements.
There were a number of factors driving that, including the specific mix of geographies, sectors and size and, in a few cases, a degree of caution about where longer cross-cycle multiples might be.
So how do all these variables translate into value movement? Well, it's a significant change in dynamics than compared to last year.
Movements from earnings, performance and multiples of GBP 141 million and GBP 36 million, respectively, are positive.

The uplift to imminent sale includes a number of smaller assets, where deals have been signed and cash is effectively in transit, it does not include Civica or Quintiles, both of which happened after our cut-off.
The negative DCF movement relates substantially to the Indian portfolio, and Simon has talked about the various challenges that we're experiencing in that geography.
Altogether, an unrealized profit of GBP 250 million, a very significant improvement on the loss of GBP 488 million of the prior period.
Of course, the critical thing is that unrealized value movements turn into realized profits.
And as Simon detailed earlier, we made good progress on that last year, and we've made a strong start in the first quarter.
And as a result, we're now well positioned to initiate distributions above the core level of dividend.
And we expect to do that later in financial '14.
Subject to shareholder approval, the dividend in financial year '13 will be the core dividend, 8.
We'll pay a final dividend of 5.
4p in July.
So to sum up.
Our results show a marked improvements in performance compared to last year.
They give you solid evidence of the cost reduction and balance sheet simplification.
Importantly, we've seen signs that the asset management initiatives are driving better performance in Private Equity.
And the growth agenda for Infrastructure and Debt Management is improving the core profitability of the group.
So in all, it's been a really busy year for everyone at 3i, and the numbers clearly show the progress that we're making.
And I'll now hand you back to Simon.
So you'd expect to add a few more of these sort of strategic coinvestors? Not unduly.
I think Civica was a very good example that we're experiencing, again, pretty strong financing conditions in Europe now, so funding is available again for the Private Equity and investment industry.
And equally, we've got strong corporates with cash there.
So I think, while we've had a particular shape to our realizations in recent months, that's bound to change as we get on with the rest of the plans and they become evident.
So I don't think -- I think the U.
is particularly hot but I think Europe, the financing markets are pretty good now as well.
It's Henry Freeman from Investec.
Just following on from the question before on your new 2 strategic coinvestors.

Is this the kind of format that we could expect going forward for, particularly, Private Equity fund raising or quasi fund raising, rather than raising money through traditional LP funds? Thanks, Julia.

So we've had a productive year at 3i, and we're changing into a tightly run business with a target of generating annual income, profits and cash flows to be used for shareholder returns and reinvestment, without the large elements of leakage that we've seen in recent years.

We see the group as having 2 parts: Proprietary capital, which is about generating portfolio income and capital profits; and fund management, which manages both the proprietary capital and third-party capital in return for fee income, carried interest and performance fees.
Going forward, you will be able to track our progress and performance, not only as a group, but you'll be able to measure our use of proprietary capital, as well as our performance as a fund manager.
We are convinced that this greater transparency will be crucial in judging how we are doing.
As I said earlier, each of our 3 businesses has different drivers and return characteristics, but together, they provide an attractive balance of income and capital returns.

And the combination of our 3 asset management skills, together with our permanent capital, provides us with a differentiated model just at a time when the private equity sector is going for a very fundamental shakeup.
The first phase of our turnaround plan has gone well, and we've exceeded all of our targets, and we're already seeing the benefits in materially improved financial performance.
And as I said earlier, we have a new set of priorities for this year.
Now I'll try and communicate this plan, and our performance, as clearly and as simply as possible.
But don't be fooled into thinking all we are doing is just taking out a few costs.
This project is far more complicated than that, and it has required a lot of careful judgment after some very detailed analysis.
The business is multilayered with important fund and LP commitments over many years.
3i is geographically diverse and employs many senior, experienced and independent-minded investment professionals.
It's got an oversized PE portfolio to match its geographic diversity.
And the asset management initiatives are critical to optimizing value from these and from future investments.
In short, the business requires relentless leadership and cut-through to make sure everybody stays on track, and we avoid the banana skins of the past.
That having been said, I'd like to just close by saying thank you to the team at 3i.
They've responded very well to some tough actions this year.
I really admire the determined way they picked up their game and risen to the challenges that have been put in front of them.

When I first stood up as CEO last June and presented our new strategy, I talked about a few things that I believe underpin strong businesses: A clear vision guiding an ambitious but practical strategy; integrity and respect for individuals, be they colleagues, customers or suppliers; high energy levels and a good work ethic; and clear decisions based on thorough analysis, followed by rapid implementation.
Today's 3i team has embraced this approach with real enthusiasm.
The culture is changing, and we've become a better focused, flatter organization with a can-do attitude and high-energy levels.
We're doing things smartly again, and I'm excited about the progress we will make over the next few years.
It's going to be rewarding for everyone involved.
Thank you for listening.
And we'd now like to throw it open to Q&A.
Chris Brown from JPMorgan Cazenove.
Just a couple of questions.
Just on the NAV.
Obviously, there are a number of deals you did around quite recently.

I'm just trying to get a feel for what's not been included on the March 31 NAV, and what a kind of pro forma NAV might look like? On Infra, again, I think there is -- there's a little bit of the investing environment in Infra that we are seeing in Private Equity, that it's becoming a very fashionable and competitive area.
There are lots of people who see the attractions of Infrastructure investment in terms of its yield, profile, in particular, but we are -- we're looking at a number of things.
We're looking at new investments in terms of a stronger whip than we saw last year and some quite big stuff across Europe.
And we're also looking at buckets of assets that we could perhaps manage on behalf of other people because of the quality and the capabilities that we have within 3i in that sector.
So there's a number of different routes that we're looking at, at the moment.
And my other question was about the hedging policy.
I mean, after going hedged [ph] for a number of years, last year was clearly very good on the currency front.

Could you just detail a little bit more how that's change and what effective currency exposures are in the NAV level? Yes, and I think if you look in your pack, we've given you a slide to give you the shape of the balance sheet.
This is a forward-looking change that we're making.
We have -- we're about 50% hedged on the euro at the moment, 40% on the dollar.
And essentially, we will let the derivative program run off over the course of the year, matching it to some of our investment flows.
If you did a pro forma basis, by the end of next year, if you assumed you had exactly the same balance sheet, we'll be about 22% hedged on the Euro portfolio and nowhere else.

If you want a rule of thumb, and I'd caution you against using it, because it's going to be dependent on the makeup of the portfolio and all those sorts of things, but a 1% movement in the Euro is about GBP 10 million on NAV and a 1% movement on the dollar is about GBP 7 million today.
I think it's a reflection of the changing shape of the portfolio.

We are going to look -- it's not that we're going to not manage our currency risk but we're going to do that on an entry point and an exit point, much more consistent with our focus on cash-to-cash returns.
It's Rob Jones from Liberum Capital.
Two questions, if I may.
First one, on realizations.
Obviously, it's positive to see average 49% uplift to carrying value and realized gains of GBP 190 million in the year.
You mentioned, obviously, it's a good selling environment for realizations, currently, and you're taking good advantage of these conditions.
When I turned to Page 21 of the section 2 of our pack in front of us, we've got Continental Europe's realizations falling from GBP 670 million to GBP 201 million, a fall of 70% year-on-year.
Does this concern you? It's possible.
We still have the goal in 2 or 3 years time to raise a fund focused on our Northern European/North American capability.
It's interesting that Eurofund V, the fund that we raised at the top of the market and spent largely at the top of the market did improve from 0.
75 cost to 0.
91 cost over the last year.
There is real momentum in terms of the recovery of value there.
The vintages of '11 and '12 that are in that fund are performing particularly well, I would say.
You don't have to get very far over 1 to start getting into the second and top quartiles.
And I'm ambitious for the team to really recover significant ground in that fund over the next few years, which will tie into when we want to raise the fund.
In the meantime, we have lots of capital to invest ourselves.
We have these 2 arrangements and we could well have others.
There is one here.
Chris? It's Philip Middleton from Merrill's.

I wonder if you can talk through what you see the implications for your business, and particularly in private equity would be, if the current conditions of strong realizations, difficult investment continues for a year or 2, because obviously -- for a time you can carry on selling responsibly, which is what you're doing and not worry about the investment levels, at some point you have to worry about them and I just wondered how you think about that? I think part of the shakeout going on in Private Equity is a reassessment by more experienced LPs as to how they want to gain exposure to this sector.
And many of the more sophisticated ones are looking at this type of arrangement in preference to being tied up in a general fund for 10 years.
So I do think that, that is part of this shift that is going on in the structural sense across the sector.
I don't think everyone is there.
But I think some of the more sophisticated investors are moving to that as their preferred route for investment.

If we look at how the market is developing and the pipeline in terms of potential investments, the comments I would make are, over the last 6 months, we've seen a very considerable improvement in pipeline potential investments.
It had been very lean prior to that period, particularly in terms of quality, as well as quantity.
So we've seen some better prospects in Northern Europe, as well as the U.
and Brazil.
We think these prospects are more interesting for both numerous and quality reasons.
And we've got pretty close on 2 investments in Europe, one we couldn't agree a final price with the vendor so we decided to pull back from that.
It was an engineering business based out of Germany.
And another business in Holland, we got overbid at the last stage of an auction with a very aggressive price from another Private Equity house.
So we are there.
We are in the game.
We have a better whip in Brazil and the U.
at the moment.
whip is particularly interesting, and it reflects businesses that we like, which have strong capabilities in both Europe and North America, like HILITE, like Element.
These sorts of businesses.
So I don't think we're going to see a prolonged phase where we're doing just selling and not investing.
I don't envisage that at all.
In any event, though, what I'd like to see in terms of the shape of the group is that we have about half the Private Equity investments we have today.
So we're on a bit of a journey to reduce that oversized portfolio.
We need to be more active on that side of things.
And I think the next few years will help us in that regard.
And yes, what we typically have in the other category are companies, which are valued on a different sort of basis.
So the majority of our portfolio is valued on an earnings basis.
We have some companies, which would be involved on industry metrics, for example, Hyperion is an example of that, that we've seen.
And of course, ACR would be another example.
So it's a multitude of things.
Okay, why don't I take the last bit first.
In terms of those arrangements, firstly, it's not discretionary money.
That money is there if they like the investment in question.
But these 2 institutions have been long-term investors with 3i in a number of structures, and we know each other extremely well, and they've been very active investors with the past.
So we have a high degree of confidence that they like what we like and they rate the current team, which is why they've entered into these framework agreements.
The economics of these framework agreements are equivalent to invested money economics in a more general buyout fund.
So they don't pay commitment fees, but they will pay deal fees, management fees and carry to the team in return for good performance there.
So they're very similar to invested money in a fund.
The taste of the 2 is a little different.
One likes to hit boundaries, fours and sixes in terms of the checks it writes.
On the other ones to have a slice of most of our deals with smaller checks.
So they're complementary in that regard.
They obviously don't want their name disclosed at this point.
But I think it will become evident as we invest who they are.
If we just talk about the 0s, it's quite a numerous -- it's a too numerous bucket, I'm afraid.
I don't know the exact number, but there's quite a lot of them, and enterprise was the most relevant recent example of that, and I'm sure some of them will be recovering above their base value.
But it will be single digits and millions or tens of millions.
It won't be hundreds of millions.
Good morning, everyone.
It's almost 1 year since I stood up in June 2012 to take you through the future strategy of 3i and our restructuring plan.
I'm pleased to say that we've made very significant and rapid progress in implementing that plan.
Our strong set of results for the year, which show material improvement across the board against 2012, clearly demonstrate the progress that we've made.
We've delivered against all of the priorities we set ourselves for the financial year ending March 2013 and, in particular, we've materially exceeded our cost and debt reduction targets.
We've seen considerable improvement in our Private Equity performance, including an impressive run of cash realizations.
In short, it's been a very good year of recovery for 3i after too many disappointing ones.
So I'd like to start by focusing on our strategic objectives and progress over the last year.
Julia will take you through the group's financial performance and I will then make some concluding remarks and throw it open to Q&A.
But first, I'd like to remind you about our strategy.
It's simple and embraces all 3 of our businesses: Private Equity, Infrastructure and Debt Management.

The combination of our complementary asset management capabilities across these 3 platforms, together with our permanent capital, gives our investors a differentiated and attractive value proposition.

Our 3 businesses are each different in terms of drivers and return characteristics, but they complement each other, and together, they're capable of providing an interesting balance of income and capital growth.
You will have seen this slide before.
It captures the key return drivers for each of our businesses, as well as demonstrating their cyclicality.

Now I bought shares in 3i because after analyzing the fundamentals of the group and its prospects, it was clear to me that the business, if run well, represented a compelling multiyear value proposition.
I was convinced that this value proposition was underpinned by valuable portfolio of investments and by the prospect of significant cash distributions over time.

Today, everybody at 3i sees the simplicity of growing the earnings of our portfolio, realizing our investments at attractive cash multiples, generating annual cash profits by running our 3 fund management businesses well, using our permanent capital to take advantage of value and growth opportunities, and turning this into cash for the benefit of LPs shareholders.
I hope it all sounds very simple, but it's actually taken quite a lot of hard work and careful thought to begin delivering on this strategy and moving 3i on to the solid footing it's on today.
We've had to put in some fundamental new asset management initiatives in Private Equity.
We've refocused that division and put a real emphasis on exit planning and smart execution.
Across our businesses, we are focusing on growing third-party AUM and growing our income against the rightsized cost base.

We've used our capital to exploit opportunities in the debt management sector, and we've reduced gross debt and our cost of funding, so that more of the cash goes back to shareholders and back to the business to be invested.
Our multiyear value build is based on a number of different phases of organizational change and strategic delivery.
We've delivered all of the strategic priorities we set for the financial year 2013.
And we're already progressing well in transition and delivery, the next phase of our plan.
You will recall that we set ourselves 6 strategic objectives last year.
So I'd now like to take you through our progress against each in a little more detail.
Last June, we said we'd reduce our headcount by 160 by the 31st of March.
In fact, we achieved a net headcount reduction of 168.
That's almost 40% of the group's headcount that we had in March last year.
And we closed the 6 offices we said we would, and we reduced our property expenses even further by making significant rental savings in both London and New York.
We originally targeted annualized cost savings of GBP 40 million by March '13 and, in fact, we cut out GBP 51 million.
That puts us 28% ahead of our target and also represents, coincidentally, a 28% reduction to our opening costs of GBP 185 million.
Over 70% of the staff reduction has come from the back office.
That's 119 out of the 168.
As a result, we have a better balance of investment staff versus back-office support.
And this slide gives you an idea of where the headcount reduction has taken place.
Geography has determined the reductions in the investment teams with finance, admin, property, IT, HR and marketing accounting for the 119 staff reductions in the group functions.
And here's a little more detail on where we've over-performed in cost reductions.
This slide gives you some examples of how further savings have come about.
In general, we have found additional savings through a sharper focus on cost control and by introducing much stronger approval mechanisms across the group.
We've also delayered to become a simple, less hierarchical organization.
As a result of our progress up to March 2013, we're today announcing a material increase in our cost reduction target for this current financial year to March 2014.
We're moving our total cost reduction target up to GBP 60 million from the original GBP 45 million.
So that represents a like-for-like reduction of almost 1/3 against our cost base of GBP 185 million in March last year.
As the benefits of the changes we've already implemented take place, and we continue to manage the business tightly, we will see further reductions.
And we'll be doing this at the same time that we're making sure that we have the right platform and the right level of support to grow our Debt Management and Infrastructure businesses.
And we've delivered another material win around the balance sheet.
Having set the target of GBP 1 billion of gross debt by June '13, we brought it down to close to GBP 900 million by April.
That's a reduction of 44% from our starting position of over GBP 1.
6 billion in March last year.
And that's a clear reflection of our success in realizing from our Private Equity portfolio.
An important part of restructuring over the last year has been to achieve a greater degree of central control and focus.
And to get there, we've removed organizational complexity and bureaucracy.
By removing committees and hierarchies, we've created a much more efficient organization.
When you combine that simplification with a more energized team, you can create a much more dynamic culture.
And that's exactly what we've done, a simple organization with shorter lines of communication leads to much faster and more consistent decision-making.
And that in turn is driving improved performance.
In June last year, we announced 6 new asset management initiatives in Private Equity.
That program has now been substantially implemented and is beginning to make a huge difference to the quality of our asset management in Private Equity.
You've seen some of this already with our realization successes and the improvements in the overall portfolio value, and we expect to see further benefits over time.
We've also refined our investment review process.
We've combined our separate investment and portfolio committee structures under one Investment Committee, which I chair.
The new Investment Committee considers all decisions from original investment ideas, right through to divestment.

We've also involved the Investment Committee earlier on in the investment process, and we've involved it in all material decisions in the life of an investment, such as refinancing and senior management changes.
With the geographic breadth and sheer scale of the 3i investment portfolio, I'm convinced these changes are critical.
We've tightened up our processes on asset management -- on management assessment, rather, and we made our approach consistent across all our investing teams.
And we've become much more proactive in replacing underperforming management.
Since September last year, we've replaced 11 Chairmen and CEOs after a proper evaluation of their performance.
And as most of you will recall, the introduction of the 3i dashboard last September has transformed how quickly we recognize and react to performance issues within our portfolio of companies.
It's working very well, and it's leading to new improved asset management performance across the entire portfolio.
Since March last year, we've increased the emphasis on developing detailed exit strategies for all our Private Equity investments.
We review and update those plans twice a year, with a view to optimizing cash proceeds for shareholders and LPs.

If an investment is ready to be sold, we'll take advantage of market conditions, but equally, we're prepared to think if there is better value down the road, or that we should -- we're prepared to consider refusing a cheap offer or waiting for better value down the road.
You've recently seen the results of this planning and execution with the sales of Mold-Masters and Civica and we have plans for each asset in our Private Equity portfolio.
In some cases, those plans run out a number of years.
In other cases, we have like -- companies likely to be sold in the near term.
It's been an excellent year for realizations.
We've generated a total of GBP 575 million.
It's an uplift of 49% over the opening book value and a money multiple of 2.
1x against our initial investment, not a bad performance in my book.
I'd also like to remind you again that I believe cash is the best measure of the performance of our investments.

I also feel that, in many cases, a focus on our current NAV fails to recognize the likely future or auction value for each of the investments we have and that we've set out in our individual exit plans.
And I hope our recent sales are convincing you that we've got this right.
We can achieve good premium offers when the financing markets are robust as they are right now.
We refocused our Private Equity business around Northern Europe, the U.
and Brazil.
We've suspended new investments in Asia and Spain, and we're highly selective in the core regions we are investing in.
It's no secret that this has been a difficult environment for investing.
And while we found some investing opportunities in Brazil, we've struggled to get comfortable with the pricing in Northern Europe, in particular.
So in this environment, we're delighted to be more focused on selling.
As most of you know, it has been a really good selling environment with strong financial markets and plenty of cash-rich private equity and corporate buyers.
And I think it's fair to say that our recent record shows that we are taking good advantage of these conditions.
The next slide I showed you last June.
The Private Equity portfolio has traded well in a generally very difficult macro environment.
We've had resilient performances in Northern Europe, the U.
and Brazil, some very tough conditions in Spain, and a rapid deterioration in the environment in France and some very tough conditions in India.
And when I review the Private Equity portfolio, I think about it in 4 buckets.
The keepers, e.
Action, Element, Mayborn, which offer terrific long-term growth.
Second is the strong performers, which we expect to good -- achieve good sales proceeds, like Civica, like Mold-Masters, which I mentioned just a minute ago.
The third bucket is made up of those investments which have the potential for material value recovery from where they have historically traded, companies such as Xellia, Azelis and OneMed.
And finally, what I call the 0s, which account for little of our NAV today, but represent option value, in the case that the enterprise value recovers above the level of the debt.
The company, Enterprise, was a good example of this category.
The third bucket is our largest bucket by cost of investments and has significant scope to increase value over time.
As you know, we conducted a group-wide compensation review this year.
At around 60% of operating costs, the payroll is our largest expense.
We've got to make sure we have a legitimate split of returns between shareholders and employees.
That's the only way we can retain both the right talent and create long-term shareholder value.
We have had broad shareholder support for our new proposals.
And these new compensation arrangements are to be introduced in June 2013.
Going forward, group compensation will be driven by how we perform against our key strategic objectives.
This will give us a much clearer link between staff compensation and shareholder returns.
In addition, a lot bigger proportion of total compensation will be in deferred shares of 3i Group plc.
For example, senior staff in the group will have a shareholding target, which will be set as a multiple of annual gross salary, so that we can enhance our alignment with shareholders.
We're already making strong progress in the next phase of our strategic plan, transition and delivery.
And this slide shows our key objectives for the year ahead.
We expect cash income to cover operating cost by March 2014 on a run rate basis.
And by the way, 3i has not done that for a very long time, to lead to a more balanced contribution to third-party fee income over time.
In Private Equity, we focused on finding the best way to reestablish our investment track record.
We've done that by investing alongside institutional coinvestors in Brazil and establishing 2 framework agreements for investing in Northern Europe.
One of these agreements is with a leading U.
institution and one is with a very large sovereign wealth fund.
Infrastructure continued to make a strong contribution to the group's cash income last year.
The European portfolio performed well, and the value of the holding in 3i Infrastructure increased by 7%.
We did see some pullback in the valuations of some of our Indian assets, given the challenging supply-side and macroeconomic conditions we face in India.
We've got one of the best teams in the Infrastructure sector, and our pipeline in European opportunities is good going into this financial year.
And we, therefore, expect to see good growth.
Our Debt Management business has had a very strong year.
They've almost doubled third-party funds under management to GBP 6.
They also acquired a very strong U.
franchise in Fraser Sullivan and issued almost 1 billion of CLOs in the U.
The business has a very experienced group of credit professionals and is well-placed to take advantage of further opportunities as this sector continues to change.
This financial year, we intend to pursue our enhanced capital distribution policy.
We've already met our goals for gearing of less than 20% and gross debt below GBP 1 billion.

We intend to distribute 15% to 20% of gross cash proceeds in the next 12 months, and the GBP 222 million from Mold-Masters is going to be part of this calculation, and all other realizations this year will contribute.
The current total, including Mold-Masters and realizations announced so far, is GBP 422 million.

So our priorities for the year are clear: To realize fully the benefits from the Private Equity asset management initiatives, continue to grow Debt Management and Infrastructure's third-party businesses, and look for new investments in Private Equity using proprietary capital and third-party coinvestors.
We'll further reduce our operating and funding costs and fully implement our new compensation arrangements.
So clearly, it's been a good year for 3i.
And I'd now like to ask Julia to take you through the numbers.

Ladies and gentlemen, good morning, and welcome to 3i's Interim Results.
We've had another good first half, with solid results across the group.
Despite the tricky macro and volatile stock markets, we're building real value growth across our investment portfolios.
We see a good level of realization activity, and we made some important new investments in North America and Germany.
And we have made good progress with group KPIs, with further reductions in operating and interest costs.
We've also delivered the growing base of cash realizations to underpin this year's dividend.
We secured GBP 324 million of realizations in the first half and another GBP 218 million of cash since then, including the successful placing of some of our stock in Quintiles last week.
The portfolio has performed well.
In fact, we've seen GBP 360 million of value growth and income based on strong earnings momentum in our larger investments, such as Action and Element.
Operating costs are now running at 1% of AUM compared to 1.
That's very much in line with or better than industry benchmarks, and this has helped in increasing our first half Fund Management profit of GBP 13 million.
Now as you know, I took over as CEO in May 2012, and we announced the new strategy for the group in June 2012.
Well, we've come along the way since then, and I'm pleased to say there is very strong momentum in the group today.

Even with adverse foreign currency markets, we've produced a good recovery in total returns underpinned by strong asset management and realization performance, a substantial reduction in cost and much improved cash flow.
That's the stuff that pays dividends to shareholders and cash back to LPs.
You should now all be familiar with our strategy.
It's simple and it includes all 3 of our businesses.

The combination of our complementary asset management capabilities across 3 platforms, together with our permanent capital, gives our shareholders a clearly differentiated and attractive value proposition.
Now I'd like to use the 3i Value Build, which we first presented in 2012, as the structure for today's presentation.
I'll comment on each of the steps starting with portfolio earnings.
Here are the 4 3i buckets which are used to analyze the Private Equity portfolio.
I've set down some examples for each bucket and the percentage of value using the 30th of September values that each bucket accounts for.
Back in May 2012, 3i had 130 investments, with too many in buckets 3 and 4.
So we've been on a journey with the aim of reducing that number of investments down to 40 or less, with those 40 comprising the 2 stronger buckets, 1 and 2.
We've had another good run of realizations, and the majority of which have come from our non-core buckets 3 and 4.
So the overall portfolio is increasingly dominated by our keepers or higher-value potential assets in bucket 1 or our strong performance in bucket 2.
In fact, the value weighted average LTM earnings growth of 17% across the portfolio is driven by the strong growth we are seeing across our larger investments in buckets 1 and 2.
While our companies in the top 2 buckets are more able to cope with a challenging macro climate, it is not always the case for those companies in buckets 3 and 4.

The strong market for realizations, which is underpinned by QE and lots of dry powder of potential buyers, has meant we've been able to trade out a number of our weaker or non-core companies at attractive valuations.

Our mid-market P portfolio has good earnings momentum, which compares very favorably with stock market comparables or indeed other PE portfolios and will underpin significant cash distributions from the group over the coming years.
We've overhauled our approach to asset management in 2012 and introducing 6 new initiatives and much greater productivity across the portfolio.
These changes, which encompass our monthly dashboard monitoring and more rigorous exit planning, are an important factor in the resilient performance of the portfolio we're seeing today.
And I thought this would be a useful time to look at the investments we made last year.
We made 4 investments, 3 new and 1 large follow-on in Scandlines.
And despite the competition for good assets, we bought them well at attractive entry multiples, an average across the floor of 8x EBITDA.
All are performing in line or ahead of plan, with average earnings growth of 23% over the last 12 months.
And I'd now like to give you a look at each of those investments.
Gift is a gem in testing and engineering business focused on transmission systems in the automotive sector.
We know the testing in automotive sectors extremely well, and Gift is a classic German Mittelstand business.
Our long-term plan is to reposition the business as much more of a pure-play testing business, with the value-added engineering capability and to continue its drive for international expansion.
The plan is going well, with the business expecting to generate EBITDA growth of 25% for the current financial year and a good buildup of sales in the China operation, in particular.
JMJ is a global leader in safety consultancy and works for major oil, industrial and aerospace companies around the world.
The business is based out of Austin, Texas, but it has a U.
It is a sector leader and is capable of significant international expansion as well as growing through entering new sectors.
It enjoyed strong levels of organic growth and has a very blue-chip roster of major clients such as Chevron, Shell and Lendlease.
The business was introduced to us by the Chairman of Element, which gave us the chance to buy the company away from an auction process.
Now I talked about Basic-Fit last year.
It's our discount gym format in the Benelux.
If you like, it's our action of the gym world.

Again, we purchased Basic-Fit away from a competitive process and have enjoyed some spectacular growth in the company's first year under our ownership, with 42 new clubs and the likely increase of over 50% in EBITDA this year.
We're now the market leader in both Holland and Belgium and have just started to open gyms in France and Spain.
So our new investments are performing well, and we have sensible in-prices against which to target our money multiple returns.
Gift and JMJ our classic bucket 2 investments, and it's already pretty clear the Basic-Fit is more likely to be a bucket 1 candidate.
We've delivered another good round of realizations and refinancing in the first half, and Julia will be giving more detail on this in her section.
We've continued to focus on this pulseless of non-core assets with just 1 sale from bucket 2 in the first half and another 2 highlight LHI closing last month.
At the 30th of September, we have reduced the number of investments to 72.
Now I'd also like to talk about 2 of those bucket 2 disposals, the DG highlight.
The DG, a French hospital group, was sold in September to CVC, netting 3i GBP 83 million of proceeds and a 2x money multiple in 4 years.
Now France is a very difficult market at present, and our Paris team did a great job in securing this exit on these terms.
We made a 48% profit over our March 14 book value on this sale.
Highlights, a German automotive group in which we bought in 2011 was another classic bucket 2 asset.
We refocused the group investing in R&D and expanding geographic sales through China, in particular.
1x our money through a very competitive auction process, eventually selling to a Chinese company, Avic Electromechanical Systems, at the end of October.
Now moving to the group.
Our operating cash profit continued it's been improving trajectory in the first half at GBP 60 million.
That reflects a further reduction in the cost base and improving income performance across our 3 businesses.
Debt Management has made a good contribution to net income.
To date, they've issued 4 CLOs, 2 in the U.
and 2 in Europe as well as growing their U.
Senior Loan Fund and achieving a first close on the European Middle Market Loan Fund at EUR 250 million this week.

The Infrastructure team has also had a productive first half, seeing strong growth in its core European portfolio and securing a steady flow of primary PPP investment opportunities as well as developing a pipeline of potential new core Infrastructure projects.
The India fund has remain challenging despite the election this year, but we did manage to sell some of our holding in power in thermal markets around the time of the election there.
Importantly, the Infrastructure team agreed an extension to the investment advisory agreement with 3iN at the beginning of the financial year.
Our strong balance sheet has facilitated further investments this year, which will provide good capital growth as well as income going forward.
We've made 2 new PE investment in the U.
this year as well as a further investment in Germany.
These are 2 of the stronger economies we're operating in today, and I'm pleased we're increasing the group's exposure to the U.
and Germany at this time.
All 3 investments are decent-sized businesses where we are confident of meeting our 2x return project on in-prices between 8.
5 and 9x EBITDA.
We took an opportunity to purchase an LP position in Eurofund V, increasing 3i's ownership to 57% of a fund that is now recovering very strongly.
And on the income front, we have seated 4 new CLOs as well as establishing new warehouse facilities for the further CLO launches.
We purchased Dynatech in August this year.
Dynatech is a U.
-based manufacturer of protective equipment, with operations in the U.
and Germany.
The industrial sector has been 3i's most consistent performer over many years, and the U.
and Germany have been key for that performance.
We've also signed an agreement to buy Q Holdings, another U.
group focused on the manufacture of precision-molded rubber and silicone components.
It has 6 manufacturing plants across the U.
and China as well as sales offices in Germany and Mexico.
A key part of our plan is to help the business grow organically and by acquisition in Europe.
We've also announced the purchase of Krist, a leading retailer of watches and jewelry Germany.
We have an existing presence in this segment through our Amor, our existing jewelry business, and we've been tracking Krist for some time.
So far, realization progress has been good with over GBP 540 million of cash from sales and refinancings, and we have a good number of sales and refinancings in progress at the moment.
So today, we're announcing an interim dividend of 2.
7p and an additional dividend of 3.
3p, making 6p in total as well as committing to at least a 15p total dividend for the year, given the projects and refinancings that we have in hand.
I'm pleased with this outcome, and Julia will give more detail in a few minutes.
Now when we first put the new plan together in June 2012, we expected FY '15 to be a relatively weak year for realizations but subject to markets, and that's a big but.
It now like it could turn out to be very much better than we originally planned.
We're continuing to see a very positive shift in capital efficiency and allocation as our operating costs come down further and we reduce our interest build.
So this is the fifth results presentation since we announced our restructuring and new strategy, and we've made material strides over that time.
After that deep restructuring in FY '13 and the resulting reduction in costs, we are now looking like a proper business, and all 3 of our divisions are performing well in terms of income this year.
The asset management initiatives are having a profound impact on the performance of our portfolio of PE investments.
We continue to see significant value growth and momentum, even after allowing for the rise in sterling over the last 12 months or so.
And the investments we have made in recent years are performing particularly well and demonstrating the power of the 3i model in the international mid-market.
We aim to buy at sensible prices and grow our businesses to generate consistent alpha for shareholders and investors.
Our strategic priorities for this year very much remain more of the same, thoughtful and well-executed asset management, careful new investment and tight cost control.
It's a tough environment out there, and there is no question the macro environment across much of Europe is becoming more difficult.
But I now have confidence that 3i is in a far stronger position to meet any of those challenges.
So let me close by saying another thank you to the team of 3i for all their good work in the first half and Pass over to Julia.

I mean, we all know with various complexions Continental Europe struggling, so are you saying that the opportunities are being pushed away don't fully reflect what is it going on in underlying economies? Justin on price.
I guess in both yours and Julia's presentation, the thread was talking about new investments of caution.
I'm just wondering what informs that view? Thank you, Simon.
I am delighted to be reporting another set of strong results.
Today's numbers demonstrate that we're continuing to do what we said we would do in the way we build value for our investors.
We delivered excellent momentum in our Private Equity portfolio, with valuated earnings growth of 17%.
We've made further progress on realizations at an average money multiple of 1.
We're sustaining an annual cash profit, with GBP 16 million in the first half.
During the period, we invested GBP 104 million of our Proprietary Capital and Private Equity and GBP 95 million to support further fundraising in Debt Management.
And we've confirmed that we expect to pay a total dividend this year of at least 15p, the 6p of that being declared today as an interim.
NAV at the 30th of September 2014 is 358p per share.
The strong earnings momentum in Private Equity, together with realized and operating profits, increased NAV per share by 36p.
The volatility in the currencies and strength in sterling continues to be a drag on the accounting return, reducing NAV by 8p.
And we also paid the final dividend for financial year 2014 in July of 13.
So the corresponding movements for the second quarter are shown on this slide, which shows a very similar story.
Simon spent some time talking about investment, so I'm going to focus on other aspects of the Value Build, starting with the performance of the Private Equity portfolio.
Here's our current view on the top 20 Private Equity investments, which now account for 77% of the total Proprietary Capital invested in Private Equity.
As you can see in the significant majority of cases, current performance is positive.
There's some strong progression in our larger assets.
Now obviously, we can't be entirely immune to the economic conditions in some of the markets where we operate, so, in particular, we stay cautious on investments in France and Spain.
The earnings growth is particularly strong at 17% on a valuated basis.
A key driver in that statistic is the performance of our largest asset, Action, which continues to show solid progression in its store rollout program and strong like-for-likes.
Excluding Action, the value-weighted earnings growth is still very good at 11%, so we're seeing good performance across the portfolio as a whole.
And that all the performance is reflected in unrealized value growth of GBP 308 million in the first half for our Private Equity investments.
Here's the breakdown of Private Equity value growth.
As well as earnings growth, the performance category reflects movements in net debt.
The value-weighted net debt for companies valued on an earnings basis was stable at 3.
Within that, we have taken the opportunity to refinance investments such as Element, Animal, plus Action has completed a sale and leaseback of its new distribution center.

Equity markets in our principal countries for investments were down in the second quarter and over the half as well, so it may seem surprising that we have GBP 13 million of value growth from multiple movements.
The weighted average multiple moved up from 9.
We've held Action at 12.
5x on a post-discount level, but since its value has increased, so has its weight on the average.
Excluding Action, the weighted average multiple is broadly flat at 9.
And within that, we've also taken a small number of multiples out to reflect derisking, such as refinancing or progress with an acquisition, for example.
I've talked previously about how we moderate our choice of multiples to value the portfolio.

You'll recall we look at company-specific factors and our longer-term view of expectations, and we felt for some time that market multiples were trading ahead of long-term average than transaction multiples.
This means that the multiples that we've used are generally lower by some margin than the straightforward comparable set would imply, and that margin acts a cushion in volatile markets.
Our monthly portfolio dashboard monitoring continue to play a fundamental role in our asset management strategy.
It allows us to identify when a portfolio company is not on track, so we can tackle potential issues quickly.

Of course, that doesn't mean that all our companies will always be on track, and to recognize that, as a matter of policy, we do use forecast earnings to value a company if they are lower than the last 12 months management's accounts.
Reflecting our more cautious outlook in Continental Europe, the number of companies that we've used forecast earnings for has gone up from 4 in March to 7.
By value, 69% of the Private Equity portfolio is valued on an earnings basis, and these 7 companies account for 12% of that value.
The imminent sell component includes highlights and LHI.
Both of these sales completed in October and, therefore, been converted into cash of GBP 189 million.
Finally, the DCF category relates mainly to our investments in Scandlines, which is also continuing to perform well since we made a further investment last year.
The very good realizations we've achieved in the period have validated the strong performance of our portfolio of companies.
Our exit from the DG, a French healthcare business, is a good example.

The uplift to opening book of 48% reflects the uncertainty that exists at the year-end about achieving this result, which was subject to French government clearance, so we're very pleased with this outcome.
We also took the opportunities to sell a number of investments, which would not be part of our investments strategy today.
A patient approach means we have still generated good money multiples in a wide range of situations, 1.
5x following the IPO and partial exit of Fibro, a U.
animal healthcare business in which we held a minority stake; 1.
8x on the sale of Fostering Partners where we've had a minority stake since 2007 and in which we've kept a loan investment; and 1.
9x on the sale of the minority stake in John Hardy, a Hong Kong Chinese jewelry design and distribution business and another 2007 asset.
As I mentioned earlier, we also took advantage of positive financing markets to refinance some of our best investments, creating opportunity for cash distribution.
You can see some of them here in Action, Element and Amore.
And since the end of the period, the completion of the highlight and LHI exits have delivered returns of 2.
9x, respectively.
And we've sold 20% of our investments in Quintiles above its quoted price of the 30th of September and adding another GBP 29 million of proceeds.
A feature of this half is the lower uplift to sale than we've seen in recent periods.
As you can see from the money multiples on this slide, the 12% does not mean we're doing less successful exits.
There are 2 factors having an influence.
The Phibro, Fostering Partners and John Hardy exits were very well progressed at the 31st of March and closed early in this period, so there's no further uplift to recognize.
And when we refinance an investment, it often results in the repayment of a portion of our original shareholder loans.
This will not result in a meaningful uplift.
It does concentrate value in the remaining equity.
Now as I talked about in May, a consequence of this good realized and unrealized value growth is the need to recognize the potential for carry that's payable to our investing teams.
We're through the performance hurdles from an accounting perspective, so we accrue carry payable between 10% and 15% on our gross investment returns.
This has continued in this first half as we accrued a further GBP 45 million.
Again, cash paid is much lower at GBP 7 million in the period.
Importantly, strong performance from Fresco, Quintiles and a number of other assets in the growth capital fund means that we're recognizing carry receivable on that fund for the first time.
We've also seen strong performance from assets owned by 3i Infrastructure plc and are recognizing a performance fee there, too.
You can see the details on this slide.
One of our key targets in restructuring the business was achieving the operating profit on a cash basis.
We achieved that key milestone in March, recording our first operating cash profit of GBP 5 million for the year.
Now this is not an easy target, so I'm delighted that we've made another profit in the first half of GBP 16 million.

I say it's easy because it continue to focus on keeping costs under control, whilst investing to develop fee income as well as finding sensible ways to generate cash income from a portfolio that principally delivers capital returns.
On costs, having taken the significant steps to reduce the March 2002 run rate of GBP 185 million by GBP 70 million, actual costs are now only 1% of assets under management.
With restructuring behind us, we're investing in people.

For example, we have recently recruited a number of investors in our Private Equity and Infrastructure teams and fund investment relations in Debt Management, and we have launched our graduate program in the last 6 months.
Now I've talked a lot about Private Equity so far.
This slide shows that Infrastructure and Debt Management are also important constituents of our strategic model.
The Debt Management team have had a very successful period of fundraising in the first half, and that will underpin their excellent contribution to the operating profit from fee income.
And the equity that we invest in the CLOs raised also generates a good cash yield.
Our investments in 3i Infrastructure plc generates good cash dividend income, and we provide advisory services to that business.
The agreement for those services was renegotiated and agreed in July, and that agreement secures further advisory and performance fees for at least another 5 years.
The combination of Private Equity, Infrastructure and Debt Management is important from a cash operating perspective.
It's also important with respect to our Fund Management platform.
We have made further improvement in the operating margin and absolute profitability of our Fund Management activities, as you can see here.
Simon has talked in detail about the new Private Equity investments we made in 2013.
We remain cautious and select investors in these markets.
In Private Equity, we may one new investment in the U.
business, now named Dynatech, and we also took an opportunity to acquire a small LP stake in Eurofund V, which increases our exposure to assets that we know very well.
After the period end, we completed a further Eurofund V investment, a gem and jewelry business called Krist and another new U.
deal, Q Holdings.
Together, these investments put another GBP 196 million of shareholder capital to work.
Finally, the success of the Debt Management business in raising new CLOs in the Europe and the U.
has led to further equity investment of EUR 27 million and $10 million, respectively, as well as continued support for warehouses to build portfolios ahead of future CLO raises.
Now in the light of the current market conditions, we remain happy being more active sellers than buyers and continuing to generate net divestment.
As a result, the balance sheet continues to strengthen.
Gross debt fell as we bought back our B shares in June, and we had some benefit from euro translation of the 2017 bond.
As I said previously, it doesn't really make economic sense to reduce our gross debt further at this stage.
Our credit is attractive, and investors have no obvious alternative, so any restructure would be fully priced.
We have taken advantage of financing conditions for our own revolving credit facilities.
At the beginning of September, we replaced our existing facilities of GBP 500 million, which were due to mature in 2016, with the new facility of GBP 350 million.
That new facility will mature at 2019 at the earliest.
And in terms under lower amount mean that we'll save about GBP 1.
5 million in our annual interest build.
With gearing up 5%, there's clearly no constraint in our ability to pay additional shareholder distributions under the policy that we've been operating since May 2012.
As a reminder, provided gross debt is less than GBP 1 billion and gearing is less than 20%, we will distribute 15% to 20% of gross realization proceeds.
That gives shareholders a direct participation in our success.
The total distribution will always be at least 8.
We call out our base dividend.
We've said that levels of investments will determine whether we pay at the 15% end of the range or the 20% end of the range.
This time last year, we had an unusually clear view of the likely alternative realizations for the full year.
That view was supported by the very strong first half sales and our decision to bring forward GBP 220 million of proceeds from the previous year.
This allowed us to confirm a total dividend of 20p at the half year results.
This time, we've had another strong start to the financial year, with over GBP 500 million of proceeds received or on their way, so we're well on track to at least meet previous guidance.
The realizations for this would be about the same level as last year or about GBP 700 million.
In setting the interim dividend today, we've taken the following approach.
Firstly, investment levels are improving, but they remain below our longer-term car rate.
Market conditions mean we remain cautious about investment outlook, therefore, we expect to be paying 20% of proceeds this year.
So with GBP 542 million proceeds received so far, we will pay 20% of that, which is a part of GBP 108 million.
Secondly, the cost of the base dividend is about GBP 77 million.
That means that the 8.
1p is already fully covered by the GBP 108 million, and we paid the base dividend 1/3, 2/3.
Thirdly, this leaves GBP 31 million in the pot, funding an additional dividend to date of 3.
So 6p declared today is made up of 1/3 of 8.
1p, which is 2.
7p, topped up by the 3.
3p additional.
Looking forward to the final.
We'll pay the remaining 2/3 of the base, being 5.
4p [ph] and 20% of further realizations.

And considering the visibility we have on the realizations pipeline and subject to market conditions outside our control, we expect the total dividend for FY 2015 to be at least 15p per share, including the 6p declared today.
So to sum up.
We are building value for our investors in the way that we said we would.
We have excellent earnings momentum in the Private Equity portfolio.
We continue to exit well.
Our disciplined focus on costs means we have a positive operating cash profit again.
We have made some careful new investments, and we expect our full year dividend of at least 15p, with 6p of that today declared as an interim.
Thank you very much, and we'll now go over to Q&A.

I wonder if you could say a little bit about the Fund Management business, in particular, the economics of that and the operating leverage in that? Do you feel that you've got the Infrastructure you need in place here, and therefore, new CLO launches would just add top line and profitably? Or do you still think you need to do some investing in that business? I think in the Debt Management business, we are -- we're moving through what I would call the low point, if you like, CLO -- old CLOs are coming off as we write new CLOs.
So I think we're moving into that positive territory, so you will see decent growth going forward if we remain at the same rate of issuance.
And we'll also see good growth coming from non-CLO funds.
I referred to 2 in the results today, the U.
Senior Loan Fund and then a middle market fund in Europe where they've just on their first close.
So we're investing in our business to grow that.
And providing begin stay at the same rate of issuance that we've seen, we do expect those numbers to move forward quite well.
Chris, up at the front, yes.
In terms of Krist, it's actually deemed a further investment in Eurofund V, so we did that together with the LPs in Eurofund V.
The other 2 investments, the North American investments, were 3i investments.

So it still sensible to assume high single digits low-double digits earnings growth? Yes, we probably bailed out of half a dozen processes at least this year, where the pricing has got away from us fairly quickly, and we just been uncomfortable with that.
So I would say, average pricing in the mid-market where we're looking is above 10x in Europe, and the better stuff is going for even higher than that.
And I'm just not convinced that 2x, 2x on that sort of level isn't going to be that easy with the outlook that we have.
So we are running out in those processes quite quickly.
Over at the back.
Do you want to do both? Daniel Garrod from Barclays.
Two questions from me.
There was a hit to the NAV from negative FX in the first half.
I wonder how much of that might have reversed in sort of October, November? If you could give us any color on that.
And second question, the -- x Action, the average multiple barely changed 9.

I wonder if you could provide any more color on the size of discounts that you use in the calculate that and how much that might have varied in the period? You have discretion over which companies to benchmark in your averages.

Are there some sort of sectors very actually sort of capped on multiple that you use by the upside that, that gives you a cushion on the way downside and whether any sector where the actually deep down hidden by the average of being flat? It's Anil Sharma from Morgan Stanley.
Couple of questions.
The first one is, with regards to the earnings growth of the company, obviously been quite a lot of caution today in your remarks.
I'm just trying to think, x Action, it was 11% earnings growth.
Obviously, 75% of the portfolio is U.
and Europe.

What your sort of expedition the next 12 months in terms of earnings growth sort of companies? And then the way you kind of split the buckets, 1 to 4, could you give us a sense of the vintage is in each of those buckets now? On what we're seeing at the moment, I would certainly think so.
I think the caution around the environment is more about realizations in refinancings.
There is confidence is required for those things.
We have a lot of stuff in trying.
If things don't change, that will be great, but if we have another October rolling out for 3 or 4 months, then it would obviously impact all sorts of markets.
Any others? Okay, thanks for coming along today.
Much appreciated.
Do you want to do both? It's Anil Sharma from Morgan Stanley.
Just a couple of questions.
The first one is with regards to the earnings growth of the company, obviously, there's been quite a lot of caution today in your remarks.
I'm just trying to think, x Action, it was 11% earnings growth.
Obviously, 75% of the portfolio is U.
and Europe.

How should -- what's your sort of expectation for the next 12 months in terms of earnings growth for this sort of companies? And then the way you kind of split the buckets, 1 to 4, could you give us a sense of the vintages in each of those buckets now? In terms of Christ, it's actually deemed a further investment in Eurofund V.
So we did that together with the LPs in Eurofund V.
The other 2 investments, the North American investments, were 3i investments.
Well, I think we've put some general caution out there about the economies across Europe, in particular.
And maybe if I can touch on that and then talk about the investments specifically, we're seeing quite a mixed bag of performance.
So we find that our portfolios in Germany and Benelux are doing well.
Germany, we think the economy, in the shape of the companies we have, has proved quite resilient.
In Benelux, we're very exposed to the discount sector.
So whether it's Basic-Fit or whether it's Action, it's the right part of that market to be in because it's quite a tough market at the time.
Scandinavia is a mixed bag.
We think Sweden is pretty strong at the moment.
It's quite like the U.
, we would suggest, whereas Finland is really struggling.
So Finland, we think, is really weak and has deteriorated as has France.
There's been a marked deterioration, in our view, in France this year, particularly from late spring, early summer, and we don't see any change in that.
So that's why we were particularly pleased to come out of Vedici in the way that we did.
Spain, we still think, is a difficult economy.
It's better than it was, but nothing's easy in Spain.
Two strong economies would be North America, in particular, and the U.
-- and the U.

And in terms of looking at where we're putting money to the work, what we're seeing at the moment is more attractive pricing generally in North America than in Europe because there is a better balance of supply of targets in the States than there is here at the moment.

So we can hunt in the middle of America for these nice industrial companies that we're quite good at and find those processes are very much less competitive than anything good that happens to come up in Continental Europe.
Christ played to us because people could see we had a degree of synergy with our existing jewelry investment in Germany and, therefore, were put off competing with us for that asset.
So that was a very sensible purchase, at this time, of a very good business.
So it's harder to find stuff of value in Europe at the moment, I would say, and it's more attractive in the States.
So it's still sensible to assume high single-digit, low double-digit earnings growth? I think it was reflective of the asset value at March and under the asset value at September.
Any more questions? Yes, one at the front here.
Daniel Garrod from Barclays.
