Are there some sort of sectors where you're actually sort of capped on multiple that you use on the upside that then gives you cushion on the way downside? And were there any sectors, actually, where the multiples did go down? It's just dwarfed by the -- no, hidden by the average of being flat.
Ladies and gentlemen, good morning, and welcome to 3i's Interim Results.
We've had another good first half, with solid results across the group.
Despite the tricky macro and volatile stock markets, we're building real value growth across our investment portfolios.
We've seen a good level of realization activity, and we've made some important new investments in North America and Germany.
And we have made good progress with group KPIs, with further reductions in operating and interest costs.
We've also delivered a growing base of cash realizations to underpin this year's dividend.
We secured GBP 324 million of realizations in the first half and another GBP 218 million of cash since then, including the successful placing of some of our stock in Quintiles last week.
The portfolio has performed well.
In fact, we've seen GBP 360 million of value growth and income based on strong earnings momentum in our larger investments, such as Action and Element.
Operating costs are now running at 1% of AUM compared to 1.
That's very much in line with or better than industry benchmarks, and this has helped in increasing our first half Fund Management profit of GBP 13 million.
Now as you know, I took over as CEO in May 2012, and we announced the new strategy for the group in June 2012.
Well, we've come a long a way since then, and I'm pleased to say there is very strong momentum in the group today.

Even with adverse foreign currency markets, we've produced a good recovery in total returns underpinned by strong asset management and realization performance, a substantial reduction in costs and much improved cash flow.
That's the stuff that pays dividends to shareholders and cash back to LPs.
You should now all be familiar with our strategy.
It's simple and it includes all 3 of our businesses.

The combination of our complementary asset management capabilities across 3 platforms, together with our permanent capital, gives our shareholders a clearly differentiated and attractive value proposition.
Now I'd like to use the 3i Value Build, which we first presented in 2012, as the structure for today's presentation.
I'll comment on each of the steps, starting with portfolio earnings.
Here are the 4 3i buckets, which I used to analyze the Private Equity portfolio.
I've set down some examples for each bucket and the percentage of value using the 30th September values that each bucket accounts for.
Back in May 2012, 3i had 130 investments, with too many in buckets 3 and 4.
So we've been on a journey with the aim of reducing that number of investments down to 40 or less, with those 40 comprising the 2 stronger buckets, 1 and 2.
We've had another good run of realizations, and the majority of which have come from our non-core buckets 3 and 4.
So the overall portfolio is increasingly dominated by our keepers or higher-value potential assets in bucket 1 or our strong performance in bucket 2.
In fact, the value weighted average LTM earnings growth of 17% across the portfolio is driven by the strong growth we are seeing across our larger investments in buckets 1 and 2.

While our companies in the top 2 buckets are more able to cope with the challenging macro climate, it is not always the case for those companies in buckets 3 and 4, but the strong market for realizations, which is underpinned by QE and lots of dry powder of potential buyers, has meant we have been able to trade out a number of our weaker or non-core companies at attractive valuations.

Our mid-market PE portfolio has good earnings momentum, which compares very favorably with stock market comparables or, indeed, other PE portfolios and will underpin significant cash distributions from the group over the coming years.
We've overhauled our approach to asset management in 2012 and introducing 6 new initiatives and much greater productivity across the portfolio.

These changes, which encompassed our monthly dashboard monitoring and more rigorous exit planning, are an important factor in the resilient performance of the portfolio we're seeing today, and I thought this would be a useful time to look at the investments we made last year.

We made 4 investments, 3 new and 1 large follow-on in Scandlines, and despite the competition for good assets, we bought them well at attractive entry multiples, an average across the floor of 8x EBITDA.
All are performing in line or ahead of plan, with average earnings growth of 23% over the last 12 months.
And I'd now like to give you a look at each of those investments.
GIF is a German testing and engineering business focused on transmission systems in the automotive sector.
We know the testing on automotive sectors extremely well, and GIF is a classic German Mittelstand business.
Our long-term plan is to reposition the business as much more of a pure-play testing business with the value-added engineering capability and to continue its drive for international expansion.
The plan is going well, with the business expecting to generate EBITDA growth of 25% for the current financial year and a good buildup of sales in the China operation, in particular.
JMJ is a global leader in safety consultancy and works for major oil, industrial and aerospace companies around the world.
The business is based out of Austin, Texas, but it has a U.
It is a sector leader and is capable of significant international expansion as well as growing [ph] through entering new sectors.
It enjoys strong levels of organic growth and has a very blue-chip roster of major clients, such as Chevron, Shell and Lend Lease.
The business was introduced to us by the Chairman of Element, which gave us the chance to buy the company away from an auction process.
Now I talked about Basic-Fit and its founder, Rene Moos, last year.
It's our discount gym format in the Benelux.
If you like, it's our Action of the gym world.

Again, we purchased Basic-Fit away from a competitive process and have enjoyed some spectacular growth in the company's first year under our ownership, with 42 new clubs and a likely increase of over 50% in EBITDA this year.
We are now the market leader in both Holland and Belgium and have just started to open gyms in France and Spain.
So our new investments are performing well, and we have sensible end prices against which to target our money multiple returns.
GIF and JMJ are classic bucket 2 investments, and it's already pretty clear the Basic-Fit is more likely to be a bucket 1 candidate.
We've delivered another good round of realizations and refinancing in the first half, and Julia will be giving you more detail on this in her section.
We've continued to focus on disposals of non-core assets, with just one sale from bucket 2 in the first half and another 2, Hilite and LHi, closing last month.
At the 30th of September, we had reduced the number of investments to 72.
Now I'd also like to talk about 2 of those bucket 2 disposals, Vedici and Hilite.
Vedici, a French hospital group, was sold in September to CVC, netting 3i GBP 83 million of proceeds and a 2x money multiple in 4 years.
Now France is a very difficult market at present, and our Paris team did a great job in securing this exit on these terms.
We made a 48% profit over our March 14 book value on this sale.
Hilite, a German automotive group which we bought in 2011, was another classic bucket 2 asset.
We refocused the group, investing in R&D and expanding geographic sales through China, in particular.
1x our money through a very competitive auction process, eventually selling to a Chinese company, AVIC Electromechanical Systems, at the end of October.
Now moving to the group.
Our operating cash profit continued its improving trajectory in the first half at GBP 16 million.
That reflects a further reduction in the cost base and improving income performance across our 3 businesses.
Debt Management has made a good contribution to that income.
To date, they have issued 4 CLOs, 2 in the U.
and 2 in Europe, as well as grown their U.
Senior Loan Fund and achieving a first close on a European Middle Market Loan Fund at EUR 250 million this week.

The Infrastructure team has also had a productive first half, seeing strong growth in its core European portfolio and securing a steady flow of primary PPP investment opportunities as well as developing a pipeline of potential new core infrastructure projects.
The India Fund has remained challenging despite the election this year, but we did manage to sell some of our holding in Adani Power in thermal markets around the time of the election there.
Importantly, the Infrastructure team agreed an extension to the investment advisory agreement with 3iN at the beginning of the financial year.
Our strong balance sheet has facilitated further investments this year, which will provide good capital growth as well as income going forward.
We've made 2 new PE investments in the U.
this year as well as a further investment in Germany.
These are 2 of the stronger economies we're operating in today, and I am pleased we're increasing the group's exposure to the U.
and Germany at this time.
All 3 investments are decent-sized businesses, where we are confident of meeting our 2x return target on end prices of between 8.
5 and 9x EBITDA.

We took an opportunity to purchase an LP position in Eurofund V, increasing 3i's ownership to 57% of a fund that is now recovering very strongly, and on the income front, we have seeded 4 new CLOs as well as establishing new warehouse facilities for the further CLO launches.
We purchased Dynatect in August this year.
Dynatect is a U.
-based manufacturer of protective equipment, with operations in the U.
and Germany.
The industrial sector has been 3i's most consistent performer over many years, and the U.
and Germany have been key to that performance.
We've also signed an agreement to buy Q Holdings, another U.
group focused on the manufacture of precision-molded rubber and silicone components.
It has 6 manufacturing plants across the U.
and China as well as sales offices in Germany and Mexico.
A key part of our plan is to help the business grow organically and by acquisition in Europe.
We've also announced the purchase of Christ, a leading retailer of watches and jewelry Germany.
We have an existing presence in this segment through Amor, our existing jewelry business, and we've been tracking Christ for some time.
So far, realization progress has been good, with over GBP 540 million of cash from sales and refinancings, and we have a good number of sales and refinancings in progress at the moment.
So today, we're announcing an interim dividend of 2.
7p and an additional dividend of 3.
3p, making 6p in total, as well as committing to at least a 15p total dividend for the year given the projects and refinancings that we have in hand.
I'm pleased with this outcome, and Julia will give you more detail in a few minutes.

Now when we first put the new plan together in June 2012, we expected FY '15 to be a relatively weak year for realizations, but subject to markets -- and that's a big but, it now looks like it could turn out to be very much better than we originally planned.
We're continuing to see a very positive shift in capital efficiency and allocation as our operating costs come down further and we reduce our interest bill.
So this is the fifth results presentation since we announced our restructuring and new strategy, and we have made material strides over that time.
After the deep restructuring in FY '13 and the resulting reduction in costs, we are now looking like a proper business, and all 3 of our divisions are performing well in terms of income this year.
The asset management initiatives are having a profound impact on the performance of our portfolio of PE investments.

We continue to see significant value growth and momentum even after allowing for the rise in sterling over the last 12 months or so, and the investments we have made in recent years are performing particularly well and demonstrating the power of the 3i model in the international mid-market.
We aim to buy at sensible prices and grow our businesses to generate consistent alpha for shareholders and investors.
Our strategic priorities for this year very much remain more of the same: thoughtful and well-executed asset management, careful new investment and tight cost control.

It's a tough environment out there, and there is no question the macro environment across much of Europe is becoming more difficult, but I now have confidence that 3i is in a far stronger position to meet any of those challenges.
So let me close by saying another thank you to the team of 3i for all their good work in the first half and pass over to Julia.
Thanks, Julia.
We have some mics for Q&A, so if you -- this is being recorded, so if you could wait for a mic and then say your name and give us your question.
Daniel? Okay.
Let me try and answer those 2 questions.
I think in -- my words of caution are really focused on the macro in certain countries and the volatility in the financial markets.
They're not focused on the performance of our companies in buckets 1 and 2.
We have very good momentum in most of those companies, and as I said in my words, they're the sort of companies who can cope.
We have a difficult environment, and that's what we're seeing.
So there's no stop warning about that aspect of our portfolio.
To the second point, the bigger and the newer companies tend to be heavily represented in buckets 1 and 2.
So that's where the value is.
That's where the stronger momentum is.
A lot of the '07, '08 type companies are in buckets 3 and 4, if I were to generalize in that way.
Nothing we've bought recently is in bucket 4.
I can assure you that.
So I mean, we all know that with various complexions, Continental Europe is struggling.

So are you saying that the opportunities that are being pushed away don't fully reflect what is going on in underlying economies? And just another question, could you perhaps disclose what sort of price relative to asset value was paid for the stake in Eurofund V? It's Justin Thomson from T.
Rowe Price.
I guess, in both yours and Julia's presentation, the thread was talking about new investments of caution.
I'm just wondering what informs that view.
I think in the Debt Management business, we're moving through, what I would call, the low point in that, if you like, CLO -- old CLOs are coming off as we write new CLOs.
So I think we're moving into net positive territory.
So you will see decent growth going forward if we remain at the same rate of issuance, and we'll also see good growth coming from non-CLO funds.
I referred to 2 in the results today, the U.
Senior Loan Fund and the new Middle Market Fund in Europe, where they adjust [ph] on the first close.
So we're investing in our business to grow that, and providing we can stay at the same rate of issuance that we've seen, we do expect those numbers to move forward quite well.
Chris? Up at the front here.
Thank you, Simon.
I am delighted to be reporting another set of strong results.
Today's numbers demonstrate that we're continuing to do what we said we would do in the way we build value for our investors.
We delivered excellent momentum in our Private Equity portfolio, with valuated earnings growth at 17%.
We've made further progress on realizations at an average money multiple of 1.
We're sustaining an annual cash profit, with GBP 16 million in the first half.

During the period, we invested GBP 104 million of our Proprietary Capital and Private Equity and GBP 95 million to support further fund-raising in Debt Management, and we've confirmed that we expect to pay a total dividend this year of at least 15p, the 6p of that being declared today as an interim.
NAV at the 30th of September 2014, is 358p per share.
The strong earnings momentum in Private Equity, together with realized and operating profits, increased NAV per share by 36p.
The volatility in currencies and strength in sterling continued to be a drag on the accounting return, reducing NAV by 8p, and we also paid the final dividend for financial year 2014 in July of 13.
So the corresponding movements for the second quarter are shown on this slide, which shows a very similar story.
Simon spent some time talking about investment.
So I'm going to focus on other aspects of the Value Build, starting with the performance of the Private Equity portfolio.
Here's our current view on the top 20 Private Equity investments, which now account for 77% of the total Proprietary Capital invested in Private Equity.
As you can see, in the significant majority of cases, current performance is positive.
There's some strong progression in our larger assets.
Now obviously, we can't be entirely immune to the economic conditions in some of the markets where we operate.
So, in particular, we stay cautious on investments in France and Spain.
The earnings growth is particularly strong at 17% on a valuated basis.
A key driver in that statistic is the performance of our largest asset, Action, which continues to show solid progression in its store rollout program and strong like-for-likes.
Excluding Action, the value-weighted earnings growth is still very good at 11%.

So we're seeing good performance across the portfolio as a whole, and that solid performance is reflected in unrealized value growth of GBP 308 million in the first half for our Private Equity investments.
Here's the breakdown of Private Equity value growth.
As well as earnings growth, the performance category reflects movements in net debt.
The value-weighted net debt for companies valued on an earnings basis was stable at 3.
Within that, we have taken the opportunity to refinance investments, such as Element and Amor, plus Action has completed a sale and leaseback of its new distribution center.
Equity markets in our principal countries for investment were down in the second quarter and over the half as well.
So it may seem surprising that we have GBP 13 million of value growth from multiple movements.
The weighted average multiple moved up from 9.
We've held Action at 12.
5x on a post-discount level, but since its value has increased, so has its weight in the average.
Excluding Action, the weighted average multiple is broadly flat at 9.
1x, and within that, we've also taken a small number of multiples out to reflect derisking, such as refinancing or progress with an acquisition, for example.
I've talked previously about how we moderate our choice of multiples to value the portfolio.

You will recall we look at company-specific factors and our longer-term view of expectations, and we felt for some time that market multiples were trading ahead of long-term average transaction multiples.
This means that the multiples that we've used are generally lower by some margin than the straightforward comparable set would imply, and that margin acts as a cushion in volatile markets.
Our monthly portfolio dashboard monitoring continue to play a fundamental role in our asset management strategy.
It allows us to identify when a portfolio company is not on track so we can tackle potential issues quickly.

Of course, that doesn't mean that all our companies will always be on track, and to recognize that, as a matter of policy, we use forecast earnings to value a company if they are lower than the last 12 months' management accounts.
Reflecting our more cautious outlook in Continental Europe, the number of companies that we've used forecast earnings for has gone up from 4 in March to 7.
By value, 69% of the Private Equity portfolio is valued on an earnings basis, and these 7 companies account for 12% of that value.
The imminent sale component includes Hilite and LHi.
Both of these sales completed in October and have, therefore, been converted into cash of GBP 189 million.
Finally, the DCF category relates mainly to our investment in Scandlines, which has also continued to perform well since we made our further investment last year.
The very good realizations we've achieved in the period have validated the strong performance of our portfolio of companies.
Our exit from Vedici, a French health care business, is a good example.
The uplift to opening book of 48% reflects the uncertainty that existed at the year-end about achieving this result, which was subject to French government clearance.
So we're very pleased with this outcome.
We also took the opportunity to sell a number of investments, which would not be part of our investment strategy today.
A patient approach means we have still generated good money multiples in a wide range of situations, 1.
5x following the IPO and partial exit of Phibro, a U.
animal health care business in which we held a minority stake; 1.
8x on the sale of Foster + Partners, where we've had a minority stake since 2007 and in which we've kept a loan investment; and 1.
9x on the sale of the minority stake in John Hardy, a Hong Kong Chinese jewelry design and distribution business and another 2007 asset.
As I mentioned earlier, we also took advantage of positive financing markets to refinance some of our best investments, creating the opportunity for cash distribution.
You can see some of them here in Action, Element and Amor.
And since the end of the period, the completion of the Hilite and LHi exits have delivered returns of 2.
9x, respectively, and we've sold 20% of our investments in Quintiles above its quoted price at the 30th of September and adding another GBP 29 million of proceeds.
A feature of this half is the lower uplift to sale than we've seen in recent periods.
As you can see from the money multiples on this slide, the 12% does not mean we're doing less successful exits.
There are 2 factors having an influence.
The Phibro, Foster + Partners and John Hardy exits were very well progressed at the 31st of March and closed early in this period.
So there's no further uplift to recognize.
And when we refinance an investment, it often results in the repayment of a portion of our original shareholder loans.
This will not result in a meaningful uplift.
It does concentrate value in the remaining equity.
Now as I talked about in May, a consequence of this good realized and unrealized value growth is the need to recognize the potential for carry that's payable to our investing teams.
We're through the performance hurdles from an accounting perspective.
So we accrue carry payable between 10% and 15% on our gross investment returns.
This has continued in this first half as we accrued a further GBP 45 million.
Again, cash paid is much lower at GBP 7 million in the period.
Importantly, strong performance from Refresco, Quintiles and a number of other assets in the growth capital fund means that we're recognizing carry receivable on that fund for the first time.
We've also seen strong performance from assets owned by 3i Infrastructure plc and are recognizing a performance fee there, too.
You can see the details on this slide.
One of our key targets in restructuring the business was achieving the operating profit on a cash basis.
We achieved that key milestone in March, recording our first operating cash profit of GBP 5 million for the year.
Now this is not an easy target.
So I'm delighted that we have made another profit in the first half of GBP 16 million.

I say it isn't easy because it needs continued focus on keeping costs under control whilst investing to develop fee income as well as finding sensible ways to generate cash income from a portfolio that principally delivers capital returns.
On costs, having taken the significant steps to reduce the March 2002 run rate of GBP 185 million by GBP 70 million, actual costs are now only 1% of assets under management.
With restructuring behind us, we're investing in people.

For example, we have recently recruited a number of investors in our Private Equity and Infrastructure teams and in fund investor relations in Debt Management, and we have launched our graduate program in the last 6 months.
Now I've talked a lot about Private Equity so far.
This slide shows that Infrastructure and Debt Management are also important constituents of our strategic model.

The Debt Management team have had a very successful period of fund-raising in the first half, and that will underpin their excellent contribution to the operating profit from fee income, and the equity that we invest in the CLOs raised also generates a good cash yield.
Our investment in 3i Infrastructure plc generates good cash dividend income, and we provide advisory services to that business.
The agreement for those services was renegotiated and agreed in July, and that agreement secures further advisory and performance fees for at least another 5 years.
The combination of Private Equity, Infrastructure and Debt Management is important from a cash operating perspective.
It's also important with respect to our Fund Management platform.
We have made further improvement in the operating margin and absolute profitability of our Fund Management activities, as you can see here.
Simon has talked in detail about the new Private Equity investments we made in 2013.
We remain cautious and selective investors in these markets.
In Private Equity, we made one new investment in a U.
business, now named Dynatect, and we also took an opportunity to acquire a small LP stake in Eurofund V, which increases our exposure to assets that we know very well.
After the period end, we completed a further Eurofund V investment, a German jewelry business called Christ, and another new U.
deal, Q Holdings.
Together, these investments put another GBP 196 million of shareholder capital to work.
Finally, the success of the Debt Management business in raising new CLOs in Europe and the U.
has led to further equity investment of EUR 27 million and $10 million, respectively, as well as continued support for warehouses to build portfolios ahead of future CLO raises.
Now in the light of the current market conditions, we remain happy being more active sellers than buyers and continuing to generate net divestment.
As a result, the balance sheet continues to strengthen.
Gross debt fell as we bought back our B shares in June, and we had some benefit from euro translation of the 2017 bond.
As I said previously, it doesn't really make economic sense to reduce our gross debt further at this stage.
Our credit is attractive, and investors have no obvious alternative.
So any restructure would be fully priced.
We have taken advantage of financing conditions for our own revolving credit facilities.
At the beginning of September, we replaced our existing facilities of GBP 500 million, which were due to mature in 2016, with a new facility of GBP 350 million.
That new facility will mature at 2019 at the earliest, and improved terms and the lower amount mean that we'll save about GBP 1.
5 million on our annual interest bill.
With gearing at 5%, there's clearly no constraint on our ability to pay additional shareholder distributions under the policy that we've been operating since May 2012.
As a reminder, provided gross debt is less than GBP 1 billion and gearing is less than 20%, we will distribute 15% to 20% of gross realization proceeds.
That gives shareholders a direct participation in our success.
The total distribution will always be at least 8.
We call that our base dividend.
We've said that levels of investments will determine whether we pay at the 15% end of the range or the 20% end of the range.
This time last year, we had an unusually clear view of the likely outturn of realizations for the full year.
That view was supported by the very strong first half sales and our decision to bring forward GBP 220 million of proceeds from the previous year.
This allowed us to confirm a total dividend of 20p at the half year results.
This time, we've had another strong start to the financial year with over GBP 500 million of proceeds received or on their way.
So we're well on track to at least meet our previous guidance that realizations for the year would be about the same level as last year or about GBP 700 million.
In setting the interim dividend today, we've taken the following approach: Firstly, investment levels are improving, but they remain below our longer-term par rate.
Market conditions mean we remain cautious about investment outlook.
Therefore, we expect to be paying 20% of proceeds this year.
So with GBP 542 million proceeds received so far, we will pay 20% of that, which is at pot of GBP 108 million.
Secondly, the cost of the base dividend is about GBP 77 million.
That means that the 8.
1p is already fully covered by the GBP 108 million, and we paid the base dividend 1/3, 2/3.
Thirdly, this leaves GBP 31 million in the pot, funding an additional dividend to date of 3.
So the 6p declared today is made up of 1/3 of 8.
1p, which is 2.
7p, topped up by the 3.
3p additional.
Looking forward to the final, we'll pay the remaining 2/3 of the base, being 5.
4p, and 20% of further realizations.

And considering the visibility that we have on the realizations pipeline and subject to market conditions outside our control, we expect the total dividend for FY 2015 to be at least 15p per share, including the 6p declared today.
So to sum up.
We are building value for our investors in the way that we said we would.
We have excellent earnings momentum in the Private Equity portfolio.
We continue to exit well.
Our disciplined focus on costs means we have a positive operating cash profit again.
We have made some careful new investments, and we expect our full year dividend of at least 15p, with 6p of that today declared as an interim.
Thank you very much, and we'll now go over to Q&A.
We've probably bailed out of half a dozen processes at least this year, where the pricing has got away from us fairly quickly and we've just been uncomfortable with that.
So I would say, average pricing in the mid-market, where we're looking, is above 10x in Europe, and the better stuff is going for even higher than that.
And I'm just not convinced that 2x on that sort of level isn't going to be that easy with the outlook that we have.
So we are running out in those processes quite quickly.
Over at the back.
On what we're seeing at the moment, I would certainly think so.
I think the caution around the environment is more about realizations and refinancings.
This confidence is required for those things.
We have a lot of stuff in train [ph].
If things don't change, that will be great, but if we have another October rolling out for 3 or 4 months, then it will obviously impact all sorts of market.
Any others? Okay, thanks for coming along today.
I much appreciate it.
Philip? I wonder if you could say a little bit about the Fund Management business, in particular the economics of that and the operating leverage in that.

The last time I looked, it was -- about GBP 27 million had reversed.
We have given you the sensitivity, again, in the pack.
I think it's on Slide 51, where you can see what a 1% movement in the currency does based on the net assets at the 30th of September.
On the multiples, as you said, excluding Action, which -- as I explained, we didn't move the multiple.
It's one of our highest multiples in the valuations at 12.
5x on a post-discount basis and it's our largest Private Equity asset.
So holding that flat for the value going up pushes up the multiple average including it.
Elsewhere, we have been doing this for a while.

When we set -- when we look at the concepts that we're choosing, we're looking at a number of factors, things that you'd expect, the right sector, the absolute size of the company, its relative performance, the levels of leverage.
And they're pretty bespokely chosen now in terms of how we then adjust that comp set to the asset that we're trying to value.
It's all the more important because the top 20 is 77% of the values.
So it makes sense to be quite precise in the way that we do that.
Because of that, I can't really give you sort of a thematic in this sector we have taken this approach.
We have absolutely looked at some of our businesses, where we have a view about likely exit multiple.
And as we've seen, the market moved away at the beginning of this calendar year.
We've effectively kept that multiple.

It doesn't mean we hold the multiples completely flat, and as I mentioned in a couple of stronger cases of our assets, we treat multiples up slightly, where they completed refinancing or made some progress with the transformation.
We've had a number of multiples that have gone, in fact, down in the period as well.
So it's quite a mixture, but the strong performance has kept the multiples overall flat.

The other 2 investments, the North American investments, were 3i investments.

and Europe.

Chris Brown from JPMorgan Caz.
Just on the new investments, to what extent did your new coinvestors take part in those? Ladies and gentlemen, good morning, and welcome to 3i's Interim Results.
We've had another good first half, with solid results across the group.
Despite the tricky macro and volatile stock markets, we're building real value growth across our investment portfolios.
We've seen a good level of realization activity, and we've made some important new investments in North America and Germany.
And we have made good progress with group KPIs, with further reductions in operating and interest costs.
We've also delivered a growing base of cash realizations to underpin this year's dividend.
We secured GBP 324 million of realizations in the first half and another GBP 218 million of cash since then, including the successful placing of some of our stock in Quintiles last week.
The portfolio has performed well.
In fact, we've seen GBP 360 million of value growth and income based on strong earnings momentum in our larger investments, such as Action and Element.
Operating costs are now running at 1% of AUM compared to 1.
That's very much in line with or better than industry benchmarks, and this has helped in increasing our first half Fund Management profit of GBP 13 million.
Now as you know, I took over as CEO in May 2012, and we announced a new strategy for the group in June 2012.
Well, we've come a long a way since then, and I'm pleased to say there is very strong momentum in the group today.

Even with adverse foreign currency markets, we've produced a good recovery in total returns underpinned by strong asset management and realization performance, a substantial reduction in costs and much improved cash flow.
That's the stuff that pays dividends to shareholders and cash back to LPs.
You should now all be familiar with our strategy.
It's simple and it includes all 3 of our businesses.

The combination of our complementary asset management capabilities across 3 platforms, together with our permanent capital, gives our shareholders a clearly differentiated and attractive value proposition.
Now I'd like to use the 3i Value Build, which we first presented in 2012, as the structure for today's presentation.
I'll comment on each of the steps, starting with portfolio earnings.
Here are the 4 3i buckets, which I used to analyze the Private Equity portfolio.
I've set down some examples for each bucket and the percentage of value using the 30th September values that each bucket accounts for.
Back in May 2012, 3i had 130 investments, with too many in buckets 3 and 4.
So we've been on a journey with the aim of reducing that number of investments down to 40 or less, with those 40 comprising the 2 stronger buckets, 1 and 2.
We've had another good run of realizations, and the majority of which have come from our non-core buckets 3 and 4.
So the overall portfolio is increasingly dominated by our keepers or higher-value potential assets in bucket 1 or our strong performance in bucket 2.
In fact, the value weighted average LTM earnings growth of 17% across the portfolio is driven by the strong growth we are seeing across our larger investments in buckets 1 and 2.

While our companies in the top 2 buckets are more able to cope with the challenging macro climate, it is not always the case for those companies in buckets 3 and 4, but the strong market for realizations, which is underpinned by QE and lots of dry powder or potential buyers, has meant we have been able to trade out a number of our weaker or non-core companies at attractive valuations.

Our mid-market PE portfolio has good earnings momentum, which compares very favorably with stock market comparables or, indeed, other PE portfolios and will underpin significant cash distributions from the group over the coming years.
We've overhauled our approach to asset management in 2012 and are introducing 6 new initiatives and much greater productivity across the portfolio.

These changes, which encompassed our monthly dashboard monitoring and more rigorous exit planning, are an important factor in the resilient performance of the portfolio we're seeing today, and I thought this would be a useful time to look at the investments we made last year.
We made 4 investments, 3 new and 1 large follow-on in Scandlines, and despite the competition for good assets, we bought them well at attractive entry multiples, an average across the 4 of 8x EBITDA.
All are performing in line or ahead of plan, with average earnings growth of 23% over the last 12 months.
And I'd now like to give you a look at each of those investments.
GIF is a German testing and engineering business focused on transmission systems in the automotive sector.
We know the testing and automotive sectors extremely well, and GIF is a classic German Mittelstand business.
Our long-term plan is to reposition the business as much more of a pure-play testing business with the value-added engineering capability and to continue its drive for international expansion.
The plan is going well, with the business expecting to generate EBITDA growth of 25% for the current financial year and a good buildup of sales in the China operation, in particular.
JMJ is a global leader in safety consultancy and works for major oil, industrial and aerospace companies around the world.
The business is based out of Austin, Texas, but it has a U.
It is a sector leader and is capable of significant international expansion as well as growing through entering new sectors.
It enjoys strong levels of organic growth and has a very blue-chip roster of major clients, such as Chevron, Shell and Lend Lease.
The business was introduced to us by the Chairman of Element, which gave us the chance to buy the company away from an auction process.
Now I talked about Basic-Fit and its founder, Rene Moos, last year.
It's our discount gym format in the Benelux.
If you like, it's our Action of the gym world.

Again, we purchased Basic-Fit away from a competitive process and have enjoyed some spectacular growth in the company's first year under our ownership, with 42 new clubs and a likely increase of over 50% in EBITDA this year.
We are now the market leader in both Holland and Belgium and have just started to open gyms in France and Spain.
So our new investments are performing well, and we have sensible end prices against which to target our money multiple returns.
GIF and JMJ are classic bucket 2 investments, and it's already pretty clear the Basic-Fit is more likely to be a bucket 1 candidate.
We've delivered another good round of realizations and refinancings in the first half, and Julia will be giving you more detail on this in her section.
We've continued to focus on disposals of non-core assets, with just one sale from bucket 2 in the first half and another 2, Hilite and LHi, closing last month.
At the 30th of September, we had reduced the number of investments to 72.
Now I'd also like to talk about 2 of those bucket 2 disposals, Vedici and Hilite.
Vedici, a French hospital group, was sold in September to CVC, netting 3i GBP 83 million of proceeds and a 2x money multiple in 4 years.
Now France is a very difficult market at present, and our Paris team did a great job in securing this exit on these terms.
We made a 48% profit over our March 14 book value on this sale.
Hilite, a German automotive group which we bought in 2011, was another classic bucket 2 asset.
We refocused the group, investing in R&D and expanding geographic sales through China, in particular.
1x our money through a very competitive auction process, eventually selling to a Chinese company, AVIC Electromechanical Systems, at the end of October.
Now moving to the group.
Our operating cash profit continued its improving trajectory in the first half at GBP 16 million.
That reflects a further reduction in the cost base and improving income performance across our 3 businesses.
Debt Management has made a good contribution to that income.
To date, they have issued 4 CLOs, 2 in the U.
and 2 in Europe, as well as growing their U.
Senior Loan Fund and achieving a first close on a European Middle Market Loan Fund at EUR 250 million this week.

The Infrastructure team has also had a productive first half, seeing strong growth in its core European portfolio and securing a steady flow of primary PPP investment opportunities as well as developing a pipeline of potential new core infrastructure projects.
The India Fund has remained challenging despite the election this year, but we did manage to sell some of our holding in Adani Power in firmer markets around the time of the election there.
Importantly, the Infrastructure team agreed an extension to the investment advisory agreement with 3iN at the beginning of the financial year.
Our strong balance sheet has facilitated further investments this year, which will provide good capital growth as well as income going forward.
We've made 2 new PE investments in the U.
this year as well as a further investment in Germany.
These are 2 of the stronger economies we're operating in today, and I am pleased we're increasing the group's exposure to the U.
and Germany at this time.
All 3 investments are decent-sized businesses, where we are confident of meeting our 2x return target on end prices of between 8.
5 and 9x EBITDA.

We took an opportunity to purchase an LP position in Eurofund V, increasing 3i's ownership to 57% of a fund that is now recovering very strongly, and on the income front, we have seeded 4 new CLOs as well as establishing new warehouse facilities for the further CLO launches.
We purchased Dynatect in August this year.
Dynatect is a U.
-based manufacturer of protective equipment, with operations in the U.
and Germany.
The industrial sector has been 3i's most consistent performer over many years, and the U.
and Germany have been key to that performance.
We've also signed an agreement to buy Q Holdings, another U.
group focused on the manufacture of precision-molded rubber and silicone components.
It has 6 manufacturing plants across the U.
and China as well as sales offices in Germany and Mexico.
A key part of our plan is to help the business grow organically and by acquisition in Europe.
We've also announced the purchase of Christ, a leading retailer of watches and jewelry in Germany.
We have an existing presence in this segment through Amor, our existing jewelry business, and we've been tracking Christ for some time.
So far, realization progress has been good, with over GBP 540 million of cash from sales and refinancings, and we have a good number of sales and refinancings in progress at the moment.
So today, we're announcing an interim dividend of 2.
7p and an additional dividend of 3.
3p, making 6p in total, as well as committing to at least a 15p total dividend for the year given the projects and refinancings that we have in hand.
I'm pleased with this outcome, and Julia will give you more detail in a few minutes.

Now when we first put the new plan together in June 2012, we expected FY '15 to be a relatively weak year for realizations, but subject to markets -- and that's a big but, it now looks like it could turn out to be very much better than we originally planned.
We're continuing to see a very positive shift in capital efficiency and allocation as our operating costs come down further and we reduce our interest bill.
So this is the fifth results presentation since we announced our restructuring and new strategy, and we have made material strides over that time.
After the deep restructuring in FY '13 and the resulting reduction in costs, we are now looking like a proper business, and all 3 of our divisions are performing well in terms of income this year.
The asset management initiatives are having a profound impact on the performance of our portfolio of PE investments.

We continue to see significant value growth and momentum even after allowing for the rise in sterling over the last 12 months or so, and the investments we have made in recent years are performing particularly well and demonstrating the power of the 3i model in the international mid-market.
We aim to buy at sensible prices and grow our businesses to generate consistent alpha for shareholders and investors.
Our strategic priorities for this year very much remain more of the same: thoughtful and well-executed asset management, careful new investment and tight cost control.

It's a tough environment out there, and there is no question the macro environment across much of Europe is becoming more difficult, but I now have confidence that 3i is in a far stronger position to meet any of those challenges.
So let me close by saying another thank you to the team of 3i for all their good work in the first half and pass over to Julia.
Daniel Garrod from Barclays.
Two questions from me.
There was an AP hit to the NAV from negative FX in the first half.
I wonder if you track how much of that might have reversed in sort of October, November, if you could give us any color on that.
And the second question, the x Action, the average multiple barely changed, 9.
I wonder if you could provide any more color on the size of discounts that you're using to calculate that and how much that might have varied in the period.
You have discretion over which companies to benchmark in your averages.

Are there some sort of sectors where you're actually sort of capped on multiple that you use on the upside that then gives you cushion on the way downside? And were there any sectors, actually, where the multiples did go down? It's just dwarfed by the -- hidden by the average of being flat.
Well, I think we've put some general caution out there about the economies across Europe, in particular.
And maybe if I can touch on that and then talk about the investments specifically.
We're seeing quite a mixed bag of performance.
So we find that our portfolios in Germany and Benelux are doing well.
Germany, we think the economy and the shape of the companies we have, has proved quite resilient.
In Benelux, we're very exposed to the discount sector.
So whether it's Basic-Fit or whether it's Action, it's the right part of that market to be in because it's quite a tough market at the time.
Scandinavia is a mixed bag.
We think Sweden is pretty strong at the moment.
It's quite like the U.
, we would suggest, whereas Finland is really struggling.
So Finland, we think, is really weak and has deteriorated as has France.
There's been a marked deterioration, in our view, in France this year, particularly from late spring, early summer, and we don't see any change in that.
So that's why we were particularly pleased to come out of Vedici in the way that we did.
Spain, we still think, is a difficult economy.
It's better than it was, but nothing's easy in Spain.
Two strong economies would be North America, in particular, and the U.
-- and the U.

And in terms of looking at where we're putting money to the work, what we're seeing at the moment is more attractive pricing generally in North America than in Europe because there is a better balance of supply of targets in the States than there is here at the moment.

So we can hunt in the middle of America for these nice industrial companies that we're quite good at and find those processes are very much less competitive than anything good that happens to come up in Continental Europe.
Christ played to us because people could see we had a degree of synergy with our existing jewelry investment in Germany and, therefore, were put off competing with us for that asset.
So that was a very sensible purchase, at this time, of a very good business.
So it's harder to find stuff of value in Europe at the moment, I would say, and it's more attractive in the States.
Yes, it's one my favorite jobs, is tracking the FX movements on a daily basis, and we have recouped quite a bit since the end of September.
The last time I looked, it was -- about GBP 27 million had reversed.
We have given you the sensitivity, again, in the pack.
I think it's on Slide 51, where you can see what a 1% movement in the currency does based on the net assets at the 30th of September.
On the multiples, as you said, excluding Action, which -- as I explained, we didn't move the multiple.
It's one of our highest multiples in the valuations at 12.
5x on a post-discount basis and it's our largest Private Equity asset.
So holding that flat with the value going up pushes up the multiple average including it.
Elsewhere, we have been doing this for a while.

When we set -- when we look at the comp sets that we're choosing, we're looking at a number of factors, things that you'd expect, the right sector, the absolute size of the company, its relative performance, the levels of leverage.
And they're pretty bespokely chosen now in terms of how we then adjust that comp set to the asset that we're trying to value.
It's all the more important because the top 20 is 77% of the value.
So it makes sense to be quite precise in the way that we do that.
Because of that, I can't really give you sort of a thematic "in this sector we have taken this approach.
" We have absolutely looked at some of our businesses, where we have a view about likely exit multiple.
And as we've seen, the market move away at the beginning of this calendar year, we've effectively kept that multiple.

It doesn't mean we hold the multiples completely flat, and as I mentioned in a couple of stronger cases of our assets, we tweaked multiples up slightly, where they completed refinancing or made some progress with the transformation.
We've had a number of multiples that have gone flat down in the period as well.
So it's quite a mixture, but the strong performance has kept the multiples overall flat.
Thank you, Simon.
I am delighted to be reporting another set of strong results.
Today's numbers demonstrate that we're continuing to do what we said we would do in the way we build value for our investors.
We delivered excellent momentum in our Private Equity portfolio, with valuated earnings growth of 17%.
We've made further progress on realizations at an average money multiple of 1.
We're sustaining an annual cash profit, with GBP 16 million in the first half.

During the period, we invested GBP 104 million of our Proprietary Capital in Private Equity and GBP 95 million to support further fund-raising in Debt Management, and we've confirmed that we expect to pay a total dividend this year of at least 15p, the 6p of that being declared today as an interim.
NAV at the 30th of September 2014, is 358p per share.
The strong earnings momentum in Private Equity, together with realized and operating profits, increased NAV per share by 36p.
The volatility in currencies and strength in sterling continue to be a drag on the accounting return, reducing NAV by 8p, and we also paid the final dividend for financial year 2014 in July of 13.
So the corresponding movements for the second quarter are shown on this slide, which shows a very similar story.
Simon spent some time talking about investment.
So I'm going to focus on other aspects of the Value Build, starting with the performance of the Private Equity portfolio.
Here's our current view on the top 20 Private Equity investments, which now account for 77% of the total Proprietary Capital invested in Private Equity.
As you can see, in the significant majority of cases, current performance is positive.
There's some strong progression in our larger assets.
Now obviously, we can't be entirely immune to the economic conditions in some of the markets where we operate.
So, in particular, we stay cautious on investments in France and Spain.
The earnings growth is particularly strong at 17% on a valuated basis.
A key driver in that statistic is the performance of our largest asset, Action, which continues to show solid progression in its store rollout program and strong like-for-likes.
Excluding Action, the value-weighted earnings growth is still very good at 11%.

So we're seeing good performance across the portfolio as a whole, and that solid performance is reflected in unrealized value growth of GBP 308 million in the first half for our Private Equity investments.
Here's the breakdown of Private Equity value growth.
As well as earnings growth, the performance category reflects movements in net debt.
The value-weighted net debt for companies valued on an earnings basis was stable at 3.
Within that, we have taken the opportunity to refinance investments, such as Element and Amor, plus Action has completed a sale and leaseback of its new distribution center.
Equity markets in our principal countries for investment were down in the second quarter and over the half as well.
So it may seem surprising that we have GBP 13 million of value growth from multiple movements.
The weighted average multiple moved up from 9.
We've held Action at 12.
5x on a post-discount level, but since its value has increased, so has its weight in the average.
Excluding Action, the weighted average multiple is broadly flat at 9.
1x, and within that, we've also taken a small number of multiples up to reflect derisking, such as refinancing or progress with an acquisition, for example.
I've talked previously about how we moderate our choice of multiples to value the portfolio.

You will recall we look at company-specific factors and our longer-term view of expectations, and we felt for some time that market multiples were trading ahead of long-term average transaction multiples.
This means that the multiples that we've used are generally lower by some margin than the straightforward comparable set would imply, and that margin acts as a cushion in volatile markets.
Our monthly portfolio dashboard monitoring continues to play a fundamental role in our asset management strategy.
It allows us to identify when a portfolio company is not on track so we can tackle potential issues quickly.

Of course, that doesn't mean that all our companies will always be on track, and to recognize that, as a matter of policy, we use forecast earnings to value a company if they are lower than the last 12 months' management accounts.
Reflecting our more cautious outlook in Continental Europe, the number of companies that we've used forecast earnings for has gone up from 4 in March to 7.
By value, 69% of the Private Equity portfolio is valued on an earnings basis, and these 7 companies account for 12% of that value.
The imminent sale component includes Hilite and LHi.
Both of these sales completed in October and have, therefore, been converted into cash of GBP 189 million.
Finally, the DCF category relates mainly to our investment in Scandlines, which has also continued to perform well since we made our further investment last year.
The very good realizations we've achieved in the period have validated the strong performance of our portfolio of companies.
Our exit from Vedici, a French health care business, is a good example.
The uplift to opening book of 48% reflects the uncertainty that existed at the year-end about achieving this result, which was subject to French government clearance.
So we're very pleased with this outcome.
We also took the opportunity to sell a number of investments, which would not be part of our investment strategy today.
A patient approach means we have still generated good money multiples in a wide range of situations, 1.
5x following the IPO and partial exit of Phibro, a U.
animal health care business in which we held a minority stake; 1.
8x on the sale of Foster + Partners, where we've had a minority stake since 2007 and in which we've kept a loan investment; and 1.
9x on the sale of the minority stake in John Hardy, a Hong Kong Chinese jewelry design and distribution business and another 2007 asset.
As I mentioned earlier, we also took advantage of positive financing markets to refinance some of our best investments, creating the opportunity for cash distribution.
You can see some of them here in Action, Element and Amor.
And since the end of the period, the completion of the Hilite and LHi exits have delivered returns of 2.
9x, respectively, and we've sold 20% of our investments in Quintiles above its quoted price at the 30th of September and adding another GBP 29 million of proceeds.
A feature of this half is the lower uplift to sale than we've seen in recent periods.
As you can see from the money multiples on this slide, the 12% does not mean we're doing less successful exits.
There are 2 factors having an influence.
The Phibro, Foster + Partners and John Hardy exits were very well progressed at the 31st of March and closed early in this period.
So there's no further uplift to recognize.
And when we refinance an investment, it often results in the repayment of a portion of our original shareholder loans.
This will not result in a meaningful uplift.
It does concentrate value in the remaining equity.
Now as I talked about in May, a consequence of this good realized and unrealized value growth is the need to recognize the potential for carry that's payable to our investing teams.
We're through the performance hurdles from an accounting perspective.
So we accrue carry payable between 10% and 15% on our gross investment returns.
This has continued in this first half as we accrued a further GBP 45 million.
Again, cash paid is much lower at GBP 7 million in the period.
Importantly, strong performance from Refresco, Quintiles and a number of other assets in the growth capital fund means that we're recognizing carry receivable on that fund for the first time.
We've also seen strong performance from assets owned by 3i Infrastructure plc and are recognizing a performance fee there, too.
You can see the details on this slide.
One of our key targets in restructuring the business was to achieve an operating profit on a cash basis.
We achieved that key milestone in March, recording our first operating cash profit of GBP 5 million for the year.
Now this is not an easy target.
So I'm delighted that we have made another profit in the first half of GBP 16 million.

I say it isn't easy because it needs continued focus on keeping costs under control whilst investing to develop fee income as well as finding sensible ways to generate cash income from a portfolio that principally delivers capital returns.
On costs, having taken the significant steps to reduce the March 2002 run rate of GBP 185 million by GBP 70 million, actual costs are now only 1% of assets under management.
With restructuring behind us, we're investing in people.

For example, we have recently recruited a number of investors in our Private Equity and Infrastructure teams and in fund investor relations in Debt Management, and we have launched our graduate program in the last 6 months.
Now I've talked a lot about Private Equity so far.
This slide shows why Infrastructure and Debt Management are also important constituents of our strategic model.

The Debt Management team have had a very successful period of fund-raising in the first half, and that will underpin their excellent contribution to the operating profit from fee income, and the equity that we invest in the CLOs raised also generates a good cash yield.
Our investment in 3i Infrastructure plc generates good cash dividend income, and we provide advisory services to that business.
The agreement for those services was renegotiated and agreed in July, and that agreement secures further advisory and performance fees for at least another 5 years.
The combination of Private Equity, Infrastructure and Debt Management is important from a cash operating perspective.
It's also important with respect to our Fund Management platform.
We have made further improvement in the operating margin and absolute profitability of our Fund Management activities, as you can see here.
Simon has talked in detail about the new Private Equity investments we made in 2013.
We remain cautious and selective investors in these markets.
In Private Equity, we made one new investment in a U.
business, now named Dynatect, and we also took an opportunity to acquire a small LP stake in Eurofund V, which increases our exposure to assets that we know very well.
After the period end, we completed a further Eurofund V investment, a German jewelry business called Christ, and another new U.
deal, Q Holdings.
Together, these investments put another GBP 196 million of shareholder capital to work.
Finally, the success of the Debt Management business in raising new CLOs in Europe and the U.
has led to further equity investment of EUR 27 million and $10 million, respectively, as well as continued support for warehouses to build portfolios ahead of future CLO raises.
Now in the light of the current market conditions, we remain happy being more active sellers than buyers and continuing to generate net divestment.
As a result, the balance sheet continues to strengthen.
Gross debt fell as we bought back our B shares in June, and we had some benefit from euro translation of the 2017 bond.
As I said previously, it doesn't really make economic sense to reduce our gross debt further at this stage.
Our credit is attractive, and investors have no obvious alternative.
So any restructure would be fully priced.
We have taken advantage of financing conditions for our own revolving credit facilities.
At the beginning of September, we replaced our existing facilities of GBP 500 million, which were due to mature in 2016, with a new facility of GBP 350 million.
That new facility will mature at 2019 at the earliest, and improved terms and the lower amount mean that we'll save about GBP 1.
5 million on our annual interest bill.
With gearing at 5%, there's clearly no constraint on our ability to pay additional shareholder distributions under the policy that we've been operating since May 2012.
As a reminder, provided gross debt is less than GBP 1 billion and gearing is less than 20%, we will distribute 15% to 20% of gross realization proceeds.
That gives shareholders a direct participation in our success.
The total distribution will always be at least 8.
We call that our base dividend.
We've said that levels of investments will determine whether we pay at the 15% end of the range or the 20% end of the range.
This time last year, we had an unusually clear view of the likely outturn of realizations for the full year.
That view was supported by the very strong first half sales and our decision to bring forward GBP 220 million of proceeds from the previous year.
This allowed us to confirm a total dividend of 20p at the half year results.
This time, we've had another strong start to the financial year with over GBP 500 million of proceeds received or on their way.
So we're well on track to at least meet our previous guidance that realizations for the year would be about the same level as last year or about GBP 700 million.
In setting the interim dividend today, we've taken the following approach: Firstly, investment levels are improving, but they remain below our longer-term par rate.
Market conditions mean we remain cautious about investment outlook.
Therefore, we expect to be paying 20% of proceeds this year.
So with GBP 542 million proceeds received so far, we will pay 20% of that, which is a pot of GBP 108 million.
Secondly, the cost of the base dividend is about GBP 77 million.
That means that the 8.
1p is already fully covered by the GBP 108 million, and we paid the base dividend 1/3, 2/3.
Thirdly, this leaves GBP 31 million in the pot, funding an additional dividend to date of 3.
So the 6p declared today is made up of 1/3 of 8.
1p, which is 2.
7p, topped up by the 3.
3p additional.
Looking forward to the final, we'll pay the remaining 2/3 of the base, being 5.
4p, and 20% of further realizations.

And considering the visibility that we have on the realizations pipeline and subject to market conditions outside our control, we expect the total dividend for FY 2015 to be at least 15p per share, including the 6p declared today.
So to sum up.
We are building value for our investors in the way that we said we would.
We have excellent earnings momentum in the Private Equity portfolio.
We continue to exit well.
Our disciplined focus on costs means we have a positive operating cash profit again.
We have made some careful new investments, and we expect our full year dividend of at least 15p, with 6p of that today declared as an interim.
Thank you very much, and we'll now go over to Q&A.
Philip? Okay.
Let me try and answer those 2 questions.
I think in -- my words of caution are really focused on the macro in certain countries and the volatility in the financial markets.
They're not focused on the performance of our companies in buckets 1 and 2.
We have very good momentum in most of those companies, and as I said in my words, they're the sort of companies who can cope with a difficult environment, and that's what we're seeing.
So there's no stock warning about that aspect of our portfolio.
To the second point, the bigger and the newer companies tend to be heavily represented in buckets 1 and 2.
So that's where the value is.
That's where the stronger momentum is.
A lot of the '07, '08 type companies are in buckets 3 and 4, if I were to generalize in that way.
Nothing we've bought recently is in bucket 4.
I can assure you of that.
Thanks, Julia.
We have some mics for Q&A, so if you -- this is being recorded, so if you could wait for a mic and then say your name and give us your question.
Daniel? Well, I think we've put some general caution out there about the economies across Europe, in particular.
And maybe if I can touch on that and then talk about the investments specifically.
We're seeing quite a mixed bag of performance.
So we find that our portfolios in Germany and Benelux are doing well.
Germany, we think the economy and the shape of the companies we have, has proved quite resilient.
In Benelux, we're very exposed to the discount sector.
So whether it's Basic-Fit or whether it's Action, it's the right part of that market to be in because it's quite a tough market at the time.
Scandinavia is a mixed bag.
We think Sweden is pretty strong at the moment.
It's quite like the U.
, we would suggest, whereas Finland is really struggling.
So Finland, we think, is really weak and has deteriorated as has France.
There's been a marked deterioration, in our view, in France this year, particularly from late spring, early summer, and we don't see any change in that.
So that's why we were particularly pleased to come out of Vedici in the way that we did.
Spain, we still think, is a difficult economy.
It's better than it was, but nothing's easy in Spain.
Two strong economies would be North America, in particular, and the U.
-- and the U.

And in terms of looking at where we're putting money to the work, what we're seeing at the moment is more attractive pricing generally in North America than in Europe because there is a better balance of supply of targets in the States than there is here at the moment.

So we can hunt in the middle of America for these nice industrial companies that we're quite good at and find those processes are very much less competitive than anything good that happens to come up in Continental Europe.
Christ played to us because people could see we had a degree of synergy with our existing jewelry investment in Germany and, therefore, were put off competing with us for that asset.
So that was a very sensible purchase, at this time, of a very good business.
So it's harder to find stuff of value in Europe at the moment, I would say, and it's more attractive in the States.
So it's still sensible to assume high single-digit to low double-digit earnings growth? Thank you, Simon.
I am delighted to be reporting another set of strong results.
Today's numbers demonstrate that we're continuing to do what we said we would do in the way we build value for our investors.
We delivered excellent momentum in our Private Equity portfolio, with value-weighted earnings growth of 17%.
We've made further progress on realizations at an average money multiple of 1.
We're sustaining an annual cash profit, with GBP 16 million in the first half.

During the period, we invested GBP 104 million of our Proprietary Capital in Private Equity and GBP 95 million to support further fund-raising in Debt Management, and we've confirmed that we expect to pay a total dividend this year of at least 15p, with 6p of that being declared today as an interim.
NAV at the 30th of September 2014, is 358p per share.
The strong earnings momentum in Private Equity, together with realized and operating profits, increased NAV per share by 36p.
The volatility in currencies and strength in sterling continue to be a drag on the accounting return, reducing NAV by 8p, and we also paid the final dividend for financial year 2014 in July of 13.
So the corresponding movements for the second quarter are shown on this slide, which shows a very similar story.
Simon spent some time talking about investment.
So I'm going to focus on other aspects of the Value Build, starting with the performance of the Private Equity portfolio.
Here's our current view on the top 20 Private Equity investments, which now account for 77% of the total Proprietary Capital invested in Private Equity.
As you can see, in the significant majority of cases, current performance is positive with some strong progression in our larger assets.
Now obviously, we can't be entirely immune to the economic conditions in some of the markets where we operate.
So, in particular, we stay cautious on investments in France and Spain.
The earnings growth is particularly strong at 17% on a value-weighted basis.
A key driver in that statistic is the performance of our largest asset, Action, which continues to show solid progression in its store rollout program and strong like-for-likes.
Excluding Action, the value-weighted earnings growth is still very good at 11%.

So we're seeing good performance across the portfolio as a whole, and that solid performance is reflected in unrealized value growth of GBP 308 million in the first half for our Private Equity investments.
Here's the breakdown of Private Equity value growth.
As well as earnings growth, the performance category reflects movements in net debt.
The value-weighted net debt for companies valued on an earnings basis was stable at 3.
Within that, we have taken the opportunity to refinance investments, such as Element and Amor, plus Action has completed a sale and leaseback of its new distribution center.
Equity markets in our principal countries for investment were down in the second quarter and over the half as well.
So it may seem surprising that we have GBP 13 million of value growth from multiple movements.
The weighted average multiple moved up from 9.
We've held Action at 12.
5x on a post-discount level, but since its value has increased, so has its weight in the average.
Excluding Action, the weighted average multiple is broadly flat at 9.
1x, and within that, we've also taken a small number of multiples up to reflect derisking, such as refinancing or progress with an acquisition, for example.
I've talked previously about how we moderate our choice of multiples to value the portfolio.

You will recall we look at company-specific factors and our longer-term view of expectations, and we felt for some time that market multiples were trading ahead of long-term average transaction multiples.
This means that the multiples that we've used are generally lower by some margin than the straightforward comparable set would imply, and that margin acts as a cushion in volatile markets.
Our monthly portfolio dashboard monitoring continues to play a fundamental role in our asset management strategy.
It allows us to identify when a portfolio company is not on track so we can tackle potential issues quickly.

Of course, that doesn't mean that all our companies will always be on track, and to recognize that, as a matter of policy, we use forecast earnings to value a company if they are lower than the last 12 months' management accounts.
Reflecting our more cautious outlook in Continental Europe, the number of companies that we've used forecast earnings for has gone up from 4 in March to 7.
By value, 69% of the Private Equity portfolio is valued on an earnings basis, and these 7 companies account for 12% of that value.
The imminent sale component includes Hilite and LHi.
Both of these sales completed in October and have, therefore, been converted into cash of GBP 189 million.
Finally, the DCF category relates mainly to our investment in Scandlines, which has also continued to perform well since we made our further investment last year.
The very good realizations we've achieved in the period have validated the strong performance of our portfolio of companies.
Our exit from Vedici, a French health care business, is a good example.
The uplift to opening book of 48% reflects the uncertainty that existed at the year-end about achieving this result, which was subject to French government clearance.
So we're very pleased with this outcome.
We also took the opportunity to sell a number of investments, which would not be part of our investment strategy today.
A patient approach means we have still generated good money multiples in a wide range of situations, 1.
5x following the IPO and partial exit of Phibro, a U.
animal health care business in which we held a minority stake; 1.
8x on the sale of Foster + Partners, where we've had a minority stake since 2007 and in which we've kept a loan investment; and 1.
9x on the sale of the minority stake in John Hardy, a Hong Kong Chinese jewelry design and distribution business and another 2007 asset.
As I mentioned earlier, we also took advantage of positive financing markets to refinance some of our best investments, creating the opportunity for cash distribution.
You can see some of them here in Action, Element and Amor.
And since the end of the period, the completion of the Hilite and LHi exits have delivered returns of 2.
9x, respectively, and we've sold 20% of our investments in Quintiles above its quoted price at the 30th of September and adding another GBP 29 million of proceeds.
A feature of this half is the lower uplift to sale than we've seen in recent periods.
As you can see from the money multiples on this slide, the 12% does not mean we're doing less successful exits.
There are 2 factors having an influence.
The Phibro, Foster + Partners and John Hardy exits were very well progressed at the 31st of March and closed early in this period.
So there's no further uplift to recognize.
And when we refinance an investment, it often results in the repayment of a portion of our original shareholder loans.
This will not result in a meaningful uplift.
It does concentrate value in the remaining equity.
Now as I talked about in May, a consequence of this good realized and unrealized value growth is the need to recognize the potential for carry that's payable to our investing teams.
We're through the performance hurdles from an accounting perspective.
So we accrue carry payable between 10% and 15% on our gross investment returns.
This has continued in this first half as we accrued a further GBP 45 million.
Again, cash paid is much lower at GBP 7 million in the period.
Importantly, strong performance from Refresco, Quintiles and a number of other assets in the growth capital fund means that we're recognizing carry receivable on that fund for the first time.
We've also seen strong performance from assets owned by 3i Infrastructure plc and are recognizing a performance fee there, too.
