Chris Brown from JPMorgan Caz.

Just on the new investments, to what extent did your new co-investors take part in those? Yes, it's one of my favorite jobs, is tracking the FX movements on a daily basis, and we have recouped quite a bit since the end of September.
The last time I looked, it was -- about GBP 27 million had reversed.
We have given you the sensitivity, again, in the pack.
I think it's on Slide 51, where you can see what a 1% movement in the currency does based on the net assets at the 30th of September.
On the multiples, as you said, excluding Action, which -- as I explained, we didn't move the multiple.
It's one of our highest multiples in the valuations at 12.
5x on a post-discount basis and it's our largest Private Equity asset.
So holding that flat with the value going up pushes up the multiple average including it.
Elsewhere, we have been doing this for a while.

When we set -- when we look at the comp sets that we're choosing, we're looking at a number of factors, things that you'd expect, the right sector, the absolute size of the company, its relative performance, the levels of leverage.
And they're pretty bespokely chosen now in terms of how we then adjust that comp set to the asset that we're trying to value.
It's all the more important because the top 20 is 77% of the value.
So it makes sense to be quite precise in the way that we do that.
Because of that, I can't really give you sort of a thematic "in this sector we have taken this approach.
" We have absolutely looked at some of our businesses, where we have a view about likely exit multiple.
And as we've seen, the market move away at the beginning of this calendar year, we've effectively capped that multiple.

It doesn't mean we hold the multiples completely flat, and as I mentioned in a couple of stronger cases of our assets, we've tweaked the multiples up slightly, where they completed refinancing or made some progress with the transformation.
We've had a number of multiples that have gone flat down in the period as well.
So it's quite a mixture, but the strong performance has kept the multiples overall flat.
Do you want to do both? On what we're seeing at the moment, I would certainly think so.
I think the caution around the environment is more about realizations and refinancings.
There's confidences required for those things.
We have a lot of stuff in train.
If things don't change, that will be great, but if we have another October rolling out for 3 or 4 months, then it will obviously impact all sorts of markets.
Any others? Okay, thanks for coming along today.
Much appreciated.
So I mean, we all know that with various complexions, Continental Europe is struggling.

So are you saying that the opportunities that are being pushed away don't fully reflect what is going on in underlying economies? In terms of Christ, it's actually deemed a further investment in Eurofund V.
So we did that together with the LPs in Eurofund V.
The other 2 investments, the North American investments, were 3i investments.
Philip? Okay.
Let me try and answer those 2 questions.
I think in -- my words of caution are really focused on the macro in certain countries and the volatility in the financial markets.
They're not focused on the performance of our companies in buckets 1 and 2.
We have very good momentum in most of those companies, and as I said in my words, they're the sort of companies who can cope with a difficult environment, and that's what we're seeing.
So there's no stark warning about that aspect of our portfolio.
To the second point, the bigger and the newer companies tend to be heavily represented in buckets 1 and 2.
So that's where the value is.
That's where the stronger momentum is.
A lot of the '07, '08 type companies are in buckets 3 and 4, if I were to generalize in that way.
Nothing we've bought recently is in bucket 4.
I can assure you of that.
I think it was reflective of the asset value at March and under the asset value at September.
Any more questions? Yes, one at the front here.
Daniel Garrod from Barclays.
Two questions from me.
There was an 8p hit to the NAV from negative FX in the first half.
I wonder if you track how much of that might have reversed in sort of October, November, if you could give us any color on that.
And the second question, the x Action, the average multiple barely changed, 9.
I wonder if you could provide any more color on the size of discounts that you're using to calculate that and how much that might have varied in the period.
You have discretion over which companies to benchmark in your averages.

Are there some sort of sectors where you're actually sort of capped on multiple that you use on the upside that then gives you cushion on the way downside? And were there any sectors actually where the multiples did go down that's just dwarfed by the -- hidden by the average of being flat.
Ladies and gentlemen, good morning, and welcome to 3i's Interim Results.
We've had another good first half, with solid results across the group.
Despite the tricky macro and volatile stock markets, we're building real value growth across our investment portfolios.
We've seen a good level of realization activity, and we've made some important new investments in North America and Germany.
And we have made good progress with group KPIs, with further reductions in operating and interest costs.
We've also delivered a growing base of cash realizations to underpin this year's dividend.
We secured GBP 324 million of realizations in the first half and another GBP 218 million of cash since then, including the successful placing of some of our stock in Quintiles last week.
The portfolio has performed well.
In fact, we've seen GBP 360 million of value growth and income based on strong earnings momentum in our larger investments, such as Action and Element.
Operating costs are now running at 1% of AUM compared to 1.
That's very much in line with or better than industry benchmarks, and this has helped in increasing our first half Fund Management profit of GBP 13 million.
Now as you know, I took over as CEO in May 2012, and we announced a new strategy for the group in June 2012.
Well, we've come a long a way since then, and I'm pleased to say there is very strong momentum in the group today.

Even with adverse foreign currency markets, we've produced a good recovery in total returns underpinned by strong asset management and realization performance, a substantial reduction in costs and much improved cash flow.
That's the stuff that pays dividends to shareholders and cash back to LPs.
You should now all be familiar with our strategy.
It's simple and it includes all 3 of our businesses.

The combination of our complementary asset management capabilities across 3 platforms, together with our permanent capital, gives our shareholders a clearly differentiated and attractive value proposition.
Now I'd like to use the 3i Value Build, which we first presented in 2012, as the structure for today's presentation.
I'll comment on each of the steps, starting with portfolio earnings.
Here are the 4 3i buckets, which I used to analyze the Private Equity portfolio.
I've set down some examples for each bucket and the percentage of value using the 30th September values that each bucket accounts for.
Back in May 2012, 3i had 130 investments, with too many in buckets 3 and 4.
So we've been on a journey with the aim of reducing that number of investments down to 40 or less, with those 40 comprising the 2 stronger buckets, 1 and 2.
We've had another good run of realizations, and the majority of which have come from our non-core buckets 3 and 4.
So the overall portfolio is increasingly dominated by our keepers or higher-value potential assets in bucket 1 or our strong performers in bucket 2.
In fact, the value weighted average LTM earnings growth of 17% across the portfolio is driven by the strong growth we are seeing across our larger investments in buckets 1 and 2.

While our companies in the top 2 buckets are more able to cope with the challenging macro climate, it is not always the case for those companies in buckets 3 and 4, but the strong market for realizations, which is underpinned by QE and lots of dry powder potential buyers, has meant we have been able to trade out a number of our weaker or non-core companies at attractive valuations.

Our mid-market PE portfolio has good earnings momentum, which compares very favorably with stock market comparables or, indeed, other PE portfolios and will underpin significant cash distributions from the group over the coming years.
We've overhauled our approach to asset management in 2012 and introducing 6 new initiatives and much greater proactivity across the portfolio.

These changes, which encompassed our monthly dashboard monitoring and more rigorous exit planning, are an important factor in the resilient performance of the portfolio we're seeing today, and I thought this would be a useful time to look at the investments we made last year.
We made 4 investments, 3 new and 1 large follow-on in Scandlines, and despite the competition for good assets, we bought them well at attractive entry multiples, an average across the 4 of 8x EBITDA.
All are performing in line or ahead of plan, with average earnings growth of 23% over the last 12 months.
And I'd now like to give you a look at each of those investments.
GIF is a German testing and engineering business focused on transmission systems in the automotive sector.
We know the testing and automotive sectors extremely well, and GIF is a classic German Mittelstand business.
Our long-term plan is to reposition the business as much more of a pure-play testing business with the value-added engineering capability and to continue its drive for international expansion.
The plan is going well, with the business expecting to generate EBITDA growth of 25% for the current financial year and a good buildup of sales in the China operation, in particular.
JMJ is a global leader in safety consultancy and works for major oil, industrial and aerospace companies around the world.
The business is based out of Austin, Texas, but it has a U.
It is a sector leader and is capable of significant international expansion as well as growing through entering new sectors.
It enjoys strong levels of organic growth and has a very blue-chip roster of major clients, such as Chevron, Shell and Lend Lease.
The business was introduced to us by the Chairman of Element, which gave us the chance to buy the company away from an auction process.
Now I talked about Basic-Fit and its founder, Rene Moos, last year.
It's our discount gym format in the Benelux.
If you like, it's our Action of the gym world.

Again, we purchased Basic-Fit away from a competitive process and have enjoyed some spectacular growth in the company's first year under our ownership, with 42 new clubs and a likely increase of over 50% in EBITDA this year.
We are now the market leader in both Holland and Belgium and have just started to open gyms in France and Spain.
So our new investments are performing well, and we have sensible in prices against which to target our money multiple returns.
GIF and JMJ are classic bucket 2 investments, and it's already pretty clear that Basic-Fit is more likely to be a bucket 1 candidate.
We've delivered another good run of realizations and refinancings in the first half, and Julia will be giving you more detail on this in her section.
We've continued to focus on disposals of non-core assets, with just one sale from bucket 2 in the first half and another 2, Hilite and LHi, closing last month.
At the 30th of September, we had reduced the number of investments to 72.
Now I'd also like to talk about 2 of those bucket 2 disposals, Vedici and Hilite.
Vedici, a French hospital group, was sold in September to CVC, netting 3i GBP 83 million of proceeds and a 2x money multiple in 4 years.
Now France is a very difficult market at present, and our Paris team did a great job in securing this exit on these terms.
We made a 48% profit over our March '14 book value on this sale.
Hilite, a German automotive group which we bought in 2011, was another classic bucket 2 asset.
We refocused the group, investing in R&D and expanding geographic sales through China, in particular.
1x our money through a very competitive auction process, eventually selling to a Chinese company, AVIC Electromechanical Systems, at the end of October.
Now moving to the group.
Our operating cash profit continued its improving trajectory in the first half at GBP 16 million.
That reflects a further reduction in the cost base and improving income performance across our 3 businesses.
Debt Management has made a good contribution to that income.
To date, they have issued 4 CLOs, 2 in the U.
and 2 in Europe, as well as growing their U.
Senior Loan Fund and achieving a first close on a European Middle Market Loan Fund at EUR 250 million this week.

The Infrastructure team has also had a productive first half, seeing strong growth in its core European portfolio and securing a steady flow of primary PPP investment opportunities as well as developing a pipeline of potential new core infrastructure projects.
The India Fund has remained challenging despite the election this year, but we did manage to sell some of our holding in Adani Power in firmer markets around the time of the election there.
Importantly, the Infrastructure team agreed an extension to the investment advisory agreement with 3iN at the beginning of the financial year.
Our strong balance sheet has facilitated further investments this year, which will provide good capital growth as well as income going forward.
We've made 2 new PE investments in the U.
this year as well as a further investment in Germany.
These are 2 of the stronger economies we're operating in today, and I am pleased we're increasing the group's exposure to the U.
and Germany at this time.
All 3 investments are decent-sized businesses, where we are confident of meeting our 2x return target on in prices of between 8.
5 and 9x EBITDA.

We took an opportunity to purchase an LP position in Eurofund V, increasing 3i's ownership to 57% of a fund that is now recovering very strongly, and on the income front, we have seeded 4 new CLOs as well as establishing new warehouse facilities for the further CLO launches.
We purchased Dynatect in August this year.
Dynatect is a U.
-based manufacturer of protective equipment, with operations in the U.
and Germany.
The industrial sector has been 3i's most consistent performer over many years, and the U.
and Germany have been key to that performance.
We've also signed an agreement to buy Q Holdings, another U.
group focused on the manufacture of precision-molded rubber and silicone components.
It has 6 manufacturing plants across the U.
and China as well as sales offices in Germany and Mexico.
A key part of our plan is to help the business grow organically and by acquisition in Europe.
We've also announced the purchase of Christ, a leading retailer of watches and jewelry in Germany.
We have an existing presence in this segment through Amor, our existing jewelry business, and we've been tracking Christ for some time.
So far, realization progress has been good, with over GBP 540 million of cash from sales and refinancings, and we have a good number of sales and refinancings in progress at the moment.
So today, we're announcing an interim dividend of 2.
7p and an additional dividend of 3.
3p, making 6p in total, as well as committing to at least a 15p total dividend for the year given the projects and refinancings that we have in hand.
I'm pleased with this outcome, and Julia will give you more detail in a few minutes.

Now when we first put the new plan together in June 2012, we expected FY '15 to be a relatively weak year for realizations, but subject to markets -- and that's a big but, it now looks like it could turn out to be very much better than we originally planned.
We're continuing to see a very positive shift in capital efficiency and allocation as our operating costs come down further and we reduce our interest bill.
So this is the fifth results presentation since we announced our restructuring and new strategy, and we have made material strides over that time.
After the deep restructuring in FY '13 and the resulting reduction in costs, we are now looking like a proper business, and all 3 of our divisions are performing well in terms of income this year.
The asset management initiatives are having a profound impact on the performance of our portfolio of PE investments.

We continue to see significant value growth and momentum even after allowing for the rise in sterling over the last 12 months or so, and the investments we have made in recent years are performing particularly well and demonstrating the power of the 3i model in the international mid-market.
We aim to buy at sensible prices and grow our businesses to generate consistent alpha for shareholders and investors.
Our strategic priorities for this year very much remain more of the same: thoughtful and well-executed asset management, careful new investment and tight cost control.

It's a tough environment out there, and there is no question the macro environment across much of Europe is becoming more difficult, but I now have confidence that 3i is in a far stronger position to meet any of those challenges.
So let me close by saying another thank you to the team of 3i for all their good work in the first half and pass over to Julia.
It's Justin Thomson from T.
Rowe Price.

Thanks, Simon, and good morning, everybody.
This has been a year of strong delivery, and we've generated real momentum.
And you can see the evidence in the results that Simon and I are talking about today.

We believe that this makes our results easier to understand, and we're calling this our investment basis.

But enough of the technicalities.
3% total return we have delivered is a great result.
And almost so, because the numbers are after the headwind of Sterling's strength, which I'll come onto in a minute.
At a group level, we have achieved an annual cash operating profit of GBP 5 [PH] million.
This is an important milestone.
It demonstrates that our financial model is far more sustainable, and that we can make capital allocation decisions without leakage from our cost base.

As you know and Simon confirmed a minute ago, we've made good progress in reducing our costs, but staying focused on the cash operating profit, means we won't lose sight of this operational efficiency.
As well as efficiency, we've built momentum for growth during the year.
We have put up the proprietary capital to work, making cash investment of GBP 337 million in Private Equity and Debt Management.
And we've continued to strengthen the balance sheet.
With the realizations of GBP 677 million of good money multiples, and a further reduction in gross debt to GBP 857 million.
We're now giving more information about the profitability of our fund management platform, and this is for the first time.
I'm going to take you through that in more detail later, but note here, the fee income is stable, and we've improved both profitability and margin.
We closed the period with NAV per share of 348p.
And you can see here how that has progressed since December, and over the course of the year.

Very strong performance from our Private Equity portfolio in realizations and portfolio value growth, significant reductions in our cost base and interest bill, mean that the dilution of those returns is dramatically lower.
But there is a reduction, from the increase in our carry provision because of the strong portfolio performance, and in FX translation loss as sterling ha strengthened.
Finally, we paid 1/3 of our proposed 20p dividend in January, and together with last year's final dividend, that gives you the 12.
1p that you can see here.
So first, let's look at the performance of our Private Equity business.
The GBP 647 million gross investment return that we've generated, is 24% over opening portfolio valuation of GBP 2.
7 billion, and within that, the return from the core Northern European and North American portfolio was excellent, at 30%.
And that now accounts the 90% of the total portfolio value.
Simon talked about some of the significant realizations that that have driven very nice profits of GBP 201 million, and the uplift of 43% over opening value.
Just to note, as you may have already seen in the press release, we're now reporting gross investment return after foreign exchange movements on the portfolio.
So the GBP 647 million that you can see here, is net of a translation loss of GBP 100 million.

So what are the drivers of the unrealized value growth? 
The weighted average 12 months earnings growth for those companies that we value using earnings was 19%, driven particularly by the assets in our keepers bucket, such as Action an Element.
We talked a lot around the Q3 [PH] IMS, about cautioned and following the market up, when we set our valuation multiples.
This is still the case, but we will re-rate the companies, if we think the performance and our expectations about exit potential merit it.
I'm going to show separately about how we valued Action in a minute, because it has a big affect on the numbers that you can see here.
Before I do, please also note, the low level of companies that are being valued using forecast earnings.
We do that then earnings are lower than the last 12 months to anticipate a downturn in performance.
So a low number here, just 3% by value, is a good metric.
Net debt in the portfolio stayed low at an average of 3.
1x, and 79% of that debt is now due up to 2016, as we've taken opportunities to refinance.
So there's been quite a lot of focus on our investment in Action.
It is clearly immaterial part of the book, so I'm going to give you some more specific details about how we valued it.

We've been using the run rate adjusted earning since 
[Audio Gap]
to reflect the significant growth in the business from store openings.

The success of the management team in that store rollout and strong like-for-likes, now gives us the confidence to reset the comparable multiples, and to include high-growth companies which we've previously excluded.
And of course, the recent IPO of pound [PH] land has given us any data point.
So we've increased the post discount multiple from 10x to 12.
Action generates very good free cash flow, and after the refinancing that we did last summer, it's net debt is only 3.
Having made these changes, we now hold Action in our books at a value of GBP 501 million, which is 14.
1% of our portfolio.
All other things being equal, at the 31st of March, an increase in the multiple from 12.
15x [PH] to 13.
5x, would increase our book value by GBP 50 million.
And by the way, this is one of the reasons why we're putting a resolution at the AGM to amend our investment policy.
Since our keeper assets demonstrate strong growth, we have a so-called nice problem to have, that a single asset could account for more than 15% [PH] of portfolio value.
And that's a limit in our current investment policy.
Now we don't think it makes sense for us to have to reduce an investment if we think there is better shareholder value to be had by keeping the investment for longer.
So we're proposing to change the limit to apply it to investment costs rather than value.
Coming back to the valuations in total, you can see here how the earnings growth and stable net debt in the portfolio as a whole, means strong growth of GBP 182 million from performance.
The single biggest driver of the GBP 216 million increase in value from multiples is that decision to increase the Action multiple.
Valuation of Scandlines is included in the DCF line, and since the further investment and appointment of the new Chairman, we're positive about the outlook for this business.
The combined value of the old and new money has increased by GBP 21 million since that acquisition.
In the credit [PH] portfolio, particularly Quintiles, and Gain Capital in the U.
, have performed very well in the year.
But this strong performance overall, the top 20 Private Equity assets, now accounts for 76% of the total Private Equity portfolio.
Here they are.
And you can see there's only a few exceptions where our view is not positive on performance.
And that is generally true in the remainder of the portfolio.
As we've had another year with no provisions or material write-downs.
A consequence of this strong performance is that the provision to remain for carry payable has stepped up materially in the last quarter.
And we pay carry on our proprietary capital investment to the investment teams at rates of between 10% and 15%, in schemes set the 2 years.
Every quarter, we test each scheme ot see whether it would've hit its performance hurdle, if it's sold on the assets of the balance sheet value.
And if it has, they make accrue carry as if assets are being sold.
But we discount it to reflect the actual payment date maybe many years into the future.
When a scheme hits the hurdle for the first time, there's also catch-up effect.
The 2010 [PH] to 2012 assets have performed particularly strongly.
This scheme includes Action, and it's hit its hurdle for the first time this year on a accruals basis.
Rate on the scheme is just below 15%, and the provision for this scheme makes up the biggest part of the charge.
We received carry on third-party capital over the life of the relevant fund, some of which is then shared with the investment teams.
The performance of Eurofund V has improved dramatically, with the current fund multiple increasing to 1.
13x at the 31st of March.
However, that's not a strong enough recovery, to let it start accruing for carry receivable on this month.
In fact, the drag from the 2007 to 2009 investments in this bond, means we haven't recognized it's carry receivable yet.
In cash terms, carry paid and carry received on cash realizations schemes actually there hurdles was much lower at GBP 25 million and GBP 5 million, respectively.
Let me now turn in infrastructure, where it has been comparatively quieter year, although as you have seen from our infrastructure the results last week, there have been some good developments.
We're building our PPP capability, and progress on the renewal of our advisory agreement with 3iN.
Our 34% shareholding in 3iN delivers good dividend income.
We received GBP 21 million this year, a very important underpin to our cash profit metric.
The core European portfolio continues to perform well, but the performance of the Indian portfolio has been disappointing.
The value of our direct holding in these investments fell by 25%, and that includes the significant rupee and dollar depreciation in the year.
The PPP platform already covers its costs and Further fundraising by that team might also make a positive contribution to the cash profit metric and the group's fund management profitability.
Our debt management business has the biggest contributor to that fund management profitability.
During the year, it closed 2 new CLOs in Europe, and 2 in the U.
And that added GBP 1.
2 billion assets under management, and offset the run off of the older funds.
We finished the year with assets under management of GBP 6.
Fee income was stable at GBP 32 million, but as I said at the half-year, the catch-up fees on older funds contributed GBP 6 million last year, and they no longer feature.
Excluding these catch-up fees, fee income grew by GBP 7 million.
So an overall improvement in the quality of earnings.
Bringing together fund management contributions from all our businesses, you can see the profitability of 3i's platform.
When we look at the fund management businesses' profitability, we recognized that it should receive a notional fee on the proprietary capital that it is managing on behalf of 3i Group's shareholders.
These synthetic fees are set with reference to our third-party bond mandates.
For this year and last, they're set at 1.
5% on our capital invested in Private Equity and infrastructure, and 0.
5% on Debt Management capital.
We've also allocated operating expenses between the fund management platform and to the proprietary capital investment business.
The positive impact from cost savings, as Simon talked about earlier, flow through here, with the reduction from GBP 140 million last year to GBP 108 million this year.
So with stable combined fee income, the fund management platform became profitable for the first time at an absolute level.
And when we take our restructuring and amortization costs, underlying profit was GBP 33 million, and as a respectable margin of 26%.
Our proprietary capital business, has also seen an improvement year-on-year.
I've already talked about good realized profit and strong value growth.
The majority portfolio is invested outside the U.
It's 51% denominated in euros, and 16% in dollars.
So revaluing this portfolio in a period where sterling has strengthened does result in significant differences.
We're talking about a translation loss of GBP 113 million, against a GBP 52 million gain last year.
And this is how that movement is made up.
And based on the balance sheet at the 3st of March, a further 1% movement in the euro or dollar, will change returns by GBP 13 million and GBP 6 million, respectively.
Proprietary capital business has the balance sheet funding costs.
You can see here the very positive impact of our gross debt reduction, with interest payable, down 47% to GBP 54 million in the year, well ahead of our GBP 60 million target.
Most significant aspects of proprietary investments was the increase in momentum in Private Equity.
Although we remain highly selective about opportunities.
As Simon talked about, we made cash investment of GBP 276 million in Private Equity, including 3 new investments, Basic Fit, GIF and JMJ, and the furthe investments in Scandlines with Eurofund V.

Our proprietary capital lets us support the growth of our Debt Management business through warehouse vehicles, which are used to build up credit portfolios in order to see CLO launches and to avoid cash drag on returns.
At the 31st of March, we had a total of GBP 21 million invested in our European and U.
warehouse vehicles, ahead of the next CLO launches in these regions.
We also invest in the equity of a CLO when it is launched.
This is particularly important, because new regulatory developments require fund managers to have the skin in the game.
Our proprietary capital means that we can do that.
During the year, we invested GBP 40 million into the 4 new CLOs raised.
Core infrastructure investment is principally funded by 3i infrastructure plc, and we've have no other calls on the proprietary capital for that business.
Bringing all this together on the group balance sheet, investment momentum has improved in the year but market conditions mean that it's a better time for realizations.
So we finished the year with net cash divestment of GBP 340 million.
The portfolio value increased to GBP 3.
6 billion, because of the effect of the net divestment, was offset by strong value growth.
We used proceeds from realizations to reduce gross debt.
Gross debts reduced to GBP 857 million, and net debt to GBP 160 million, with gearing of only 5%.
So we have clearly satisfied the criteria to operate our enhanced distribution policy.
And we indicated at the half-year, that we expected to pay a dividend of 20p in total for this year.
Realizations have been good, investment levels having improved, but as Simon talked about, the environment for midmarket Private Equity investing remains very competitive.
Taking these factors into account, we have confirmed the 20p dividend today.
Subject to shareholder approval, we declared a final dividend of 13.
As for the year that we're now in, we expect to pay above our 8.
1p base level dividend again, but the level of additional dividend will be a bit lower in financial year 2014.
So to sum up.
Our performance in financial year 2014 has been strong, and shows the benefit of our restructuring coming through.

It has been underpinned by excellent performance in the Private Equity business, achieving an annual cash operating profit, a significant milestone for the group, and an outperformance against all the strategic targets that we set out in June 2012.
The momentum in the business continues, and we are well-placed to build further value to shareholders in the next year of transition and delivery.
So thank you.
And Simon and I will now be happy to take questions.
I think we -- the 15% cost is clearly the new policy.
I think as a company, we would, in general, like to work well within that figure, because I would expect as we reshape the portfolio, we'll come down to a natural number of say, 30 investments.

Good morning, everyone.
Welcome to 3i's results for the year 31ST March, 2014.
Well, as you can see, the momentum in the business has continued and we've had an excellent 6 months since our interim presentation last November.

We've made some very promising Private Equity investments, the portfolio is developing well, realizations and cash flow have been strong, and both infrastructure and Debt Management have achieved important milestones.
These results clearly show the very significant benefits from our restructuring and financial year '13, as well as from our new asset management initiatives.
So I'd like to start by focusing on our strategic objectives on our progress over the last year and gross with some comments about our business model before handing over to Julia.

It's been another good year to be a shareholder in 3i, with a total shareholder return of 30%, including a 20p dividend, which gives a 6% yield on the share price in the beginning of our financial year 2014.

We've achieved the second year of 40%-plus returns on our Private Equity realizations, and we have returned to the new investment market with GBP 372 million in 3 new and 1 large follow-on investment.
We've again, materially outperformed our second year cost-saving targets of GBP 60 million, by coming in at GBP 70 million.
And as you can see, the operational linkages we have suffered from, are now a thing of the past, with cash income in the year exceeding our new reduced cost base by GBP 5 million.

You're familiar with our model, so I'd like to start by focusing on our strategic objectives and our progress over the year and those with some comments about our business model before handing over to Julia.
It's important to note at this stage that we have made good progress in our 2  smaller businesses: Infrastructure and Debt Management, as well as Private Equity.
These results we've delivered reflect every aspect of 3i's value build.
This is not just to jam tomorrow's story, this is jam today, as well as jam tomorrow.
The portfolios delivering growth in earnings in value, and has been another strong year of realizations.
Cash flow relative to costs has been strong, and we've made good progress in fund management profits.
We've made some excellent new investments, as well as a strategic acquisition in the infrastructure sector, and we've significantly raised our share holder distributions.
We are now more than halfway through the plan I set out in June 2012, and we now have real momentum in the face of transition and delivery.
After our fundamental restructuring in financial year 2013, we had 6 strategic priorities for financial year 2014, and we've either exceeded our met every single one, as you can see here.
It's been a great year for Private Equity, and I'd like to say well done to the 3i team.

We've seen strong growth in our proprietary portfolio through both earnings and valuation multiples, and we've seen a good flow of realizations at excellent uplifts and decent said cash on cash multiples.
Julia will give you a couple of examples in a minute.
Once again, we've not been selling any of our keeper assets but we have sold the mix from our buckets 2, 3 and 4.
Those disposals have given us a meaningful reduction in the number of smaller problem investments in our portfolio.
New investment has picked up, but we've been very careful to be disciplined on price and careful to be consistent with our strategic focus.

We've added 5 new executives in the last 6 months, bringing our total number of investors to 59, and we've a stable core parter team, balanced across our key geographies and they are focusing on our core sectors of industrial consumer and business services.
We've seen very strong returns across our European and U.
businesses, and the 2011 onwards investments have performed particularly well.
I'm delighted to see how the team has embraced the asset management initiatives, which we put in place during 2012.
We are monitoring the portfolio closely, and we're focusing hard on those situations where performance is below our expectations.
Right at the start, I said that it has been another excellent year for realizations, and here's how they look.
We've delivered proceeds of GBP 669 million at a 43% uplift to opening values.
The money multiple of 1.
8x is very good, especially, when we've sold a decent number of our smaller or underperforming investments during the year.

We're seeing excellent earnings growth in our keepers bucket, which now accounts for over 40% of the PE portfolio value.
Action is the standout investment here.
But we have a number of other promising investments, which have to prove the potential to drive cash on cash returns, significantly above 2x over the medium-term.
And they include a number of our most recent investments.
Of our 24 realizations, 6 were either partially realizations or from bucket 2, and 18 were from buckets 3 and 4.
That shows you the extent of the tidying up exercises here, and how we have now reduced the portfolio to 81 company from over 100.

And I'm very excited about the PE investments we've made this year.
We made a significant follow-on investment in Sandlines, which has already been already a strong investment for 3i.

Basic Fit, JMJ and GIF, are all new investments, which are consistent with our strategic focus on local origination of international companies.
They maintain our price disciplined over this assets, buying all of them at attractive multiples.

Basic Fit is the largest discount fitness operator in Europe.
We know the business for several years and have attracted since 2011.
To give you an idea of its scale, it had 64,000 new members in January this year alone.
Rene is a former professional tennis player.
He's highly competitive and he's a gifted businessman.
We first approached Rene, the founder and CEO of Basic Fit, in 2011, after our consumer team had identified discount as a winning theme in retail and the retail services sector.
Rene had 3 businesses at the time, a golf course business, an up market gym business, and Basic Fit.
We approached him at roughly the same time we approached and purchased Action.
But Rene wasn't interested in our approach.
He didn't accept that the discount format was his best business, and was unconvinced by arguments that the discount business of scale up, and make his fortune in.

But after reading about and seeing the success of Action, Rene contracted our Amsterdam team in early 2003 -- 2013, and after a meeting to discuss the success of Action and our current thoughts on Basic Fit fit.
When I met Rene in September and toward Basic Fit, I was impressed by his energy and detailed understanding of the Basic Fit business and the broader fitness market.
At the washup meeting with him at the end of the tour and the day, and before I supported the investment proposal, I asked him why he was dealing with 3i.
I haven't talked to any other buyout firms, and I liked what I heard.
He said your PE team has educated me on the protection of Basic Fit on where I would succeed.
For too long, I've been dazzled by the upmarket gym business without really understanding the power of a large scale value-for-money discount franchise.
And your team is Dutch, which is important to me.
They've been investing in Dutch companies for decades.
They speak my language.
And they have a great track record in this market.
So I would rather work with your local Dutch team than deal with Brits or Americans who fly in and out of ship hold on an irregular basis.
This was an interesting comment given 5 minutes earlier, I'd ask him to ask his PA to print my boarding card.
But anyway, as you can say, Rene can be very direct, and is a classic entrepreneur.
Now that's what I call competitive advantage.
We are on the ground and we have the skills to identify companies with strong potential, and we can provide financial and operational support.
It was the same for Action, and it gives us the opportunity to invest in these strong businesses away from the froth of hotly contested auctions in London.
Infrastructure has continued to make good contribution to the group's annual cash income, and the European portfolio has performed well.
The new leadership team has settled in quickly and has agreed with 3iN to further extend the advisory agreement.
India had a challenging time again, and we saw further pullback in the valuations, although we did see a more stable second half.
We've also broadened our platform through the acquisition of a PPP-focused team form Barclays.
They have a strong pipeline of deals, and we are now focusing on the next fundraising.
We now have 25 investors in London and Paris, and 6 investors in Mumbai.
Debt Management has delivered another productive year.
They've raised 4 new CLOs in the U.
and in the newly-opened European market, and they manage GBP 6.
5 billion of AUM.
And they're now in the top 10 global CLO managers.
You'll be pleased to hear that we significantly overreached on cost savings for our second year in a row.
Our cost metrics are now very much in line with the rest of the industry, including the 2 acquisitions of Fraser, Sullivan and BIFM, the group's now got operating cost of about GBP 129 million.

Our cash income actually exceeded operating cost in financial year 2014, and that something the group has not achieved for a very long time, that outcome was a direct result of our cost-reduction program.
This is a tight metric for 3i because of our preponderance of proprietary capital, so I'm particularly pleased by this step this year.
We've also significantly cut our interest bill by repaying debt, it's now down to GBP 54 million from GBP 101 million in our last financial year.
And we've now fully implemented our new compensation arrangements, and they've closely aligned senior staff to our key strategic objectives.
3i shares now make up a significant Element of variable compensation, and that gives us further alignment with the shareholders.
Now I'd like to move to financial year '15, the second year of our transition and delivery phase.
Here are our strategic priorities for the year.
h They're clear, but fundamentally, they remain focused on thoughtful and well executed asset management, careful new investments and tight cost control.
And if we achieve that, we will deliver another year of marked improvement in capital efficiency and allocation, as we did this year.
This shift you can see in capital allocations is increasing cash for new investments and the shareholder distributions.
Now let me turn to the group's business model.
We have a hybrid model, we have a large portfolio of proprietary investments, as well as acting as a fund manager for third-party capital.
The weight of our proprietary capital in midmarket private equity is the fundamental driver of our results, and gives us a competitive advantage in closing and investments.
We're an active owner of investments, as well as being manager of third-party funds.
In our Private Equity and infrastructure vehicles, we are the single largest investor.
We back our analysis and judgment with 3i cash, alongside the cash of our external LPs.

The revenues and profits from our fund management activities contribute  to the cost of running our investment platforms, and they create another source of value for 3i shareholders, especially as our fund management franchise grows.
We want you to be able to track our progress in proprietary capital investing and as a fund manager.
We think this greater transparency will be helpful in judging just how well we're doing.
Going forward, we'll be using this core set of KPIs, so that you can track our progress and performance at group level in our returns on proprietary capital and from our fund management activities.
I'd like to close by saying we had a very good year where we have a see the clear benefits of our restructuring and from our new asset management initiatives in Private Equity.
We've also been clearing up our Private Equity portfolio, and we've put out the fires.
We've good earnings momentum across the portfolio and cash flow is strong, particularly in our larger investments.
We have some very special investments in our keeper bucket of assets.
And as I said, a minute ago, they now account for over 40% of portfolio value.
We think they are capable of very strong growth over the medium-term.
We are of course, hostage to broader economic and political trends.
But subject to those broader trends, I would expect to see another strong year for 3i.
As the portfolio moves forward, we take advantage of bouyant realization markets, and we remain energetic but selective when finding new investments.
So on that note, I'd like to pass over to Julia to give you more details and color on the results.

The flipside of that is the competitive and high-priced nature of the investment environment.
And we have been using and focusing on our platform very hard to find stuff away from these very busy auctions.
But that is clearly harder to do than just asking for book on everything that's being sold.
And if you look back over statistics for Private Equity, and as I've said before, 3i has its own library on this, given how long it's been around.
While we all like to feel we're geniuses in Private Equity, Vintage is the biggest determinant of returns.

And therefore, you need to moderate your excitement and compulsion to invest when banks are banging on your door with large debt packages and other things, because it's generally a pretty good sign that this might not be one of the finer vintages for investing.
And that in reality, accounts for an awful lot of returns, both going up and going down in the Private Equity sector.
So I think the smart people who are really smart, will be quite careful about investing in this environment.
And I'm pretty glad we don't have a fun with lots of money burning a hole in our pocket, because we might feel under more pressure to buy stuff than we actually do.
So we'll continue to make investments.

We'll continue to use our platform, but we are going to be very careful about the end prices, because the end prices would be the biggest determinants of the returns we're making in these investments.

Good morning, everyone.
Welcome to 3i's results for the year to 31st March, 2014.
Well, as you can see, the momentum in the business has continued, and we've had an excellent 6 months since our interim presentation last November.

We've made some very promising Private Equity investments, the portfolio is developing well, realizations and cash flow have been strong, and both Infrastructure and Debt Management have achieved important milestones.
These results clearly show the very significant benefits from our restructuring in financial year '13, as well as from our new asset management initiatives.
So I'd like to start by focusing on our strategic objectives and our progress over the last year and close with some comments about our business model before handing over to Julia.

It's been another good year to be a shareholder in 3i, with a total shareholder return of 30%, including a 20p dividend, which gives a 6% yield on the share price at the beginning of our financial year 2014.
We've achieved the second year of 40%-plus returns on our Private Equity realizations.
And we have returned to the new investment market with GBP 372 million in 3 new and 1 large follow-on investment.
We've again materially outperformed our second year cost-saving targets of GBP 60 million by coming in at GBP 70 million.
And as you can see, the operational leakages we have suffered from are now a thing of the past, with cash income in the year exceeding our new reduced cost base by GBP 5 million.

You're familiar with our model, so I'd like to start by focusing on our strategic objectives and our progress over the year and close with some comments about our business model before handing over to Julia.
It's important to note at this stage that we have made good progress in our 2 smaller businesses: Infrastructure and Debt Management, as well as Private Equity.
These results we've delivered reflect every aspect of 3i's value build.
This is not just to jam tomorrow's story, this is jam today, as well as jam tomorrow.
The portfolio is delivering growth in earnings and value and has been another strong year of realizations.
Cash flow relative to costs has been strong, and we've made good progress in Fund Management profits.
We've made some excellent new investments, as well as a strategic acquisition in the infrastructure sector.
And we've significantly raised our shareholder distributions.
We are now more than halfway through the plan I set out in June 2012.
And we now have real momentum in the face of transition and delivery after our fundamental restructuring in financial year 2013.
We had 6 strategic priorities for financial year 2014, and we've either exceeded or met every single one, as you can see here.
It's been a great year for Private Equity, and I'd like to say well done to the 3i PE team.
We've seen strong growth in our proprietary portfolio through both earnings and valuation multiples.
And we've seen a good flow of realizations at excellent uplifts and decent cash on cash multiples.
Julia will give you a couple of examples in a minute.
Once again, we've not been selling any of our keeper assets, but we have sold the mix from our buckets 2, 3 and 4.
Those disposals have given us a meaningful reduction in the number of smaller problem investments in our portfolio.
New investment has picked up, but we've been very careful to be disciplined on price and careful to be consistent with our strategic focus.
We've added 5 new executives in the last 6 months, bringing our total number of investors to 59.
And we have a stable core partner team balanced across our key geographies, and they are focusing on our core sectors of industrial consumer and business services.
We've seen very strong returns across our European and U.
businesses, and the 2011 onwards investments have performed particularly well.
I'm delighted to see how the team has embraced the asset management initiatives, which we put in place during 2012.
We are monitoring the portfolio closely, and we're focusing hard on those situations where performance is below our expectations.
Right at the start, I said that it has been another excellent year for realizations, and here's how they look.
We've delivered proceeds of GBP 669 million at a 43% uplift to opening values.
The money multiple is 1 -- of 1.
8x is very good, especially when we've sold a decent number of our smaller or underperforming investments during the year.
Now I'd like to talk briefly about portfolio segmentation or what I call the buckets.
We're seeing excellent earnings growth in our keepers bucket, which now accounts for over 40% of the PE portfolio value.
Action is the standout investment here.
But we have a number of other promising investments, which have the potential to drive cash on cash returns significantly above 2x over the medium term.
And they include a number of our most recent investments.
Of our 24 realizations, 6 were either partial realizations or from bucket 2, and 18 were from buckets 3 and 4.
That shows you the extent of the tidying-up exercises here and how we have now reduced the portfolio to 81 companies from over 100.
I expect the value of our keepers bucket to continue to grow well over the next 12 months.
And we will also see a further reduction in the number of overall investments in the portfolio.
And I'm very excited about the PE investments we've made this year.
We made a significant follow-on investment in Scandlines, which has already been a strong investment for 3i.

This is a large keeper bucket asset, and we're anticipating a strong value growth over the medium term, as Steve Ridgway, the new Chairman and former CEO of Virgin Atlantic, works with the existing management team of Scandlines.
Basic-Fit, JMJ and GIF are all new investments, which are consistent with our strategic focus on local origination of international companies.
We maintained our price discipline on these assets, buying all of them at attractive multiples.
