One point I want to note just at the start, this year, we've adopted a new accounting consolidation standard.

It has no effect on the results, but it changes the components of our returns, balance sheet and cash flow, and that means that the audited financial statutory statements actually look very different.
And it's a bit hard to see the detailed picture, so we decided that it would be more helpful to present the numbers today on the basis that's consistent with previous periods.
We believe that this makes our results easier to understand, and we're calling this our investment basis.
And that's what we used in our press release this morning as well.
I'm not going to go through the change in detail here today.
There's an explanation and reconciliation in the press release and some explanatory slides in the back of your packs.
Of course, I'm happy to take any questions at the end of the presentation, but enough of the technicalities.
3% total return we have delivered is a great result and all the more so because the numbers are after the headwind of sterling's strength, which I'll come onto in a minute.
At a group level, we have achieved an annual cash operating profit of GBP 5 million.
This is an important milestone.
It demonstrates that our financial model is far more sustainable and that we can make capital allocation decisions without leakage from our cost base.

As you know and as Simon confirmed a minute ago, we've made great progress in reducing our costs, but staying focused on the cash operating profit means we won't lose sight of this operational efficiency.
But as well as efficiency, we've built momentum for growth during the year.
We have put our Proprietary Capital to work, making cash investment of GBP 337 million in Private Equity and Debt Management.
And we've continued to strengthen the balance sheet, with the realizations of GBP 677 million of good money multiples and a further reduction in gross debt to GBP 857 million.
We're now giving more information about the profitability of our Fund Management platform, and this is for the first time.
I'm going to take you through that in more detail later, but note here that fee income is stable, and we've improved both profitability and margin.
We closed the period with NAV per share of 348p.
And you can see here how that has progressed since December and over the course of the year.

Very strong performance from our Private Equity portfolio in realizations and portfolio value growth, significant reductions in our cost base and interest bill mean that the dilution of those returns is dramatically lower.
But there is a reduction from the increase in our carry provision because of the strong portfolio performance and in FX translation loss as sterling has strengthened.
Finally, we paid 1/3 of our proposed 20p dividend in January, and together with last year's final dividend, that gives you the 12.
1p that you can see here.
So first, let's look at the performance of our Private Equity business.
The GBP 647 million gross investment return that we've generated is 24% over opening portfolio valuation of GBP 2.
And within that, the return from the core Northern European and North American portfolio was excellent at 30%, and that now accounts for 90% of the total portfolio value.
Simon talked about some of the significant realizations that have driven the realized profits of GBP 201 million and the uplift of 43% over opening value.
Just to note, as you may have already seen in the press release, we're now reporting gross investment return after foreign exchange movements on the portfolio.
So the GBP 647 million that you can see here is net of the translation loss of GBP 100 million.

So what are the drivers of the unrealized value growth? The weighted average 12 months earnings growth for those companies that we value using earnings was 19%, driven particularly by the assets in our keepers bucket, such as Action and Element.
We talked a lot around the Q3 IMS about our cautioned in following the market up when we set our valuation multiples.
This is still the case, but we will re-rate companies if we think that their performance and our expectations about exit potential merit it.
I'm going to talk separately about how we valued Action in a minute because it has a big affect on the numbers that you can see here.
Before I do, please also note the low level of companies that are being valued using forecast earnings.
We do that when earnings are lower than the last 12 months to anticipate a downturn in performance, so a low number here, just 3% by value, is a good metric.
Net debt in the portfolio stayed low at an average of 3.
And 79% of that debt is now due up to 2016, as we've taken opportunities to refinance.
So there's been quite a lot of focus on our investment in Action.
It is clearly a material part of the book, so I'm going to give you some more specific detail about how we valued it.
We've been using the run rate adjusted earning since this time last year to reflect the significant growth in the business from store openings.

The success of the management team in that store rollout and strong like-for-likes now gives us the confidence to reset the comparable multiples and to include high-growth companies which we've previously excluded.
And of course, the recent IPO of Poundland has given us a new data point.
So we've increased the post-discount multiple from 10x to 12.
Action generates very good free cash flow.
And after the refinancing that we did last summer, its net debt is only 3.
Having made these changes, we now hold Action in our books at a value of GBP 501 million, which is 14.
1% of our portfolio.
All other things being equal, at the 31st of March, an increase in the multiple from 12.
5x would increase our book value by GBP 50 million.
And by the way, this is one of the reasons why we're putting a resolution at the AGM to amend our investment policy.
Since our keeper assets demonstrate strong growth, we have a so-called nice problem to have, that single asset could account for more than 15% of portfolio value.
And that's a limit in our current investment policy.
Now we don't think it makes sense for us to have to reduce an investment if we think there is better shareholder value to be had by keeping the investment for longer.
So we're proposing to change the limit to apply it to investment costs rather than value.
Coming back to the valuations in total, you can see here how the earnings growth and stable net debt in the portfolio as a whole means strong growth of GBP 182 million from performance.
The single biggest driver of the GBP 216 million increase in value from multiples is that decision to increase the Action multiple.
Valuation of Scandlines is included in the DCF line.
And since the further investments and appointment to the new Chairman, we're positive about the outlook for this business.
The combined value of the old and new money has increased by GBP 21 million since that acquisition.
And the Equity [ph] portfolio, particularly Quintiles and GAIN Capital in the U.
, have performed very well in the year.
With this strong performance overall, the top 20 Private Equity assets now account for 76% of the total Private Equity portfolio.
Here they are.
And you can see there's only a few exceptions, where our view is not positive on performance.
And that is generally true in the remainder of the portfolio, as we've had another year with no provisions or material write-downs.
A consequence of this strong performance is that the provision that we make for carry payable has stepped up materially in the last quarter.
And we pay carry on our Proprietary Capital investment to the investment teams at rates of between 10% and 15% in schemes set every 2 years.
Every quarter, we test each scheme to see whether it would've hit its performance hurdle if we'd sold all the assets at the balance sheet value.
And if it has, they may accrue carry as if the asset is being sold, but we discount it to reflect that the actual payment date may be many years into the future.
When a scheme hits the hurdle for the first time, there's also a catch-up effect.
The 2010 to 2012 assets have performed particularly strongly.
This scheme includes Action.
And it's hit its hurdle for the first time this year on an accruals basis.
Rate on the scheme is just below 15%, and the provision for this scheme makes up the biggest part of the charge.
We received carry on third-party capital over the life of the relevant funds, some of which is then shared with the investment teams.
The performance of Eurofund V has improved dramatically, with the current fund multiple increasing to 1.
13x at the 31st of March.
However, that's not a strong enough recovery to let it start accruing for carry receivable on this fund.
In fact, the drag from the 2007 to 2009 investments in this fund means we haven't recognized its carry receivable yet.
In cash terms, carry paid and carry received on cash realizations in schemes actually through their hurdles was much lower at GBP 25 million and GBP 5 million, respectively.

Let me now turn to Infrastructure, where it's been comparatively quieter year, although, as you have seen from 3i Infrastructure plc's results last week, there have been some good developments, with building our PPP capability and progress on the renewal of our advisory agreement with 3iN.
Our 34% shareholding in 3iN delivers good dividend income.
We received GBP 21 million this year, a very important underpin to our cash profit metric.
The core European portfolio continues to perform well, but the performance of the Indian portfolio has been disappointing.
The value of our direct holding in these investments fell by 25%.
That includes the significant rupee and dollar depreciation in the year.
The PPP platform already covers its costs.
And further fundraising by that team will also make a positive contribution to the cash profit metric and the group's Fund Management profitability.
Our Debt Management business has the biggest contributor to that Fund Management profitability.
During the year, it closed 2 new CLOs in Europe and 2 in the U.
, and that added GBP 1.
2 million -- GBP 1.
2 billion assets under management and offset the run-off of the older funds.
We finished the year with assets under management of GBP 6.
Fee income was stable at GBP 32 million.
But as I said at the half year, the catch-up fees on older funds contributed GBP 6 million last year, and they no longer feature.
Excluding these catch-up fees, fee income grew by GBP 7 million, so an overall improvement in the quality of earnings.
Bringing together Fund Management contributions from all our businesses, you can see here the profitability of 3i's platform.
When we look at the Fund Management business's profitability, we recognize that it should receive a notional fee on the Proprietary Capital that it's managing on behalf of 3i Group's shareholders.
These synthetic fees are set with reference to our third-party bond mandates.
For this year and last, they're set at 1.
5% on our capital invested in Private Equity and Infrastructure and 0.
5% on Debt Management capital.
We've also allocated operating expenses between the Fund Management platform and to the Proprietary Capital investment business.
The positive impact from cost savings, as Simon talked about earlier, flow through here, with the reduction from GBP 140 million last year to GBP 108 million this year.
So with stable combined fee income, the Fund Management platform became profitable for the first time at an absolute level.
And when we take out restructuring and amortization costs, underlying profit was GBP 33 million, and that's a respectable margin of 26%.
Our Proprietary Capital business has also seen an improvement year-on-year.
I've already talked about good realized profit and strong value growth.

The majority of
[Audio Gap] 
portfolio is invested outside the U.
, with 51% denominated in euros and 16% in dollars.
So revaluing this portfolio in a period where sterling has strengthened does result in significant differences.
We're talking about a translation loss of GBP 113 million against a GBP 52 million gain last year.
This is how that movement is made up.
And based on the balance sheet at the 3st of March, a further 1% movement in the euro or dollar would change returns by GBP 13 million and GBP 6 million, respectively.
Proprietary Capital business has the balance sheet funding costs.
You can see here the very positive impact of our gross debt reduction, with interest payable down 47% to GBP 54 million in the year, well ahead of our GBP 60 million target.
The most significant aspect of Proprietary Capital investments was the increase in momentum in Private Equity, although we remain highly selective about opportunities.
As Simon talked about, we made cash investment of GBP 276 million in Private Equity, including 3 new investments: Basic-Fit, GIF and JMJ, and the further investment in Scandlines with Eurofund V.

Our Proprietary Capital lets us support the growth of our Debt Management business through warehouse vehicles, which are used to build up credit portfolios in order to cede CLO launches and to avoid cash drag on returns.
At the 31st of March, we had a total of GBP 21 million invested in our European and U.
warehouse vehicles, ahead of the next CLO launches in these regions.
We also invest in the equity of a CLO when it is launched.
This is particularly important because new regulatory developments require fund managers to have skin in the game.
Our Proprietary Capital means that we can do that.
During the year, we invested GBP 40 million into the 4 new CLOs raised.
Core Infrastructure investment is principally funded by 3i Infrastructure plc, and we've had no other calls on the Proprietary Capital for that business.
Bringing all this together on the group balance sheet, investment momentum has improved in the year, but market conditions mean that it's a better time for realizations.
So we finished the year with net cash divestment of GBP 340 million.
The portfolio value increased to GBP 3.
6 billion because of the effect of the net divestment was offset by strong value growth.
We used proceeds from realizations to reduce gross debt.
Gross debt reduced to GBP 857 million, and net debt to GBP 160 million, with gearing that's only 5%.
So we have clearly satisfied the criteria to operate our enhanced distribution policy.
And we indicated at the half year that we expected to pay a dividend of 20p in total for this year.
Realizations have been good.
Investment levels have improved.
But as Simon talked about, the environment for mid-market Private Equity investing remains very competitive.
Taking these factors into account, we have confirmed the 20p dividend today.
Subject to shareholder approval, we declared a final dividend of 13.
As for the year that we're now in, we expect to pay above our 8.
1p base level dividend again, but the level of additional dividend will be a bit lower than financial year 2014.
So to sum up, our performance in financial year 2014 has been strong and shows the benefits of our restructuring coming through.

It has been underpinned by excellent performance in the Private Equity business, achieving an annual cash operating profit, a significant milestone for the group, and an outperformance against all the strategic targets that we set out in June 2012.
The momentum in the business continues, and we are well placed to build further value for shareholders in the next year of transition and delivery.
So thank you, and Simon and I would now be happy to take questions Okay, let me take the first 2, and then Julia can deal with the Action question.
On realizations, I think it's -- I would probably choose to modify my view a little.
Looking at our pipeline at the moment, and this is always subject to what might happen out there, I think we'll be at a similar level to the year just finished.
So it's a bit stronger in terms of the realization pipeline, I would suggest.
On pricing and the environment in general, I think we're at a -- we are at a very interesting place.
We are clearly benefiting from buoyant conditions in the realization program.
And we are getting very good prices, sometimes on even quite mediocre investments that we're selling.
The flip side of that is the competitive and high-priced nature of the investment environment.
And we have been using and focusing on our platform very hard to find stuff away from these very busy auctions.
But that is clearly harder to do than just asking for a book on everything that's being sold.

And if you look back over statistics for Private Equity, and as I've said before, 3i has its own library on this, given how long it's been around, while we all like to feel we're geniuses in Private Equity, vintage is the biggest determinant of returns, and therefore, you need to moderate your excitement and compulsion to invest when banks are banging on your door with large debt packages and other things because it's generally a pretty good sign that this might not be one of the finer vintages for investing.
And that in reality, meter [ph] accounts for an awful lot of returns, both going up and going down in the Private Equity sector.
So I think the smart people who are really smart will be quite careful about investing in this environment.
And I'm pretty glad we don't have a fund with lots of money burning a hole in our pocket because we might feel under more pressure to buy stuff than we actually do.

So we'll continue to make investments, we'll continue to use our platform, but we are going to be very careful about the end prices because the end prices will be the biggest determinants of the returns we'll make on these investments.
Do you want to pick up on Action? 15, their best investment.
CVC, they're going to be holding Formula One for a long time.
So I mean, there are plenty of examples of running winners in this industry if they produce a lot of cash and produce a lot of value, and we will be no different.
Any more before we wind up? Okay, well, thanks for coming.
Happy to mingle afterwards.
Ewan Lovett-Turner from Numis.

With the disposal of some of the sort of noncore investments and the focus on the keeper assets, what sort of level of portfolio concentration are you happy with going forward, how big would we see, the largest investments? It's Anil Sharma from Morgan Stanley.
Just a couple of questions.

The first one is the example you gave about Vespa [ph], I just wanted to kind of flip it on its head because, obviously, in the last couple years, you've done quite a lot of restructuring, particularly in sort of the Southern Europe.
So are there any sort of investments you're actually missing out on because your footprint's kind of not big enough anymore? And then my second question would just be around sort of Action again.
You've mentioned you've just done a refinancing, and correct me if I'm wrong, a large portion of that refinancing comes back to 3i as a dividend.
So I'm just trying to think, when is the next refinancing due and should we be expecting another kind of big dividend? Okay, I think, let's start.
Good morning, everyone.
Welcome to 3i's results for the year to 31st March, 2014.
Well, as you can see, the momentum in the business has continued, and we've had an excellent 6 months since our interim presentation last November.

We've made some very promising Private Equity investments, the portfolio is developing well, realizations and cash flow have been strong, and both Infrastructure and Debt Management have achieved important milestones.
These results clearly show the very significant benefits from our restructuring in financial year '13, as well as from our new asset management initiatives.
So I'd like to start by focusing on our strategic objectives and our progress over the last year and close with some comments about our business model before handing over to Julia.

It's been another good year to be a shareholder in 3i, with a total shareholder return of 30%, including a 20p dividend, which gives a 6% yield on the share price at the beginning of our financial year 2014.
We've achieved the second year of 40%-plus returns on our Private Equity realizations.
And we have returned to the new investment market with GBP 372 million in 3 new and 1 large follow-on investment.
We've again materially outperformed our second year cost-saving targets of GBP 60 million by coming in at GBP 70 million.
And as you can see, the operational leakages we have suffered from are now a thing of the past, with cash income in the year exceeding our new reduced cost base by GBP 5 million.

You're familiar with our model, so I'd like to start by focusing on our strategic objectives and our progress over the year and close with some comments about our business model before handing over to Julia.
It's important to note at this stage that we have made good progress in our 2 smaller businesses: Infrastructure and Debt Management, as well as Private Equity.
These results we've delivered reflect every aspect of 3i's value build.
This is not just to jam tomorrow's story, this is jam today, as well as jam tomorrow.
The portfolio is delivering growth in earnings and value and it's been another strong year of realizations.
Cash flow relative to costs has been strong, and we've made good progress in Fund Management profits.
We've made some excellent new investments, as well as a strategic acquisition in the infrastructure sector.
And we've significantly raised our shareholder distributions.
We are now more than halfway through the plan I set out in June 2012.
And we now have real momentum in the face of transition and delivery after our fundamental restructuring in financial year 2013.
We had 6 strategic priorities for financial year 2014, and we've either exceeded or met every single one, as you can see here.
It's been a great year for Private Equity, and I'd like to say well done to the 3i PE team.
We've seen strong growth in our proprietary portfolio through both earnings and valuation multiples.
And we've seen a good flow of realizations at excellent uplifts and decent cash on cash multiples.
Julia will give you a couple of examples in a minute.
Once again, we've not been selling any of our keeper assets, but we have sold the mix from our buckets 2, 3 and 4.
Those disposals have given us a meaningful reduction in the number of smaller problem investments in our portfolio.
New investment has picked up, but we've been very careful to be disciplined on price and careful to be consistent with our strategic focus.
We've added 5 new executives in the last 6 months, bringing our total number of investors to 59.
And we have a stable core partner team balanced across our key geographies, and they are focusing on our core sectors of industrial consumer and business services.
We've seen very strong returns across our European and U.
businesses, and the 2011 onwards investments have performed particularly well.
I'm delighted to see how the team has embraced the asset management initiatives, which we put in place during 2012.
We are monitoring the portfolio closely, and we're focusing hard on those situations where performance is below our expectations.
Right at the start, I said that it has been another excellent year for realizations, and here's how they look.
We've delivered proceeds of GBP 669 million at a 43% uplift to opening values.
The money multiple is 1 -- of 1.
8x is very good, especially when we've sold a decent number of our smaller or underperforming investments during the year.
Now I'd like to talk briefly about portfolio segmentation or what I call the buckets.
We're seeing excellent earnings growth in our keepers bucket, which now accounts for over 40% of the PE portfolio value.
Action is the standout investment here.
But we have a number of other promising investments, which have the potential to drive cash on cash returns significantly above 2x over the medium term.
And they include a number of our most recent investments.
Of our 24 realizations, 6 were either partial realizations or from bucket 2, and 18 were from buckets 3 and 4.
That shows you the extent of the tidying-up exercises here and how we have now reduced the portfolio to 81 companies from over 100.
I expect the value of our keepers bucket to continue to grow well over the next 12 months.
And we will also see a further reduction in the number of overall investments in the portfolio.
And I'm very excited about the PE investments we've made this year.
We made a significant follow-on investment in Scandlines, which has already been a strong investment for 3i.

This is a large keeper bucket asset, and we're anticipating a strong value growth over the medium term, as Steve Ridgway, the new Chairman and former CEO of Virgin Atlantic, works with the existing management team of Scandlines.
Basic-Fit, JMJ and GIF are all new investments, which are consistent with our strategic focus on local origination of international companies.
We maintained our price discipline on these assets, buying all of them at attractive multiples.
Now looking around the room, I can see there's a number of you who are fitness fanatics.
Don't worry, Bill, I wasn't looking at you.
I want to tell you about my day with Rene Moos, the CEO of Basic-Fit.
This was last September, and this was before we bought the business.
And I think it shows how we find deals and the power of 3i's international franchise.
Basic-Fit is the largest discount fitness operator in Europe.
We've known the business for several years and have tracked it since 2011.
To give you an idea of its scale, it had 64,000 new members in January this year alone.
Rene is a former professional tennis player.
He's highly competitive, and he's a gifted businessman.
We first approached Rene, the Founder and CEO of Basic-Fit, in 2011, after our consumer team had identified discount as the winning theme in retail and the retail services sector.
Rene had 3 businesses at the time: a golf course business, an upmarket gym business and Basic-Fit.
We approached him at roughly the same time we approached and purchased Action.
But Rene wasn't interested in our approach.
He didn't accept that the discount format was his best business and was unconvinced by our arguments that discount was a business to scale up and make his fortune in.

But after reading about and seeing the success of Action, Rene contacted our Amsterdam team in early 2003 -- 2013 and asked for a meeting to discuss the success of Action and our current thoughts on Basic-Fit.
When I met Rene in September and toured Basic-Fit, I was impressed by his energy and detailed understanding of the Basic-Fit business and the broader fitness market.

At the washup meeting with him at the end of it all and the day and before I supported the investment proposal, I asked him why he was dealing with 3i and haven't talked to any other buyout firms, and I liked what I heard.
He said, "Your PE team has educated me on the potential of Basic-Fit, on where I would succeed.
For too long, I've been dazzled by the upmarket gym business without really understanding the power of a large-scale, value-for-money discount franchise.
And your team is Dutch, which is important to me.
They've been investing in Dutch companies for decades, they speak my language, and they have a great track record in this market.
So I would rather work with your local Dutch team than deal with Brits or Americans, who fly in and out of ship hold on an irregular basis.
" This was an interesting comment, given 5 minutes earlier, I'd ask him to ask his PA to print my boarding card.
But anyway, as you can say, Rene can be very direct and is a classic entrepreneur.
Now that's what I'd call competitive advantage.
We are on the ground, and we have the skills to identify companies with strong potential, and we can provide financial and operational support.
It was the same for Action, and it gives us the opportunity to invest in these strong businesses away from the froth of hotly contested auctions in London.
Infrastructure has continued to make good contribution to the group's annual cash income.
And the European portfolio has performed well.
The new leadership team has settled in quickly and has agreed with 3iN to further extend the advisory agreement.
India had a challenging time again, and we saw a further pullback in the valuations, although we did see a more stable second half.
We've also broadened our platform through the acquisition of a PPP-focused team from Barclays.
They have a strong pipeline of deals, and we are now focusing on the next fundraising.
We now have 25 investors in London and Paris and 6 investors in Mumbai.
Debt Management has delivered another productive year.
They've raised 4 new CLOs in the U.
and in the newly opened European market.
And they manage GBP 6.
5 billion of AUM.
And they're now in the top 10 global CLO managers.
You'll be pleased to hear that we significantly overreached on cost savings for our second year in a row.
Our cost metrics are now very much in line with the rest of the industry.
Including the 2 acquisitions, Fraser Sullivan and BIFM, the group's now got operating costs of about GBP 129 million.
Our cash income actually exceeded operating costs in financial year 2014, and that's something the group has not achieved for a very long time.
That outcome was a direct result of our cost-reduction program.
This is a tight metric for 3i because of our preponderance of Proprietary Capital, so I'm particularly pleased by this step this year.
We've also significantly cut our interest bill.
By repaying debt, it's now down to GBP 54 million from GBP 101 million in our last financial year.
And we've now fully implemented our new compensation arrangements, and they've closely aligned senior staff to our key strategic objectives.
3i shares now make up a significant element of variable compensation, and that gives us further alignment with the shareholders.
Now I'd like to move to financial year '15, the second year of our transition and delivery phase.
Here are our strategic priorities for the year.
They're clear, but fundamentally, they remain focused on thoughtful and well-executed asset management, careful new investments and tight cost control.
And if we achieve that, we will deliver another year of marked improvement in capital efficiency and allocation, as we did this year.
This shift you can see in capital allocations is increasing cash for new investments and shareholder distributions.
Now let me turn to the group's business model.
We have a hybrid model.
We have a large portfolio of proprietary investments, as well as acting as a fund manager for third-party capital.
The weight of our Proprietary Capital in mid-market Private Equity is the fundamental driver of our results and gives us the competitive advantage in closing new investments.
We're an active owner of investments, as well as being manager of third-party funds.
In our Private Equity and Infrastructure vehicles, we are the single largest investor.
We back our analysis and judgment with 3i cash, alongside the cash of our external LPs.

The revenues and profits from our Fund Management activities contribute to the cost of running our investment platforms, and they create another source of value for 3i shareholders, especially as our Fund Management franchise grows.
We want you to be able to track our progress in Proprietary Capital investing and as a fund manager.
We think this greater transparency will be helpful in judging just how well we're doing.
Going forward, we'll be using this core set of KPIs so that you can track our progress and performance at group level in our returns on Proprietary Capital and from our Fund Management activities.
I'd like to close by saying we've had a very good year, where we have seen the clear benefits from our restructuring and from our new asset management initiatives in Private Equity.
We've also been clearing up our Private Equity portfolio, and we've put out the fires.
We have good earnings momentum across the portfolio, and cash flow is strong, particularly in our larger investments.
We have some very special investments in our keeper bucket of assets, and as I said a minute ago, they now account for over 40% of portfolio value.
We think they are capable of very strong growth over the medium term.
We are, of course, hostage to broader economic and political trends.
But subject to those broader trends, I would expect to see another strong year for 3i.
As the portfolio moves forward, we take advantage of bouyant realization markets, and we remain energetic but selective when finding new investments.
So on that note, I'd like to pass over to Julia to give you more detailed color on the results.
So would it be fair to say it's largely on price, that you're not investing more? Yes.
So there was a refinancing in Action in the first half.
And actually, because of the way that was structured, that came back as proceeds to us.
So we received GBP 59 million of proceeds in the first half.
As I said, it's got very good free cash flow.
And post that refinancing, net debt is now down to 3.
So we will obviously continue to look at ways of making sure that that's the most efficient, and we could be looking at further refinancings in the future.
Okay, let me take the first 2, and then Julia can deal with the Action question.

On pricing and the environment in general, I think we're at a -- we are at a very interesting place.
We are clearly benefiting from buoyant conditions in the realization program.
And we are getting very good prices, sometimes on even quite mediocre investments that we're selling.
The flip side of that is the competitive and high-priced nature of the investment environment.
And we have been using and focusing on our platform very hard to find stuff away from these very busy auctions.
But that is clearly harder to do than just asking for a book on everything that's being sold.

And if you look back over statistics for Private Equity, and as I've said before, 3i has its own library on this, given how long it's been around, while we all like to feel we're geniuses in Private Equity, vintage is the biggest determinant of returns, and therefore, you need to moderate your excitement and compulsion to invest when banks are banging on your door with large debt packages and other things because it's generally a pretty good sign that this might not be one of the finer vintages for investing.
And that in reality, meter [ph] accounts for an awful lot of returns, both going up and going down in the Private Equity sector.
So I think the smart people who are really smart will be quite careful about investing in this environment.
And I'm pretty glad we don't have a fund with lots of money burning a hole in our pocket because we might feel under more pressure to buy stuff than we actually do.

So we'll continue to make investments, we'll continue to use our platform, but we are going to be very careful about the end prices because the end prices will be the biggest determinants of the returns we'll make on these investments.
Do you want to pick up on Action? Do you want to deal with the Action one first? Daniel Garrod, Barclays.
Simon, a question for you first, and then one for Julia.
You mentioned a couple of times the sort of strong external environment, what you achieved in full year '14, before then accelerating again in 2016, 2017.

Have your thoughts changed from that kind of outlook because of what you're seeing around the external environment? And in the outlook, it kind of reads the pricing for new investments remains quite difficult.
You're indicating there you've done 4 deals in sort of recent months, that we could see a sort of slow and cautious approach there on the investment side.
And then a question for Julia on what exactly you've done on Action.
It looked -- so GBP 500 million valuation of Action at March.
At September, I think that equivalent figure was GBP 300 million.
The split of that, it -- from what you've said around the sensitivity, it strikes me about 60% of that is the multiple uplift, and about 40% is earnings growth.
Am I right, ballpark, in that estimation? I mean, I would just add on Action, when you look at it, because it's been a subject of significant discussion within 3i.
Clearly, the IPO of Poundland has had an impact, and there are quite strong signals that B&M, another hard discounter in the U.
, is coming to the market.
But if you just reference Poundland, we've put this thing on a 12.
5x EBITDA multiple on these run rate earnings compared to something like Poundland that's trading on 18x to 19x on a prospective EBITDA multiple.
So there's plenty of room there.
The difference between the 2 is that Action is growing strongly in 4 big economies: Germany, France, Holland and Belgium.
It has materially higher like-for-likes.
It's opening over 100 new stores this year, and it's gotten very high returns on equity.
So this is quite, quite an interesting business in our portfolio.
Iain Scouller.
The multiples one.
So I would say that the increase in the average multiple in the year, clearly, the Action multiple has an impact, and we've given you the numbers, excluding the Action impact.
So that's a 9.
We talked at the Q3 trading statement that we would cap multiples, taking into account a number of factors.
We thought the market was moving up.
We've got good performance in a number of our assets, and so we have tweaked some multiples up as we go through.

I mean, to answer your specific question about new investments, no, the investments that we've been -- we've done have been lower than those sort of averages that we've just been talking about, so it's not -- they're not a cause of the impact.
It's more market driven and Action driven.
And then on the CLO equity performance, yes, we've seen some good returns coming out of that.
We have a relatively modest amount of capital in the business, but it can generate good, double-digit returns for us.
It's Iain Scouller from Oriel Securities.
I've got a couple.
First, there's obviously quite a big increase in the multiples used on the valuation over the year.
Did the inclusion of new investments at presumably relatively higher multiples have much of an impact on this number? And the second one is the CLO portfolios.
I was wondering if you could just talk a bit about the performance of that.
There seemed to be a number of gains coming through there.
Do you want to take this? Thanks, Simon, and good morning, everybody.
This has been a year of strong delivery, and we've generated real momentum, and you can see the evidence in the results that Simon and I are talking about today.
One point I want to note just at the start, this year, we've adopted a new accounting consolidation standard.

It has no effect on the results, but it changes the components of our returns, balance sheet and cash flow, and that means that the audited financial statutory statements actually look very different.
And it's a bit hard to see the detailed picture, so we decided that it would be more helpful to present the numbers today on the basis that's consistent with previous periods.
We believe that this makes our results easier to understand, and we're calling this our investment basis.
And that's what we used in our press release this morning as well.
I'm not going to go through the change in detail here today.
There's an explanation and reconciliation in the press release and some explanatory slides in the back of your packs.
Of course, I'm happy to take any questions at the end of the presentation, but enough of the technicalities.
3% total return we have delivered is a great result and all the more so because the numbers are after the headwind of Sterling's strength, which I'll come onto in a minute.
At a group level, we have achieved an annual cash operating profit of GBP 5 million.
This is an important milestone.
It demonstrates that our financial model is far more sustainable and that we can make capital allocation decisions without leakage from our cost base.

As you know and as Simon confirmed a minute ago, we've made great progress in reducing our costs, but staying focused on the cash operating profit means we won't lose sight of this operational efficiency.
But as well as efficiency, we've built momentum for growth during the year.
We have put our Proprietary Capital to work, making cash investment of GBP 337 million in Private Equity and Debt Management.
And we've continued to strengthen the balance sheet, with the realizations of GBP 677 million of good money multiples and a further reduction in gross debt to GBP 857 million.
We're now giving more information about the profitability of our Fund Management platform, and this is for the first time.
I'm going to take you through that in more detail later, but note here that fee income is stable, and we've improved both profitability and margin.
We closed the period with NAV per share of 348p.
And you can see here how that has progressed since December and over the course of the year.

Very strong performance from our Private Equity portfolio in realizations and portfolio value growth, significant reductions in our cost base and interest bill mean that the dilution of those returns is dramatically lower.
But there is a reduction from the increase in our carry provision because of the strong portfolio performance and in FX translation loss as sterling has strengthened.
Finally, we paid 1/3 of our proposed 20p dividend in January, and together with last year's final dividend, that gives you the 12.
1p that you can see here.
So first, let's look at the performance of our Private Equity business.
The GBP 647 million gross investment return that we've generated is 24% over opening portfolio valuation of GBP 2.
And within that, the return from the core Northern European and North American portfolio was excellent at 30%, and that now accounts for 90% of the total portfolio value.
Simon talked about some of the significant realizations that have driven the realized profits of GBP 201 million and the uplift of 43% over opening value.
Just to note, as you may have already seen in the press release, we're now reporting gross investment return after foreign exchange movements on the portfolio.
So the GBP 647 million that you can see here is net of the translation loss of GBP 100 million.

So what are the drivers of the unrealized value growth? The weighted average 12 months earnings growth for those companies that we value using earnings was 19%, driven particularly by the assets in our keepers bucket, such as Action and Element.
We talked a lot around the Q3 IMS about our cautioned in following the market up when we set our valuation multiples.
This is still the case, but we will re-rate companies if we think that their performance and our expectations about exit potential merit it.
I'm going to talk separately about how we valued Action in a minute because it has a big affect on the numbers that you can see here.
Before I do, please also note the low level of companies that are being valued using forecast earnings.
We do that when earnings are lower than the last 12 months to anticipate a downturn in performance, so a low number here, just 3% by value, is a good metric.
Net debt in the portfolio stayed low at an average of 3.
And 79% of that debt is now due up to 2016, as we've taken opportunities to refinance.
So there's been quite a lot of focus on our investment in Action.
It is clearly a material part of the book, so I'm going to give you some more specific detail about how we valued it.
We've been using the run rate adjusted earning since this time last year to reflect the significant growth in the business from store openings.

The success of the management team in that store rollout and strong like-for-likes now gives us the confidence to reset the comparable multiples and to include high-growth companies which we've previously excluded.
And of course, the recent IPO of Poundland has given us a new data point.
So we've increased the post-discount multiple from 10x to 12.
Action generates very good free cash flow.
And after the refinancing that we did last summer, its net debt is only 3.
Having made these changes, we now hold Action in our books at a value of GBP 501 million, which is 14.
1% of our portfolio.
All other things being equal, at the 31st of March, an increase in the multiple from 12.
5x would increase our book value by GBP 50 million.
And by the way, this is one of the reasons why we're putting a resolution at the AGM to amend our investment policy.
Since our keeper assets demonstrate strong growth, we have a so-called nice problem to have, that single asset could account for more than 15% of portfolio value.
And that's a limit in our current investment policy.
Now we don't think it makes sense for us to have to reduce an investment if we think there is better shareholder value to be had by keeping the investment for longer.
So we're proposing to change the limit to apply it to investment cost rather than value.
Coming back to the valuations in total, you can see here how the earnings growth and stable net debt in the portfolio as a whole means strong growth of GBP 182 million from performance.
The single biggest driver of the GBP 216 million increase in value from multiples is that decision to increase the Action multiple.
Valuation of Scandlines is included in the DCF line.
And since the further investments and appointment to the new Chairman, we're positive about the outlook for this business.
The combined value of the old and new money has increased by GBP 21 million since that acquisition.
In the [indiscernible] portfolio, particularly Quintiles and GAIN Capital in the U.
, have performed very well in the year.
With this strong performance overall, the top 20 Private Equity assets now account for 76% of the total Private Equity portfolio.
Here they are.
And you can see there's only a few exceptions, where our view is not positive on performance.
And that is generally true in the remainder of the portfolio, as we've had another year with no provisions or material write-downs.
A consequence of this strong performance is that the provision that we make for carry payable has stepped up materially in the last quarter.
And we pay carry on our Proprietary Capital investment to the investment teams at rates of between 10% and 15% in schemes set every 2 years.
Every quarter, we test each scheme to see whether it would've hit its performance hurdle if we'd sold all the assets at the balance sheet value.
And if it has, they may accrue carry as if the asset is being sold, but we discount it to reflect that the actual payment date may be many years into the future.
When a scheme hits the hurdle for the first time, there's also a catch-up effect.
The 2010 to 2012 assets have performed particularly strongly.
This scheme includes Action.
And it's hit its hurdle for the first time this year on an accruals basis.
Rate on the scheme is just below 15%, and the provision for this scheme makes up the biggest part of the charge.
We received carry on third-party capital over the life of the relevant funds, some of which is then shared with the investment teams.
The performance of Eurofund V has improved dramatically, with the current fund multiple increasing to 1.
13x at the 31st of March.
However, that's not a strong enough recovery to let us start accruing for carry receivable on this fund.
In fact, the drag from the 2007 to 2009 investments in this fund means we haven't recognized its carry receivable yet.
In cash terms, carry paid and carry received on cash realizations in schemes actually through their hurdles was much lower at GBP 25 million and GBP 5 million, respectively.

Let me now turn to Infrastructure, where it's been comparatively quieter year, although, as you have seen from 3i Infrastructure plc's results last week, there have been some good developments, with building our PPP capability and progress on the renewal of our advisory agreement with 3iN.
Our 34% shareholding in 3iN delivers good dividend income.
We received GBP 21 million this year, a very important underpin to our cash profit metric.
The core European portfolio continues to perform well, but the performance of the Indian portfolio has been disappointing.
The value of our direct holding in these investments fell by 25%.
That includes the significant rupee and dollar depreciation in the year.
The PPP platform already covers its costs.
And further fundraising by that team will also make a positive contribution to the cash profit metric and the group's Fund Management profitability.
Our Debt Management business has the biggest contributor to that Fund Management profitability.
During the year, it closed 2 new CLOs in Europe and 2 in the U.
, and that added GBP 1.
2 million -- GBP 1.
2 billion assets under management and offset the run-off of the older funds.
We finished the year with assets under management of GBP 6.
Fee income was stable at GBP 32 million.
But as I said at the half year, the catch-up fees on older funds contributed GBP 6 million last year, and they no longer feature.
Excluding these catch-up fees, fee income grew by GBP 7 million, so an overall improvement in the quality of earnings.
Bringing together Fund Management contributions from all our businesses, you can see here the profitability of 3i's platform.
When we look at the Fund Management business's profitability, we recognize that it should receive a notional fee on the Proprietary Capital that it's managing on behalf of 3i Group's shareholders.
These synthetic fees are set with reference to our third-party fund mandates.
For this year and last, they're set at 1.
5% on our capital invested in Private Equity and Infrastructure and at 0.
5% on Debt Management capital.
We've also allocated operating expenses between the Fund Management platform and to the Proprietary Capital investment business.
The positive impact from cost savings, as Simon talked about earlier, flow through here, with the reduction from GBP 140 million last year to GBP 108 million this year.
So with stable combined fee income, the Fund Management platform became profitable for the first time at an absolute level.
And when we take out restructuring and amortization costs, underlying profit was GBP 33 million, and that's a respectable margin of 26%.
Our Proprietary Capital business has also seen an improvement year-on-year.
I've already talked about good realized profit and strong value growth.

The majority of
[Audio Gap] 
portfolio is invested outside the U.
, with 51% denominated in euros and 16% in dollars.
So revaluing this portfolio in a period where sterling has strengthened does result in significant differences.
We're talking about a translation loss of GBP 113 million against a GBP 52 million gain last year.
This is how that movement is made up.
And based on the balance sheet at the 3st of March, a further 1% movement in the euro or dollar would change returns by GBP 13 million and GBP 6 million, respectively.
Proprietary Capital business has the balance sheet funding costs.
You can see here the very positive impact of our gross debt reduction, with interest payable down 47% to GBP 54 million in the year, well ahead of our GBP 60 million target.
The most significant aspect of Proprietary Capital investments was the increase in momentum in Private Equity, although we remain highly selective about opportunities.
As Simon talked about, we made cash investment of GBP 276 million in Private Equity, including 3 new investments: Basic-Fit, GIF and JMJ, and the further investment in Scandlines with Eurofund V.

Our Proprietary Capital lets us support the growth of our Debt Management business through warehouse vehicles, which are used to build up credit portfolios in order to cede CLO launches and to avoid cash drag on returns.
At the 31st of March, we had a total of GBP 21 million invested in our European and U.
warehouse vehicles, ahead of the next CLO launches in these regions.
We also invest in the equity of a CLO when it is launched.
This is particularly important because new regulatory developments require fund managers to have skin in the game.
Our Proprietary Capital means that we can do that.
During the year, we invested GBP 40 million into the 4 new CLOs raised.
Core Infrastructure investment is principally funded by 3i Infrastructure plc, and we've had no other calls on the Proprietary Capital for that business.
Bringing all this together on the group balance sheet, investment momentum has improved in the year, but market conditions mean that it's a better time for realizations.
So we finished the year with net cash divestment of GBP 340 million.
The portfolio value increased to GBP 3.
6 billion because of the effect of the net divestment was offset by strong value growth.
We used proceeds from realizations to reduce gross debt.
Gross debt reduced to GBP 857 million, and net debt to GBP 160 million, with gearing that's only 5%.
So we have clearly satisfied the criteria to operate our enhanced distribution policy.
And we indicated at the half year that we expected to pay a dividend of 20p in total for this year.
Realizations have been good.
Investment levels have improved.
But as Simon talked about, the environment for mid-market Private Equity investing remains very competitive.
Taking these factors into account, we have confirmed the 20p dividend today.
Subject to shareholder approval, we declared a final dividend of 13.
As for the year that we're now in, we expect to pay above our 8.
1p base level dividend again, but the level of additional dividend will be a bit lower than financial year 2014.
So to sum up, our performance in financial year 2014 has been strong and shows the benefits of our restructuring coming through.

It has been underpinned by excellent performance in the Private Equity business, achieving an annual cash operating profit, a significant milestone for the group, and an outperformance against all the strategic targets that we set out in June 2012.
The momentum in the business continues, and we are well placed to build further value for shareholders in the next year of transition and delivery.
So thank you, and Simon and I would now be happy to take questions Thanks, Julia.
Daniel? I think we -- the 15% cost is clearly the new policy.
I think, as a company, we would, in general, like to work well within that figure because I would expect, as we reshape the portfolio, we'll come down to a natural number of, say, 30 investments.
We'll have, hopefully, in that 30 no bucket 4 investments, we'll have very few bucket 3, so it'll be bucket 1 or 2.
So it will be a more balanced value across the 30 assets.

But when we have a truly special investment, like an Action, we need to be able to run that sort of winner, take a leaf out of Warren Buffett's book, and that's what we'd do, and we want the flexibility to do that if we find such a thing.
And there are other examples of that around the Private Equity world, where people have run winners for a very long time.

I know Electra [ph] one of Chris's [ph] favorites stocks, they ran -- how long did they handle [ph] Flex 4, was it 10 years or something? Yes, I think it's very likely there'll be an Action refinancing this year.
I think on are we missing out because we're no longer proactively investing in, say, Southern Europe, we don't feel we are.
We still feel there's a lot of issues in that market.
And in the sort of sectors that we're looking in, we think there are better opportunities where we have the core teams at the moment, so we don't think we're losing out materially.
Ewan Lovett-Turner from Numis.

With the disposal of some of the sort of noncore investments and the focus on the keeper assets, what sort of level of portfolio concentration are you happy with going forward, how big would we see, the largest investments? 15, their best investment.

So I mean, there are plenty of examples of running winners in this industry if they produce a lot of cash and produce a lot of value, and we will be no different.
Any more before we wind up? Okay, well, thanks for coming.
Happy to mingle afterwards.
It's very much on price.
We have the best pipeline of potential new investments that I've seen since I joined 3i.
And we're getting a good look at quite a lot of stuff, but we're discarding quite a lot because of the relationship with price and expectation.
Any more? One at the front.
To give you a rough guidance, and I'll give it to you, from March to March, the value at March was GBP 280 million.

There are -- the really important dynamic in Action is the strong earnings growth that we see both in very good like-for-likes but also the store rollout program that they've got.
