During the year, it closed 2 new CLOs in Europe and 2 in the U.
, and that added GBP 1.
2 million -- GBP 1.
2 billion assets under management and offset the run-off of the older funds.
We finished the year with assets under management of GBP 6.
Fee income was stable at GBP 32 million.
But as I said at the half year, the catch-up fees on older funds contributed GBP 6 million last year, and they no longer feature.
Excluding these catch-up fees, fee income grew by GBP 7 million, so an overall improvement in the quality of earnings.
Bringing together Fund Management contributions from all our businesses, you can see here the profitability of 3i's platform.
When we look at the Fund Management business's profitability, we recognize that it should receive a notional fee on the Proprietary Capital that it's managing on behalf of 3i Group's shareholders.
These synthetic fees are set with reference to our third-party fund mandates.
For this year and last, they're set at 1.
5% on our capital invested in Private Equity and Infrastructure and at 0.
5% on Debt Management capital.
We've also allocated operating expenses between the Fund Management platform and to the Proprietary Capital investment business.
The positive impact from cost savings, as Simon talked about earlier, flow through here, with the reduction from GBP 140 million last year to GBP 108 million this year.
So with stable combined fee income, the Fund Management platform became profitable for the first time at an absolute level.
And when we take out restructuring and amortization costs, underlying profit was GBP 33 million, and that's a respectable margin of 26%.
Our Proprietary Capital business has also seen an improvement year-on-year.
I've already talked about good realized profit and strong value growth.

The majority of
[Audio Gap] 
portfolio is invested outside the U.
, with 51% denominated in euros and 16% in dollars.
So revaluing this portfolio in a period where sterling has strengthened does result in significant differences.
We're talking about a translation loss of GBP 113 million against a GBP 52 million gain last year.
This is how that movement is made up.
And based on the balance sheet at the 3st of March, a further 1% movement in the euro or dollar would change returns by GBP 13 million and GBP 6 million, respectively.
Proprietary Capital business has the balance sheet funding costs.
You can see here the very positive impact of our gross debt reduction, with interest payable down 47% to GBP 54 million in the year, well ahead of our GBP 60 million target.
The most significant aspect of Proprietary Capital investments was the increase in momentum in Private Equity, although we remain highly selective about opportunities.
As Simon talked about, we made cash investment of GBP 276 million in Private Equity, including 3 new investments: Basic-Fit, GIF and JMJ, and the further investment in Scandlines with Eurofund V.

Our Proprietary Capital lets us support the growth of our Debt Management business through warehouse vehicles, which are used to build up credit portfolios in order to cede CLO launches and to avoid cash drag on returns.
At the 31st of March, we had a total of GBP 21 million invested in our European and U.
warehouse vehicles, ahead of the next CLO launches in these regions.
We also invest in the equity of a CLO when it is launched.
This is particularly important because new regulatory developments require fund managers to have skin in the game.
Our Proprietary Capital means that we can do that.
During the year, we invested GBP 40 million into the 4 new CLOs raised.
Core Infrastructure investment is principally funded by 3i Infrastructure plc, and we've had no other calls on the Proprietary Capital for that business.
Bringing all this together on the group balance sheet, investment momentum has improved in the year, but market conditions mean that it's a better time for realizations.
So we finished the year with net cash divestment of GBP 340 million.
The portfolio value increased to GBP 3.
6 billion because of the effect of the net divestment was offset by strong value growth.
We used proceeds from realizations to reduce gross debt.
Gross debt reduced to GBP 857 million, and net debt to GBP 160 million, with gearing that's only 5%.
So we have clearly satisfied the criteria to operate our enhanced distribution policy.
And we indicated at the half year that we expected to pay a dividend of 20p in total for this year.
Realizations have been good.
Investment levels have improved.
But as Simon talked about, the environment for mid-market Private Equity investing remains very competitive.
Taking these factors into account, we have confirmed the 20p dividend today.
Subject to shareholder approval, we declared a final dividend of 13.
As for the year that we're now in, we expect to pay above our 8.
1p base level dividend again, but the level of additional dividend will be a bit lower than financial year 2014.
So to sum up, our performance in financial year 2014 has been strong and shows the benefits of our restructuring coming through.

It has been underpinned by excellent performance in the Private Equity business, achieving an annual cash operating profit, a significant milestone for the group, and an outperformance against all the strategic targets that we set out in June 2012.
The momentum in the business continues, and we are well placed to build further value for shareholders in the next year of transition and delivery.
So thank you, and Simon and I would now be happy to take questions Ewan Lovett-Turner from Numis.

With the disposal of some of the sort of noncore investments and the focus on the keeper assets, what sort of level of portfolio concentration are you happy with going forward, how big would we see, the largest investments? It's very much on price.
We have the best pipeline of potential new investments that I've seen since I joined 3i.
And we're getting a good look at quite a lot of stuff, but we're discarding quite a lot because of the relationship with price and expectation.
Any more? One at the front.
Thanks, Julia.
Daniel? 15, their best investment.
CVC, they're going to be holding Formula One for a long time.
So I mean, there are plenty of examples of running winners in this industry if they produce a lot of cash and produce a lot of value, and we will be no different.
Any more before we wind up? Okay, well, thanks for coming.
Happy to mingle afterwards.
So would it be fair to say it's largely on price, that you're not investing more? Daniel Garrod, Barclays.
Simon, a question for you first, and then one for Julia.
You mentioned a couple of times the sort of strong external environment, what you achieved in full year '14, before then accelerating again in 2016, 2017.

Have your thoughts changed from that kind of outlook because of what you're seeing around the external environment? And in the outlook, it kind of reads the pricing for new investments remains quite difficult.
You're indicating there you've done 4 deals in sort of recent months, that we could see a sort of slow and cautious approach there on the investment side.
And then a question for Julia on what exactly you've done on Action.
It looked -- so GBP 500 million valuation of Action at March.
At September, I think that equivalent figure was GBP 300 million.
The split of that, it -- from what you've said around the sensitivity, it strikes me about 60% of that is the multiple uplift, and about 40% is earnings growth.
Am I right, ballpark, in that estimation? Okay, I think, let's start.
Good morning, everyone.
Welcome to 3i's results for the year to 31st March, 2014.
Well, as you can see, the momentum in the business has continued, and we've had an excellent 6 months since our interim presentation last November.

We've made some very promising Private Equity investments, the portfolio is developing well, realizations and cash flow have been strong, and both Infrastructure and Debt Management have achieved important milestones.
These results clearly show the very significant benefits from our restructuring in financial year '13, as well as from our new asset management initiatives.
So I'd like to start by focusing on our strategic objectives and our progress over the last year and close with some comments about our business model before handing over to Julia.

It's been another good year to be a shareholder in 3i, with a total shareholder return of 30%, including a 20p dividend, which gives a 6% yield on the share price at the beginning of our financial year 2014.
We've achieved the second year of 40%-plus returns on our Private Equity realizations.
And we have returned to the new investment market with GBP 372 million in 3 new and 1 large follow-on investment.
We've again materially outperformed our second year cost-saving targets of GBP 60 million by coming in at GBP 70 million.
And as you can see, the operational leakages we have suffered from are now a thing of the past, with cash income in the year exceeding our new reduced cost base by GBP 5 million.

You're familiar with our model, so I'd like to start by focusing on our strategic objectives and our progress over the year and close with some comments about our business model before handing over to Julia.
It's important to note at this stage that we have made good progress in our 2 smaller businesses: Infrastructure and Debt Management, as well as Private Equity.
These results we've delivered reflect every aspect of 3i's value build.
This is not just to jam tomorrow's story, this is jam today, as well as jam tomorrow.
The portfolio is delivering growth in earnings and value and it's been another strong year of realizations.
Cash flow relative to costs has been strong, and we've made good progress in Fund Management profits.
We've made some excellent new investments, as well as a strategic acquisition in the infrastructure sector.
And we've significantly raised our shareholder distributions.
We are now more than halfway through the plan I set out in June 2012.
And we now have real momentum in the face of transition and delivery after our fundamental restructuring in financial year 2013.
We had 6 strategic priorities for financial year 2014, and we've either exceeded or met every single one, as you can see here.
It's been a great year for Private Equity, and I'd like to say well done to the 3i PE team.
We've seen strong growth in our proprietary portfolio through both earnings and valuation multiples.
And we've seen a good flow of realizations at excellent uplifts and decent cash on cash multiples.
Julia will give you a couple of examples in a minute.
Once again, we've not been selling any of our keeper assets, but we have sold the mix from our buckets 2, 3 and 4.
Those disposals have given us a meaningful reduction in the number of smaller problem investments in our portfolio.
New investment has picked up, but we've been very careful to be disciplined on price and careful to be consistent with our strategic focus.
We've added 5 new executives in the last 6 months, bringing our total number of investors to 59.
And we have a stable core partner team balanced across our key geographies, and they are focusing on our core sectors of industrial consumer and business services.
We've seen very strong returns across our European and U.
businesses, and the 2011 onwards investments have performed particularly well.
I'm delighted to see how the team has embraced the asset management initiatives, which we put in place during 2012.
We are monitoring the portfolio closely, and we're focusing hard on those situations where performance is below our expectations.
Right at the start, I said that it has been another excellent year for realizations, and here's how they look.
We've delivered proceeds of GBP 669 million at a 43% uplift to opening values.
The money multiple is 1 -- of 1.
8x is very good, especially when we've sold a decent number of our smaller or underperforming investments during the year.
Now I'd like to talk briefly about portfolio segmentation or what I call the buckets.
We're seeing excellent earnings growth in our keepers bucket, which now accounts for over 40% of the PE portfolio value.
Action is the standout investment here.
But we have a number of other promising investments, which have the potential to drive cash on cash returns significantly above 2x over the medium term.
And they include a number of our most recent investments.
Of our 24 realizations, 6 were either partial realizations or from bucket 2, and 18 were from buckets 3 and 4.
That shows you the extent of the tidying-up exercises here and how we have now reduced the portfolio to 81 companies from over 100.
I expect the value of our keepers bucket to continue to grow well over the next 12 months.
And we will also see a further reduction in the number of overall investments in the portfolio.
And I'm very excited about the PE investments we've made this year.
We made a significant follow-on investment in Scandlines, which has already been a strong investment for 3i.

This is a large keeper bucket asset, and we're anticipating a strong value growth over the medium term, as Steve Ridgway, the new Chairman and former CEO of Virgin Atlantic, works with the existing management team of Scandlines.
Basic-Fit, JMJ and GIF are all new investments, which are consistent with our strategic focus on local origination of international companies.
We maintained our price discipline on these assets, buying all of them at attractive multiples.
Now looking around the room, I can see there's a number of you who are fitness fanatics.
Don't worry, Bill, I wasn't looking at you.
I want to tell you about my day with Rene Moos, the CEO of Basic-Fit.
This was last September, and this was before we bought the business.
And I think it shows how we find deals and the power of 3i's international franchise.
Basic-Fit is the largest discount fitness operator in Europe.
We've known the business for several years and have tracked it since 2011.
To give you an idea of its scale, it had 64,000 new members in January this year alone.
Rene is a former professional tennis player.
He's highly competitive, and he's a gifted businessman.
We first approached Rene, the Founder and CEO of Basic-Fit, in 2011, after our consumer team had identified discount as the winning theme in retail and the retail services sector.
Rene had 3 businesses at the time: a golf course business, an upmarket gym business and Basic-Fit.
We approached him at roughly the same time we approached and purchased Action.
But Rene wasn't interested in our approach.
He didn't accept that the discount format was his best business and was unconvinced by our arguments that discount was a business to scale up and make his fortune in.

But after reading about and seeing the success of Action, Rene contacted our Amsterdam team in early 2003 -- 2013 and asked for a meeting to discuss the success of Action and our current thoughts on Basic-Fit.
When I met Rene in September and toured Basic-Fit, I was impressed by his energy and detailed understanding of the Basic-Fit business and the broader fitness market.

At the washup meeting with him at the end of it all and the day and before I supported the investment proposal, I asked him why he was dealing with 3i and haven't talked to any other buyout firms, and I liked what I heard.
He said, "Your PE team has educated me on the potential of Basic-Fit, on where I would succeed.
For too long, I've been dazzled by the upmarket gym business without really understanding the power of a large-scale, value-for-money discount franchise.
And your team is Dutch, which is important to me.
They've been investing in Dutch companies for decades, they speak my language, and they have a great track record in this market.
So I would rather work with your local Dutch team than deal with Brits or Americans, who fly in and out of ship hold on an irregular basis.
" This was an interesting comment, given 5 minutes earlier, I'd ask him to ask his PA to print my boarding card.
But anyway, as you can say, Rene can be very direct and is a classic entrepreneur.
Now that's what I'd call competitive advantage.
We are on the ground, and we have the skills to identify companies with strong potential, and we can provide financial and operational support.
It was the same for Action, and it gives us the opportunity to invest in these strong businesses away from the froth of hotly contested auctions in London.
Infrastructure has continued to make good contribution to the group's annual cash income.
And the European portfolio has performed well.
The new leadership team has settled in quickly and has agreed with 3iN to further extend the advisory agreement.
India had a challenging time again, and we saw a further pullback in the valuations, although we did see a more stable second half.
We've also broadened our platform through the acquisition of a PPP-focused team from Barclays.
They have a strong pipeline of deals, and we are now focusing on the next fundraising.
We now have 25 investors in London and Paris and 6 investors in Mumbai.
Debt Management has delivered another productive year.
They've raised 4 new CLOs in the U.
and in the newly opened European market.
And they manage GBP 6.
5 billion of AUM.
And they're now in the top 10 global CLO managers.
You'll be pleased to hear that we significantly overreached on cost savings for our second year in a row.
Our cost metrics are now very much in line with the rest of the industry.
Including the 2 acquisitions, Fraser Sullivan and BIFM, the group's now got operating costs of about GBP 129 million.
Our cash income actually exceeded operating costs in financial year 2014, and that's something the group has not achieved for a very long time.
That outcome was a direct result of our cost-reduction program.
This is a tight metric for 3i because of our preponderance of Proprietary Capital, so I'm particularly pleased by this step this year.
We've also significantly cut our interest bill.
By repaying debt, it's now down to GBP 54 million from GBP 101 million in our last financial year.
And we've now fully implemented our new compensation arrangements, and they've closely aligned senior staff to our key strategic objectives.
3i shares now make up a significant element of variable compensation, and that gives us further alignment with the shareholders.
Now I'd like to move to financial year '15, the second year of our transition and delivery phase.
Here are our strategic priorities for the year.
They're clear, but fundamentally, they remain focused on thoughtful and well-executed asset management, careful new investments and tight cost control.
And if we achieve that, we will deliver another year of marked improvement in capital efficiency and allocation, as we did this year.
This shift you can see in capital allocations is increasing cash for new investments and shareholder distributions.
Now let me turn to the group's business model.
We have a hybrid model.
We have a large portfolio of proprietary investments, as well as acting as a fund manager for third-party capital.
The weight of our Proprietary Capital in mid-market Private Equity is the fundamental driver of our results and gives us the competitive advantage in closing new investments.
We're an active owner of investments, as well as being manager of third-party funds.
In our Private Equity and Infrastructure vehicles, we are the single largest investor.
We back our analysis and judgment with 3i cash, alongside the cash of our external LPs.

The revenues and profits from our Fund Management activities contribute to the cost of running our investment platforms, and they create another source of value for 3i shareholders, especially as our Fund Management franchise grows.
We want you to be able to track our progress in Proprietary Capital investing and as a fund manager.
We think this greater transparency will be helpful in judging just how well we're doing.
Going forward, we'll be using this core set of KPIs so that you can track our progress and performance at group level in our returns on Proprietary Capital and from our Fund Management activities.
I'd like to close by saying we've had a very good year, where we have seen the clear benefits from our restructuring and from our new asset management initiatives in Private Equity.
We've also been clearing up our Private Equity portfolio, and we've put out the fires.
We have good earnings momentum across the portfolio, and cash flow is strong, particularly in our larger investments.
We have some very special investments in our keeper bucket of assets, and as I said a minute ago, they now account for over 40% of portfolio value.
We think they are capable of very strong growth over the medium term.
We are, of course, hostage to broader economic and political trends.
But subject to those broader trends, I would expect to see another strong year for 3i.
As the portfolio moves forward, we take advantage of buoyant realization markets, and we remain energetic but selective when finding new investments.
So on that note, I'd like to pass over to Julia to give you more detailed color on the results.
Do you want to take this? It's Iain Scouller from Oriel Securities.
I've got a couple.
First, there's obviously quite a big increase in the multiples used on the valuation over the year.
Did the inclusion of new investments at presumably relatively higher multiples have much of an impact on this number? And the second one is the CLO portfolios.
I was wondering if you could just talk a bit about the performance of that.
There seemed to be a number of gains coming through there.
To give you a rough guidance, and I'll give it to you, from March to March, the value at March was GBP 280 million.
And as you correctly say, the value at the end of this financial year was GBP 501 million.
There are -- the really important dynamic in Action is the strong earnings growth that we see both in very good like-for-likes but also the store rollout program that they've got.
And as I've talked about, we adjust for that in the earnings of these valuations by adding a sort of pro forma on stores being opened, and that's the run rate basis that we're using.
And then as I've said, we've also taken the decision to step up the multiple to recognize that growth rate.
If you look at the movement from March to March, there is more benefit coming from the earnings growth than the multiples.
It's a shade beyond the 50% comes from earnings, it's probably about 55%, 45%, something like that.
So there was a refinancing in Action in the first half.
And actually, because of the way that was structured, that came back as proceeds to us.
So we received GBP 59 million of proceeds in the first half.
As I said, it's got very good free cash flow.
And post that refinancing, net debt is now down to 3.
So we will obviously continue to look at ways of making sure that that's the most efficient, and we could be looking at further refinancings in the future.
Okay, let me take the first 2, and then Julia can deal with the Action question.
On realizations, I think it's -- I would probably choose to modify my view a little.
Looking at our pipeline at the moment, and this is always subject to what might happen out there, I think we'll be at a similar level to the year just finished.
So it's a bit stronger in terms of the realization pipeline, I would suggest.
On pricing and the environment in general, I think we're at a -- we are at a very interesting place.
We are clearly benefiting from buoyant conditions in the realization program.
And we are getting very good prices, sometimes on even quite mediocre investments that we're selling.
The flip side of that is the competitive and high-priced nature of the investment environment.
And we have been using and focusing on our platform very hard to find stuff away from these very busy auctions.
But that is clearly harder to do than just asking for a book on everything that's being sold.

And if you look back over statistics for Private Equity, and as I've said before, 3i has its own library on this, given how long it's been around, while we all like to feel we're geniuses in Private Equity, vintage is the biggest determinant of returns, and therefore, you need to moderate your excitement and compulsion to invest when banks are banging on your door with large debt packages and other things because it's generally a pretty good sign that this might not be one of the finer vintages for investing.
And that in reality, meter [ph] accounts for an awful lot of returns, both going up and going down in the Private Equity sector.
So I think the smart people who are really smart will be quite careful about investing in this environment.
And I'm pretty glad we don't have a fund with lots of money burning a hole in our pocket because we might feel under more pressure to buy stuff than we actually do.

So we'll continue to make investments, we'll continue to use our platform, but we are going to be very careful about the end prices because the end prices will be the biggest determinants of the returns we'll make on these investments.
Do you want to pick up on Action? The multiples one.
So I would say that the increase in the average multiple in the year, clearly, the Action multiple has an impact, and we've given you the numbers, excluding the Action impact.
So that's a 9.
We talked at the Q3 trading statement that we would cap multiples, taking into account a number of factors.
We thought the market was moving up.
We've got good performance in a number of our assets, and so we have tweaked some multiples up as we go through.

I mean, to answer your specific question about new investments, no, the investments that we've been -- we've done have been lower than those sort of averages that we've just been talking about, so it's not -- they're not a cause of the impact.
It's more market driven and Action driven.
And then on the CLO equity performance, yes, we've seen some good returns coming out of that.
We have a relatively modest amount of capital in the business, but it can generate good, double-digit returns for us.
Yes, I think it's very likely there'll be an Action refinancing this year.
I think on are we missing out because we're no longer proactively investing in, say, Southern Europe, we don't feel we are.
We still feel there's a lot of issues in that market.
And in the sort of sectors that we're looking in, we think there are better opportunities where we have the core teams at the moment, so we don't think we're losing out materially.
We are a cornerstone investor in the new Global Fund, which is another big chunk of it.
I mean it's worth bundling a bit on Debt Management, we have seen quite choppy markets there, particularly in the U.
, actually more so than Europe.
But again, I think in line with 3i's current behaviors, we have encouraged the credit team there to really take care of any loans we are worried about and move them out of the portfolio as quickly.

So we've been quite aggressive at addressing those problems so we don't have problems down the road, and encouraging those teams to then build back value in loans where they see better promise going forward.
So again, I think we are being a little ahead of the curve in heading off some of the problems that might come through in that market in the states.
And we have a relatively light exposure to oil and gas compared to most of the CLO issues in the States.
It's not a sector that we've ever liked and it's a big sector.
Richard? Simon, sorry, it's Iain Scouller from Stifel.
Simon, I note the British comments on bucket 1, what multiple is bucket 1 valued as of the end of September? Okay.
Just a follow-up quickly, and then on the debt management side, would there be any implication, for example, Dublin some of the fund manager or anything like that? Thank you, Simon.
So another half year of solid performance, with all 3 of our businesses making important progress.
And it's another set of results which give you the evidence of how 3i is a business with the sound fundamentals it takes to perform well against a difficult economic and political backdrop.
We are continuing to build value for our shareholders through strong development of earnings growth in the Private Equity portfolio.
Constructed markets, particularly in the first quarter, led to realizations of GBP 359 million and further progress on reshaping the Private Equity portfolio.
We remain focused on our operating cash profitability.
That way, we can make sure we have a sustainable and sound operating platform.
And all of this is supported by maintaining a strong balance sheet so that our investment teams can invest well at sensible prices and to support enhanced distributions to our investors.
Now as you are all aware, this has been a volatile 6 months.
And this slide shows you how our NAV share developed over the 2 quarters to the 30th of September.
You can see that our Proprietary Capital made a strong contribution to NAV, both through realized profits and through value growth.
Material interperiod swings on FX more or less canceled each other out over the 6 months.
And after the payment of the final dividend of 14p in July, NAV pence per share was 401p at the 30th of September.
So we delivered a total return of 4.
We have said that all 3 businesses made important progress in the period.
I'm now going to take you through the financial contribution each business made to our results.
I'd like to start with Private Equity, which accounts for 81% of the Proprietary Capital portfolio at the end of September.
Strong portfolio earnings growth supported growth investment return of GBP 246 million.
The impact from multiple movements was lower than you might expect given the fall in global equity markets in August and September, and I'll come on to talk about valuations in a minute.

Realized profits of GBP 26 million came from the full disposals of 9 assets, the IPO of UFO, partial sales of Quintiles, as well as the remittance of proceeds from Scandlines January disposal of the route.
Together, these transactions generated GBP 307 million.
The 9% uplift over value reflects the fact that the number of assets were held at imminent sale at the year-end, so we're talking about assets such as Azelis, Soyaconcept and Touchtunes.
Simon described our increased focus on our stronger assets and new investments, and that is reflected in the strength of the portfolio earnings growth, which you can see here.
As you can see, a very small proportion of value is made up of companies with falling earnings.
And although Action remains an important contributor to the 19% profile, the growth, excluding Action, remains a healthy 14%.
That, together with movements on net debt, is what led to the strong performance of GBP 171 million in portfolio value growth on this slide.
We valued 30 companies on an earnings basis at the 30th of September.
As usual, we used the last 12 months earnings to the 30th of June and[ph] less the most recent forecast to December 2015 showed a decline in performance.
5 out of the 30 companies have been valued on a forecast earnings basis as a result of macroeconomic factors, such as oil and gas sector exposure and currency volatility.
The negative multiple movement of GBP 24 million reflects the deterioration in equity markets in August and September.

As I've talked about for some time, we have adjusted down the multiples we use in our valuations when we think the multiple implied by the quality comparables is ahead of our view of longer-term multiples and/or our exit expectations.
We also consider the particular size and footprint of our investments.

We did this for 22 out of 33 companies at March, and we continued to do it for 19 out of 30 companies at September, even after taking into account the fall in equity markets during our second quarter.
Simon showed you that we have taken value reductions as a result of multiples for assets such as AES, Hanko and Dynatect.
On the other hand, we increased the multiple we used to value Basic-Fit to 10.
5x post-discount.
For those of you who were able to attend the Investor Day in June, you will have seen the ambition of this business.
That is accelerating.
And the new multiple reflects the growth potential of this business, as it invests to upgrade existing gyms and to build and acquire new ones.
We made no change to the multiple we used to value Action, which remains at 3.
5x post-discount.
In the tcf category, the positive movement of GBP 28 million was driven by the good performance of Scandlines.
In our view, that the competing fixed link is likely to be delayed by at least another year.
Now this good momentum, particularly over the last 12 months, flows through to the accrual for carry payable.
And more schemes are forecast to meet the performance hurdles if you assume we sold everything at its current value.
We expect to accrue carry at between 10% to 15% of Private Equity gross investment return, but we only pay out when the hurdle is met with cash returns.
To give you the specific number, we paid out GBP 13 million in the first half.
There is a negative receivable balance in this half, and this is a one-off accounting adjustment to the growth capital fund accrual, which went through its hurdle for the first time last year.
As well as generating good value growth and realizations, the Private Equity business makes an important contribution to our operating cash profit.
We confirmed in May that we have no plans in the short to medium term to raise a new third-party fund for Private Equity investment.
This makes a lot of sense from a shareholder return perspective.
But it means that the Private Equity fee income will continue to decline as we sell investments from our third-party funds, such as Eurofund 5.
However, the Private Equity portfolio itself generates income and made a strong contribution of GBP 22 million to operating cash income.
Our infrastructure business has also made a good contribution to group performance in the first half.
The teams increased investments activity has demonstrated that they are able to deploy of funds well in a highly attractive sector.
And that has been well received by 3iN's investors.
3iN generated a TSR of 7%, and we received an ordinary dividend of GBP 11 million.
And that GBP 11 million is included in our operating cash profit.
3iN also paid a special dividend in July following the completion of the sale of its investment in Eversholt Rail, and we have treated this GBP 51 million as realization proceeds.
Our investments in the Indian Infrastructure Fund continued to be impacted by the weakness in the road and power sectors and the rupee.
That has led to a value reduction of GBP 9 million, partly offsetting the good contribution from the European businesses.
Debt Management had a busy 6 months, and AUM is now GBP 7.
They closed new CLOs in Europe and the U.
and launched their Global Income Fund.
That vehicle uses the combined expertise of our European and U.
Debt Management is primarily a fund management business and it generated another GBP 17 million of fees and operating cash income of GBP 33 million for 3i.

We do invest proprietary capital in debt management, principally for regulatory reasons to meet the skin in the game rules for CLO fundraising or to support a new product, such as the Global Income Fund.
Our investment in CLO equity generates a good cash income for us.
We received GBP 14 million in the first half.
All else equal, we expect the CLO equity value to fall roughly in line with this GBP 14 million of distributions.
But in our second quarter in particular, there was also some pullback in market sentiments and appetite, especially in the U.
Together, the distributions and market volatility led to a total of GBP 18 million value reduction.
I talked earlier about the importance of a sustainable operating platform and solid balance sheet in the Value Build for shareholders.
You can see here the contribution all 3 businesses have made to our operating cash profit of GBP 17 million.
Having transformed the cost base of the group since 2012, we remain disciplined on costs.
In fact, costs have fallen to less than 1% of AUM in the first half.
We have been recruiting selectively to support the growth of all 3 businesses, so our benchmark target of 1% is an important discipline to maintain.
The balance sheet is strong.
After paying GBP 133 million out as the final dividend in July, we closed the half with net debt of GBP 12 million.
And we are well-funded, with GBP 1.
2 billion of liquidity to support investments and shareholder distributions.
That said, we expect to remain net sellers in this financial year, with realizations weighted towards the end of the second half.
So against that background, we have declared an interim dividend of 6p today, which is just over 15% of realization proceeds, and which is made up of 2.
7p base dividend and a 3.
3p additional.
We expect to be paying at the 20% end of our dividend range again this year.

And as Simon has talked about, we expect realizations to have a lumpier profile going forward, but we are confident in enough in the outlook to confirm that we expect to pay a total dividend of at least 15p for the year.
The results we are announcing today demonstrate good momentum across all 3 business lines.
Our Private Equity portfolio delivered a solid performance, supported by good contributions from both Infrastructure and Debt Management to support our strong investment platform.

As Simon has said, we cannot be immune to wider geopolitical and economic conditions, but the sound fundamentals of the group mean that we are well-positioned commercially and financially to be able to capitalize over time on attractive opportunities as they arise.
So thank you, and we are now happy to move over to questions.
I mean, both the companies in Brazil are consumer companies, and they're trading relatively robust there, so they're not on the commodity sector, they're not in the industrial sector.
So we haven't seen any dramatic drop in the performance.
What's the issue in those countries is tending to be the exchange rate and so we've suffered on the depreciation in exchange rates.
In terms of China, we have really limited exposure.
We have a large reinsurance business based out of Singapore.
We listed a company on the Hongkong Stock Exchange, a sort of Chinese version of Carphone Warehouse, volatile markets, but no discernible pattern.
And again, that business is a consumer business.
And the reinsurance business is a very unique business,, pretty unique amongst the Private Equity world, I think.
Bill? Thank you.

capability.

Thanks, everyone, for coming.
Appreciate it.
It's about 1% this time.

on a 15x EBITDA multiple.

so we've stuck on that out and put it on a 10.

Just 2 questions.

The first is I was just interested in your comments you made about some of the business indicators you're seeing have been deteriorating given the macro, particularly in industrials yet, the investment you've made it's just an industrial companies, so I was just if you could us help us think some of the of the logic there? And then and given 80% of the portfolio is basically U.
or Europe, how should we think about possible BRICs and implications for? Yes.
We don't actually tell you all of the companies that are in each bucket so.
I don't think we break out an average across the buckets, I'm afraid.
How sensitive is this valuation Scandlines to delays on the tunnel, I mean you referred today on the tunnel? Okay, I'm -- let me respond.
On the industrials question, let me start from the point that we don't have any direct exposure to oil and gas, and we don't have any direct commodity exposure.
So that the blackest parts of the scene are not things that we are familiar with.

Where we've seen impacts where companies either have customers who deal with those sectors or have contracts servicing those sectors such as JMJ, as I noted, but Action not many of our industrial groups serve the industrial market.
It's quite a limited number.
And if you take , for instance, it serves the consumer market, so it's not seeing the same sorts of pressures as a Dynatect would be seeing in the States and so that market place.
So when I think you think about industrial sectors, you need to look at the end markets that those companies serve in order to come to a proper view.

I mean the other thing I would say to balance this is that our consumer portfolio, in particular, is trading really very strongly and the consumer sector looks very different to the narrow industrial sector that we have concerns about.
The other business we bought, Euro Diesel, it basically makes these diesel engines to deal with supply, power supply problems for data centers.
The growth in data centers around the world is phenomenal and it hasn't affected that business at all in any of these industrial stuff.
So they're out with the issues I'm talking about on the industrial sector.
I mean, on the Braxis question, frankly, I don't know what it means.
I don't know how serious this will be for a lot of companies.
We don't really have a huge number of U.
companies that export large amounts to the rest of Europe.
So in that sense, I think the issue is quite narrow for us.
I don't think it will affect at all where we invest or how we work our business.
So I'm not convinced if the vote went one way or the other, it would make a huge difference to 3i's portfolio or the returns.
Let me deal with both of those.

I mean, we had some important discussions about the development of Action and the management succession question in the first half of this year, and that really led to the CEO change that we've announced.
And essentially, we wanted that commitment from management for at least 4 or 5 years because we do see a likely realization event probably calendar '17, something like that.
That could be an IPO or it could be something else, but that is a sort of broad target.
And if we're IPO-ing it, we want to make sure the team were in place for a good period after that.

And Ronald has done a fantastic job at Action, and he is an incredibly energetic and effective CEO, but he was not prepared to commit to that time scales, so we agreed with him that as we were entering a critical phase for preparing the company for that type of event, it will be better to make a change sooner rather than later.
So Sander van der Laan has come out of Ahold.
He actually comes from the same part of Holland where Action comes from, so he is part of that northern Dutch community.
He is incredibly familiar with the business.
He has been pretty envious of the growth that he's witnessed at Action and what it did to the Albert business, which he ran for a number of years at Ahold.
He is a very effective individual.
He is used to running a big company.
He's ran businesses for Ahold in the States as well.
We interviewed quite a number of candidates for this, and he was by far the best and most suitable candidate, so we are delighted to get him.
He has spent the last 3 months looking at the different countries, looking at competition and getting briefed on the business.
And he formally takes over the reins at the beginning of January.
Frdric came in a CFO late summer.
He was actually recruited last year, but it took time to disconnect him from where he'd been CFO.
He's another very effective international executive, who work very effectively on the, superb references, and he's already doing a great job.
So we have a management team in place that can see us through a big event.
And that both guys have got big company experience.
And Action is becoming a very big company.
In terms of leverage, it's become a bit of a tradition that we do a refi action every 12 months or so.
The gearing is already back below 3x EBITDA, so that could well be on the cards, Bill.
It creates cash more than 100% of its earnings, so it's a very cash generative business.
So the CLO equity at the end of the year was -- at the end of the period was GBP 51 million that we've done.
We have about GBP 130 million in total.
Bill Barnard.
I note you rather glossed over on Action, the point about management change.

Should I read anything into the fact you've changed both the CEO and the CFO, and there is a reference to the next leg of the strategic journey? And also I also see that Action is probably taken its leverage down a turn, might you be tempted to take that back up in the second half? Okay, good morning, everyone.
Welcome to 3i's interim results.
Our goal at 3i remains to deliver attractive proprietary profits from a cost-efficient investment platform.
And we've had a solid first half, with all 3 of our business lines making important progress against our plans.
Despite the volatility in the markets up until the end of September, we've seen a robust performance from our portfolio of proprietary investments.
We've also delivered on our realization plan for the first half, and we made some new investments in Private Equity and infrastructure.
Importantly, we are continuing to make strong progress on our fundamentals, the health of our Proprietary Capital portfolio and the group's financial model.
The group KPIs continued to reflect the benefits of our restructuring in 2012.
Our improved cash operating profit is underpinned by a resilient NAV performance and a strong balance sheet, and Julie will give you more detail on this shortly.
And as I have just said, our goal remains to deliver attractive proprietary profits from a cost-efficient platform.
That way, our shareholders will benefit from strong capital gains and significant cash distributions.
The main driver of our capital profits is our Private Equity business where we target international midmarket investments.
Our objective is to make at least 2x our money over a 4-year investment period.
Once again, our Private Equity team has delivered.
They have achieved a solid portfolio performance, a good level of realizations from the challenged end of our portfolio, and 2 new and 1 follow-on investment all made at sensible prices.
We have continued to reshape our Private Equity portfolio by selling assets from our weaker or non-core buckets and devoting more energy and resources to our better investments.
The majority of these realizations were completed early in the first half when conditions were more supportive of selling companies that either had issues or a checkered record.
We have a number of important realization and refinancing initiatives running in the second half, but in the main, these include some of our stronger companies.
A number of the companies we sold, such as Azelis and Lab Coat, have required intense management focus over the last few years.
But the time has been well spent, and we've built back in the significant value ahead of their sales.
Azelis to represent our contrasting approaches to problem assets.
Along with Lab Coat, these were '07, '08 vintage assets.
In the case of Azelis, the Investment Committee were very supportive of the new Chairman and CEO we put in place, and we backed that turnaround plan with funding support.
This was not the case with Inspecta, where we came to the view that further funding would not be in the interest of 3i's shareholders or our LPs.
As the result of our focus on rebuilding and realizing value in the bucket 3 assets, we are beginning to see a marked change in the makeup of our Private Equity portfolio.
We are now down to 53 companies in 5 listed holdings from over 120 in 2012.
90% of the portfolio value now resides in our keepers in bucket 1, our strong performers in bucket 2 or our remaining listed stakes.
And just to remind you of the definitions, while bucket 2 is our target of 2x, in bucket 1, we are expecting to do materially better than 2x.
And the quality of our current portfolio is reflected in the weighted average earnings growth of 19% in the period or 14% if we exclude action.
We've had a few situations where earnings have suffered in the current environment, such as Dynatect or JMJ.
Both of these businesses have suffered indirect blows from the oil and gas situation.
But in the main, markdowns have come about as the result of valuation changes in specific sectors.
And earnings uplifts in the portfolio have far outweighed any negative multiple adjustments.
And at 3i today, just because a company suffers a marked down, that doesn't mean it's a bad business.
I'd also like to say just a few words on Action, where I joined the board in March.
Action goes from strength to strength, with over 80 new stores opened so far this year, with the majority of those stores being in France and Germany.
The new stores in all countries are performing very well.
And like-for-likes across the entire store portfolio remains strong.

There is plenty of activity planned in the last few months of the year, with significant further openings in November and December, and the opening of Action's third distribution center near Paris early in the new year.
Personally, I have been most struck by the energy of the company, and the laserlike focus on very low prices and how the exact same store format works in every country Action enters.
And to cap it all off, Action has just won Retailer of the Year for the second year in a row in Holland amongst its peers.
Scandlines, another of our large keeper assets, is having a good year, with strong earnings momentum and excellent cash flow.
It should also benefit from even further delays which are now expected on the competing fixed link, Rugby Puttgarden route.
Let me say a little bit more about JMJ.
We acquired JMJ a couple of years ago, well before the oil price collapse.
JMJ has seen projects canceled or downsized in its core oil and gas sector as a result of that price drop.
But they have responded very effectively by initiating a cost reduction program across the entire firm and by focusing new business activity outside of the oil and gas sector.
It's absolutely clear to us that the trading environment is becoming more difficult in a number of industrial sectors.

And through our monthly dashboard monitoring process, we are very focused on supporting our management teams where they have exposure to slowing sectors or geographies or where they face other factors which were outside their control.
The Private Equity team has also been busy with new investments this year, including the purchase of, a long-established German business we acquired this summer.
We see as a platform asset where we have a very real opportunity to grow both organically and through M&A, playing to our strengths in the international midmarket.
The infrastructure team has been very busy.
They have developed a new strategy in order to broaden their investment mandate beyond the large super core sector.

They backed their new approach with GBP 187 million of new investments in the first half, as well as some capable new recruits to broaden out their origination capability without losing any of their first-class asset management performance.
And last, but not least, the excellent result on Eversholt financed the GBP 51 million special dividend we received from 3i Infrastructure this summer.
During our first half, our debt management team has continued to perform well in more challenging markets.
They have been productive in both the U.
and Europe, and new CLOs, as well as with new CLOs, as well as launching a Global Income Fund, and raising further investments for the U.
Senior Loan Fund and the European Middle Market Fund.
And once again, the division has made a very good contribution, income contribution, with GBP 17 million of fee income in the first half, as well as GBP 14 million of CLO distributions.
Now I wanted to show you this slide again, updated for September's end.
It highlights well just what an efficient machine 3i has become and bodes very well for when we come to realize some of our largest investments.

Operating and interest costs are now accounting for less than 15% of our annual cash flows compared to almost 70% over the period covering financial years '10, '11 and '12, leaving the bulk of our cash flows available for new investment and shareholder distributions.
So it's been another decent 6 months for 3i in spite of the challenging macro picture, the volatile markets and the low point of the 30th of September.
The fundamentals, our proprietary investment portfolio and the group's financial model have continued to strengthen, and each of our 3 divisions is performing well relative to their peers.
We have clear strategic priorities and we are making real progress on all of them.
And importantly, we have a strong balance sheet and a high quality portfolio just as the cycle is turning more difficult.
Over time, the silver lining of this change in investment climate will, of course, be more opportunities on the buy side.

We understand the changes in the cycle and the challenges that will bring, and the ongoing need for us to maintain our price discipline in particular, but we welcome the opportunities it will create now that we've put our own house in order.
I'd like to pass over to Julia for the remainders.
Charles Cade from Numis.

You talked about 14% earnings growth, excluding Action, but including portfolio acquisitions, can you give any sort of idea how much portfolio acquisitions contributed to that? It's very sensitive because we assume 0 cash flow from that route once the tunnel is open.
So for every year delay, it's a very considerable sum of money on top of the valuation.
We think there's likely to be another formal announcement to the further delay in the coming months.
There are significant budgeting issues.
And the formal process that Germany has to go through to approve planning and give 2 years for appeals and various other things has not been properly factored into the Danish timetable apparently.
Chris Brown from JPMorgan Cazenove.

Simon, I think you've got about 1% of the portfolio Brazil, 6% in Asia, could you talk a little bit about events in those emerging markets have affected companies in those areas? Okay, good morning, everyone.

Now as you're all aware, this has been a volatile 6 months and this slide shows you how our NAV per share developed over the 2 quarters to the 30th of September.
You can see that our Proprietary Capital made a strong contribution to NAV, both through realized profits and through value growth.

And after the payment of the final dividend of 14p in July, NAV pence per share was 401p at the 30th of September.
So we delivered a total return of 4.
We have said that all 3 businesses made important progress in the period.
I'm now going to take you through the financial contribution each business made to our results.
I'd like to start with Private Equity, which accounted for 81% of the Proprietary Capital portfolio at the end of September.
Strong portfolio earnings growth supported gross investment return of GBP 246 million.
The impact from multiple movements was lower than you might expect, given the fall in global equity markets in August and September, and I'll come on to talk about valuations in a minute.

Realized profits of GBP 26 million came from the full disposals of 9 assets, the IPO of UFO, partial sales of Quintiles as well as the remittance of proceeds from Scandlines' January disposal of the H-H route.
Together, these transactions generated GBP 307 million.
The 9% uplift over value reflects the fact that the number of assets were held at imminent sale at the year-end, so we're talking about assets such as Azelis, Soyaconcept and Touchtunes.
Simon described our increased focus on our stronger assets and new investments, and that is reflected in the strength of the portfolio earnings growth, which you can see here.
As you can see, a very small proportion of value is made up of companies with falling earnings.
And although Action remains an important contributor to the 19% profile, the growth, excluding Action, remains a healthy 14%.
That, together with movements on net debt, is what led to the strong performance of GBP 171 million in portfolio value growth on this slide.
We valued 30 companies on an earnings basis at the 30th of September.
As usual, we used the last 12 months earnings to the 30th of June, unless the most recent forecast to December 2015 showed a decline in performance.
5 out of the 30 companies have been valued on a forecast earnings basis as a result of macroeconomic factors such as oil and gas sector exposure and currency volatility.
The negative multiple movement of GBP 24 million reflects the deterioration in equity markets in August and September.

As I've talked about for some time, we have adjusted down the multiples we use in our valuations when we think the multiple implied by the quality comparables is ahead of our view of longer-term multiples and/or our exit expectations.
We also consider the particular size and footprint of our investments.

We did this for 22 out of 33 companies at March, and we continued to do it for 19 out of 30 companies at September, even after taking into account the fall in equity markets during our second quarter.
Simon showed you that we have taken value reductions as a result of multiples for assets such as AES, Etanco and Dynatect.
On the other hand, we increased the multiple we used to value Basic-Fit to 10.
5x post-discount.
For those of you who were able to attend the Investor Day in June, you will have seen the ambition of this business.
That is accelerating.
And the new multiple reflects the growth potential of this business, as it invests to upgrade existing gyms and to build and acquire new ones.
We made no change to the multiple we used to value Action, which remains at 3.
5x post-discount.
In the DCF category, the positive movement of GBP 28 million was driven by the good performance of Scandlines.
In our view, that the competing fixed link is likely to be delayed by at least another year.
Now this good momentum, particularly over the last 12 months, flows through to the accrual for carry payable.
And more schemes are forecast to meet the performance hurdles if you assume we sold everything at its current value.
We expect to accrue carry at between 10% to 15% of Private Equity gross investment return, but we only pay out when the hurdle is met with cash returns.
To give you the specific number, we paid out GBP 13 million in the first half.
There is a negative receivable balance in this half, and this is a one-off accounting adjustment to the growth capital fund accrual, which went through its hurdle for the first time last year.
As well as generating good value growth and realizations, the Private Equity business makes an important contribution to our operating cash profit.
We confirmed in May that we have no plans in the short to medium term to raise a new third-party fund for Private Equity investment.
This makes a lot of sense from a shareholder return perspective.
But it means that the Private Equity fee income will continue to decline as we sell investments from our third-party funds, such as Eurofund V.
However, the Private Equity portfolio itself generates income and made a strong contribution of GBP 22 million to operating cash income.
Our Infrastructure business has also made a good contribution to group performance in the first half.
The team's increased investments activity has demonstrated that they are able to deploy of funds well in a highly attractive sector.
And that has been well received by 3iN's investors.
3iN generated a TSR of 7%, and we received an ordinary dividend of GBP 11 million.
And that GBP 11 million is included in our operating cash profit.
3iN also paid a special dividend in July following the completion of the sale of its investment in Eversholt Rail, and we have treated this GBP 51 million as realization proceeds.
Our investments in the Indian Infrastructure Fund continued to be impacted by the weakness in the road and power sectors and the rupee.
That has led to a value reduction of GBP 9 million, partly offsetting the good contribution from the European businesses.
Debt Management had a busy 6 months, and AUM is now GBP 7.
They closed new CLOs in Europe and the U.
and launched their Global Income Fund.
That vehicle uses the combined expertise of our European and U.
Debt Management is primarily a fund management business, and it generated another GBP 17 million of fees and operating cash income of GBP 33 million for 3i.

We do invest proprietary capital in Debt Management, principally for regulatory reasons to meet the skin in the game rules for CLO fundraising or to support a new product, such as the Global Income Fund.
Our investment in CLO equity generates a good cash income for us.
We received GBP 14 million in the first half.
All else equal, we expect the CLO equity value to fall roughly in line with this GBP 14 million of distributions.
But in our second quarter in particular, there was also some pullback in market sentiment and appetite, especially in the U.
Together, the distributions and market volatility led to a total of GBP 18 million value reduction.
I talked earlier about the importance of a sustainable operating platform and solid balance sheet in the value build for shareholders.
You can see here the contribution all 3 businesses have made to our operating cash profit of GBP 17 million.
Having transformed the cost base of the group since 2012, we remain disciplined on costs.
In fact, costs have fallen to less than 1% of AUM in the first half.
We have been recruiting selectively to support the growth of all 3 businesses, so our benchmark target of 1% is an important discipline to maintain.
The balance sheet is strong.
After paying GBP 133 million out as the final dividend in July, we closed the half with net debt of GBP 12 million.
And we are well funded with GBP 1.
2 billion of liquidity to support investments and shareholder distributions.
That said, we expect to remain net sellers in this financial year, with realizations weighted towards the end of the second half.
So against that background, we have declared an interim dividend of 6p today, which is just over 15% of realization proceeds and which is made up of 2.
7p base dividend and a 3.
3p additional.
We expect to be paying at the 20% end of our dividend range again this year.

And as Simon has talked about, we expect realizations to have a lumpier profile going forward, but we are confident enough in the outlook to confirm that we expect to pay a total dividend of at least 15p for the year.
The results we are announcing today demonstrate good momentum across all 3 business lines.
Our Private Equity portfolio delivered a solid performance, supported by good contributions from both Infrastructure and Debt Management to support our strong investment platform.

As Simon has said, we cannot be immune to wider geopolitical and economic conditions, but the sound fundamentals of the group mean that we are well-positioned commercially and financially to be able to capitalize over time on attractive opportunities as they arise.
So thank you, and we are now happy to move over to questions.
Charles Murphy, Panmure.
On the debt management side of your Proprietary Capital, how much of that is invested in CLO equity? Okay.
But it must be already on a fairly high multiple relative to cost? Bill Barnard.
I note you rather glossed over on Action, the point about management change.

Should I read anything into the fact you've changed both the CEO and the CFO and there is a reference to the next leg of the strategic journey? And also, I also see that Action has probably taken its leverage down a turn.
Might you be tempted to take that back up in the second half? It's Anil Sharma from Morgan Stanley.
Just 2 questions.

The first is I was just interested in your comments you made about some of the business indicators you're seeing have been deteriorating given the macro, particularly in industrials, yet the investment you've made is just in the industrial companies.
So I was just -- if you could just help us think through kind of some of the logic there? And then -- and given 80% of the portfolio is basically U.
or Europe, how should we think about possible Brexit and implications for 3i? It's very sensitive because we assume 0 cash flow from that route once the tunnel is open.
So for every year delay, it's a very considerable sum of money on top of the valuation.
We think there's likely to be another formal pronouncement to the further delay in the coming months.
There are significant budgeting issues.
And the formal process that Germany has to go through to approve planning and give 2 years for appeals and various other things has not been properly factored into the Danish timetable apparently.
Anything else? No, okay.
Thanks, everyone, for coming.
Appreciate it.
We're a cornerstone investor in the new Global Fund, which is another big chunk of it.
I mean, it's worth just dwelling a bit on Debt Management.
We have seen really quite choppy markets there, particularly in the U.
actually, more so than Europe.
But again, I think in line with 3i's current behaviors, we've encouraged the credit team there to really take care of any loans we're worried about and move them out of the portfolio as quickly.

So we've been quite aggressive at addressing those problems so we don't have problems down the road and encouraging those teams to then build back value in loans where they see better promise going forward.
So again, I think we're being a little ahead of the curve in heading off some of the problems that might come through that market in the States.
And we have a relatively light exposure to oil and gas compared to most of the CLO issuers in the States.
It's not a sector that we've ever liked and it's a big sector.
Richard? How sensitive is the valuation of Scandlines to delays on the tunnel? I mean, you referred delays on the tunnel.
Okay, I'm -- let me respond.
On the industrials question, let me start from the point that we don't have any direct exposure to oil and gas, and we don't have any direct commodity exposure.
So the blackest parts of the scene are not things that we are familiar with.

Where we've seen impacts where companies either have customers who deal with those sectors or have contracts servicing those sectors such as JMJ, as I noted, but actually not many of our industrial groups serve the industrial market.
It's quite a limited number.
And if you take Weener, for instance, it serves the consumer market.
So it's not seeing the same sorts of pressures as a Dynatect would be seeing in the States and serves that market.
So when I think you think about industrial sectors, you need to look at the end markets that those companies serve in order to come to a proper view.

I mean, the other thing I would say to balance this is that our consumer portfolio, in particular, is trading really very strongly and the consumer sector looks very different to the narrow industrial sector that we have concerns about.
The other business we bought, Euro-Diesel, it basically makes these diesel engines to deal with supply -- power supply problems for data centers.
The growth in data centers around the world is phenomenal and it hasn't affected that business at all, any of these industrial stuff.
So they're out with the issues I'm talking about on the industrial sector.
I mean, on the Brexit question, frankly, I don't know what it means.
I don't know how serious this will be for a lot of companies.
We don't really have a huge number of U.
companies that export large amounts to the rest of Europe.
So in that sense, I think the issue is quite narrow for us.
I don't think it will affect at all where we invest or how we work our business.
So I'm not convinced if the vote went one way or the other, it would make a huge difference to 3i's portfolio or the returns.
Charles Murphy, Panmure.
On the debt management side of your Proprietary Capital, how much of that is invested in CLO equity? Yes.
I mean, both the companies in Brazil are consumer companies, and they're trading relatively robust there actually.
So they're not in the commodity sector, they're not in the industrial sector.
So we haven't seen any dramatic drop in their performance.
What's the issue in those countries is tending to be the exchange rate and so we've suffered on the depreciation in the exchange rate.
In terms of China, we have really limited exposure.
We have a large reinsurance business based out of Singapore.
We listed a company on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange, a sort of Chinese version of Carphone Warehouse, volatile markets, but no discernible pattern.
And again, that business is a consumer business.
And the reinsurance business is a very unique business, pretty unique amongst the private equity world, I think.
Thank you, Simon.

Let me deal with both of those.

I mean, we had some important discussions about the development of Action and the management succession question in the first half of this year, and that really led to the CEO change that we've announced.
And essentially, we wanted a commitment from management for at least 4 or 5 years because we do see a likely realization event probably calendar '17, something like that.
That could be an IPO or it could be something else, but that is a sort of broad target.
And if we're IPO-ing it, we want to make sure the team are in place for a good period after that.

And Ronald has done a fantastic job at Action, and he is an incredibly energetic and effective CEO, but he was not prepared to commit to that timescale, so we agreed with him that, as we were entering a critical phase for preparing the company for that type of event, it would be better to make a change sooner rather than later.
So Sander van der Laan who's come out of Ahold.
He actually comes from the same part of Holland where Action comes from, so he's part of that Northern Dutch community.
He's incredibly familiar with the business.
He's been pretty envious of the growth that he's witnessed at Action and what it did to the Albert Heijn business, which he ran for a number of years at Ahold.
He's a very effective individual.
He's used to running a big company.
He's ran businesses for Ahold in the States as well.
We interviewed quite a number of candidates for this, and he was by far the best and most suitable candidate.
So we're delighted to get him.
He has spent the last 3 months looking at the different countries, looking at competition and getting briefed on the business.
And he formally takes over the reins at the beginning of January.
Frederik came in as CFO late summer.
He was actually recruited last year, but it took time to disconnect him from Arla where he'd been CFO.
He's another very effective international executive, worked very effectively on the Arla board, superb references, and he's already doing a great job.
So we have a management team in place that can see us through a big event and they're both guys who've got big company experience.
And Action is becoming a very big company.
In terms of leverage, it's become a bit of a tradition that we do a refied action every 12 months or so.
The gearing is already back below 3x EBITDA, so that could well be on the cards, Bill.
It creates cash more than 100% of its earnings, so it's a very cash-generative business.

capability.
