Richard? Okay, good morning, everyone.
Welcome to 3i's Interim Results.
Our goal at 3i remains to deliver attractive proprietary profits from a cost-efficient investment platform.
And we've had a solid first half, with all 3 of our business lines making important progress against their plans.
Despite the volatility in the markets up until the end of September, we've seen a robust performance from our portfolio of proprietary investments.
We've also delivered on our realization plan for the first half, and we made some new investments in Private Equity and Infrastructure.
Importantly, we're continuing to make strong progress on our fundamentals, the health of our Proprietary Capital portfolio and the group's financial model.
The group KPIs continue to reflect the benefits of our restructuring in 2012.
Our improved cash operating profit is underpinned by a resilient NAV performance and a strong balance sheet, and Julia will give you more detail on this shortly.
And as I have just said, our goal remains to deliver attractive proprietary profits from a cost-efficient platform.
That way, our shareholders will benefit from strong capital gains and significant cash distributions.
The main driver of our capital profits is our Private Equity business, where we target international mid-market investments.
Our objective is to make at least 2x our money over a 4-year investment period.
Once again, our Private Equity team has delivered.
They've achieved a solid portfolio performance, a good level of realizations from the challenged end of our portfolio and 2 new and 1 follow-on investment, all made at sensible prices.
We've continued to reshape our Private Equity portfolio by selling assets from our weaker or non-core buckets and devoting more energy and resources to our better investments.
The majority of these realizations were completed early in the first half when conditions were more supportive of selling companies that either had issues or a checkered record.
We have a number of important realization and refinancing initiatives running in the second half, but in the main, these include some of our stronger companies.
A number of the companies we sold, such as Azelis and Labco, have required intense management focus over the last few years.
But the time has been well spent, and we've built back significant value ahead of their sales.
Azelis and Inspecta represent our contrasting approaches to problem assets.
Along with Labco, these were '07, '08 vintage assets.
In the case of Azelis, the Investment Committee were very supportive of the new Chairman and CEO we put in place, and we backed their turnaround plan with funding support.
This was not the case with Inspecta, where we came to the view that further funding would not be in the interest of 3i's shareholders or our LPs.
As a result of our focus on rebuilding and realizing value in the bucket 3 assets, we're beginning to see a marked change in the makeup of our Private Equity portfolio.
We're now down to 53 companies and 5 listed holdings from over 120 in 2012.
90% of the portfolio value now resides in our keepers in bucket 1, our strong performers in bucket 2 or our remaining listed stakes.
And just to remind you of the definitions, while bucket 2 is our target of 2x, in bucket 1, we are expecting to do materially better than 2x.
And the quality of our current portfolio is reflected in the weighted average earnings growth of 19% in the period or 14% if we exclude Action.
We've had a few situations where earnings have suffered in the current environment, such as Dynatect or JMJ.
Both of these businesses have suffered indirect blows from oil -- the oil and gas situation.
But in the main, markdowns have come about as a result of valuation changes in specific sectors.
And earnings uplifts in the portfolio have far outweighed any negative multiple adjustments.
And at 3i today, just because a company suffers a markdown, that doesn't mean it's a bad business.
I'd also like to say just a few words on Action, where I joined the board in March.
Action goes from strength to strength, with over 80 new stores opened so far this year, with the majority of those stores being in France and Germany.
The new stores in all countries are performing very well and like-for-likes across the entire store portfolio remain strong.

There is plenty of activity planned in the last few months of the year with significant further openings in November and December and the opening of Action's third distribution center near Paris early in the new year.
Personally, I've been most struck by the energy of the company and the laser-like focus on very low prices and how the exact same store format works in every country Action enters.
And to cap it all off, Action has just won Retailer of the Year for the second year in a row in Holland amongst its peers.
Scandlines, another of our large keeper assets, is having a good year with strong earnings momentum and excellent cash flow.
It should also benefit from even further delays, which are now expected on the competing fixed link, Rdby-Puttgarden route.
Let me say a little more about JMJ.
We acquired JMJ a couple of years ago, well before the oil price collapse.
JMJ has seen projects canceled or downsized in its core oil and gas sector as a result of that price drop.
But they've responded very effectively by initiating a cost reduction program across the entire firm and by focusing new business activity outside of the oil and gas sector.
It's absolutely clear to us that the trading environment is becoming more difficult in a number of industrial sectors.

And through our monthly dashboard monitoring process, we are very focused on supporting our management teams where they have exposure to slowing sectors or geographies or where they face other factors which are outside their control.
The Private Equity team has also been busy with new investments this year, including the purchase of Weener, a long-established German business we acquired this summer.
We see Weener as a platform asset where we have a very real opportunity to grow both organically and through M&A, playing to our strengths in the international mid-market.
The infrastructure team has been very busy.
They have developed a new strategy in order to broaden their investment mandate beyond the large super core sector.

They've backed their new approach with GBP 187 million of new investments in the first half as well as some capable new recruits to broaden out their origination capability without losing any of their first-class asset management performance.
And last, but not least, the excellent result on Eversholt financed the GBP 51 million special dividend we received from 3i Infrastructure this summer.
During our first half, our debt management team has continued to perform well in more challenging markets.
They've been productive in both the U.
and Europe.
And new CLOs as well as -- with new CLOs as well as launching a Global Income Fund and raising further investments for the U.
Senior Loan Fund and the European Middle Market Fund.
And once again, the division has made a very good contribution, income contribution, with GBP 17 million of fee income in the first half as well as GBP 14 million of CLO distributions.
Now I wanted to show you this slide again, updated for September's end.
It highlights well just what an efficient machine 3i has become and bodes very well for when we come to realize some of our largest investments.

Operating and interest costs are now accounting for less than 15% of our annual cash flows compared to almost 70% over the period covering financial years '10, '11 and '12, leaving the bulk of our cash flows available for new investment and shareholder distributions.
So it's been another decent 6 months for 3i in spite of the challenging macro picture, the volatile markets and the low point of the 30th of September.
The fundamentals, our proprietary investment portfolio and the group's financial model have continued to strengthen, and each of our 3 divisions is performing well relative to their peers.
We have clear strategic priorities, and we're making real progress on all of them.
And importantly, we have a strong balance sheet and a high quality portfolio just as the cycle is turning more difficult.
Over time, the silver lining of this change in investment climate will, of course, be more opportunities on the buy side.

We understand the changes in the cycle and the challenges that will bring, and the ongoing need for us to maintain our price discipline in particular, but we welcome the opportunities it will create now that we've put our own house in order.
I'd like to pass over to Julia for the remainder.
Chris Brown from JPMorgan Cazenove.
Simon, I note you've got about 1% of the portfolio in Brazil, 6% in Asia.
Can you talk about a little bit about how events in those emerging markets have affected companies in those areas? It's Anil Sharma from Morgan Stanley.
Just 2 questions.

The first is I was just interested in your comments you made about some of the business indicators you're seeing have been deteriorating given the macro, particularly in industrials, yet the investment you've made is just in the industrial companies.
So I was just -- if you could just help us think through kind of some of the logic there? And then -- and given 80% of the portfolio is basically U.
or Europe, how should we think about possible Brexit and implications for 3i? Yes.
So the CLO equity at the end of the year was -- at the end of the period was GBP 51 million that we've done.
We have about GBP 130 million in total.
But it must be already on a fairly high multiple relative to cost? Okay, I'm -- let me respond.
On the industrials question, let me start from the point that we don't have any direct exposure to oil and gas, and we don't have any direct commodity exposure.
So the blackest parts of the scene are not things that we are familiar with.

Where we've seen impacts are where companies either have customers who deal with those sectors or have contracts servicing those sectors such as JMJ, as I noted, but actually not many of our industrial groups serve the industrial market.
It's quite a limited number.
And if you take Weener, for instance, it serves the consumer market.
So it's not seeing the same sorts of pressures as a Dynatect would be seeing in the States and serves that market.
So when I think you think about industrial sectors, you need to look at the end markets that those companies serve in order to come to a proper view.

I mean, the other thing I would say to balance this is that our consumer portfolio, in particular, is trading really very strongly and the consumer sector looks very different to the narrow industrial sector that we have concerns about.
The other business we bought, Euro-Diesel, it basically makes these diesel engines to deal with supply -- power supply problems for data centers.
The growth in data centers around the world is phenomenal and it hasn't affected that business at all, any of this industrial stuff.
So they're out with the issues I'm talking about on the industrial sector.
I mean, on the Brexit question, frankly, I don't know what it means.
I don't know how serious this will be for a lot of companies.
We don't really have a huge number of U.
companies that export large amounts to the rest of Europe.
So in that sense, I think the issue is quite narrow for us.
I don't think it will affect at all where we invest or how we work our business.
So I'm not convinced if the vote went one way or the other, it would make a huge difference to 3i's portfolio or the returns.
Anything else? No, okay.
Thanks, everyone, for coming.
Appreciate it.
I don't think so.
I think the multiple, it's heavily skewed by Action.
We have 1 or 2 other businesses like -- long-established business like Element, which were on aggressive multiples given the sectors they come from.
So I don't think we're too far away from the average that you see there without Action really across the buckets.
I mean, the one multiple we did change positively was Basic-Fit.
It's growing really well.
It's investing a lot in gyms.
We saw Planet Fitness float in the U.
on a 15x EBITDA multiple.
We saw The Gym Group float, I think, this week on an even higher multiple in the U.
So we've stuck our neck out and put it at 10.
Let me have a go.
I mean, in terms of the earnings growth, I think this really splits down.
So ultimately, it's the management of these businesses, that really determine the strength of the earnings growth, whether it be an Azelis or whether it be an Action.

But the 3i teams are very knowledgeable and engaged shareholders, so they can be very good at prompting change and also, making judgments that use our other experiences in the past or across the portfolio to help management tackle market challenges.
And in particular, our own style is to help businesses internationalize.
And again, we have a lot of experience in internationalizing these mid-sized companies and bringing contacts and other benefits to those management.

So the fundamental driver, particularly of the better company, is down, I would say, in the main to them being good companies and interesting sectors with strong management teams, and a very engaged shareholder.

We've been more hands-on and more active in the problem companies, where we've seen a very significant turnaround from negative earnings momentum to some cases, really quite positive earnings momentum.
And that's involved a great deal of time from the 3i executives involved in them.

I mean, is it sustainable? I suppose what we have seen a broadly is a pickup in confidence and the overall environment over the last 6 months, in particular, really since the European Central Bank started signaling that QB was going to be the order of the day.
So that was quite noticeable across much of the portfolio.
So I think the better companies will continue to prosper.
Fortunately, for us, the better company is now dominate the value of the portfolio.
So we're anticipating another healthy year coming out of this portfolio.
We don't see any dramatic change or anything like that.
The last point was the investment point? Okay.
Well, maybe Julia can take the second question, I'll deal with the first.
I think we come out of auctions pretty well, if the clearing price in the auction is a sensible price.
So both American assets and Aspen Pumps were auctions, they were quite narrow auctions.
And ultimately, once the price got to a certain point, the influence of management, included rather travel with going forward, becomes very important.

And I think our team do a really good job at getting alongside management, and convincing them that the approach of 3i and the longer-term perspective that we have about investing, is a very good place for them to join, if you like.
So all 3 of those businesses were in auctions.
All 3 of those business, we bought at prices we're very comfortable with.
But in the end, it came down to choices of the management, astutely they chose, and they chose us.
So I think that's the sort of performance we like to see when we're in an auction process.
If it's just about price, and as I said, there is a hurdle or 2 in there, that we're not going to play in that.
I think, Chris, on the other hand, we had very good insights into that business because of Amor.
So although that may have been dressed up as an auction, it was pretty clear to us we had a very powerful position and we were able to lock that investment done, pretty early in the process.
It's Haley Tam from Citigroup.
Two questions, please.
Firstly, you have mentioned the very buoyant realization environment, and we can see that buckets 2, 3 and 4 fallen from over [ph] 60% of our portfolio to just 30% at the end of March '15 [ph].

Would you discourage me from thinking about that going to 0 by the end of the year, and if so, why? Should that continued progress realizations or is there any chance that should shift from our cash flow basis? Okay.
There are some mics at the back.
I'll bring them up to.
Philip? I think we'd like to be up to EUR 750 million-type of new investment.
That's where would like to be out of Proprietary Capital.
And we can see that very easily.
But I'll just repeat, we're not going to go there, if it means opening the filters 1 iota.
So we'll only go there if we are completely comfortable with the price.
Yes? Just a couple, 1 sort of, I guess, following on from Philip's question is, I guess, no process is purely proprietary.
So where you do have to compete in auctions, i.

paying the top price, or are you able to bring some kind of edge into play, you have a network, your experience in internationalizing businesses, et cetera? And just on Action, increasing it by a turn, was that you're decision, or was that taken discussions, I guess, with the auditors, given your previous comments on the valuation of that asset? Okay.
On the realizations, I'd love to think it would -- well, particularly, the bottom 2 buckets get a 0, but I think that's unlikely.
I think we're always going to have it rank back around at the bottom.
But it'll be de minimis, in terms of value, ultimately.
So it won't be, in any way, a real driver or a drag on the growth coming out of our portfolio.
So I would expect to see this trend continue quite strongly over the next couple of years, even if it doesn't guide get to 0.
And in terms of dividend policy, maybe, I'll make a comment, and then Julia can pick this up.
I would say we gave you guidance back in 2012, '13 to reassure shareholders that we were going to be providing meaningful cash dividends going forward, the 15% to 20% of realizations.
And that's what we've used.
It's been a guidance for that.
But if you look at 3i today, I think it is a strong cash machine going forward.
So whether we're a slave to that original dividend guidance, or whether we tipped slightly over it, as we did today, I think these are nicer problems to have that will just as we come to it.
[indiscernible] Yes, I think that's right.

We've -- in terms of modeling, you should keep using the guidance that we've given, but we've shown ourselves to be practical in the cage once we've gone through our criteria article in the we would applied it both last year and this year.
So -- but for now, I would continue to use the 15% -- 15% to 20% when you're modeling, and 20%, which is what we said, when investment levels are below where would like to be.

Bill? And then on the decision to change the multiple on Action, I mean, it will surprise you to know that there's a fair amount of potential journey or the audit process and the valuation of the process of the valuation of Action.
But I'd say, there were sort of a number of drivers.
We've had another year of strong performance of Action under our ownership, so the confidence in these store rollouts, the use of the run rate earnings, was reinforced for us.
And I think actually, we've been able to develop a more relevant concept than we had when we first invested in the asset, when really, we were only able to look at more mature U.
discounters, and then some local retailers with the listings of other European and U.
-based discounters, that has allowed us to actually develop a concept which is more relevant.
And I think having an eye to that, was also important.
I think we still think that there's plenty to do in developing the value of Action.
Philip Middleton, from Merrill Lynch.
Obviously, these are fantastic result, which well done.
Just a couple of questions arising out of those.
Firstly, you talked about the investment pipeline.

Could you tell us a bit more about what you're seeing in terms of valuation there, and in a particular, are there any geographical distinctions or any sectoral distinctions, is there any areas where you feel you've got the particular edge that's enabling you to compete because presumably, will be key in the next year or 2? Secondly, on the balance sheet, I can't entirely understand why you're backing away from the balance sheet structure you had in certain other areas.

0% is a bit off, is slightly conservative, when you look at where -- for example, into immediate capital is doing, when you look at what some of the other comp side vendor are also doing, I just wondered what modeling you've done to determine that 0% is a good number? Okay, I'll take the first.
I'll make 1 comment about the second, but Julia will, no doubt, want to talk about that as well.
I mean, in terms of the investment pipeline, the wheat, as we call it, is pretty busy.
It is reflecting opportunities across our key geographies of North America and Northern Europe.
It's very much in those sectors that we like.
It is big and it's terms of range of size, so I would think it varies between equity checks of GBP 50 million and GBP 175 million, in terms of size of potential investments from our point of view.

And clearly, some of those processes are what I would call more proprietorial than general, and where we find ourselves for 1 reason or another, in the more  proprietorial process, it obviously ultimately, leads to better pricing dynamic, I would say.
In general, if it's a very competitive process, we're careful about how much money we spend on due diligence before we get a better sense of where the pricing is going to be moved to.
So I think this is one of these things where the crystal ball is very hard to say at the moment.

The good things are that the witness wide, there's lots to look at, ll the teams are more focused on origination than asset management because we have the portfolio, generally, n a much better shape, the existing portfolio.
But how many we pulled the trigger on ultimately, because of pricing, it's very hard for me to say today.
But there are some coming to investment committee, which are obviously, we're very interested in.
So I think the outlook for investment gradually improves, but it's always dependent on the market and whether there's some out there pay us a good price for that particular asset or not.

I think on the balance sheet, what I would say, as the banker that helped dropped the 3i prospectus in 1994, we -- at that time, we have a Scottish CEOS at 3i, Ewan Macpherson, who is a very strong CEO of the business, and we debated aggressively about the capital structure.
And we came to the very simple position that there was enough debt in the portfolio, we didn't need more in the center.

Because when the portfolio went the wrong way, we would need resources to support the portfolio because of the gearing in the portfolio, which averaged similar amounts of gearing to what we see today, so that was the wisdom.
And that philosophically, I haven't moved a long way from that.
I think it holds as well today as it did then.

I'm not sure we want to travel with large amounts of cash, but having a degree of liquidity and little of our own debt to worry about, does put us in a very good position, to pull the trigger on helping our own companies in a down cycle or a shock, and actually, going after some very interesting investments should that happen.
And I think should that happen, we're in a much better position to capitalize on that now.
Yes, that's fine.

Well, I talked -- I gave you the names of the ones that are in the imminent sale category, which is Azelis, Inspector, Touch Tunes and Sawyer, and they're effectively all more or less, all baked into the numbers, there's a small difference potentially on those.
And that's roughly about GBP 130 million, and we expect to get in.
FX has not been my friend since the 31st of March, particularly post the election results.
So the last time I looked at, that looked like another GBP 60 million, principally due -- well, both due to euro and dollar.
And as I said, in the back of the pack, you'll see the 1% sensitivities that we've had on FX since the March balance sheet day.
Any other questions? Great, okay.
Thanks for coming today.
Good to see all.
When we gave that guidance, we were coming from a position where the group had been seeing about GBP 100 million of operating cost leakage a year.
So the other big factor that's clearly changed is we're making an operating cash surplus out of the current business.
Chris Brown from JPMorgan Cazenove.

Just wondering if you could give a guidance, on what's happened ever since that 31st [ph] of March, basically, in terms of sort of the amount of realizations that you've agreed that haven't yet completed, what the uplifts might be on there and the FX effect? Thank you, Simon.
So Simon has confirmed we have consistently met or exceeded the objectives we set for ourselves for the 3 years since 2012.
These results give you further evidence of the progress that we've made in building value for our shareholders.
Importantly, the results show how all 3 of our businesses are performing well.
Just to be clear, I will, again, be referring to our investment basis numbers rather than our audited statutory results.
As usual, I've included reconciliation to the 2 sets of numbers in the pack.
The total return and NAV are the same under each basis.
Our results show how we are building value.
You can see the excellent performance from our portfolio of investments and the 19% increase in Private Equity portfolio earnings, which underpinned the GBP 684 million value growth.
We generated a good flow of realizations, delivering proceeds of GBP 841 million, and a money multiple of 2x.
When you exclude refinancings, the uplift over book value was 27%.
We have a significantly more robust and efficient platform, and our cash operating profit increased from GBP 5 million to GBP 28 million.

Our Fund Management business has delivered an underlying operating profit of GBP 33 million, and as Simon said, our balance sheet is sound, and we have funded GBP 474 million of total cash investments.
The strength of realizations and the significant reduction in cash leakage from cost and interests, have allowed us to close the year with no gearing.
The model is working well.
And that's why we have announced a total dividend for the year of 20p per share.
We closed the year with NAV per share of 396p, up 14% on last year, and a total return of 20%.
That's great results.
You can see on this slide the positive contribution that we've had from both value growth realized profits.
The impact of the reduction in our cost base and interest build, means that the dilution of those returns is significantly lower.
The net carry payable is a direct cost of the strong portfolio performance that we've delivered.
Currency was volatile throughout the year.
In the end, the net translation effects of a strong U.
dollar and a weaker euro to 12p of NAV.
I've given you the updated sensitivities and the breakdown of net assets by currency in the back of the pack, so you can continue to track these effects.
Finally, we paid 6p of our proposed 20p total dividend in January, together with last year's final dividend that results in the 19p that you can see here.
As you've seen, all 3 of our businesses contributed to the strong performance in the year.
Our focus on the individual businesses first, before covering the group KPIs in further detail.
Private Equity has had a very good year, generating a gross investment return of GBP 719 [ph] million, and that's after FX, or 24% of opening portfolio value.
We've reduced the portfolio to 65 investments at the year end, right in line with our longer-term aim to reduce to less than 40 assets.

And while the overall number of companies in the portfolio, reducing the overall number of companies in the portfolio, we've generated realized profits of GBP 144 million, and an uplift of 27% over opening value.
So we've reshaped the portfolio towards what we call our keeper assets.

Of the GBP 830 million cash proceeds that we received from Private Equity, GBP 155 million was the result of our decision to take advantage of the favorable debt markets, to refinance some of our strongest and cash generative investments.
Here, I'm talking about Action, Element and Amor.
When there is a refinancing, cash is usually returned to us by repayments of shareholder loans, which means, there's little or no uplift on those proceeds.
In total, we fully sold 19 assets, generating GBP 456 million of proceeds, as well as realizing good returns from investments such as Hilite, a 31% IRR and a 2.
1x money multiple; and Vedici, a 48% uplift and another 2x money multiple.
We also sold a 12 investments, which had an individual book values of less than GBP 5 million each, at the 31st of March 2014.
Bouyant Equity Markets, meant we were able to IPO 4 companies: Phibro in the U.
in April, diphone in China in July; they were followed by Eltel in Stockholm, and Refresco in Amsterdam towards the end of the year.
We completely sold down our investments in Phibro during the year, and we realized GBP 273 million in proceeds from IPOs and quota sales.
And as at the 31st of March 2015, our quota portfolio had a closing value of GBP 273 million.
Realizations and our cash to cash returns are the ultimate measure of our success.
But in the meantime, the value growth in our portfolio gives you evidence of the progress that we are making.
Value-weighted earnings growth was 19% for the 33 companies that we value on an earnings basis.
By comparison, that measure was 9% 3 years ago.
And although the 19% and the 9% is not directly comparable, what they do show, is the improvement in the portfolio mix, the buckets that we talked about.
At the 31st of March 2012, 22% of the portfolio value was in 31 companies with negative earnings growth.
Now 3 years later, only 7% by value of the portfolio, or 7 companies, have negative growth.
So the strong performance of our keepers on our more recent investments, are not being diluted.
Action makes a significant contribution to this measure of earnings growth, because it's our largest investment and it's growing at 30%.
If you take out Action, the growth is 16%, which is still very respectable.

All our most recent investments are included in the calculation, and about 2% of the total growth comes from the 20-or-so acquisitions made by our portfolio companies, and substantially funded from their own resources.
That's the effect of the portfolio dynamism that Simon talked about.
The growth goes flows to the unrealized value growth, in what we call performance of GBP 417 million.
That strong performance also reflects the fact that we have only used lower forecast earnings for 2 portfolio companies, with a total value of GBP 63 million.
That's down from 4 companies valued at GBP 99 million last year.
Now in the past, I've talked about the approach we take to setting multiples, and the effect that approach has on our valuations, especially when Equity Markets are so high.
We monitor comparable quota companies, but we are also guided by our exit expectations and the longer-term cycle or sector trends.

With the FTSE 100 around 7,000 and the average multiple of our relevant global market indices increasing by over 16% in the year, and 12% in the last quarter alone, we adjusted the multiples are used in 70% of cases.
We still recorded a GBP 64 million increase in value from multiple expansion, and that was mostly due to our decision to increase the multiple we used to value Action, from 12.
5x post-discount to 13.
If we exclude Action, the value-weighted average post-discount multiple is 9.
Simon mentioned our investments in Scandlines, as well as good performance, the valuation has also increased because we have extended our assumption about the opening date of the competing tunnel.
Scandlines is the main contributor to the increase in the DCF category.
The imminent sale category includes Azelis, Touch Tunes, Inspector and Zoya.
The sale of Azelis is an excellent outcome.
Its value of the 31st of March was GBP 26 million.
We completed the transaction last week, and expect to receive proceeds of GBP 66 million shortly.
And that GBP 66 million is fully reflected in the value at the 31st of March 2015.
The performance of our quota portfolio reflects the investment's good performance and the positive equity market sentiment.
Finally, on the portfolio, here the top 20 Private Equity investments.
They account for 79% of the portfolio, and are generally trending with a positive outlook.
The strong performance of the portfolio and our realizations mean an increase in the amount that we accrue for carried interest payable to the investment team.
The majority of our Private Equity investments are now held in carry schemes that have met their performance hurdle, assuming we sold everything today at book value.
So we now expect to accrue carry capable of between 10% to 15% of the gross investment return.
And it's only paid out when the hurdle is met with cash returns.
As you can see, we paid GBP 7 million in cash in the period.
The multiples and the growth capital fund have now increased to 1.
The 2010 to 2012 assets in Eurofund V, which include Action, continued to perform well.
But other fund level, we also include the 2007 to 2009 investments.
And we reman below performance hurdle, that means we are not recognizing carry receivable for this fund.
During the year, the growth capital fund has passed this performance hurdle on the valuation basis.
And we've now recognized GBP 25 million of carry receivable from this fund.
So this has been another strong year for Private Equity, the biggest contributor and our solid foundation for our NAV progression.
Our Infrastructure business contributes to our returns through our 34% investment in 3i Infrastructure plc, and through the profitability of its Funds Management and advisory activity.
There has been a step change in infrastructure's contribution through gross investment return.
That's because the share price of 3iN increased by 19% to 160p, which together with dividend income, contributed to a total shareholder return of 25%.
3iN announced its results on Tuesday, and they reported a 24.
6% [ph] return as a result of the sale of Eversholt Rail, and significant valuation uplifts on its core European portfolio.
As well as the advisory fee, we earn an NAV based performance fee.
And as a result of 3iN's strong performance in the year, we expect to receive a fee of GBP 45 million.
75% of that has been set aside for the investment team, in line with the maintenance that we have put in place at the time of 3iN's listing.
We've introduced a significant element of deferral in these performance rewards, and we will award a substantial portion over at least 3 to 5 years.
And that will be in line with the principles of the compensation review that we completed in 2013.
Our Debt Management business is principally a Funds Management platform.
Our teams at both the U.
and Europe, had a very good year of fundraising.
During the year, Debt Management closed 6 new CLOs in Europe and the U.
, and the team launched a new mid-market loan fund in Europe.
Those CLOs and new fund added GBP 2.
4 billion to our AUM, which more than offset the runoff in the older European funds.
So we've finished the year with assets under management of GBP 7.

We invested GBP 105 million of our Proprietary Capital in Debt Management, split between GBP 26 million in warehouses, that will siege future CLO launches, and GBP 79 million in the CLOs that we've actually launched.
After divestments, we had 160 [ph] -- GBP 176 million of value invested in Debt Management products.
Ignoring capital flows, there was a net value reduction of GBP 25 million this year.
Almost 2/3 of that GBP 25 million was the result of distributions paid.
But there were also some short-term mark-to-market volatility in the valuation of recent CLO issues.
Fee income increased to GBP 34 million, and if we include portfolio income, the business generated GBP 56 million of cash.
So all 3 businesses contributed to the strong performance, and that is borne out by our strong set of KPIs.
At the group level, we have achieved an annual cash operating profit of GBP 28 million, and that's a very real increase from our first time profit of GBP 5 million in 2014.
We've also made progress in generating operating income from both our fund and asset management activities while staying highly disciplined on costs.
Operating expenses, excluding restructuring costs, have increased by 2% [ph] mainly due to increased in variable compensation as business performance has improved and AUM increased by 4%.
As we finished the period of restructuring and transition, we have started some recruitment to support investment activity in all 3 business lines.
But we remain totally focused on cost discipline, and we expect costs to stay at around 1% of AUM.
We have a strong balance sheet and our financial performance during the year has strengthened it even further.
We finished the year with net cash of GBP 49 million and gross debt of GBP 815 [ph] million, made up of our bonds due in 2017, 2023 and 2032.
We refinanced the RCF in September, extending its maturities to 2019, with the potential to extend out to 2020 and 2021.
Liquidity is also strong.
GBP 864 million  of the GBP 1.
2 billion is now cash.
In 2012, we talked about a target capital allocation model that would increase the funds available for future investments and enhance distribution to shareholders.
As Simon said, today, we have proposed a 20p dividend for the year, which equates to a final dividend of 14p.

That's ahead of our expected range of 15% to 20% of gross cash realization proceeds, but it reflects the board's confidence in both the performance of the business and the strength of the balance sheet.
At the 14p proposed, 5.
4p is the final base dividend, and 8.
6p is the additional dividend.
So our performance in FY 2015 was strong.
All 3 businesses are performing well, and our results provide further evidence of the progress that we have made since 2012.
Thank you very much, and Sam Min and I will now be happy to take your questions.
I mean, [indiscernible] much, much to said I would echo that.
I mean clearly, we still operate with a quite significant cash flows in and out each individual transaction now, is material.
I may not be the Scottish Finance Director, but I am the finance director that talked to you about the gearing of 103% [ph], within the sort of more recent memory.
So the gearing on gearing within the portfolio, is a real factor that we have to think about.

And I mean, clearly, the cash is very strong, with an eye telling the net cash balance on the balance sheet, that we wanted to be practical about the application of our dividend policy, and confirm the dividend of 20p today.
And we'll consider that sort of practical application.
Good morning, everyone.
Welcome to 3i's results for the year to the 31st of March 2015.
We've had another very active 6 months, and we have closed 3i's financial year '15, delivering some excellent returns across the group.
All 3 of our businesses have performed well, and they will exceeded their objectives for the year.
It's been another good year to be a shareholder in 3i, with a total return on equity of 20%.
It turned out to be a very good year for realizations with total Private Equity proceeds of GBP 831 million at an average of 2x.
And we have made some GBP 369 million of new investments in Private Equity.
Our portfolio Private Equity investments is maturing well, and the quality of the investments is underlined by the 19% [ph] weighted average earnings growth over the year.
Infrastructure provided GBP 47 million [ph] of cash income, and a 20% gross investment return.
Debt Management provided GBP 34 million of fee income, after raising a further GBP 2.
4 billion of new AUM.
As a result, group operating cash has exceeded budget, and has risen to GBP 28 million, from GBP 5 million last year.
We've completed our 3-year restructuring as we planned, and the 3i of today is a very different business to that it was in 2012.
It's now demonstrably, more resilient both commercially and financially.
We've put a real focus on embedding institutional quality investment management processes throughout our 3 businesses, and our ongoing cost discipline has underpinned our transformation.
Over the last 3 years, we've met or exceeded all of our strategic priorities, and we've generated a very attractive return for shareholders.
At TSR of 177% since our strategy announcement on the 28th of June 2012.
That's based on a substantial increase in NAV per share, at the same time that we've also achieved the balance sheet with a net cash position.
This slide shows the progress on our journey from the difficult days of 2012 to our far stronger position today.
There has been a complete transformation in our total return on opening net asset value.
And we've matched that with a very material reduction in the group's cost base.
Our asset management initiatives are much sharper focus in PE, have driven our solid Proprietary Capital performance.
At the same time, our cost discipline and the development of our 2 smaller businesses have removed the leakage the company was seeing from an unnecessary large and complex cost base.

We not only paid dividends of about GBP 500 million over this period, but as I said a minute ago, we've also changed the shape of the balance from GBP 464 million of net debt to GBP 49 million of net cash.

We've done that at the same time as investing in our infrastructure and Debt Management platforms, as well as a funding some very promising new investments in our Private Equity business out of Proprietary Capital.
So how will we take 3i forward from here? Well, the emphasis going forward is based on our assessment of where we can secure the best returns for shareholders.
In particular, we see mid-market Private Equity investment across our northern European and U.
platforms, as giving us the best opportunity for attractive and sustainable alpha returns.
But we have to stay in the mid-market, where we believe the competition is less intense.
And we have to be prepared to be patient, and to pass on opportunities where the valuation challenges our confidence in delivering a 2x return.

So because we have a strong balance sheet and we see a limited opportunity for high return investments in today's competitive markets, we intend to fund the lion's share of new PE investments from proprietary 3i capital.

We don't think it's sensible to turn ourselves into an asset gatherer with lower return expectations, when we are choosing to focus on the mid-market where you can only put so much money to work if we maintain our price discipline.
As a result, we don't plan to raise a new buyout from, from third-party investors, at least, in the short to medium term.
Infrastructure and Debt Management will become the main drivers of third-party Fund Management growth.
And because of the extreme compression of the returns in the fixed income and core infrastructure markets, we will be careful about where we put our Proprietary Capital in those 2 areas.
Once again, these results reflect the simple steps we've taken in the 3i Value Build, with all 3 of our businesses making a strong contribution to this year's results.
So now I'd like to focus on each of the 3i businesses in turn, starting with Private Equity.
It's been another very good year for the team, and well done to them.
Originally, this was meant to be a relatively quiet year for realization proceeds, but we've materially exceeded our expectations.
The majority of our divestment activity is focused on our weaker assets in buckets 3 and 4, where we've recovered significant value by more active asset management over the last few years.
Although we also sold too high-quality bucket 2 assets earlier in the year at 2x cost being highlighted.
We now have about half the investments we started with in 2012, and we aim to take this further down to between 30 and 40 companies over the next few years.
That will allow more time for active asset management as well as thoughtful origination.
We have, once again, been carefully investors, passing on opportunities where pricing is too aggressive, and sticking close to our key sectors and geographies.
And the quality of the portfolio has improved yet again.
We've sold a good number of challenged investments in this benign environment for realizations.
As a result, our stronger investments or keepers now dominate our portfolio, and this bodes very well for future value growth of 3i.
You can clearly see the quality of our current PE portfolio in the 19% weighted average earnings growth over the year.
And the dynamism in this portfolio is demonstrated by the EUR 400 million of bolt-on acquisitions our investee companies made over that year.
As I said earlier, we have taken advantage of current pricing environment and current [ph] IPO markets to move on some of our important buckets 3 assets, including Phibro, ALLTEL and Refresco Gerber.
And that realization momentum has continued into this year.

In 2012, the business was performing very poorly and running out of cash.
And I was very reluctant to put more money into the company without some very fundamental change.
So we agreed to change the Chairman, the CEO and most of the senior management team, and supports a new plan for the business.

Committing to put more funding into a poorly performing company in a difficult sector in a tough environment is always a real challenge, especially if you happen to be the Chairman of the investment committee.
But our faith in the new team and in their plan has definitely paid off with nets and sales and recovery value which we completed last month.
Well done to the 3i team and the Azelis management on this one, it's been a real grind.

We wound up selling the asset for GBP 6 million after our March year end.
But let's turn to the sunny upland in some of our keeper assets.
Action continues to power on, with another fantastic performance of 30% earnings growth in 2014, and like-for-like growth of some 7%.
It opened over 100 new stores, with the majority being in France and Germany, where the concept has been very well received by consumers.
This year, they will embark on an even more ambitious store opening program.
Scandlines has also enjoyed its strong year, with good EBITDA growth and a very successful and value accretive sale of their joint venture.

The prospects for 2015 looks sound, and it's clear from the comments of various parties involved, that delays are more tricky to the completion of the tunnel, which will ultimately compete with Scandlines main route, between rugby and put guard.
And by the way, we are intending to bring the management of Scandlines and Basic-Fit to London on June 15 for an investor and analyst presentation.
We've again been very active in the new investment market, as well as supporting a good number of bolt-on acquisitions for our portfolio of companies.

In fact, we've committed GBP 368 million, but pricing took a number of targets out of our reach, and we're determined to maintain our price discipline in the current environment, even if that means the lower levels of realization of investment for a period of time.
Our infrastructure team delivered a strong year, with the gross investment return of 20%, driven by a total shareholder return of 25% at 3iN.
And the underperformance fee of GBP 45 million, based on  3iN's strong NAV growth and the sale of Eversholt.
The new investment market across the Infrastructure segment has seen some very rich prices paid for super core assets, well beyond our appetite.

The very successful sale of Eversholt was one of a series of recent transactions in the sector where very high prices have been paid.
Fortunately for us, 3iN owns a quality portfolio of core assets which were assembled in a very different environment to the one we see today.
Today's environment could be characterized as a land grab, where a limited supply of available super core assets by investors such as Sovereign Wealth Funds.
You often have a very long time horizon, and who are struggling to find long-term yield in today's traditional investment markets and fixed income.
And in the light of these tightening market conditions, 3iN has decided to update its own return objectives and dividend policy, as you can see here.
And I know our team is very focused on where they can find further core investments, away from those large super core assets.
Our Debt Management team has also, had a very productive year, with strong CLO issuance and good new product developments.
They are now beginning to make an important contribution to the group's economics, and the profitability of the fund management business, in particular.

We have delivered another large shift in capital efficiency and capital allocation, with a material reduction in operating and interest costs, making more cash available for shareholder distributions and investment.
And as a result of our strong realizations and healthy balance sheet, we're announcing today, a final dividend of 14p per share.

I think we come out of auctions pretty well, if the clearing price in the auction is a sensible price.

So both American assets and Aspen Pumps were auctions, they were quite narrow auctions and, ultimately, once the price got to a certain point, the influence of management in who they'd rather travel with going forward becomes very important.

And I think our team do a really good job at getting alongside management and convincing them that the approach of 3i and the longer-term perspective that we have about investing, is a very good place for them to join, if you like.
So all 3 of those businesses were in auctions.
All 3 of those business, we bought at prices we're very comfortable with.
But in the end, it came down to choice of management as to who they chose, and they chose us.
So I think that's the sort of performance we like to see when we're in an auction process.
If it's just about price, and as I said there is a [indiscernible] or 2 in there, then we're not going to play in that.

You can see the excellent performance from our portfolio of investments in the 19% increase in Private Equity portfolio earnings, which underpinned the GBP 684 million value growth.
We generated a good flow of realizations, delivering proceeds of GBP 841 million, and a money multiple of 2x.
When you exclude refinancings, the uplift over book value was 27%.
We have a significantly more robust and efficient platform, and our cash operating profit increased from GBP 5 million to GBP 28 million.
Our Fund Management business has delivered an underlying operating profit of GBP 33 million.
And as Simon said, our balance sheet is sound, and we have funded GBP 474 million of total cash investments.
The strength of realizations and the significant reduction in cash leakage from cost and interests, have allowed us to close the year with no gearing.
The model is working well.
And that's why we have announced a total dividend for the year of 20p per share.
We closed the year with NAV per share of 396p, up 14% on last year, and a total return of 20%.
That's great results.
You can see on this slide the positive contribution that we've had from both value growth realized profits.
The impact of the reduction in our cost base and interest build means that the dilution of those returns is significantly lower.
The net carry payable is a direct cost of the strong portfolio performance that we've delivered.
Currency was volatile throughout the year.
In the end, the net translation effect of a strong U.
dollar and a weaker euro took 12p off NAV.
I've given you the updated sensitivities and the breakdown of net assets by currency in the back of the pack, so you can continue to track these effects.

Together with last year's final dividend, that results in the 19p that you can see here.
As you've seen, all 3 of our businesses contributed to the strong performance in the year.
I'll focus on the individual businesses first before covering the group KPIs in more detail.
Private Equity has had a very good year, generating a gross investment return of GBP 719 million, and that's after FX, or 24% of opening portfolio value.
We've reduced the portfolio to 65 investments at the year end, right in line with our longer-term aim to reduce to less than 40 assets.

And while the overall number of companies in the portfolio -- reducing the overall number of companies in the portfolio, we've generated realized profits of GBP 144 million, and an uplift of 27% over opening value.
So we've reshaped the portfolio towards what we call our keeper assets.

Of the GBP 830 million cash proceeds that we received from Private Equity, GBP 155 million was the result of our decision to take advantage of favorable debt markets to refinance some of our strongest and cash-generative investments.
Here, I'm talking about Action, Element and Amor.
When there is a refinancing, cash is usually returned to us by repayment of shareholder loans, which means there's little or no uplift on those proceeds.
In total, we fully sold 19 assets, generating GBP 456 million of proceeds as well as realizing good returns from investments such as Hilite, a 31% IRR and a 2.
1x money multiple; and Vedici, a 48% uplift and another 2x money multiple.
We also sold a 12 investments, which had an individual book values of less than GBP 5 million each, at the 31st of March 2014.
Bouyant Equity Markets meant we were able to IPO 4 companies: Phibro in the U.
in April, D.
Phone in China in July; they were followed by Eltel in Stockholm; and Refresco in Amsterdam towards the end of the year.
We completely sold down our investments in Phibro during the year, and we realized GBP 273 million in proceeds from IPOs and quota sales.
And as at the 31st of March 2015, our quota portfolio had a closing value of GBP 273 million.
Realizations and our cash to cash returns are the ultimate measure of our success.
But in the meantime, the value growth in our portfolio gives you evidence of the progress that we are making.
Value-weighted earnings growth was 19% for the 33 companies that we value on an earnings basis.
By comparison, that measure was 9% 3 years ago.
And although the 19% and the 9% are not directly comparable, what they do show is the improvement in the portfolio mix, the buckets that we talked about.
At the 31st of March 2012, 22% of the portfolio value was in 31 companies with negative earnings growth.
Now 3 years later, only 7% by value of the portfolio, or 7 companies, have negative growth.
So the strong performance of our keepers and our more recent investments are not being diluted.
Action makes a significant contribution to this measure of earnings growth because it's our largest investment and it's growing at 30%.
If you take out Action, the growth is 16%, which is still very respectable.

All our most recent investments are included in the calculation, and about 2% of the total growth comes from the 20-or-so acquisitions made by our portfolio companies, and substantially funded from their own resources.
That's the effect of the portfolio dynamism that Simon talked about.
The growth goes flows through to the unrealized value growth in what we call performance of GBP 417 million.
That strong performance also reflects the fact that we have only used lower forecast earnings for 2 portfolio companies, with a total value of GBP 63 million.
That's down from 4 companies valued at GBP 99 million last year.
Now in the past, I've talked about the approach we take to setting multiples and the effect that approach has on our valuations, especially when Equity Markets are so high.
We monitor comparable quota companies, but we are also guided by our exit expectations and the longer-term cycle or sector trends.

With the FTSE 100 around 7,000 and the average multiple of our relevant global market indices increasing by over 16% in the year, and 12% in the last quarter alone, we adjusted the multiples we used in 70% of cases.
We still recorded a GBP 64 million increase in value from multiple expansion, and that was mostly due to our decision to increase the multiple we used to value Action, from 12.
5x post-discount to 13.
If we exclude Action, the value-weighted average post-discount multiple is 9.
Simon mentioned our investments in Scandlines.
As well as good performance, the valuation has also increased because we have extended our assumption about the opening date of the competing tunnel.
Scandlines is the main contributor to the increase in the DCF category.
The imminent sale category includes Azelis, Touchtunes, Inspecta and Soya.
The sale of Azelis is an excellent outcome.
Its value at the 31st of March was GBP 26 million.
We completed the transaction last week, and expect to receive proceeds of GBP 66 million shortly.
And that GBP 66 million is fully reflected in the value at the 31st of March 2015.
The performance of our quota portfolio reflects the investment's good performance and positive equity market sentiment.
Finally, on the portfolio, here are the top 20 Private Equity investments.
They account for 79% of the portfolio, and are generally trending with a positive outlook.
The strong performance of the portfolio and our realizations mean an increase in the amount that we accrue for carried interest payable to the investment team.
The majority of our Private Equity investments are now held in carry schemes that have met their performance hurdle, assuming we sold everything today at book value.
So we now expect to accrue carry payable at between 10% to 15% of the gross investment return.
And it's only paid out when the hurdle is met with cash returns.
As you can see, we paid GBP 7 million in cash in the period.
The multiples for Eurofund V and the growth capital fund have now increased to 1.
The 2010 to 2012 assets in Eurofund V, which include Action, continued to perform well.
But at the fund level, we also include the 2007 to 2009 investments.
And we remain below the performance hurdle, and that means we are not recognizing carry receivable for this fund.
During the year, the growth capital fund has passed its performance hurdle on a valuation basis.
And we've now recognized GBP 25 million of carry receivable from this fund.
So this has been another strong year for Private Equity, the biggest contributor and now a solid foundation for our NAV progression.
Our Infrastructure business contributes to our returns through our 34% investment in 3i Infrastructure plc, and through the profitability of its Funds Management and advisory activity.
There has been a step change in Infrastructure's contribution through gross investment return.
That's because the share price of 3iN increased by 19% to 160p, which together with dividend income, contributed to a total shareholder return of 25%.
3iN announced its results on Tuesday, and they reported a 24.
6% return as a result of the sale of Eversholt Rail and significant valuation uplifts on its core European portfolio.
As well as the advisory fee, we earn an NAV-based performance fee.
And as a result of 3iN's strong performance in the year, we expect to receive a fee of GBP 45 million.
75% of that has been set aside for the investment team, in line with the arrangements that were put in place at the time of 3iN's listing.
We've introduced a significant element of deferral in these performance rewards, and we will award a substantial proportion over at least 3 to 5 years.
And that will be in line with the principles of the compensation review that we completed in 2013.
Our Debt Management business is principally a Funds Management platform.
Our teams at both the U.
and Europe, had a very good year of fundraising.
During the year, Debt Management closed 6 new CLOs in Europe and the U.
, and the team launched a new mid-market loan fund in Europe.
Those CLOs and new fund added GBP 2.
4 billion to our AUM, which more than offset the runoff in the older European funds.
So we've finished the year with assets under management of GBP 7.

We invested GBP 105 million of our Proprietary Capital in Debt Management, split between GBP 26 million in warehouses that will seat future CLO launches, and GBP 79 million in the CLOs that we've actually launched.
After divestments, we had 160 [ph] -- GBP 176 million of value invested in Debt Management products.
Ignoring capital flows, there was a net value reduction of GBP 25 million this year.
Almost 2/3 of that GBP 25 million was the result of distributions paid.
But there were also some short-term mark-to-market volatility in the valuation of recent CLO issues.
Fee income increased to GBP 34 million, and if we include portfolio income, the business generated GBP 56 million of cash.
So all 3 businesses contributed to the strong performance, and that is borne out by our strong set of KPIs.
At the group level, we have achieved an annual cash operating profit of GBP 28 million, and that's a very real increase from our first time profit of GBP 5 million in 2014.
We've also made progress in generating operating income from both our fund and asset management activities, while staying highly disciplined on costs.
Operating expenses, excluding restructuring costs, have increased by 2%, mainly due to increased variable compensation, as business performance has improved and AUM increased by 4%.
As we finished the period of restructuring and transition, we have started some recruitment to support investment activity in all 3 business lines.
But we remain totally focused on cost discipline, and we expect costs to stay at around 1% of AUM.
We have a strong balance sheet and our financial performance during the year has strengthened this even further.
We finished the year with net cash of GBP 49 million and gross debt of GBP 815 million, made up of our bonds due in 2017, 2023 and 2032.
We refinanced the RCF in September, extending its maturity to 2019, with the potential to extend out to 2020 and 2021.
Liquidity is also strong.
GBP 864 million of the GBP 1.
2 billion is now cash.
In 2012, we talked about a target capital allocation model that would increase the funds available for future investments and enhance distribution to shareholders.
As Simon said, today, we have proposed a 20p dividend for the year, which equates to a final dividend of 14p.

That's ahead of our expected range of 15% to 20% of gross cash realization proceeds, but it reflects the board's confidence in both the performance of the business and the strength of the balance sheet.
Of the 14p proposed, 5.
4p is the final base dividend and 8.
6p is the additional dividend.
So our performance in FY 2015 was strong.
All 3 businesses are performing well, and our results provide further evidence of the progress that we have made since 2012.
Thank you very much, and Simon and I will now be happy to take questions.
Just a couple.
One, sort of, I guess following on from Philip's question is, I guess, no process is purely proprietary.

So where you do have to compete in auctions, are you paying the top price? Or are you able to bring some kind of edge into play? You have a network, your experience in internationalizing businesses, et cetera.

And just on Action, increasing it by a turn, was that you're decision or was that taken in discussion, I guess, with the auditors, given your previous comments on the valuation of that asset? It's worth reflecting on Action, what it is and how it's different because you've seen a couple of stocks come to the market here, B&M and Poundland.

Action, unlike those 2, is a multi-country retailer, and it's got what I call, the Holy Grail of retail in that the box that opens in Holland is the same as the box that opens in Belgium, in Germany and in France, and wherever it decides to go to next.
So that is a great advantage the company has.
It's not dependent on food.
It's got 10 categories, they're all about the same.
So it's a general discounter.

And it has a lot of momentum in the business in Europe, because finding good retail sites or sites that Action trade out off fairly easily, is much easier than it would be if it was trying to find the same sort of sites in the U.
So there are a lot of fundamental drivers about Action that give us a great deal of confidence.

You want to do? And then on the decision to change the multiple on Action, I mean, it won't surprise you to know that there's a fair amount of attention during the audit process and the valuation process on the valuation of Action.
But I'd say, there were sort of a number of drivers.
We've had another year of strong performance of Action under our ownership, so the confidence in the store rollouts, the use of the run rate earnings was reinforced for us.
And I think actually, we've been able to develop a more relevant concept than we had when we first invested in the asset when, really, we were only able to look at more mature U.
discounters, and then some local retailers with the listings of other European and U.
-based discounters, that has allowed us to actually develop a concept which is more relevant.
And I think having an eye to that was also important.
I think we still think that there's plenty to do in developing the value of Action.
Yes, I think that's right.
We've -- in terms of modeling, you should keep using the guidance that we've given.
But we've shown ourselves to be practical in the upper cage [ph].
Once we've gone through our criteria, we've been practical in the way that we've applied it, both last year and this year.
So -- but for now, I would continue to use 15% -- 15% to 20% when you're modeling, and at 20%, which is what we said, when investment levels are below where would like to be.
When we gave that guidance, we were coming from a position where the group had been seeing about GBP 100 million of operating cost leakage a year.
So the other big factor that's clearly changed is we're making an operating cash surplus out of the current business.
I think we'd like to be up to EUR 750 million-type of new investment.
That's where we'd like to be out of Proprietary Capital.
And we can feed that very easily.
But I'll just repeat, we're not going to go there, if it means opening the filters 1 iota.
So we'll only go there if we're completely comfortable with the pricing.
Yes? Philip Middleton, Merrill Lynch.
Obviously, these are fantastic results which are well done.
Just a couple of questions arising out of those.
Firstly, you talked about the investment pipeline.

Could you tell us a bit more about what you're seeing in terms of valuation there and, in particular, are there any geographical distinctions or are there any sectoral distinctions or any areas where you feel you've got the particular edge that's enabling you to compete? Because that, presumably, will be key in the next 1 or 2 years.
Secondly, on the balance sheet, I can entirely understand why you're backing away from the balance sheet structure you had in certain other areas.

0% is a bit off, is slightly conservative, though, when you look at where -- what, for example, Intermediate Capital is doing, when you look at what some of the other companies like Wendel's doing, I just wondered what modeling you've done to determine that 0% is a good number? It's Anil Sharma from Morgan Stanley.
Just 2 questions, please.
So the first one is just thinking about the earnings growth in the underlying portfolio.

It's been strong for quite a while now, and I don't mean this to come across the wrong way, but how much of that is 3i management and how much of that is just because the companies are in structural growth industries? And I guess, following on from that, how sustainable is that earnings growth momentum, do you think? And then my second question is just on the investment side.
You mentioned you don't really want to, as a business, keep just sort of gathering cash.
So how should we think about like a run rate investment number now, or how do you -- I should say, how do you think about 3i's investments in terms of the run rate? Bill? Okay, I'll take the first.
I'll make 1 comment about the second, but Julia will, no doubt, want to talk about that as well.
I mean, in terms of the investment pipeline, the WIP, as we call it, is pretty busy.
It is reflecting opportunities across our key geographies of North America and northern Europe.
It's very much in those sectors that we like.

It is big and it's -- in terms of range of size, so I would think it varies between equity checks of GBP 50 million and GBP 175 million, in terms of size of potential investments, from our point of view.

And clearly, some of those processes are what I would call more proprietorial than general, and where we find ourselves, for one reason or another, in the more proprietorial process, it obviously ultimately leads to a better pricing dynamic, I would say.
In general, it's a very competitive process.
We're careful about how much money we spend on due diligence before we get a better sense of where the pricing is going to be move to.
So I think this is one of these things where the crystal ball is very hard to say at the moment.
The good things are that the WIP is wide, there's lots to look at.
All the teams are more focused on origination than asset management because we have the portfolio, generally, in much better shape, the existing portfolio.
But how many we pull the trigger on ultimately, because of pricing, is very hard for me to say today.
But there are some coming to investment committee, which we're -- obviously, we're very interested in.

So I think the outlook for investment gradually improves, but it's always dependent on the market and whether there's some [indiscernible] out there who's going to pay us a good price for that particular asset or not.

I think on the balance sheet, what I would say, as the bank that [ph] helped draw up the 3i prospectus in 1994, we -- at that time, we had a Scottish CEO at 3i, called Ewen MacPherson, who is a very strong CEO of the business, and we debated aggressively about the capital structure.
And we came to the very simple position that there was enough debt in the portfolio, we didn't need more in the center.

Because when the portfolio went the wrong way, we would need resources to support the portfolio because of the gearing in the portfolio, which averaged similar amounts of gearing to what we see today.
So that was the wisdom.
And philosophically, I haven't moved a long way from that.
I think it holds as well today as it did then.

I'm not sure we want to travel with large amounts of cash, but having a degree of liquidity and little of our own debt to worry about does put us in a very good position to pull the trigger on helping our own companies in a downcycle or a shock, and actually going after some very interesting investments, should that happen.
And I think, should that happen, we're in a much better position to capitalize on that now.
It's Haley Tam from Citigroup.
Two questions, please.
Firstly, you have mentioned the very buoyant realization environment, and we can see that buckets 2, 3 and 4 have fallen from over [ph] 60% of your portfolio to just 30% at the end of March '15.

Would you discourage me from thinking about that going to 0 by the end of the year, and if so, why? And I guess the follow-up question would be, in relation to that, your dividend policy in the medium-term, how should I think about that? Should that continue -- related to gross realizations or is there any chance that should shift to more of a cash flow basis? Yes, that's fine.

Well, I talked -- I gave you the names of the ones that are on the imminent sale category, which is Azelis, Inspecta, Touchtunes and Soya, and they're effectively all, more or less, all baked into the numbers.
There's a small difference, potentially, on those.
And that's roughly about GBP 130 million that we would expect to get in.
FX has not been my friend since the 31st of March, particularly,, post the election results.
So the last time I looked, that looked like another GBP 60 million, principally, due -- well, both due to euro and dollar.
And as I said, in the back of the pack, you'll see the 1% sensitivities that we've had on FX since the March balance sheet day.
Any other questions? Great, okay.
Thanks for coming today.
Good to see you all.
Well, maybe Julia can take the second question, I'll deal with the first.
I think we come out of auctions pretty well, if the clearing price in the auction is a sensible price.

So both American assets and Aspen Pumps were auctions, they were quite narrow auctions and, ultimately, once the price got to a certain point, the influence of management in who they'd rather travel with going forward becomes very important.

And I think our team do a really good job at getting alongside management and convincing them that the approach of 3i and the longer-term perspective that we have about investing, is a very good place for them to join, if you like.
So all 3 of those businesses were in auctions.
All 3 of those business, we bought at prices we're very comfortable with.
But in the end, it came down to choice of management as to who they chose, and they chose us.
So I think that's the sort of performance we like to see when we're in an auction process.
If it's just about price, and as I said there is a Herbert or 2 in there, then we're not going to play in that.
I think, Christ, on the other hand, we had very good insight into that business because of Amor.
So although that may have been dressed up as an auction, it was pretty clear to us we had a very powerful position and we were able to lock that investment down pretty early on in the process.
