Our goal remains to deliver attractive proprietary investment profits and growing cash distributions from a cost efficient platform.

Once again, our Private Equity business has delivered a very strong performance.
The Private Equity team gave us an excellent portfolio performance, with a GIR of GBP 1 billion.
And we completed a good number of realizations as well as making some interesting new investments at sensible prices.
Our portfolio now has 44 companies and 3 listed holdings.
It's been good to see strong performance across the portfolio.
And apart from Action, the strongest performance came from the assets we purchased since our strategic review in 2012.
In all cases, we bought these assets with tight price disciplines, and they've already valued a 1.
This compares very well with other funds of that same vintage.
You're probably tired of hearing me say it, but Action continues to power on at the same sort of growth rates they've produced for the last 5 years.
The store opening program has stepped up another gear.
And in the last few months, the Action team has celebrated opening its 700th store, it's 750th, and will shortly celebrate its 800th opening.
The new stores in all countries are performing consistently well, and they produce returns on capital of over 100% in their first year.
Today, if you were to capitalize each new stores' profits at any sensible multiple, you can value each store at over EUR 5 million.
And it looks like we'll open close to 200 this year.
That's an outstanding value creation by any measure.
And cash flow and like-for-likes remain as strong as you've seen in previous year.
The oil and gas sector remains weak all over the world, and that affects the performance of our oil and gas related assets, namely JMJ and Dynatect.
And it's also been a tricky year in retail.
Footfall is down and it's a difficult luxury market.

We've signaled for some time the impact of a declining luxury spend, but that macro factor has been compounded by an inconsistent store expansion program and some accounting issues we only discovered in August but appear to go back a number of years.
Agent Provocateur is the largest write-down in the first half, even though it's less than 1% of our portfolio.
Moving on, we've had another busy half of realizations.
We delivered some GBP 650 million of proceeds at an average multiple of 2.
And about 1/3 of that money has come from the more recent investment vintages.
Recently, there's been volatility in both sentiment and markets, and that's not making realization activity easy or predictable.
But with our very strong start, we feel confident in generating a good level of proceeds for the full year.
We've seen a good pickup in our investment pipeline, but we've continued to be careful in our assessment of these targets.
In August, we made another new investment in Germany in a company called Schlemmer.
We have good experience and expertise in the automotive sector and Schlemmer is a strong international company with well-developed OEM relationships.
It's prime to grow on the back of the accelerating need for more wires and electronics in cars.
We also purchased BoConcept in a public to private transaction in Denmark.
The bulk of the shares were bought from the founding family.
BoConcept is a classic Scandinavian style for urban living.
The company has a very strong brand for its size and has significant further international potential that's underpinned by strong demographic trends.
I suspect a few of you here may enjoy stretching out on your BoConcept sofa at weekends.
And for those of you who have yet to experience those, I'm glad to say there's a BoConcept store in Tottenham Court Road.
And as some of you have seen, we just announced the acquisition of Ponroy Sant on Friday last week.
Again, this was a purchase from the founding family in a primary buyout.
This is a very well-regarded company based in France.
Ponroy has strong brands, and it sits right in the megatrend of natural healthcare and well-being.
We have ambitious plans to accelerate the growth of this plans -- these brands internationally.
It's worth mentioning that the list of potential new investments is strong for both Private Equity and Infrastructure.
As a result, we remain very selective.
That means we're putting a very sharp focus on any potential investment thesis and on the price returns balance.
Our 4 principle bucket have continued to develop well, with buckets 1 and 2 remaining dominant.

Infrastructure is a core division of the group.

We have ambitious plans to accelerate the growth of this plans -- these brands internationally.
It's worth mentioning that the list of potential new investments is strong for both Private Equity and Infrastructure.
As a result, we remain very selective.
That means we're putting a very sharp focus on any potential investment thesis and on the price-returns balance.
Our 4 principal bucket have continued to develop well, with buckets 1 and 2 remaining dominant.
The majority of companies in the top 2 buckets are now made up of 2012-plus investments, and that's even after transferring Basic-Fit to bucket 5.
Infrastructure is a core division of the group.
Let me say that again.
Infrastructure is a core division of the group and has had a very good start to the year.
And we have real momentum in that division.
They've been very active investing, and the team has put together an interesting set of midsized infrastructure investments.
They produced excellent returns for 3i group through both portfolio performance and operating cash income.
Unlike other 3iN shareholders, we've done very well from the equity placing in June at 165p.
One of the reasons behind our recent sale of Debt Management was because of the sound financial position of the group.

A lean cost base, strong cash flow and top-tier performance from our 2 main investment divisions give us confidence in delivering strong financial returns as well as good levels of shareholder distributions.
And as Julia will explain shortly, given the exceptional performance of the group, we now expect to recommend a total dividend for the year of not less than 22p.
So another decent half for 3i against some pretty tricky markets and macroeconomic environment.
The overall strength of our portfolio proprietary investments continues to improve, and the group is now in really good shape financially.
We have good focus and has a high energy level across all of our teams.
We're now better placed to cope with tougher macro conditions and the old bump in the road.
And the current momentum in the group should offer the prospect of excellent shareholder returns going forward.
So thank you, and I'll now pass over to Julia.
Daniel Garrod, Barclays.
Couple questions for me.
First for Julia, question on the earnings momentum.
Appreciate you said you didn't want to provide an average snap, but it only looks like from the buckets detail that you've given a fair chunk has moved into that greater-than-30% earnings growth.
I think you spoke in May when you last presented of an expectation that the average of that 8% that you detailed, ex Action, at that point would have been a trough.
Do you think you have seen improvement on average? That bucket disclosure would seem to suggest that, but if you can sort of confirm that first.
Second question to Simon.
You've spoken in the past about sort of your excitement around specifically the Euro-Diesel and Aspen Pumps assets.
There are obviously sort of currently less evaluation in your rankings, low valued, but they look very fast growing.

You don't detail them in the examples on your sort of 4-, 5-bucket categories, but am I right in presuming they would be bucket 1 category, that these are long-term holds for you? Any comment on that? I think there are a number of levers to pull, and we're obviously more confident about being able to meet that challenge without the Debt Management business.
And that was part of the consideration of the timing of that sale.
It's not going to come from a new Private Equity fund, but we do on fees when we invest co-investor's money.
And in a number of investments we look at, we will look to bring in co-investors with us, as we have done this year.
And also in Infrastructure, we have a growing number of initiatives, and 3iN itself is growing very strongly.

So we do see a good ramp-up in income across the group, across both sides of that, and a significant reduction in costs as a result of selling Debt Management and a result of taking out one of the long-term debt issues.

Any more? Can't tempt you?
Okay, thanks for coming.
Really appreciate the time.
All right, bye-bye.
So let me pick up earnings growth first.
[indiscernible] at least a couple of words.
If we look at the targeted cash core income, obviously selling the debt business makes that harder.
On the other hand, the refi or just getting rid of the Eurobond makes that easier.

How important is it to you to be breakeven? If you don't -- if it's really important to you, what levers have you got to pull for that? Or are you just saying to yourselves we're much more robust now with the loading of cash now? If it's there or thereabouts, that's fine.
No is the response there.
Philip, just behind you.
Oh, Iain Scouller.
No is the response to that.
Yes, please.
Iain Scouller from Stifel.
Given the continuing strong performance from the investment portfolio, do you have any plans to launch or issue a new LP Private Equity Fund? Hold on.
We've got Daniel here.
Thank you, Simon.
We've had a busy first half of the year and produced an excellent set of results.
As you know, we've also sold -- announced the sale of our Debt Management business.
In a minute, I'll talk about that transaction and its implications for our numbers.
We closed the period with NAV of 551p per share, 19% up from the start of the year.
And that's after counting for FY '16's final dividend of 16p.
The biggest contribution to that growth was the strong performance from our Private Equity portfolio.
Infrastructure progressed well, and it was actually the best 6 months ever for our Debt Management business.
Sterling's weakness since the outcome of the Brexit referendum has been a positive for us because 70% of our assets are euro and dollar denominated.
While it's good to see FX go the right way for us after several years of losses, the gain is only on translation.
To mitigate actual FX exposure, we're holding euros for euro investment and dollars for dollar investment.
That way, we can match our large cash flows as much as possible.
If you net out carry, costs and last year's final dividend, we get to the 551p per share.
So let's look at our Private Equity business, where we have GBP 4.
4 billion of our proprietary capital invested.
We generated an excellent gross investment return of GBP 989 million, giving a return of 26%.
Simon just talked about the realizations in the period, which generated cash proceeds of GBP 654 million.
That was over 2x the money invested.
The uplift over opening value was 9%, which reflects the timing of the sales of Mayborn and Amor, and GBP 143 million of the proceeds were from the sales of quoted investments such as Quintiles.
A big driver of Private Equity's gross investment return was the strength of our portfolio performance and earnings growth.
This slide shows you the earnings growth of the 20 large investments, which account for 89% of the total Private Equity portfolio value.
You'll see that we've dropped the value-weighted average earnings measure.
We now have only 44 unquoted investments and 3 quoted stakes.
So talking about averages is less meaningful than talking about individual investments.
But the shape of the chart here does show you how well our investments are doing.
It's a very good picture with 15 out of the 20 companies showing positive earnings growth and 60% of the total Private Equity portfolio value growing better than 10%.
In particular, 3/4 of the investments we made in the last 4 years are in the right-hand 3 bars.
Of course, Action is GBP 1.
5 billion of the greater-than-30% bar.
But even without it, the profile is sound.
Investments with negative earnings are the businesses we have been talking about for a while, which continue to be impacted by macro challenges.
But I'm pleased to say that a number of companies have moved to the greater-than-30% bucket in the last 6 months.
This strong portfolio performance comes through the value growth of GBP 643 million, which you can see here in detail.
We have materially increased the value of our investments in Action from GBP 902 million at the 31st of March 2016, to GBP 1.
5 billion at the 30th of September.
As a lot of you saw at the Capital Markets Day in June, Action continues to perform ahead of expectations.
That strong execution is being noticed, and we've had a number of third-party approaches.
Needless to say, we decline to discuss any of these propositions.
About half of Action's GBP 547 million value gain is because we increased its multiple from 14x at March to 18.
2x in June.
And given its earnings performance and cash generation, it's already down to 16.
8x post discount at September.
If you take Action out of the equation, the average multiple came down from 10.
7x, and this is principally due to Basic-Fit now being quoted.
More generally, we continue to adjust multiples down, where we think that the comparable multiples are ahead of longer-term and sector averages.
Our aim is to mitigate some of the market volatility that we might otherwise see.
Scandlines is the most significant Private Equity investment that we value on a DCF basis.
Its good performance and cash generation is reflected in lower debt and, therefore, in it's weighted average cost of capital, which is used in the discount rate.
And that's the main cause of its value increase in this period.
Basic-Fit came to market in June this year, and its shares have performed very well since IPO.
It accounts for a majority of our quoted uplift of GBP 56 million.
The Agent Provocateur write-down of GBP 39 million is reflected in the other category, and that's because we've taken it off an earnings basis for now.
You'll notice that we do not have any investments in the imminent sale category.
Although we've announced the signing of an implementation agreement for the sale of ACR, there are a number of regulatory steps to complete.
So we've taken a cautious view of valuation at this time.
The strong performance of the Private Equity portfolio is reflected in the amount of carry payable and carry receivable that we recognize.
A way of reminder, 3i receives carry on the third-party money that we manage, subject to performance conditions.
We're already recognizing carry on the growth capital fund.
At the year-end, we said that Eurofund V had also gone through its hurdle on an accounting basis.
So we're now accruing carry receivable on investments in that fund.
The growth in Action and realizations, such as Amor and Geka, are factors in the GBP 203 million we recognized in the first half.
We pay carry to our investment teams, past and present, again subject to performance conditions.
And we've been through the performance hurdles on most of our schemes on an accounting basis for quite some time.
That's all about accounting recognition.
We passed an important milestone in the first half.
The Amor disposal means that the 2010 to '12 carry payable scheme is now through its hurdle on a cash basis.
That means we're now actually paying out carry on this plan, not just accruing for it.
That is the main reason why the net cash paid in the period has increased to GBP 54 million.
Private Equity's principal contribution to NAV and Group performance is the capital returns from its investments.
As you can see here, we've also maintained a good level of portfolio dividend and interest income.
As I've said before, this income is asset specific and can vary depending on investment and realization flows.
But we will continue to focus on cash portfolio income, where it makes sense to do so.
Our Infrastructure team have had a particularly busy 6 months.
They raised equity for 3i Infrastructure plc and had a lot of investing activity, including new investments such as TCR and WIG.
3iN shares performed very strongly, increasing by more than 15% compared to its equity issue price.
The increase in 3iN share price accounts for GBP 80 million of the GBP 90 million in our gross investment return.
The Infrastructure business also makes an important contribution to cash income through fees and dividends.
And we expect the returns from Infrastructure to be a more meaningful component of our operating cash profit in the future.
That's particularly after the sale of Debt Management completes.
Before talking about that transaction, I'd like to show you the contribution that the Debt Management business has made in this 6-month period.
The team have also been busy with the launch of 2 new CLOs in Europe and 1 in the U.
In fact, they added GBP 1 billion to their AUM.
It's a particularly strong 6 months for the valuation of our CLO equity investments.

One reason for that is the generally improved investor sentiment, meaning we recognize value growth of GBP 13 million, and that's despite also receiving GBP 24 million of distributions in the same period, which is included in the total cash income of GBP 50 million.
After allowing for the businesses' direct costs of GBP 12 million, the net contribution to our total return was GBP 84 million.
We announced the sale of the Debt Management business on the 25th of October, and that transaction will result in a significant simplification of the Group.
Transaction is subject to a number of closing conditions, including a regulatory approval in the U.
and Bahrain, but we expect it to complete by the 31st of March 2017.
As a result, we're showing the business line as a discontinued operation.
You'll see some of this disclosure in today's full announcement.
We said in our announcement that Debt Management has played an important role in the operational efficiency of the Group since the strategic review in 2012.
Here's a reminder of how far we've come since then.
Maintaining an operating cash profit without the Debt Management business will be more of a challenge.

We have had the benefit of their contribution in the first half of this financial year, and we will be helped by the good progress of the initiatives and investment in the Infrastructure business as well as continuing focus on generating income in the Private Equity business.
And of course, we're still acutely focused on maintaining a lean cost base across the Group to mitigate against the leakages of the past.
Operating expenses will step down as a result of the Debt Management disposal.
The annual direct costs of that business are about GBP 20 million.
Improved cost efficiency has been a key part of the reallocation of capital across the Group.
And you can also see that reallocation in the strength of our balance sheet.
We've talked about the increase in portfolio value, which was GBP 5.
1 million -- billion, excluding the Debt Management business.
Total cash at the 30th of September was GBP 1,031,000,000.
If you combine that with the GBP 329 million of undrawn RCF, it means we have liquidity of almost GBP 1.
When we repay our eurobond in March, the gross debt of GBP 844 million will step down by about GBP 270 million.
Like our approach to matching investment flows, we are holding euro cash to fund that repayment.
Net cash at the 30th of September was GBP 187 million.
In line with our policy, which we updated in May, we have declared an 8p interim dividend.
And of course, that's half of the 16p base dividend.
Our policy change gives us more flexibility when we're setting the additional dividend that we'll pay at the final.
With such strong first half performance and a good half for realizations, we have confirmed today that we expect to pay a total dividend for the year of not less than last year's 22p.
So this has been a very good first half performance, and it's been underpinned by excellent performance overall from the Private Equity portfolio and good execution from the Infrastructure business.
As Simon said in his statement today, the macroeconomic and geopolitical landscape continues to be challenging.
Our investments, obviously, can't be immune to the markets that they operate in, but we are navigating these challenges from our position of real strength.
Thank you, and we'll now take questions.
If I could safely [ph]  tempt you into at least a couple of words.
If we look at the targeted cash core income, obviously selling the debt business makes that harder.
On the other hand, the refi or just getting rid of the eurobond makes that easier.

How important is it to you to be breakeven? If you don't -- if it's really important to you, what levers have you got to pull for that? Or are you just saying to yourselves, "We're much more robust, we can load in that cash now?" If it's there or thereabouts, that's fine.
Good morning, and welcome to 3i's Interim Results.
We live in interesting times.
But I'm pleased to say that 3i continues to deliver solid results.
All 3 of our business lines have performed well in the first half, and we generated a robust performance in our portfolio of investments.
Realization flows have remained strong, and we've made interesting new investments in both Private Equity and Infrastructure.
The Group's financial model continues to work well, and we're enjoying good momentum.
You can see what I mean by momentum in these KPIs, which are actually for a 6-month period, not a full year.
Our investment portfolio is driving very strong NAV performance and delivering an excellent return on equity.
The strong operating cash performance we've generated is underpinned by a robust balance sheet.
Julia will give you more details on that in a minute.
Our goal remains to deliver attractive proprietary investment profits and growing cash distributions from a cost-efficient platform.
On the 25th of October, we announced the sale of our Debt Management division to Invescorp.
The division has performed well since we bought it in 2011, and AUM has doubled to about $12 billion under 3i's ownership.
But Debt Management is a very different business to our 2 other investment divisions, and its annual cash flows are less important to the 3i of today than they were.
Once again, our Private Equity business has delivered a very strong performance.
The Private Equity team gave us an excellent portfolio performance with a GIR of GBP 1 billion.
And we completed a good number of realizations as well as making some interesting new investments at sensible prices.
Our portfolio now has 44 companies and 3 listed holdings.
It's been good to see strong performance across the portfolio.
And apart from Action, the strongest performance came from the assets we purchased since our strategic review in 2012.
In all cases, we bought these assets with tight price disciplines, and they've already valued at 1.
This compares very well with other funds of that same vintage.
You're probably tired of hearing me say it, but Action continues to power on at the same sort of growth rates they produced for the last 5 years.
The store opening program has stepped up another gear.
And in the last few months, the Action team has celebrated opening its 700th store, it's 750th, and will shortly celebrate its 800th opening.
The new stores in all countries are performing consistently well, and they produce returns on capital of over 100% in their first year.
Today, if you were to capitalize each new store's profits at any sensible multiple, you can value each store at over EUR 5 million.
And it looks like we'll open close to 200 this year.
That's outstanding value creation by any measure.
And cash flow and like-for-likes remain as strong as you've seen in previous years.
The oil and gas sector remains weak all over the world, and that affects the performance of our oil and gas-related assets, namely JMJ and Dynatect.
And it's also been a tricky year in retail.
Footfall is down, and it's a difficult luxury market.
We've taken a write-down on our investment in Agent Provocateur, which is a Eurofund V legacy asset from 2007.

We've signaled for some time the impact of a declining luxury spend, but that macro factor has been compounded by an inconsistent store expansion program and some accounting issues we only discovered in August but appear to go back a number of years.
Agent Provocateur is our largest write-down in the first half even though it's less than 1% of our portfolio.
Moving on, we've had another busy half of realizations.
We delivered some GBP 650 million of proceeds, an average multiple of 2.
And about 1/3 of that money has come from the more recent investment vintages.
Recently, there's been volatility in both sentiment and markets.
And that's not making realization activity easy or predictable.
But with our very strong start, we feel confident in generating a good level of proceeds for the full year.
We've seen a good pickup in our investment pipeline, but we've continued to be careful in our assessment of these targets.
In August, we made another new investment in Germany in a company called Schlemmer.
We have good experience and expertise in the automotive sector, and Schlemmer is a strong international company with well-developed OEM relationships.
It's primed to grow on the back of the accelerating need for more wires and electronics in cars.
We also purchased BoConcept in a public-to-private transaction in Denmark.
The bulk of the shares were bought from the founding family.
BoConcept is a classic Scandinavian style for urban living.
The company has a very strong brand for its size and has significant further international potential that's underpinned by strong demographic trends.
I suspect a few of you here may enjoy stretching out on your BoConcept sofa at weekends.
And for those of you who've yet to experience this, I'm glad to say there's a BoConcept store in Tottenham Court Road.
And as some of you have seen, we've just announced the acquisition of Ponroy Sant on Friday last week.
Again, this was a purchase from the founding family in a primary buyout.
This is a very well-regarded company based in Nantes in France.
Ponroy has strong brands, and it sits right on the megatrend of natural health care and well-being.
We have ambitious plans to accelerate the growth of this plans -- these brands internationally.
It's worth mentioning that the list of potential new investments is strong for both Private Equity and Infrastructure.
As a result, we remain very selective.
That means we are putting a very sharp focus on any potential investment thesis and on the price-returns balance.
Our 4 principal buckets have continued to develop well, with buckets 1 and 2 remaining dominant.
The majority of companies in the top 2 buckets are now made up of 2012-plus investments, and that's even after transferring Basic-Fit to bucket 5.
Infrastructure is a core division of the Group.
Let me say that again.
Infrastructure is a core division of the Group and has had a very good start to the year.
And we have real momentum in that division.
They've been very active investing, and the team has put together an interesting set of mid-sized infrastructure investments.
They produced excellent returns for 3i Group through both portfolio performance and operating cash income.
Unlike other 3iN shareholders, we've done very well from the equity placing in June at 165p.
One of the reasons behind our recent sale of Debt Management was because of the sound financial position of the Group.

A lean cost base, strong cash flow and top-tier performance from our 2 main investment divisions give us confidence in delivering strong financial returns as well as good levels of shareholder distributions.
And as Julia will explain shortly, given the exceptional performance of the Group, we now expect to recommend a total dividend for the year of not less than 22p.
So another decent half for 3i against some pretty tricky markets and macroeconomic environment.
The overall strength of our portfolio proprietary investments continues to improve, and the Group is now in really good shape financially.
We have good focus and has a high energy level across all of our teams.
We're now better placed to cope with tougher macro conditions and the old bump in the road.
And the current momentum in the Group should offer the prospect of excellent shareholder returns going forward.
So thank you, and I'll now pass over to Julia.
I think there are a number of levers to pull, and we're obviously more confident about being able to meet that challenge without the Debt Management business.
And that was part of the consideration of the timing of that sale.
It's not going to come from a new Private Equity fund, but we do on fees when we invest co-investor's money.
And in a number of investments we look at, we will look to bring in co-investors with us, as we have done this year.
And also in Infrastructure, we have a growing number of initiatives, and 3iN itself is growing very strongly.

So we do see a good ramp-up in income across the Group, across both sides of that, and a significant reduction in costs as a result of selling Debt Management and a result of taking out one of the long-term debt issues.

Any more? Can't tempt you?
Okay, thanks for coming.
Really appreciate the time.
All right, bye-bye.

So we're now accruing carry receivable on investments in that fund.
The growth in Action and realizations, such as Amor and Geka, are factors in the GBP 203 million we recognized in the first half.
We pay carry to our investment teams, past and present, again subject to performance conditions.
And we've been through the performance hurdles on most of our schemes on an accounting basis for quite some time.
That's all about accounting recognition.
We passed an important milestone in the first half.
The Amor disposal means that the 2010 to '12 carry payable scheme is now through its hurdle on a cash basis.
That means we're now actually paying out carry on this plan, not just accruing for it.
That is the main reason why the net cash paid in the period has increased to GBP 54 million.
Private Equity's principal contribution to NAV and group performance is the capital returns from its investments.
As you can see here, we've also maintained a good level of portfolio dividend and interest income.
As I've said before, this income is asset specific and can vary depending on investment and realization flows.
But we will continue to focus on cash portfolio income, where it makes sense to do so.
Our Infrastructure team have had a particularly busy 6 months.
They raised equity for 3i Infrastructure plc and had a lot of investing activity, including new investments such as TCR and WIG.
3iN shares performed very strongly, increasing by more than 15% compared to its equity issue price.
The increase in 3iN share price accounts for GBP 80 million of the GBP 90 million in our gross investment return.
The Infrastructure business also makes an important contribution to cash income through fees and dividends.
And we expect the returns from Infrastructure to be a more meaningful component of our operating cash profit in the future.
That's particularly after the sale of Debt Management completes.
Before talking about that transaction, I'd like to show you the contribution that the Debt Management business has made in this 6-month period.
The team have also been busy with the launch of 2 new CLOs in Europe and 1 in the U.
In fact, they added GBP 1 billion to their AUM.
It's a particularly strong 6 months for the valuation of our CLO equity investments.

One reason for that is the generally improved investor sentiment, meaning we recognize value growth of GBP 13 million, and that's despite also receiving GBP 24 million of distributions in the same period, which is included in the total cash income of GBP 50 million.
After allowing for the businesses' direct costs of GBP 12 million, the net contribution to our total return was GBP 84 million.
We announced the sale of the Debt Management business on the 25th of October, and that transaction will result in a significant simplification of the group.
Transaction is subject to a number of closing conditions, including a regulatory approval in the U.
and Bahrain, but we expect it to complete by the 31st of March 2017.
As a result, we're showing the business line as a discontinued operation.
You'll see some of this disclosure in today's full announcement.
We said in our announcement that Debt Management has played an important role in the operational efficiency of the group since the strategic review in 2012.
Here's a reminder of how far we've come since then.
Maintaining an operating cash profit without the Debt Management business will be more of a challenge.

We have had the benefit of their contribution in the first half of this financial year, and we will be helped by the good progress of the initiatives and investment in the Infrastructure business as well as continuing focus on generating income in the Private Equity business.
And of course, we're still acutely focused on maintaining a lean cost base across the group to mitigate against the leakages of the past.
Operating expenses will step down as a result of the Debt Management disposal.
The annual direct costs of that business are about GBP 20 million.
Improved cost efficiency has been a key part of the reallocation of capital across the group.
And you can also see that reallocation in the strength of our balance sheet.
We've talked about the increase in portfolio value, which was GBP 5.
1 million -- billion, excluding the Debt Management business.
Total cash at the 30th of September was GBP 1,031,000,000.
If you combine that with the GBP 329 million of undrawn RCF, it means we have liquidity of almost GBP 1.
When we repay our eurobond in March, the gross debt of GBP 844 million will step down by about GBP 270 million.
Like our approach to matching investment flows, we are holding euro cash to fund that repayment.
Net cash at the 30th of September was GBP 187 million.
In line with our policy, which we updated in May, we have declared an 8p interim dividend.
And of course, that's half of the 16p base dividend.
Our policy change gives us more flexibility when we're setting the additional dividend that we'll pay at the final.
With such strong first half performance and a good half for realizations, we have confirmed today that we expect to pay a total dividend for the year of not less than last year's 22p.
So this has been a very good first half performance, and it's been underpinned by excellent performance overall from the Private Equity portfolio and good execution from the Infrastructure business.
As Simon said in his statement today, the macroeconomic and geopolitical landscape continues to be challenging.
Our investments, obviously, can't be immune to the markets that they operate in, but we are navigating these challenges from our position of real strength.
Thank you, and we'll now take questions.
If I could safely [ph] tempt you into at least a couple of words.
If we look at the targeted cash core income, obviously selling the debt business makes that harder.
On the other hand, the refi or just getting rid of the eurobond makes that easier.

How important is it to you to be breakeven? If you don't -- if it's really important to you, what levers have you got to pull for that? Or are you just saying to yourselves, "We're much more robust, we can load in that cash now?" If it's there or thereabouts, that's fine.
Yes, please.
Philip, just behind you.
Iain Scouller.
We've got Daniel here.
Iain Scouller from Stifel.
Given the continuing strong performance from the investment portfolio, do you have any plans to launch or issue a new LP Private Equity Fund? Good morning, and welcome to 3i's interim results.
We live in interesting times.
But I'm pleased to say that 3i continues to deliver solid results.
All 3 of our business lines have performed well in the first half, and we generated a robust performance in our portfolio of investments.
Realization flows have remained strong, and we've made interesting new investments in both Private Equity and Infrastructure.
The group's financial model continues to work well, and we're enjoying good momentum.
You can see what I mean by momentum in these KPIs, which are actually for a 6-month period, not a full year.
Our investment portfolio is driving very strong NAV performance and delivering an excellent return on equity.
The strong operating cash performance we've generated is underpinned by a robust balance sheet.
Julia will give you more details on that in a minute.
Our goal remains to deliver attractive proprietary investment profits and growing cash distributions from a cost-efficient platform.
On the 25th of October, we announced the sale of our Debt Management division to Invescorp.
The division has performed well since we bought it in 2011, and AUM has doubled to about $12 billion under 3i's ownership.
But Debt Management is a very different business to our 2 other investment divisions, and its annual cash flows are less important to the 3i of today than they were.
Once again, our Private Equity business has delivered a very strong performance.
The Private Equity team gave us an excellent portfolio performance with a GIR of GBP 1 billion.
And we completed a good number of realizations as well as making some interesting new investments at sensible prices.
Our portfolio now has 44 companies and 3 listed holdings.
It's been good to see strong performance across the portfolio.
And apart from Action, the strongest performance came from the assets we purchased since our strategic review in 2012.
In all cases, we bought these assets with tight price disciplines, and they've already valued at 1.
This compares very well with other funds of that same vintage.
You're probably tired of hearing me say it, but Action continues to power on at the same sort of growth rates they produced for the last 5 years.
The store opening program has stepped up another gear.
And in the last few months, the Action team has celebrated opening its 700th store, it's 750th, and will shortly celebrate its 800th opening.
The new stores in all countries are performing consistently well, and they produce returns on capital of over 100% in their first year.
Today, if you were to capitalize each new store's profits at any sensible multiple, you can value each store at over EUR 5 million.
And it looks like we'll open close to 200 this year.
That's outstanding value creation by any measure.
And cash flow and like-for-likes remain as strong as you've seen in previous years.
The oil and gas sector remains weak all over the world, and that affects the performance of our oil and gas-related assets, namely JMJ and Dynatect.
And it's also been a tricky year in retail.
Footfall is down, and it's a difficult luxury market.
We've taken a write-down on our investment in Agent Provocateur, which is a Eurofund V legacy asset from 2007.

We've signaled for some time the impact of a declining luxury spend, but that macro factor has been compounded by an inconsistent store expansion program and some accounting issues we only discovered in August but appear to go back a number of years.
Agent Provocateur is our largest write-down in the first half even though it's less than 1% of our portfolio.
Moving on, we've had another busy half of realizations.
We delivered some GBP 650 million of proceeds, an average multiple of 2.
And about 1/3 of that money has come from the more recent investment vintages.
Recently, there's been volatility in both sentiment and markets.
And that's not making realization activity easy or predictable.
But with our very strong start, we feel confident in generating a good level of proceeds for the full year.
We've seen a good pickup in our investment pipeline, but we've continued to be careful in our assessment of these targets.
In August, we made another new investment in Germany in a company called Schlemmer.
We have good experience and expertise in the automotive sector, and Schlemmer is a strong international company with well-developed OEM relationships.
It's primed to grow on the back of the accelerating need for more wires and electronics in cars.
We also purchased BoConcept in a public-to-private transaction in Denmark.
The bulk of the shares were bought from the founding family.
BoConcept is a classic Scandinavian style for urban living.
The company has a very strong brand for its size and has significant further international potential that's underpinned by strong demographic trends.
I suspect a few of you here may enjoy stretching out on your BoConcept sofa at weekends.
And for those of you who've yet to experience this, I'm glad to say there's a BoConcept store in Tottenham Court Road.
And as some of you have seen, we've just announced the acquisition of Ponroy Sant on Friday last week.
Again, this was a purchase from the founding family in a primary buyout.
This is a very well-regarded company based in Nantes in France.
Ponroy has strong brands, and it sits right on the megatrend of natural health care and well-being.
We have ambitious plans to accelerate the growth of this plans -- these brands internationally.
It's worth mentioning that the list of potential new investments is strong for both Private Equity and Infrastructure.
As a result, we remain very selective.
That means we are putting a very sharp focus on any potential investment thesis and on the price-returns balance.
Our 4 principal buckets have continued to develop well, with buckets 1 and 2 remaining dominant.
The majority of companies in the top 2 buckets are now made up of 2012-plus investments, and that's even after transferring Basic-Fit to bucket 5.
Infrastructure is a core division of the group.
Let me say that again.
Infrastructure is a core division of the group and has had a very good start to the year.
And we have real momentum in that division.
They've been very active investing, and the team has put together an interesting set of mid-sized infrastructure investments.
They produced excellent returns for 3i Group through both portfolio performance and operating cash income.
Unlike other 3iN shareholders, we've done very well from the equity placing in June at 165p.
One of the reasons behind our recent sale of Debt Management was because of the sound financial position of the group.

A lean cost base, strong cash flow and top-tier performance from our 2 main investment divisions give us confidence in delivering strong financial returns as well as good levels of shareholder distributions.
And as Julia will explain shortly, given the exceptional performance of the group, we now expect to recommend a total dividend for the year of not less than 22p.
So another decent half for 3i against some pretty tricky markets and macroeconomic environment.
The overall strength of our portfolio proprietary investments continues to improve, and the group is now in really good shape financially.
We have good focus and has a high energy level across all of our teams.
We're now better placed to cope with tougher macro conditions and the old bump in the road.
And the current momentum in the group should offer the prospect of excellent shareholder returns going forward.
So thank you, and I'll now pass over to Julia.
Daniel? Thank you, Simon.
As you just heard, this has been an excellent year for 3i.
Our financial performance provides evidence of the resilience of our operating and business model even against a background of volatility and uncertainty in those markets that Simon has talked about.
And we continue to execute our well-defined strategy.
We closed the year with very strong performance in the final quarter.
We delivered NAV per share of 463p and a 21.
7% return on our opening net assets.
The main drivers of NAV growth contributing 77p was solid portfolio performance and successful realizations.
That performance is also reflected in the increase in net carry payables with an 11p impact.
We benefited from Sterling's weakness, which gave us a net 16p translation gain in the year.
And finally, we paid total dividends of 20p in the year.
Now I know some of you like the bridge for the quarter 2, so that's in the back of the pack.
The Private Equity business had a very good year.
They generated growth investment return of over GBP 1 billion or 32% of opening portfolio value.
And that's an excellent performance, especially in these market conditions.
P/E realizations of GBP 743 million include 11 smaller and older assets and GBP 179 million from the sale of Element.
It was one of our largest assets, and the sale was at a money multiple of 3.
The uplift of 14% is lower than last year, and that just reflects the fact that GBP 111 million of the proceeds were from sales of our quoted investments.
And the weight of the transactions was early in the year, so most of the exit value had been reflected in the opening NAV.
So we are continuing to make good progress in reshaping the portfolio.
And we put a slide in the back of the pack to give you full details of all the realizations.
Now, although the total number of investments reduced, the Private Equity portfolio value increased to GBP 3.
7 billion, supported by a number of material value increases in our largest assets.
On a really positive note, the GBP 690 million of unrealized value growth is underpinned by the performance of the portfolio, that is earnings growth and changes in net debt.
The performance of assets valued on an earnings basis accounted for GBP 460 million of the uplift, and they had value weighted average earnings growth of 17%.
If you exclude Action with this earnings growth of over 30%, the average is of 7%.
I'll come back to how that's changed in the year in a minute, but first, I'd like to spend a couple of minutes on some of the other drivers of value growth.
GBP 95 million came from a net increase in the multiples we used to value the portfolio.
The 2 biggest contributions came from Action and Basic-Fit.
We've increased Action's multiple by 0.
5 turn to 14x.
That increase in the multiple reflects continuing strength in its performance and its outlook for growth.
We also increased the multiple used to value Basic-Fit.
You would have seen Tuesday's announcement of its intention to float, which means I can't give you the actual multiple today.
But if you exclude Basic-Fit and Action from the average, then the increase in average multiples is just less than 1% prediscount.
There have been reports of further delays in the opening of the fixed link that will compete with Scandlines.
We have not reflected possible delays to the full extent that we could have.
But we delayed our opening assumption by 3 years.
So the DCF value has increased, and the biggest -- is the biggest factor in the GBP 124 million that you can see here.
We announced the sales of Amor and Mayborn in April.
Both transactions should be complete by the end of June.
They have 2 investments valued on an eminent sales basis.
Coming back then to earnings growth in the portfolio.
Overall, the portfolio continues to perform well, and our monthly portfolio monitoring helps us tackle any issues potentially arising, as they are bound to do in these tricky conditions.
Value-weighted earnings growth over the last 12 months was 17%, including the significant contribution from Action, which is obviously the majority of the far right bar here.
Excluding Action's contribution, growth is still a healthy 7%, but it's come down during the course of the year and was 12% in Q3.
There are a few factors that explain the reduction.
The sale of Element plays a part.
The measure also reflects the performance of the likes of AES, Dynatect, Etanco and JMJ that Simon has talked about.

We expect the macro environment to remain challenging and volatile, but barring unexpected events, it looks as though 7% should be the low point for a portfolio well positioned in chosen sectors and markets with good momentum.
As you can see here, we're expecting a positive trend in the majority of our top 20 investments.
[indiscernible] performance flows through the recognition of our carry.
We reached an important milestone at the 31st of March 2016.
The improvements in the year from 5 [ph] performance means we have recognized carry receivable on that fund for the first time for accounting purposes.
Eurofund V was valued at 0.
At the 31st of March 2016, its multiple at now 1.
Consistent with how we recognize carry payable, the receivable is calculated as if we sold all the assets at the 31st of March 2016 valuations.
This is the biggest component of the GBP 58 million receivable you see here.
On the payables side, most of the schemes are now through their respective performance hurdles from an accounting perspective.
We generally accrue at between 10% and 15% of gross investment return on those schemes, and we recognized a charge of GBP 171 million.
Private Equity returns are usually in capital form.
The business made a good contribution to income, all the more so as the contribution from fee income will continue to pull as we sell investments held in third-party funds.
In total, we generated GBP 50 million of income, including GBP 30 million of dividends and interest from the portfolio.
We also expect infrastructure to provide a significant contribution to our operating cash income, and it's continued to do so in this year.
Our 34% investment in 3iN delivered a GBP 33 million increase in value as our share price was resilient in the face of volatile equity markets.
We received an ordinary dividends of GBP 21 million, in addition to the GBP 51 million special dividend, which is included on our realization proceeds.
We also recognized a performance fee of GBP 20 million based on 3iN's NAV, which reflects another year of strong performance.
As Simon said, Debt Management had a good year of fundraising.
We launched 2 CLOs in Europe and 2 in the U.
as well as the new global income fund.
And that's a positive step in debt management diversification.
As a result, we had GBP 11.
6 billion of assets under management at the end of the year, supporting fee income of GBP 38 million.
For regulatory reasons, we are required to invest in each new European CLO.
And that is now also the practice in the U.
in anticipation of equivalent U.
rules, which will be effective at the end of 2016.
We may also invest more than risk required to secure a flat fund launch in more volatile markets.
Altogether, our CLO equity investment increased to  GBP 151 million.
We took a reduction in value against those CLO investments of GBP 43 million, which mostly relates to GBP 31 million of cash distributions included in portfolio income.
But a proportion did reflect negative invest sentiment more generally.
That originated in the U.
, where exposure to the oil and gas sector is more significant, although there was some contagion effect in Europe, too.
Our teams managed the underlying credit portfolios very actively, which, in some cases, might include taking early losses in volatile markets, if appropriate.
However, actual defaults are low, and our longer-term view of investment return remains positive.
Debt Management, together with Private Equity and infrastructure, contributed to further progress on our cash operating profit metric.
We generated a profit of GBP 37 million in the year.
I've talked about the components of the GBP 117 million of cash income as we've gone through the business lines.

Operating costs were GBP 134 million, which includes GBP 5 million of restructuring costs relating to planned reductions in our Nordic team, while we look to increase the size of our investment teams in our key geographies in Europe and the U.
We have also recruited to support origination and business development and to address the increasing burden of regulation.
But we continue to tightly manage costs, which we kept at 1% of AUM.
The financial strength of our operating platform is a key difference between the 3i of today and the 3i of 2008 and 2009.
And that financial strength is a significant factor in our ability to stay resilient and keep performing in challenging markets.
The strength of our balance sheet is another crucial difference and advantage.
We closed the year with net cash of GBP 165 million and total liquidity of  GBP 1.
35 billion.
We will pay our 2017 bond after cash resources.
We will also be supporting 3iN's fund raising, and we plan to invest EUR 500 million to EUR 750 million in new private equity deals.
Despite this planned investment, we expect to be net divestors over the next 5 years.
That's partly from continuing to reshape the portfolio, but more fundamentally, it's the result as we invest in opportunities that are capable of delivering 2x our money.
So with that in mind, we recommended a 10% increase in the total dividend to the year of 22p and a final dividend of 16p.
That 22p is 27% of cash realizations, somewhat ahead of a 15% to 20% guidance that we set up in 2012.
At that time, we believed it was important to give our shareholders a direct share in the success of the business.
So we set a formula to give investors confidence that we would make that a meaningful share.
We've actually paid above the upper end of the range every year the policy has been in operation.
With the strength of our balance sheet outlook, we have now updated our policy.
We are doubling our base dividend to 16p, and we expect to pay half at the interim dividend and the remaining half in the final.
We will then pay an additional final dividend that is not limited by the 15% to 20% formula.
That final dividend will depend on the level and outlook of investments, realizations and our balance sheet.
That additional dividend will still be subject to gross debt being less than GBP 1 billion and group gaining [ph] less than 20%.
But we don't believe that, that is likely to be a constraint.
So 2016 has been an excellent year for 3i.
These financial results provide further evidence of our resilience and the value of our clear, consistent strategy and disciplined approach to investments.
Thank you, and we're now happy to take questions.
Giving a bit more commentary about the 7% [ph] earnings growth, barring unexpected events, as you'd expect me to say, that should be a low point.
A lot of this is about the mix that's in that measure.
So obviously, the sale of Element, which is one of our largest assets, with 20% growth, has come out of it.
In terms of our new investments, we've got some positive investment cases there, but it's relatively early days for them to really be featuring in the calculation.

And I think if you look at those companies that Simon's talked about, the AESs, Dynatects, Etancos of this world, where they have been subject to the headwinds, we're starting to see some more positive outlook for those businesses.
And they are part of that change in the metric from 5 companies on the forecast earnings to 2 at this period.
So yes, barring anything unexpected happening, we should see that sort of stabilizing and coming out from that measure.
But we've recognized we are operating in fairly tricky times.
And the slide 29, which I think is the bar chart that shows you the breakup of the earnings growth, what you've really got in that shift, I think, is GBP 373 million in the minus 1% to minus 10% bar.
And what you've got in the components of that are the companies that we just talked about.
So they would sort of in the bar to the right previously, and they shifted over to that.
That's a historic chart.
So it's consistent with what we've just been talking, talked about.
Good morning, everyone.
Welcome to 3i's final results for the year through the 31st of March 2016.
Since we last spoke, we've had another very productive 6 months.
And we closed this year with strong returns across the group, giving us excellent momentum as we moved into the new financial year.
We've made very good progress against our key KPIs.
We closed the year with a 22% total return on equity, net cash of  GBP 165 million and an increased dividend of 22p for the year.
NAV has increased by 17% to 463p.
And group operating cash profit has increased again to GBP 37 million.
All of our divisions have performed well, and the group's portfolio of investments is coping well with the various macroeconomic challenges.
And the longer-term reshaping of 3i continues.
We're building on the foundations of our 3-year restructuring.
It's been a volatile year for the markets, but we have made further good progress.
And we enter FY '17 with a more focused portfolio of high-quality investments, good cost and investment discipline and a solid balance sheet.
And going forward, we remain focused on executing our well-established strategy and maintaining a disciplined approach to new investment.
Our international platform and sector experience, combined with our proprietary capital approach, gives us important competitive advantages in the mid-market where we compete.
There's no question that both the macro and geopolitical environment has become a lot more challenging.
And it's clear that headwinds have reduced growth in many sectors and geographies over the last 12 months.
But we remain confident of achieving returns in excess of 2x by sticking to the mid-market and by maintaining the rigor of our investment assessments and active management approach.
But in the investment world, it's not just macro headwinds that are the problem today.
You've also got to contend with the sheer amount of money looking for a home.
Even though M&A activity and growth in the last year or 2 has been up and down, fundraising has stayed at historically high levels.
And today, we now have record amounts of dry powder across the Private Equity sector.
The vast majority of the dry powder is in the mega funds, many of which we avoid while focused on the mid-market.
So we've got to maintain our discipline on new investments and be energetic and creative in looking for opportunities in those sectors and geographies we know well.
In line with that approach, we have decided to optimize our team resources by reducing our investment team for Scandinavia, and at the same time, we're increasing our resources in the U.
and Germany.
Our Private Equity team has had another busy year.
They delivered a 32% return on the year, another good level of realizations as well as making 3 interesting new investments, having looked at many more.
We started FY '16 selling or listing many of our older or smaller investments, and that led to a further rationalization in the size of our portfolio.
But the divestment environment became a lot more challenging in the second half, where our activity was fortunately more focused on some of our bigger and stronger assets.
The Element sale process coped well with the deteriorating circumstances, as did the Action refinancing.
But our Mayborn exit was not helped by weaker debt markets and a flatter profit profile for that business.
But in the end, we were pleased with the terms for Mayborn when we finally announced the sale of 3.
5x money multiple in April this year.
Earnings growth has remained strong across our Private Equity portfolio.
Our larger bucket 1 investments have made a big contribution to the growth.

And well we have avoided direct exposure to oil or commodities or to many emerging markets, we have nonetheless suffered from oil-related issues with JMJ, Dynatect and AES, and Julia will give you more detail on that shortly.
In the case of JMJ, our safety consultancy business, 65% of revenues are from the oil and gas sector.
And so that trading has been hit hard by the reductions in capital expenditure plans.
As a result, we're working closely with management to take costs out of the business and to diversify into new sectors such as aerospace.
The Russian economy and the reduced spending power of Russian consumers has had a negative impact on trading of Action Provocateurs.
And Etanco, our roofing system business, continues to suffer from low levels of construction activity in France.
At the other end of the spectrum, we have the mighty Action.
Action delivered another year of 30%-plus sales growth, a company by strong like-for-likes and excellent EBITDA and cash flow growth.
The significant store opening program continued, with 144 new openings last year.
Action has even more openings planned for this year, with expansion into 2 deep markets of France and Germany going particularly well.
But the crucial thing for Action last year was the selection of a new CFO and a new CEO.
Management is always a critical element in our Private Equity investments.
And Frederik Lotz and Xander Ventolan [ph], I am confident, we've got 2 very capable executives, who will take action onto even better performance.
And I hope many of you will come to our Investor Day on the 8th of June.
You can meet Frederick and Xander and form your own view.
FY '16 was another year to be highly disciplined when reviewing your investments.
And having had a very full whip [ph] to consider, we narrowed our investments down to just 3 quality acquisitions in Euro-Diesel, Weener Plastic and Audley Travel.
In each case, we have to persevere with the process where the early running was inevitably made by others who were unable to maintain their early leadership based on aggressive valuations.
We're satisfied that in all 3 cases, we have bought promising businesses at fair prices, with realistic plans to achieve our 2x hurdle.
And in the case of Audley Travel, we were able to use our strong balance sheet to underwrite the debt and truncate the sale process to our advantage.
Our Private Equity portfolio continues to evolve and is now even more dominated by those investments where we feel confident of making our 2x return or better.
It is also more manageable since we reduced our overall number of investments down to 47 companies by the end of March.
And we are planning to streamline it further during the current year.
We're confident in the portfolio we have put together over the last few years, and we believe our thorough research and price discipline will be well-rewarded.
Quality Private Equity portfolios have a certain shape to them, 1 or 2 stars and lots of solid returns around 2x or better, with no or very few material losses.
Our current portfolio, with no -- is beginning to look more like that.
CVC have their racing cars, and Electra have their caravans.
But we have our action stores as well as a good group of other companies capable of returning better than 2x.
You'll see the results on Element, Mayborn and Amor recently.
And we have plenty of other strong performers, including Basic-Fit, Scandlines and ATESTEO, which I haven't talked about today.
And importantly, in recent years, we've managed to avoid the material investment misjudgments, which have plagued 3i in the past.

Now I don't need to sound complacent 
[Audio Gap] 
and about some of the misguided regulation we face.
But I do feel that through our stronger processes and experience, we're a little more in control of the things that matter to our performance.
Now I'd like to turn to Infrastructure where we've engineered a mini revolution in the pace of activity at 3iN.
We've changed the management of our infrastructure team, and we agreed on a change in financial return and investment mandate for 3iN.
At the same time, we overhauled and added to the origination capability in our infrastructure team.
We're now seeing the fruits of those changes.
We're benefiting from a stronger origination performance, combined with steady asset management, which has been the hallmark of 3iN's past.
As a result, 3iN has had a more all-round year of performance.
And we they putting together a very interesting collection of midsized core infrastructure assets, which are aligned to the group's midsized focus and operational experience.
The infrastructure sector is arguably suffering from even more acute dry powder issues in private equity.
That's why the importance of our changing focus cannot be understated.
The new approach should underpin the growth in returns of 3iN going forward, and as a result, the 3i Group intends to support the placing announced by 3iN on the 12th of May last week.
Debt Management faced some very challenging market conditions in FY '16, but they performed well both financially and in protecting the creditworthiness of their portfolios.
The team raised GBP 1.
3 billion of new CLO AUM before those markets closed in January.
And they made a strong cash contribution to the group's operating cash income.
Importantly, the underlying credit performance of our CLO investments in the U.
and Europe remains sound, and confidence in the CLA market is recovering.
Our effectiveness at generating stronger returns and passing cash back to shareholders has taken another good step forward this year.
And that underpins our confidence in increasing this year's dividend and in enhancing the dividend policy going forward.
Our future performance will be determined by the consistency of our investment and asset management processes and by the quality of the investment portfolios we have put together.
And while we can't be immune to the macro and political volatility that we see everywhere we look, we remain confident of our ability to produce at least 2x returns from a good level of realizations.
If we continue to hit that target, we should deliver mid- to high teens net returns to our shareholders.
And in years like this one, with some excellent realizations, shareholders can expect to see 20% plus returns.

in particular.
