Good morning, everyone.
Welcome to 3i's final results for the year through the 31st of March 2016.
Since we last spoke, we've had another very productive 6 months, and we closed this year with strong returns across the group, giving us excellent momentum as we move into the new financial year.
We've made very good progress against our key KPIs.
We closed the year with a 22% total return on equity, net cash of  GBP 165 million and an increased dividend of 22p for the year.
NAV has increased by 17% to 463p.
And group operating cash profit has increased again to GBP 37 million.
All of our divisions have performed well, and the group's portfolio of investments is coping well with the various macroeconomic challenges.
And the longer-term reshaping of 3i continues.
We're building on the foundations of our 3-year restructuring.
It's been a volatile year for the markets, but we have made further good progress.
And we enter FY '17 with a more focused portfolio of high-quality investments, good cost and investment discipline and a solid balance sheet.
And going forward, we remain focused on executing our well-established strategy and maintaining a disciplined approach to new investment.
Our international platform and sector experience, combined with our proprietary capital approach, gives us important competitive advantages in the mid-market where we compete.

There's no question that both the macro and geopolitical environment has become a lot more challenging, and it's clear that headwinds have reduced growth in many sectors and geographies over the last 12 months.
But we remain confident of achieving returns in excess of 2x by sticking to the mid-market and by maintaining the rigor of our investment assessments and active management approach.
But in the investment world, it's not just macro headwinds that are the problem today.
You've also got to contend with the sheer amount of money looking for a home.
Even though M&A activity and growth in the last year or 2 has been up and down, fundraising has stayed at historically high levels.
And today, we now have record amounts of dry powder across the Private Equity sector.
The vast majority of the dry powder is in the mega funds, many of which we avoid while focused on the mid-market.
So we've got to maintain our discipline on new investments and be energetic and creative in looking for opportunities in those sectors and geographies we know well.
In line with that approach, we've decided to optimize our team resources by reducing our investment team for Scandinavia.
And at the same time, we're increasing our resources in the U.
and Germany.
Our Private Equity team has had another busy year.
They delivered a 32% return on the year, another good level of realizations as well as making 3 interesting new investments, having looked at many more.
We started FY '16 selling or listing many of our older or smaller investments, and that led to a further rationalization in the size of our portfolio.
But the divestment environment became a lot more challenging in the second half, where our activity was fortunately more focused on some of our bigger and stronger assets.
The Element sale process coped well with the deteriorating circumstances as did the Action refinancing.
But our Mayborn exit was not helped by weaker debt markets and a flatter profit profile for that business.
But in the end, we were pleased with the terms for Mayborn, when we finally announced the sale of 3.
5x money multiple in April this year.
Earnings growth has remained strong across our Private Equity portfolio.
Our larger bucket one investments have made a big contribution to the growth.

And while we have avoided direct exposure to oil or commodities or to many emerging markets, we have nonetheless suffered from oil-related issues with JMJ, Dynatect and AES, and Julia will give you more detail on that shortly.
In the case of JMJ, our safety consultancy business, 65% of revenues are from the oil and gas sector.
And so that trading has been hit hard by the reductions in capital expenditure plans.
As a result, we're working closely with management to take costs out of the business and to diversify into new sectors such as aerospace.
The Russian economy and the reduced spending power of Russian consumers has had a negative impact on trading of Agent Provocateur.
And Etanco, our roofing system business, continues to suffer from low levels of construction activity in France.
At the other end of the spectrum, we have the mighty Action.
Action delivered another year of 30%-plus sales growth accompanied by strong like-for-likes and excellent EBITDA and cash flow growth.
The significant store opening program continued with 144 new openings last year.
Action has even more openings planned for this year, with expansion into 2 deep markets of France and Germany going particularly well.
But the crucial thing for Action last year was the selection of a new CFO and a new CEO.
Management is always a critical element in our Private Equity investments.
And Frederik Lotz and Sander van der Laan, I am confident we've got 2 very capable executives, who will take Action on to even better performance.
And I hope many of you will come to our Investor Day on the 8th of June.
You can meet Frederik and Sander and form your own view.
FY '16 was another year to be highly disciplined when reviewing new investments.
And having had a very full whip [ph] to consider, we narrowed our investments down to just 3 quality acquisitions in Euro-Diesel, Weener Plastic and Audley Travel.
In each case, we have to persevere with the process where the early running was inevitably made by others who were unable to maintain their early leadership based on aggressive valuations.
We're satisfied that in all 3 cases, we have bought promising businesses at fair prices with realistic plans to achieve our 2x hurdle.
And in the case of Audley Travel, we were able to use our strong balance sheet to underwrite the debt and truncate the sale process to our advantage.
Our Private Equity portfolio continues to evolve and is now even more dominated by those investments where we feel confident of making our 2x return or better.
It is also more manageable since we reduced our overall number of investments down to 47 companies by the end of March.
And we are planning to streamline it further during the current year.
We're confident in the portfolio we have put together over the last few years, and we believe our thorough research and price discipline will be well rewarded.
Quality Private Equity portfolios have a certain shape to them, 1 or 2 stars and lots of solid returns, around 2x or better, with no or very few material losses.
Our current portfolio with no -- is beginning to look more like that.
CVC have their racing cars, and Electra have their caravans.
But we have our Action stores as well as a good group of other companies capable of returning better than 2x.
You've seen the results on Element, Mayborn and Amor recently.
And we have plenty of other strong performers, including Basic-Fit, Scandlines and ATESTEO, which I haven't talked about today.
And importantly, in recent years, we've managed to avoid the material investment misjudgments, which have plagued 3i in the past.

Now I don't mean to sound complacent
[Audio Gap] 
and about some of the misguided regulation we face.
But I do feel that through our stronger processes and experience, we're a little more in control of the things that matter to our performance.
Now I'd like to turn to Infrastructure, where we've engineered a mini-revolution in the pace of activity at 3iN.
We've changed the management of our Infrastructure team, and we agreed on a change in financial return and investment mandate for 3iN.
At the same time, we overhauled and added to the origination capability in our Infrastructure team.
We're now seeing the fruits of those changes.
We're benefiting from a stronger origination performance combined with steady asset management, which has been the hallmark of 3iN's past.
As a result, 3iN has had a more all-round year of performance.
And they're putting together a very interesting collection of midsized core Infrastructure assets, which are aligned to the group's midsized focus and operational experience.
The Infrastructure sector is arguably suffering from even more acute dry powder issues than Private Equity.
That's why the importance of our changing focus cannot be understated.
The new approach should underpin the growth in returns of 3iN going forward.
And as a result, the 3i Group intends to support the placing announced by 3iN on the 12th of May last week.
Debt Management faced some very challenging market conditions in FY '16, but they performed well, both financially and in protecting the creditworthiness of their portfolios.
The team raised GBP 1.
3 billion of new CLO AUM before those markets closed in January, and they made a strong cash contribution to the group's operating cash income.
Importantly, the underlying credit performance of our CLO investments in the U.
and Europe remains sound and confidence in the CLA market is recovering.

Our effectiveness at generating stronger returns and passing cash back to shareholders has taken another good step forward this year, and that underpins our confidence in increasing this year's dividend and in enhancing the dividend policy going forward.
Our future performance will be determined by the consistency of our investment and asset management processes and by the quality of the investment portfolio we have put together.
And while we can't be immune to the macro and political volatility that we see everywhere we look, we remain confident of our ability to produce at least 2x returns from a good level of realizations.
If we continue to hit that target, we should deliver mid- to high-teens net returns to our shareholders.
And in years like this one, with some excellent realizations, shareholders can expect to see 20%-plus returns.
Now I'll pass over to Julia.
I just wonder if could you say a little bit about your plans for new investment, because I understand your point about want us to be selective and focus on your core competencies.
How much new investment are you targeting this year? How do you think the outlook is looking now compared to a year ago? How much do you think your hiring in the U.

and Germany will facilitate that? And more generally, what do you think is kind of the right level of investment you need to remain relevant and to recycle your capital? Coming to a bit more commentary about the 7% earnings growth, unless there -- barring unexpected events, as you'd expect me to say, that should be a low point.
And a lot of this is about the mix that's in that measure.
So obviously, the sale of Element, which is one of our largest assets, with 20% growth, has come out of it.
In terms of our new investments, we've got some positive investment cases there, but it's relatively early days for them to really be featuring in the calculation.

And I think if you look at those companies that Simon's talked about, the AESs, Dynatects, Etancos of this world, where they have been subject to the headwinds, we're starting to see some more positive outlook for those businesses.
And they are part of that change in the metric from 5 companies on the forecast earnings to 2 at this period.
So yes, barring anything unexpected happening, we should see that sort of stabilizing and coming out from that measure.
But we've recognized that we are operating in fairly tricky times.
In the slide 29, which I think is the bar chart that shows you the breakup of the earnings growth, what you've really got in that shift, I think, is GBP 373 million in the minus 1% to minus 10% bar.
And what you've got in the components of that are the companies that we've just talked about.
So they would sort of in the bar to the right previously, and they shifted over to that.
That's a historic chart.
So it's consistent with what we've just been talking about.
Thank you, Simon.
As you just heard, this has been an excellent year for 3i.
Our financial performance provides evidence of the resilience of our operating and business model even against a background of volatility and uncertainty in those markets that Simon has talked about.
And we continue to execute our well-defined strategy.
We closed the year with very strong performance in the final quarter.
We delivered NAV per share of 463p and a 21.
7% return on our opening net assets.
The main drivers of NAV growth contributing 77p was solid portfolio performance and successful realizations.
That performance is also reflected in the increase in net carry payables with an 11p impact.
We benefited from Sterling's weakness, which gave us a net 16p translation gain in the year.
And finally, we paid total dividends of 20p in the year.
Now I know some of you like the bridge for the quarter 2, so that's in the back of the pack.
The Private Equity business had a very good year.
They generated gross investment return of over GBP 1 billion or 32% of opening portfolio value.
And that's an excellent performance, especially in these tricky market conditions.
P/E realizations of GBP 743 million include 11 smaller and older assets and GBP 179 million from the sale of Element.
It was one of our largest assets, and the sale was at a money multiple of 3.
The uplift of 14% is lower than last year, and that just reflects the fact that GBP 111 million of the proceeds were from sales of our quoted investments.
And the weight of the transactions was early in the year, so most of the exit value had been reflected in the opening NAV.
So we're continuing to make good progress in reshaping the portfolio.
And we've put a slide in the back of the pack to give you full details of all the realizations.
Now although the total number of investments reduced, the Private Equity portfolio value increased to GBP 3.
7 billion, supported by a number of material value increases in our largest assets.
On a really positive note, the GBP 690 million of unrealized value growth is underpinned by the performance of the portfolio, that is earnings growth and changes in net debt.
The performance of assets valued on an earnings basis accounted for GBP 460 million of the uplift, and they had value weighted average earnings growth of 17%.
If you exclude Action with its earnings growth of over 30%, the average is 7%.
I'll come back to how that's changed in the year in a minute.
But first, I'd like to spend a couple of minutes on some of the other drivers of value growth.
GBP 95 million came from a net increase in the multiples we used to value the portfolio.
The 2 biggest contributions came from Action and Basic-Fit, with increased Action's multiple by 0.
5 turn to 14x.
That increase in the multiple reflects continuing strength in its performance and its outlook for growth.
We also increased the multiple used to value Basic-Fit.
You will have seen Tuesday's announcement of its intention to float, which means I can't give you the actual multiple today.
But if you exclude Basic-Fit and Action from the average, then the increase in average multiples is just less than 1% previous count.
There have been reports of further delays in the opening of the fixed link that will compete with Scandlines.
We have not reflected possible delays to the full extent that we could have, but we've delayed our opening assumption by 3 years.
So the DCF value has increased and the biggest -- is the biggest factor in the GBP 124 million that you can see here.
We announced the sales of Amor and Mayborn in April.
Both transactions should be complete by the end of June.
They have achieved investments valued on an imminent sales basis.
Coming back then to earnings growth in the portfolio.
Overall, the portfolio continues to perform well, and our monthly portfolio monitoring helps us tackle any issues potentially arising, as they are bound to do in these tricky conditions.
Value-weighted earnings growth over the last 12 months was 17%, including the significant contribution from Action, which is obviously the majority of the far right bar here.
Excluding Action's contribution, growth is still a healthy 7%, but it's come down during the course of the year and was 12% in Q3.
There are a few factors that explain the reduction.
The sale of Element plays a part.
The measure also reflects the performance of the likes of AES, Dynatect, Etanco and JMJ that Simon has talked about.
We expect the macro environment to remain challenging and volatile.
But barring unexpected events, it looks as though 7% should be the low point for a portfolio well positioned in chosen sectors and markets with good momentum.
As you can see here, we're expecting a positive trend in the majority of our top 20 investments.
All this good performance flows through to the recognition of our carry.
We reached an important milestone at the 31st of March 2016.
Improvements in the year from V performance means we have recognized carry receivable on that fund for the first time for accounting purposes.
Eurofund V was valued at 0.
At the 31st of March 2016, its multiple is now 1.
Consistent with how we recognize carry payable, the receivable is calculated as if we sold all the assets at the 31st of March 2016 valuations.
This is the biggest component of the GBP 58 million receivable you see here.
On the payables side, most of the schemes are now through their respective performance hurdles from an accounting perspective.
We generally accrue at between 10% and 15% of gross investment return on those schemes, and we recognized a charge of GBP 171 million.
Private Equity returns are usually in capital form.
The business made a good contribution to income, all the more so as the contribution from fee income will continue to pull as we sell investments held in third-party funds.
In total, we generated GBP 50 million of income, including GBP 30 million of dividends and interest from the portfolio.
We also expect Infrastructure to provide a significant contribution to our operating cash income, and it's continued to do so in this year.
Our 34% investment in 3iN delivered a GBP 33 million increase in value, as the share price is resilient in the face of volatile equity markets.
We received ordinary dividends of GBP 21 million in addition to the GBP 51 million special dividend, which is included on our realization proceeds.
We also recognized a performance fee of GBP 20 million based on 3iN's NAV, which reflects another year of strong performance.
As Simon said, Debt Management had a good year of fundraising.
We launched 2 CLOs in Europe and 2 in the U.
as well as the new global income fund.
And that's a positive step in Debt Management's diversification.
As a result, we had GBP 11.
6 billion of assets under management at the end of the year, supporting fee income of GBP 38 million.
For regulatory reasons, we are required to invest in each new European CLO, and that is now also the practice in the U.
in anticipation of equivalent U.
rules, which will be effective at the end of 2016.
We may also invest more than risk required to secure a flat fund launch in more volatile markets.
All together, our CLO equity investment increased to GBP 151 million.
We took a reduction in value against those CLO investments of GBP 43 million, which mostly relates to the GBP 31 million of cash distributions included in portfolio income.
But a proportion did reflect negative investor sentiment more generally.
That originated in the U.
, where exposure to the oil and gas sector is more significant, although there was some contagion effect in Europe too.
Our teams managed the underlying credit portfolios very actively, which in some cases might include taking early losses in volatile markets if appropriate.
However, actual defaults are low, and our longer-term view of investment return remains positive.
Debt Management, together with Private Equity and Infrastructure, contributed to further progress on our cash operating profit metric.
We generated a profit of GBP 37 million in the year.
I've talked about the components of the GBP 117 million of cash income as we've gone through the business lines.

Operating costs were GBP 134 million, which includes GBP 5 million of restructuring costs relating to planned reductions in our Nordic team, where we look to increase the size of our investment teams in our key geographies in Europe and the U.
We have also recruited to support origination and business development and to address the increasing burden of regulation.
But we continue to tightly manage costs, which we kept 1% of AUM.
The financial strength of our operating platform is a key difference between the 3i of today and the 3i of 2008 and 2009.
And that financial strength is a significant factor in our ability to stay resilient and keep performing in challenging markets.
The strength of our balance sheet is another crucial difference and advantage.
We closed the year with net cash of GBP 165 million and total liquidity of  GBP 1.
35 billion.
We will pay our 2017 bond after cash resources.
We will also be supporting 3iN's fund raising.
And we plan to invest EUR 500 million to EUR 750 million in new Private Equity deals.
Despite this planned investment, we expect to be net divestors over the next 5 years.
That's partly from continuing to reshape the portfolio, but more fundamentally, it's the result as we invest in opportunities that are capable of delivering 2x our money.
So with that in mind, we've recommended a 10% increase in the total dividend to the year of 22p and a final dividend of 16p.
That 22p is 27% of cash realizations, somewhat ahead of a 15% to 20% guidance that we set in 2012.
At that time, we believed it was important to give our shareholders a direct share in the success of the business.
So we set that formula to give investors confidence that we would make that a meaningful share.
We've actually paid above the upper end of the range every year the policy has been in operation.
With the strength of our balance sheet outlook, we have now updated our policy.
We are doubling our base dividend to 16p, and we expect to pay half at the interim dividend and the remaining half in the final.
We will then pay an additional final dividend that 20% limited 20% that is not limited by the 15% to 20% formula.
That final will depend on the level and outlook of investments, realizations and our balance sheet.
That additional dividend will still be subject to gross debt being less than GBP 1 billion and group gearing less than 20%.
But we don't believe that, that is likely to be a constraint.
So 2016 has been an excellent year for 3i.
These financial results provide further evidence of our resilience and the value of our clear, consistent strategy and disciplined approach to investments.
Thank you, and we're now happy to take questions.

But if you exclude Basic-Fit and Action from the average, then the increase in average multiples is just less than 1% to previous count.
There have been reports of further delays in the opening of the Fixed Link that would compete with Scandlines.
We have not reflected possible delays to the full extent that we could have, but we've delayed our opening assumption by 3 years.
So the DCF value has increased and the biggest -- is the biggest factor in the GBP 124 million that you can see here.
We announced the sales of Amor and Mayborn in April.
Both transactions should be complete by the end of June.
They are the 2 investments valued on an imminent sales basis.
Coming back then to earnings growth in the portfolio.
Overall, the portfolio continued to perform well, and our monthly portfolio monitoring helps us tackle any issues potentially arising, as they are bound to do in these tricky conditions.
Value-weighted earnings growth over the last 12 months was 17%, including the significant contribution from Action, which is obviously the majority of the far right bar here.
Excluding Action's contribution, growth is still a healthy 7%, but it's come down during the course of the year and was 12% in Q3.
There are a few factors that explain the reduction.
The sale of Element plays a part.
The measure also reflects the performance of the likes of AES, Dynatect, Etanco and JMJ that Simon has talked about.
We expect the macro environment to remain challenging and volatile.
But barring unexpected events, it looks as though 7% should be the low point for a portfolio well-positioned in chosen sectors and markets with good momentum.
As you can see here, we're expecting a positive trend in the majority of our top 20 investments.
All this good performance flows through to the recognition of our carry.
We reached an important milestone at the 31st of March 2016.
Improvements in the Eurofund V performance means we have recognized carry receivable on that fund for the first time for accounting purposes.
Eurofund V was valued at 0.
At the 31st of March 2016, its multiple is now 1.
Consistent with how we recognize carry payable, the receivable is calculated as if we sold all the assets at the 31st of March 2016 valuations.
This is the biggest component of the GBP 58 million receivable you see here.
On the payables side, most of the schemes are now through their respective performance hurdles from an accounting perspective.
We generally accrue at between 10% and 15% of gross investment return on those schemes, and we recognized a charge of GBP 171 million.
Private Equity returns are usually in capital form.
The business made a good contribution to income, all the more so as the contribution from fee income will continue to fall as we sell investments held in third-party funds.
In total, we generated GBP 50 million of income, including GBP 30 million of dividends and interest from the portfolio.
We also expect Infrastructure to provide a significant contribution to our operating cash income, and it's continued to do so in this year.
Our 34% investment in 3iN delivered a GBP 33 million increase in value, as the share price is resilient in the face of volatile equity markets.
We received ordinary dividends of GBP 21 million in addition to the GBP 51 million special dividend, which is included on our realization proceeds.
We also recognized a performance fee of GBP 20 million based on 3iN's NAV, which reflects another year of strong performance.
As Simon said, Debt Management had a good year of fundraising.
We launched 2 CLOs in Europe and 2 in the U.
as well as the new Global Income Fund.
And that's a positive step in Debt Management's diversification.
As a result, we had GBP 11.
6 billion of assets under management at the end of the year, supporting fee income of GBP 38 million.
For regulatory reasons, we are required to invest in each new European CLO, and that is now also the practice in the U.
in anticipation of equivalent U.
rules, which will be effective at the end of 2016.
We may also invest more than is required to secure a flat fund launch in more volatile markets.
All together, our CLO equity investment increased to GBP 151 million.
We took a reduction in value against those CLO investments of GBP 43 million, which mostly relates to the GBP 31 million of cash distributions included in portfolio income.
But a proportion did reflect negative investor sentiment more generally.
That originated in the U.
, where exposure to the oil and gas sector is more significant, although there was some contagion effect in Europe, too.
Our teams managed the underlying credit portfolios very actively, which in some cases might include taking early losses in volatile markets if appropriate.
However, actual defaults are low, and our longer-term view of investment return remains positive.
Debt Management, together with Private Equity and Infrastructure, contributed to further progress on our cash operating profit metric.
We generated a profit of GBP 37 million in the year.
I've talked about the components of the GBP 117 million of cash income as we've gone through the business lines.

Operating costs were GBP 134 million, which includes GBP 5 million of restructuring costs relating to planned reductions in our Nordic team, while we look to increase the size of our investment teams in our key geographies in Europe and the U.
We have also recruited to support origination and business development and to address the increasing burden of regulation.
But we continue to tightly manage costs, which we kept to 1% of AUM.
The financial strength of our operating platform is a key difference between the 3i of today and the 3i of 2008 and 2009.
And that financial strength is a significant factor in our ability to stay resilient and keep performing in challenging markets.
The strength of our balance sheet is another crucial difference and advantage.
We closed the year with net cash of GBP 165 million and total liquidity of  GBP 1.
35 billion.
We will pay our 2017 bond out of cash resources.
We will also be supporting 3iN's fundraising.
And we plan to invest EUR 500 million to EUR 750 million in new Private Equity deals.
Despite this planned investment, we expect to be net divestors over the next 5 years.
That's partly from continuing to reshape the portfolio, but more fundamentally, it's the result as we invest in opportunities that are capable of delivering 2x our money.
So with that in mind, we've recommended a 10% increase in the total dividend for the year of 22p and a final dividend of 16p.
That 22p is 27% of cash realizations, somewhat ahead of our 15% to 20% guidance that we set up in 2012.
At that time, we believed it was important to give our shareholders a direct share in the success of the business.
So we set the formula to give investors confidence that we would make that a meaningful share.
We've actually paid above the upper end of the range every year the policy has been in operation.
With the strength of our balance sheet outlook, we have now updated our policy.
We are doubling our base dividend to 16p, and we expect to pay half at the interim dividend and the remaining half in the final.
We will then pay an additional final dividend that is not limited by the 15% to 20% formula.
That final dividend will depend on the level and outlook of investments, realizations and our balance sheet.
That additional dividend will still be subject to gross debt being less than GBP 1 billion and group gearing less than 20%, but we don't believe that, that is likely to be a constraint.
So 2016 has been an excellent year for 3i.
These financial results provide further evidence of our resilience and the value of our clear, consistent strategy and disciplined approach to investments.
Thank you, and we're now happy to take questions.
Daniel Garrod from Barclays.
A couple of questions for me.
I wondered if you could provide any more color around your comments to the, the 7% earnings growth ex Action as the confidence of that sort of being a trough.

Is that due to the timing of new investments coming online? Is there anything you can point to in terms of, I guess, proportion of forecast accounts that gives that confidence? Second question, I had a question on Slide 29 where you detailed the earnings momentum in those buckets.

The 5 assets that you outlined as sort of more problematic, you've commented on them before, that seemed to be about GBP 270 million of value, but there's about GBP 470 million there with negative earnings momentum.

So any more color on what else is in there outside of those 5 assets? Yes, I mean, they feature in our portfolio monitoring meetings, and there are some signs of stability coming back into those businesses.
We've seen in the industrial sector generally having a bit more of a positive outlook than maybe -- it looked quite gloomy at the end of last year and coming into early this year.
Well, I think we indicated in Julia's presentation that we're looking to invest EUR 500 million to EUR 700 million this year.
And I think that is the type of level that we think is the right level, given the current market conditions and the scale of the mid-market in particular.
We have probably the broadest platform in the mid-market amongst any of our competitors with the office network we have.
But we are seeing more opportunities and more flow in Germany and the U.
in particular.
And we would like to resource up those teams.
But because of the dry powder, there are times when we get quite far down a process, but there is simply a gap, either between us and another bidder or between us and the vendor.
And what we're not going to do is pay too much for something.
So there will be years, as we've seen in the last few years, where we will struggle to put that amount of money to work.
But we'll buy good quality assets of a lower amount.
But we think by having more resource, we stand a better chance of hitting the EUR 500 million to EUR 700 million without going up in price too much.
Iain? Good morning, everyone.
Welcome to 3i's final results for the year to the 31st of March 2016.
Since we last spoke, we've had another very productive 6 months, and we closed this year with strong returns across the group, giving us excellent momentum as we move into the new financial year.
We've made very good progress against our key KPIs.
We closed the year with a 22% total return on equity, net cash of  GBP 165 million and an increased dividend of 22p for the year.
NAV has increased by 17% to 463p.
And group operating cash profit has increased again to GBP 37 million.
All of our divisions have performed well, and the group's portfolio of investments is coping well with the various macroeconomic challenges.
And the longer-term reshaping of 3i continues.
We're building on the foundations of our 3-year restructuring.
It's been a volatile year for the markets, but we have made further good progress.
And we enter FY '17 with a more focused portfolio of high-quality investments, good cost and investment discipline and a solid balance sheet.
And going forward, we remain focused on executing our well-established strategy and maintaining a disciplined approach to new investment.
Our international platform and sector experience, combined with our proprietary capital approach, gives us important competitive advantages in the mid-market where we compete.

There's no question that both the macro and geopolitical environment has become a lot more challenging, and it's clear that headwinds have reduced growth in many sectors and geographies over the last 12 months.
But we remain confident of achieving returns in excess of 2x by sticking to the mid-market and by maintaining the rigor of our investment assessments and active management approach.
But in the investment world, it's not just macro headwinds that are the problem today.
You've also got to contend with the sheer amount of money looking for a home.
Even though M&A activity and growth in the last year or 2 has been up and down, fundraising has stayed at historically high levels.
And today, we now have record amounts of dry powder across the Private Equity sector.
The vast majority of the dry powder is in the mega funds, many of which we avoid while focused on the mid-market.
So we've got to maintain our discipline on new investments and be energetic and creative in looking for opportunities in those sectors and geographies we know well.
In line with that approach, we have decided to optimize our team resources by reducing our investment team for Scandinavia, and at the same time, we're increasing our resources in the U.
and Germany.
Our Private Equity team has had another busy year.
They delivered a 32% return on the year, another good level of realizations, as well as making 3 interesting new investments, having looked at many more.
We started FY '16 selling or listing many of our older or smaller investments, and that led to a further rationalization in the size of our portfolio.
But the divestment environment became a lot more challenging in the second half, where our activity was fortunately more focused on some of our bigger and stronger assets.
The Element sale process coped well with the deteriorating circumstances, as did the Action refinancing.
But our Mayborn exit was not helped by weaker debt markets and a flatter profit profile for that business.
But in the end, we were pleased with the terms for Mayborn, when we finally announced the sale at 3.
5x money multiple in April this year.
Earnings growth has remained strong across our Private Equity portfolio.
Our larger bucket 1 investments have made a big contribution to the growth.

And while we have avoided direct exposure to oil or commodities or to many emerging markets, we have nonetheless suffered from oil-related issues with JMJ, Dynatect and AES, and Julia will give you more detail on that shortly.
In the case of JMJ, our safety consultancy business, 65% of revenues are from the oil and gas sector.
And so their trading has been hit hard by the reductions in capital expenditure plans.
As a result, we're working closely with management to take costs out of the business and to diversify into new sectors such as aerospace.
The Russian economy and the reduced spending power of Russian consumers has had a negative impact on trading of Agent Provocateur.
And Etanco, our roofing system business, continues to suffer from low levels of construction activity in France.
At the other end of the spectrum, we have the mighty Action.
Action delivered another year of 30%-plus sales growth accompanied by strong like-for-likes and excellent EBITDA and cash flow growth.
The significant store opening program continued, with 144 new openings last year.
Action has even more openings planned for this year, with expansion in the 2 deep markets of France and Germany going particularly well.
But the crucial thing for Action last year was the selection of a new CFO and a new CEO.
Management is always a critical element in our Private Equity investments.
And Frederik Lotz and Sander van der Laan, I am confident we've got 2 very capable executives who will take Action on to even better performance.
And I hope many of you will come to our Investor Day on the 8th of June.
You can meet Frederik and Sander and form your own view.
FY '16 was another year to be highly disciplined when reviewing new investments.
And having had a very full width to consider, we narrowed our investments down to just 3 quality acquisitions in Euro-Diesel, Weener Plastic and Audley Travel.
In each case, we had to persevere with the process where the early running was inevitably made by others who were unable to maintain their early leadership based on aggressive valuations.
We're satisfied that in all 3 cases, we have bought promising businesses at fair prices with realistic plans to achieve our 2x hurdle.
And in the case of Audley Travel, we were able to use our strong balance sheet to underwrite the debt and truncate the sale process to our advantage.
Our Private Equity portfolio continues to evolve and is now even more dominated by those investments where we feel confident of making our 2x return or better.
It is also more manageable, since we reduced our overall number of investments down to 47 companies by the end of March.
And we are planning to streamline it further during the current year.
We're confident in the portfolio we have put together over the last few years, and we believe our thorough research and price discipline will be well rewarded.
Quality Private Equity portfolios have a certain shape to them, 1 or 2 stars and lots of solid returners, around 2x or better, with no or very few material losses.
Our current portfolio, with no -- is beginning to look more like that.
CVC have their racing cars and Electra have their caravans.
But we have our Action stores as well as a good group of other companies capable of returning better than 2x.
You've seen the results on Element, Mayborn and Amor recently.
And we have plenty of other strong performers, including Basic-Fit, Scandlines and ATESTEO, which I haven't talked about today.
And importantly, in recent years, we've managed to avoid the material investment misjudgments which have plagued 3i in the past.

Now I don't mean to sound complacent
[Audio Gap] 
and about some of the misguided regulation we face.
But I do feel that through our stronger processes and experience, we're a little more in control of the things that matter to our performance.
Now I'd like to turn to Infrastructure, where we've engineered a mini-revolution in the pace of activity at 3iN.
We've changed the management of our Infrastructure team, and we agreed on a change in financial return and investment mandate for 3iN.
At the same time, we overhauled and added to the origination capability in our Infrastructure team.
We're now seeing the fruits of those changes.
We're benefiting from a stronger origination performance combined with steady asset management, which has been the hallmark of 3iN's past.
As a result, 3iN has had a more all-round year of performance.
And they're putting together a very interesting collection of midsized core Infrastructure assets, which are aligned to the group's midsized focus and operational experience.
The Infrastructure sector is arguably suffering from even more acute dry powder issues than Private Equity.
That's why the importance of our change in focus cannot be understated.
The new approach should underpin the growth in returns of 3iN going forward.
And as a result, the 3i Group intends to support the placing announced by 3iN on the 12th of May last week.
Debt Management faced some very challenging market conditions in FY '16, but they performed well, both financially and in protecting the creditworthiness of their portfolios.
The team raised GBP 1.
3 billion of new CLO AUM before those markets closed in January, and they made a strong cash contribution to the group's operating cash income.
Importantly, the underlying credit performance of our CLO investments in the U.
and Europe remain sound and confidence in the CLO market is recovering.

Our effectiveness at generating strong returns and passing cash back to shareholders has taken another good step forward this year, and that underpins our confidence in increasing this year's dividend and in enhancing the dividend policy going forward.
Our future performance will be determined by the consistency of our investment and asset management processes and by the quality of the investment portfolio we have put together.
And while we can't be immune to the macro and political volatility that we see everywhere we look, we remain confident of our ability to produce at least 2x returns from a good level of realizations.
If we continue to hit that target, we should deliver mid- to high-teens net returns to our shareholders.
And in years like this one, with some excellent realizations, shareholders can expect to see 20%-plus returns.
Now I'll pass over to Julia.
Philip? I just wonder could you say a little bit about your plans for new investment, because I understand your point about wanting to be selective and focus on your core competencies.
How much new investment are you targeting this year? How do you think the outlook is looking now compared to a year ago? How much do you think your hiring in the U.

and Germany will facilitate that? And more generally, what do you think is kind of the right level of investment you need to remain relevant and to recycle your capital? It's Iain Scouller from Stifel.
Just on the multiple to -- that's been used to value the portfolio.
I mean, it looks as though that might be reaching a peak.

Can you give us an idea on sensitivity? I mean, if the multiple was to fall by 10% from about 10x to 9x, what sort of impact that would have on the return? But you indicate you are seeing a bit of reasons for more optimism in those 5 assets? It has been heavily impacted by a couple of changes of the bigger investments.
It's not a general move up.
Anyone else? No Brexit, no Action? Okay.
Well, thanks for coming, everyone.
And have a good day.
Not very easily is the answer, because it's such a mix of the different -- the different businesses.
So we don't normally think about it like that.
As I said, that you've got 2 big components in there, clearly is the multiple that we use to value Action at 14x.
I can't give you the multiple that we've used to value Basic-Fit, but it's obviously relative to the announcement that we made on Tuesday.
I mean, the spread of the multiples that we use is about 5.
But they tend to concentrate around the average more normally.
Thanks, Simon.
So with a total return of 11% and over GBP 500 million of new investment completed, we closed the period with an NAV per share of 652p.
You can see here, how we generated that 652p of NAV.
The 61p of strong performance from our portfolio companies.
We've got a multi-distribution from FX of 6p.
And that compares to about 30p this time last year.
And we paid our final dividend of 18.
5p in July.
For those of you who are interested in quarter-on-quarter movement, there is a bridge in the back of the pack, but the shape is pretty much the same.
Our Private Equity business was the biggest contributor to our returns, generating GBP 715 million of gross investment return.
Realized profits of GBP 53 million on GBP 350 million of proceeds, with an uplift on opening book value of 21%.
Those realized profits came mainly from the sales of menorah, the Spanish funeral services provider and at [indiscernible], our last Brazilian investment.
This was a strong half with good performance from Action, Scandlines and our more recent investments, which together contributed to GBP 517 million value growth.
When you add the GBP 500 million of new investments, as Simon just talked about, portfolio is now valued at GBP 5.
7 billion and that's up from GBP 4.
8 billion at the start of the period.
Over 90% of the portfolio by value, has grown earnings and this is a profile of earnings [ of our ] top 20 investments.
Action has another excellent period but as you can see, it is moved from 30% bar to the 29% bar this time.
And that's reflected in the company's investment in its growth agenda, particularly in its distribution centers and logistics.
The growing contribution that we're getting from investments we have made since the change in our strategy is also important.
They make up all of the company's in the greater than 30% category, and the rest of the greater than 20% category.
Together with Action, these were the biggest contributors to the GBP 283 million of performance in the value growth analysis that you can see here.
Now as you know, we tend to use multiples based on longer-term sector averages.
If we think that the current multiples in the comparable companies have expanded well ahead of longer-term sector trends.
In a couple of cases, we reviewed our investment positions relative to these longer-term averages and the concepts.
And we have been moved these up multiples to reflect that performance.
This time, we have done that for a small number of assets, including [ AAS  ]and the [ ten code ].
This not substantial re-ratings but they do largely explain the GBP 59 million movement here.
We have made no change to the multiple that we use to value Action, which remains at 16x post discount run rate.
These changes to multiples have flowed through the weighted average multiples for those assets that we valued on an earnings basis.
And it also includes the effect of some of the investments made in the period, such as Lampenwelt and Cirtec, which were in higher rated sectors.
As a result, the weighted average has increased from 9.
9x post discount at March to 10.
Turning then to our Infrastructure business.
Just to remind you, the significant majority of our investment return currently comes from our 34% investment in 3iN , which now sits results last week.
Our team have also raised 2 new funds, the 3i managed Infrastructure acquisitions fund and the 3i  European operations projects fund.
So far, these funds have added GBP 830 million to our assets under management.
And we have committed GBP 69 million to those funds.
And as you have just heard, our U.
Infrastructure team have announced their first new investment since the period end.

Because of these new initiatives, we don't have a material impact on the numbers for our Infrastructure business in the first half, so the gross investment return of GBP 32 million comes mainly from the good share price performance of 3iN.
Together with [ it's ] dividend income, and the fee income from our associated advisory agreement.
This income means our Infrastructure business is already a good contributor to operating cash income.
As expected, our cash costs exceeded our cash income by GBP 16 million in the first half.
Because we no longer have the income from the Debt Management business.
But that measure will also be improved by infrastructures fundraising initiatives.
So this has been a good half or 3iN in terms of performance, but importantly, also in terms of investment.
We were net investors in the period as we saw a good number of attractive investment opportunities.
In total, we have invested GBP 572 million, all funded from our strong balance sheet.
And we realized GBP 374 million from Private Equity and from the residual Debt Management business.
We started the year with net cash of GBP 419 million, and liquidity of GBP 1.
After the investments realization activity that we've been talking about, and paying the final dividend, we have net debt of GBP 48 million and liquidity of GBP 877 million at the 30th of September.

Looking forward to the remainder of the year and, of course, subject to the usual caveats about market conditions, with a strong pipeline of realizations, we expect the profile of investments and realizations to reverse in the second half compared to the first half.
We'll also be paying our interim dividend in the second half.
So to remind you about our dividend policy.
We pay a base dividend of 16p, half of which is paid as an interim and half as a final.
We'll also pay an additional dividend with the final.
We set the amounts of that additional dividend by taking account, of our outlook for investments and realizations and the strength of our balance sheet.
You'll be familiar with this slide, which shows the distribution to shareholders, or a fundamental part of our capital allocation model.
So our portfolio continues to perform well.
And we've made an excellent new investments, which means we are well positioned to deliver continued growth.
Thank you, and will now take questions.

Good morning.
Welcome to 3i's results presentation.
It's been another strong half for 3i.
With our strategy driving good levels of activity, and solid returns.
We took another good step forward in portfolio performance.
And we sold assets at decent uplifts.
And our Private Equity team made significant new investments like [indiscernible] in and Holland and [ Formel D ] in Germany.
And we had a strong fundraising performance in Infrastructure.
This has delivered another strong financial result, with a total return of [ 11% in the half.
] This table throws up an interesting perspective.
Not any against the restructuring baseline in 2012, but the this months return equals our full year return in 2015, underlying the strong consistent year-on-year value growth of our portfolio.
And we have entered the second half of the year with good momentum across both divisions.
Again, the portfolio has performed well this year but I'm also glad to see a good level of new investment in Private Equity.
Our Private Equity team has delivered an excellent return with a GIR of 15%.
91% of our top 20 assets grew their earnings in the first half.
And that's another good indication of the quality of our portfolio.
And we made over GBP 0.
5 billion of new investments, as well as doing some significant bolt on acquisitions.
Our portfolios performed well and delivered decent growth across-the-board with very few write-downs.
Apart from Action, the strongest growth has come from those companies, we have invested in since our restructuring.
And that relatively young 2013-16 portfolio has already delivered 1.
9x cost and value growth so far.
Action continues to perform strongly.
For financial reporting, Action uses 13 periods of [ full ] weeks and the numbers in our interims are taken from their period 9, which finished on the 10th of September.
Action had opened 111 new stores by that date and is on track to open more than 230 stores by the end of 2017.
As of yesterday, Action had opened the 192 stores and now has a total of 1044.
So that's a significant step from last year and a major ramp up in this quarter in particular.

That's an ambitious growth initiatives and even after significant levels of new investment in stores, distribution centers, country offices and central functions, like for likes in cash flow remain very strong.
Without increasing Action's multiple, we have seen half a million of value growth in the last 12 months alone.
And the major store expansion program in this final quarter will create further significant momentum for 3i second half valuation.
We produced a marked set up in our origination activity this year.
Origination has always been a great strength for 3i.
The group led the PE Sector in establishing the European network of offices in the '80s and '90s.
And now that we have dealt with most of our legacy issues, our investment teams have been freed up to focus on origination against some tighten and carefully considered criteria.
That change of focus means a good share of our recent investments have been sourced directly, away from competitive bank driven auction processes.
This chart puts this year's activity in context.
We have invested about GBP 2 billion of capital since our restructuring, but half of that GBP 2 billion has been invested over the last 15 months alone.
In addition, we entered the second half with a strong pipeline of new and follow-on investment activity.
I would now like to talk on a couple of our recent investments.

[ Cirtec ] was our most recent investment, like Q Holding's, it operates in the medical device sector and like Q, Cirtec is capable of being a platform asset that will combine strong levels of organic growth with M&A.
3i's international credentials were particularly useful and convincing the CEO that we were the right partner for his ambitious plans.
I'm very excited about our investment in Lampenwelt, which is the largest specialty online retailer of lighting products in Europe.
The business was started in Germany in 2004 by 2 brothers, who were both electrical engineers.
Lampenwelt is a classic online disruptive retailer.
It already operates in 14 European markets and is planning to selectively expand its geographic footprint further across Europe.
We spotted the business when we were doing a due diligence scan of the sector.
As part of our review last year of the sale of SLV, another lighting company.
One of our German network contacts knew the company and was able to make an introduction that led directly to an entirely off market transaction.
Lampenwelt is already highly profitable and generates lots of cash.
So I have a little doubt that it will become one of our highest growing companies very quickly.
As I said a minute ago, we are also seeing a good level of [ Bolton ] activity across the portfolio.
Power has the potential to become another important platform asset for 3i.
And [ Arsa ] is another important step on that journey.
Now I'd like to turn to the portfolio.
We have raised GBP 350 million, 2.
7x cost on realizations in the first half.
And we move into the second half with a number of important processes in terrain.
As long as markets remain resilient, we expect to raise significantly more cash from refinancings and realizations in the second half.
Here is the investment bucket slide, that we have been showing you for the last few years.
And as you can see, the top 2 buckets continue to dominate the makeup of the portfolio.
Basic-Fit continues to grow strongly as a public company and first go now subject to take a private bid from the PAI.
Now what about Infrastructure? They produced another good half with a strong performance from 3iN, good levels of cash income for the group and a number of important new fund initiatives.
The 3iN portfolio with its recent core plus additions is performing strongly and several of its larger core assets are now undergoing strategic reviews.
The return for 3i's shareholders on the 3iN June 2006 equity placing is now at a very respectable 22%.
And we have made our first move into U.
Infrastructure.
With the announcement of our acquisition of Smarte Carte.
Smarte Carte is the leading provider of airport baggage cards and self-storage lockers across the U.
Infrastructure team is already performing well.
And they are coming up with a good flow of interesting investment ideas.
We intend to fund Infrastructure investment in initially from our own balance sheet with a view to deploying third-party capital in due course.

With the Private Equity and the Infrastructure teams producing good levels of alpha in their respective sectors.

Good morning.
Welcome to 3i's results presentation.
It's been another strong half for 3i with our strategy driving good levels of activity and solid returns.
We took another good step forward in portfolio performance.
And we sold assets at decent uplifts.
And our Private Equity team made significant new investments like Hans Anders in Holland and Formel D in Germany.
And we had a strong fundraising performance in Infrastructure.
This has delivered another strong financial result with a total return of 11% in the half.
This table throws up an interesting perspective.
Not only against the restructuring baseline in 2012, but this 6 months return equals our full year return in 2015, underlying the strong consistent year-on-year value growth of our portfolio.
And we have entered the second half of the year with good momentum across both divisions.
Again, the portfolio has performed well this year, but I'm also glad to see a good level of new investment in Private Equity.
Our Private Equity team has delivered an excellent return with a GIR of 15%.
91% of our top 20 assets grew their earnings in the first half and that's another good indication of the quality of our portfolio.
And we made over GBP 0.
5 billion of new investments, as well as doing some significant bolt on acquisitions.
Our portfolio has performed well and delivered decent growth across-the-board with very few write-downs.
Apart from Action, the strongest growth has come from those companies, we have invested in since our restructuring.
And that relatively young 2013-16 portfolio has already delivered 1.
9x cost in value growth so far.
Action continues to perform strongly.
For financial reporting, Action uses 13 periods or 4 weeks and the numbers in our interims are taken from their period 9, which finished on the 10th of September.
Action had opened 111 new stores by that date and is on track to open more than 230 stores by the end of 2017.
As of yesterday, Action had opened 192 stores and now has a total of 1044.
So that's a significant step-up from last year and a major ramp up in this quarter in particular.

That's an ambitious growth initiatives and even after significant levels of new investment in stores, distribution centers, country offices and central functions, like for likes in cash flow remain very strong.
Without increasing Action's multiple, we have seen half a billion of value growth in the last 12 months alone.
And the major store expansion program in this final quarter will create further significant momentum for 3i's second half valuation.
We've produced a marked step-up in our origination activity this year.
Origination has always been a great strength of 3i.
The group led the PE Sector in establishing the European network of offices in the '80s and '90s.
And now that we have dealt with most of our legacy issues, our investment teams have been freed up to focus on origination against some tight and carefully considered criteria.
That change of focus, means a good share of our recent investments have been sourced directly, away from competitive bank driven auction processes.
This chart puts this year's activity in context.
We have invested about GBP 2 billion of capital since our restructuring, but half of that GBP 2 billion has been invested over the last 15 months alone.
In addition, we entered the second half with a strong pipeline of new and follow-on investment activity.
I would now like to touch on a couple of our recent investments.

Cirtec was our most recent investment, like Q Holding's, it operates in the medical device sector and like Q, Cirtec is capable of being a platform asset, that will combine strong levels of organic growth with M&A.
3i's international credentials were particularly useful in convincing the CEO, that we were the right partner for his ambitious plans.
I'm very excited about our investment in Lampenwelt, which is the largest specialty online retailer of lighting products in Europe.
The business was started in Germany in 2004 by 2 brothers, who were both electrical engineers.
Lampenwelt is a classic online disruptive retailer.
It already operates in 14 European markets and is planning to selectively expand its geographic footprint further across Europe.
We spotted the business, when we were doing a due diligence scan of the sector.
As part of our review last year of the sale of SLV, another lighting company.
One of our German network contacts knew the company and was able to make an introduction that led directly to an entirely off-market transaction.
Lampenwelt is already highly profitable and generates lots of cash.
So I have little doubt, that it will become one of our highest growing companies very quickly.
As I said a minute ago, we are also seeing a good level of Bolt-on activity across the portfolio.
Ponroy has the potential to become another important platform asset for 3i.
And ERSA is another important step on that journey.
Now I'd like to turn to the portfolio.
We've raised GBP 350 million, 2.
7x cost on realizations in the first half.
And we move into the second half with a number of important processes in train.
As long as markets remain resilient, we expect to raise significantly more cash from refinancings and realizations in the second half.
Here is the investment bucket slide that we've been showing you for the last few years.
And as you can see, the top 2 buckets continue to dominate the makeup of the portfolio.
Basic-Fit continues to grow strongly as a public company and Refresco is now subject to take private bid from PAI.
Now what about Infrastructure? They produced another good half with a strong performance from 3iN, good levels of cash income for the group and a number of important new fund initiatives.
The 3iN portfolio with its recent core plus additions is performing strongly and several of its larger core assets are now undergoing strategic reviews.
The return for 3i's shareholders on the 3iN June 2006 equity placing is now at a very respectable 22%.
And we've made our first move into U.
Infrastructure.
With the announcement of our acquisition of Smarte Carte.
Smarte Carte is the leading provider of airport baggage carts and self-storage lockers across the U.
Infra team is already performing well and they are coming up with a good flow of interesting investment ideas.
We intend to fund Infrastructure investment in the U.
, initially from our own balance sheet with a view to deploying third-party capital in due course.

So with a total return of 11% and over GBP 500 million of new investment completed, we closed the period with an NAV per share of 652p.
You can see here, how we generated that 652p of NAV.
The 61p of strong performance from our portfolio companies.
We've got more of this contribution from FX of 6p.
And that compares to about 30p this time last year and we paid our final dividend of 18.
5p in July.
For those of you, who are interested in the quarter-on-quarter movement, there is a bridge in the back of the pack, but the shape is pretty much the same.
Our Private Equity business was the biggest contributor to our returns, generating GBP 715 million of gross investment return.
Realized profits of GBP 53 million on GBP 350 million of proceeds, with an uplift on opening book value of 21%.
Those realized profits came mainly from the sales of Mmora, the Spanish funeral services provider and ticas Carol, our last Brazilian investment.
This was a strong half with good performance from Action, Scandlines and our more recent investments, which together contributed to the GBP 517 million value growth.
When you add the GBP 500 million of new investments, as Simon just talked about, the portfolio is now valued at GBP 5.
7 billion and that's up from GBP 4.
8 billion at the start of the period.
Over 90% of the portfolio by value, has grown earnings and this is the profile of earnings of our top 20 investments.
Action has had another excellent period, but as you can see, it has moved from the 30% plus bar to the 29% bar this time.
And that's reflected the company's investment in its growth agenda, particularly in its distribution centers and logistics.
The growing contribution that we're getting from the investments we have made since the change in our strategy is also important.
They make up all of the company's in the greater than 30% category, and the rest of the greater than 20% category.
Together with Action, these were the biggest contributors to the GBP 283 million of performance in the value growth analysis that you can see here.
Now as you know, we tend to use multiples based on longer-term sector averages.
If we think that the current multiples in the comparable companies have expanded well ahead of longer-term sector trends.
In a couple of cases, we've reviewed our investments position relative to these longer-term averages and the concepts.
And we again moved these multiples up to reflect their performance.
This time, we've done that for a small number of assets, including AES and Etanco.
This was not substantial re-ratings, but they do largely explain the GBP 59 million movement here.
We have made no change to the multiple that we use to value Action, which remains at 16x post discount run rate.
These changes to multiples have flowed through the weighted average multiple, for those assets that we valued on an earnings basis.
And it also includes the effect of some of the investments made in the period, such as Lampenwelt and Cirtec, which were in higher rated sectors.
As a result, the weighted average has increased from 9.
9x post discount at March to 10.
Turning then to our Infrastructure business.
Just to remind you, the significant majority of our investment return currently comes from our 34% investment in 3iN, which announced its results, last week.
Our team have also raised 2 new funds, the 3i managed Infrastructure acquisitions fund and the 3i European operations projects fund.
So far, these funds have added GBP 830 million to our assets under management and we have committed GBP 69 million to those funds.
And as you have just heard, our U.
Infrastructure team have announced their first new investment since the period end.
Because of these new initiatives don't have a material impact on the numbers for our Infrastructure business in the first half.
So the gross investment return of GBP 32 million comes mainly from the good share price performance of 3iN.
Together with its dividend income, and the fee income from our associated advisory agreement.
This income means our Infrastructure business is already a good contributor to operating cash income.
As expected, our cash costs exceeded our cash income by GBP 16 million in the first half.
Because we no longer have the income from the Debt Management business.
But that measure will also be improved by Infrastructure's fundraising initiatives.
So this has been a good half or 3iN in terms of performance, but importantly, also in terms of investment.
We were net investors in the period as we saw a good number of attractive investments opportunities.
In total, we have invested GBP 572 million, all funded from our strong balance sheet.
And we realized GBP 374 million from Private Equity and from the residual Debt Management business.
We started the year with net cash of GBP 419 million, and liquidity of GBP 1.

After the investments on realization activity that we've been talking about, and paying the final dividend, we have net debt of GBP 48 million and liquidity of GBP 877 million at the 30th of September.

Looking forward to the remainder of the year and of course, subject to the usual caveats about market conditions, with a strong pipeline of realizations, we expect the profile of investments and realizations to reverse in the second half compared to the first half.
We'll also be paying our interim dividend in the second half.
So to remind you about our dividend policy.
We pay a base dividend of 16p, half of which is paid as an interim and half as a final.
We'll also pay an additional dividend with the final.
We set the amounts of that additional dividend by taking account, of our outlook for investments and realizations and the strength of our balance sheet.
You'll be familiar with this slide, which shows the distribution to shareholders are a fundamental part of our capital allocation model.
So, our portfolio continues to perform well and we've made some excellent new investments, which means we are well positioned to deliver continued growth.
