Good morning.
Welcome to 3i's results presentation.
It's been another strong half for 3i, with our strategy driving good levels of activity and solid returns.
We took another good step forward in portfolio performance, and we sold assets at decent uplifts.
And our Private Equity team made significant new investments like Hans Anders in Holland and Formel D in Germany.
And we had a strong fundraising performance in Infrastructure.
This has delivered another strong financial result with a total return of 11% in the half.

This table throws up an interesting perspective not only against the restructuring baseline in 2012, but this 6-month return equals our full year return in 2015, underlying the strong, consistent year-on-year value growth of our portfolio.
And we've entered the second half of the year with good momentum across both divisions.
Again, the portfolio has performed well this year, but I'm also glad to see a good level of new investment in Private Equity.
Our Private Equity team has delivered an excellent return, with a GIR of 15%.
91% of our top 20 assets grew their earnings in the first half, and that's another good indication of the quality of our portfolio.
And we made over GBP 0.
5 billion of new investments, as well as doing some significant bolt-on acquisitions.
Our portfolio has performed well and delivered decent growth across-the-board with very few write-downs.
Apart from Action, the strongest growth has come from those companies we've invested in since our restructuring.
And that relatively young 2013-16 portfolio has already delivered 1.
9x costs in value growth so far.
Action continues to perform strongly.
For financial reporting, Action uses 13 periods, or 4 weeks, and the numbers in our interims are taken from their period 9, which finished on the 10th of September.
Action had opened 111 new stores by that date and is on track to open more than 230 stores by the end of 2017.
As of yesterday, Action had opened 192 stores and now has a total of 1,044.
So that's a significant step up from last year and a major ramp up in this quarter in particular.

That's an ambitious growth initiative, and even after significant levels of new investment in stores, distribution centers, country offices and central functions, like for likes and cash flow remain very strong.
Without increasing Action's multiple, we've seen GBP 0.
5 billion of value growth in the last 12 months alone.
And the major store expansion program in this final quarter will create further significant momentum for 3i's second half valuation.
We've produced a marked step-up in our origination activity this year.
Origination has always been a great strength of 3i.
The group led the PE Sector in establishing a European network of offices in the '80s and '90s.
And now that we have dealt with most of our legacy issues, our investment teams have been freed up to focus on origination against some tight and carefully considered criteria.
That change of focus means a good share of our recent investments have been sourced directly, away from competitive bank-driven auction processes.
This chart puts this year's activity in context.
We've invested about GBP 2 billion of capital since our restructuring, but half of that GBP 2 billion has been invested over the last 15 months alone.
In addition, we enter the second half with a strong pipeline of new and follow-on investment activity.
I'd now like to touch on a couple of our recent investments.
Cirtec was our most recent investment.
Like Q Holding's, it operates in the medical device sector, and like Q, Cirtec is capable of being a platform asset that will combine strong levels of organic growth with M&A.
3i's international credentials were particularly useful in convincing the CEO that we were the right partner for his ambitious plans.
I'm very excited about our investment in Lampenwelt, which is the largest specialty online retailer of lighting products in Europe.
The business was started in Germany in 2004 by 2 brothers, who were both electrical engineers.
Lampenwelt is a classic online disruptive retailer.
It already operates in 14 European markets and is planning to selectively expand its geographic footprint further across Europe.
We spotted the business when we were doing a due diligence scan of the sector as part of our review last year of the sale of SLV, another lighting company.
One of our German network contacts knew the company and was able to make an introduction that led directly to an entirely off-market transaction.
Lampenwelt is already highly profitable and generates lots of cash.
So I have little doubt that it will become one of our highest growing companies very quickly.
As I said a minute ago, we're also seeing a good level of bolt-on activity across the portfolio.
Ponroy has the potential to become another important platform asset for 3i.
And ERSA is another important step on that journey.
Now I'd like to turn to the portfolio.
We've raised GBP 350 million at 2.
7x cost on realizations in the first half.
And we move into the second half with a number of important processes in train.
As long as markets remain resilient, we expect to raise significantly more cash from refinancings and realizations in the second half.
Here's the investment bucket slide that we've been showing you for the last few years.
And as you can see, the top 2 buckets continue to dominate the makeup of the portfolio.
Basic-Fit continues to grow strongly as a public company, and Refresco is now subject to a take private bid from PAI.
Now what about Infrastructure? They produced another good half, with a strong performance from 3iN, good levels of cash income for the group and a number of important new fund initiatives.
The 3iN portfolio, with its recent core plus additions, is performing strongly, and several of its larger core assets are now undergoing strategic reviews.
The return for 3i's shareholders on the 3iN June 2006 equity placing is now at a very respectable 22%.
And we've made our first move into U.
Infrastructure with the announcement of our acquisition of Smarte Carte.
Smarte Carte is the leading provider of airport baggage carts and self-storage lockers across the U.
Infra team is already performing well, and they are coming up with a good flow of interesting investment ideas.
We intend to fund Infrastructure investments in the U.
initially from our own balance sheet, with a view to deploying third-party capital in due course.

So another good half for 3i, with the Private Equity and the Infrastructure teams producing good levels of alpha in their respective sectors, as well as significant income for the group from Infrastructure.
Today, our portfolios are producing excellent returns, and we now have only a small number of underperformers.
Importantly, the macro-economic environment across our chosen geographies and sectors is better than it has been for some time, even if the politics remains very, very tricky.

Technology advances and globalization are both having a greater and greater impact on every commercial sector, and we remain very focused on buying companies that can thrive in this fast-changing environment.
Without that competitive edge or resilience, companies across many different sectors are facing formidable and accelerating challenges.
So testing a company's readiness for the -- for and resilience in the face of rapid digital change is an essential part of our pre-investment reviews.
Our teams are energized about what they are doing.
And they are setting high standards in international mid-market investing.
And we are already benefiting from consistent investment processes and discipline.
In fact, I am really struck by how much simpler we have made our business and our investment portfolio and how much more straightforward it is to focus and set the right priorities across the group.
We enter the second half with good earnings momentum and a good pipeline of new investments and business initiatives.
On our current portfolio, it looks like it should generate returns significantly better than our 2x target.
I'll now pass over to Julia.
Philip? We look at a variety of things.
You know that automotive often features prominently.
I think I mentioned disruptive retailing is another sector we're looking very closely at.
We've had a bit of a leaner time on, if you like, b2B businesses like we're looking harder a number of those, just 1 or 2 interesting opportunities in the space.
I don't know if they will happen, but we're certainly looking at a bunch of things.
So it's the same themes that we're planning to do.
There's no change in that.
Do you have a question? I mean, yes, you're right, we did signal -- I mean, about this time last year, we had quite a lot of lower growth in the portfolio ex Action.
I think at that time, that was particularly the impact of some of the weaker assets that we've talked about previously, so the Dynatects of this world and some of that the retailers.

But what we're seeing now in the portfolio ex Action is the benefit of the new investments that we've done coming through their first phase of ownership and starting to really flow through into the earnings growth.
So we've talked -- I'm not going to name all of the companies that are in the different bars, but we've talked about the good earnings growth that we've seen in the likes Audley with a strong U.
performance but also a growing U.
For example, ATESTEO, you've seen some refinancing this year, so that's also performing strongly.

So for the average ex Action is always going to go up and down a little bit, especially when you got a smaller number of companies, so it's going to be very -- it's [indiscernible] to what's happening in a particular period.
But I think what we're trying to show today is our confidence in the portfolio, ex Action.
And then clearly, we have this fantastic asset on top of that as well.
On the multiple, I mean, we're content where we are in the valuation today.
As I said, we're trying to balance a number of factors, but we continue to keep it under review.
The business is obviously performing extremely well.
And you saw from the slide that Simon put up the potential for future growth.
So I wouldn't view the 16 as fixed, but I wouldn't want to try and formula in some sort of rate of improvement or increase in that.
I think if you step back and looked at the information that we have, what's occurred really is this year was a very busy year in terms of realizations early on.
So a lot of that realization occurred in the first half.
And it's tidied, up on top of the previous 4 years, the portfolio considerably.
And therefore, what we're seeing is our teams devoting much, much more of their time to origination.
And therefore, the wheat bucket, as we call it, being much fuller.

And the ability for us to look across quite a good population of assets and to determine the ones that which we wish to pursue and that's not only about the investment thesis in the business but how we think we'll do in competition with others if there is competition and whether ultimately, we'll be able to buy the price that we're comfortable with.
So there's quite a lot of judgments to how you managed that whip down.

But it's really starting from the fact that the smaller more manageable portfolio that has got less things going wrong a bit, we can spend a lot more time originating, and therefore, we're getting into a better rhythm in terms of investments, and it gives us the position to make choices over what we do, which is very important.
Chris? Well, I mean, we consider that position carefully.
We debate it within the Investment Committee.
We debate it within the board.
There are some voices that said if we could have 100% of our assets in Action, we should.
And there are others who are more cautious about the waiting.
But I think we're a long way from where we'll be uncomfortable with how much we are on Action.

The other question I had was on, what industries you're looking at in terms of foreign investments? Any particular thing that sort of any industrial subsector that pops to mind? There is an opportunity to extend that with the agreements with the LPs for another year, so till the end of '19.
We obviously haven't come to an agreement to that yet, but that's an important decision for the next year.
Adedapo Oguntade from Morgan Stanley.
Just 3 questions here.
So one, in terms of your investment for FY '18, it's close to EUR 500 million now.
What's your guidance but he much for the rest of the year? So you're also looking at European assets.
It's down to 37 assets at the [indiscernible] moment by moment.
The last few years, you've had a situation of pretty much net realizations of your investments.
Going forward, what should we expect? And then the last question, this comes to Action.
Given your long-term growth potential in Action and the earnings performance, so whitespace available, do think it's going to be better to apply in this year? Yes.
I mean, you don't get absolute complete uniformity across store performance.
But in some of these new countries and certainly in parts of France, we experienced better store economics than we experienced in Holland.
And in certain parts of Germany, we experienced less good economics than we first experienced in Holland.

But we find that as the knowledge about Action and the brand becomes greater, as it has done very quickly in France because we've been able to open more source more quickly, the economics moved up to the Holland economics and even surpassed them.
And we suspect the same will be true in Germany as the brand awareness builds up over time.
Austria is probably ahead of Holland, as another example to that mix in terms of store economics.
It's Philip Middleton from Merrill Lynch.

I wonder if you could say of the bit more about what you see happening in investments because if I were to criticize what you've been doing until fairly recently, the net investment rate is relatively slow compared to where it needed to be on a steady-state basis.
It seems to be kind of a more steady state now.

Is that something you think is sustainable as you redeploy stuff in that area? How do you see the investment landscape, the opportunities set? Just more generally, how do you feel about the sort of outtrade at the moment? Good morning, everyone.
Welcome to 3i's Results for the Year to 31st of March 2017.
As anticipated, and most of you will have seen, it's been another strong year for 3i with good results across-the-board, and we have a clear and consistent strategy.
So how did we do over the last 12 months? We closed the year with a 36% return on equity, an NAV of 604p and increased dividend of 26.
5p for the year.
Both Private Equity and Infrastructure performed well, with good levels of new investment and strong portfolio performances.
And we completed the sale of our Debt Management division in March.
The sale simplifies the group and focuses our people and resources on 2 high-quality businesses.
Realizations for the year were very strong, with almost GBP 1 billion from Private Equity and a further GBP 270 million from the sale of Debt Management.
3i is now performing as it should, and the approach we've taken over the last 5 years has transformed the group on all key KPIs.
Today's results are built on the sound fundamentals that we have put in place, and the numbers don't tell the full story.

The portfolio value number is considerably larger, but just as importantly, our portfolio today is made up of a smaller set of stronger, cleaner companies with much better earnings and value momentum.
So I've broken my presentation down into 4 parts, with one part being Action, but I'd like to start with Private Equity.
We still have a dry powder issue in this sector, and it's even bigger today than this time last year.
Most of this dry powder is in the mega funds, but those of us in the midmarket still have to maintain the discipline we have demonstrated over the last 5 years.
And we've got to continue looking for opportunities away from broad-based options as we successfully did this year.
Our PE team had a great year.
They delivered a 43% return, a good level of exciting new investments as well as GBP 1 billion of realizations.
So a good harvest, but some quality seed sown for the future.
Earnings and value growth have both accelerated across our Private Equity portfolio, with our larger Bucket 1 investments continuing to make a major contribution.
The performance from our 1316 vintage has been particularly strong, and we have seen much less value reduction this year.
Our 1316 vintage is still a relatively immature portfolio, and yet it kicked in at 29% return for the year.
Of course, there are 1 or 2 weak spots, but in general, we have seen really solid growth right across the portfolio.
At the interims, I mentioned the problems of Agent Provocateur where accounting irregularities had concealed the true financial position of the company and its lack of liquidity.
As you know, we were not able to sort out the problems, and the company went into an administration process in March.
This resulted in a GBP 49 million write-off for 3i.
Moving on, our investments since 2013 are performing well, with the 1316 vintage already at 1.
And the new investments of the last 12 months, BoConcept, Schlemmer, Ponroy Sant are already making a promising contribution.
The investments we've made since financial year '13, including the ones we've recently announced, now total about GBP 2 billion.
These new assets will underpin significant gains going forward, especially if we beat our minimum 2x target.
And we've entered this year with strong new investment momentum with the purchase of Lampenwelt, Hans Anders and Formel D.
These 3 new investments are all in our sweet spot.
Two disruptive retailers and a B2B German service business focused on the automotive sector.
It's been another strong year of realizations and refinancings.
As I said a minute ago, the makeup of our Private Equity portfolio has been transformed by careful purchases and by the sale of many of our weaker legacy assets.
We are now down to 37 companies.
That's a net reduction of close to 100 over that 5-year period, and Buckets 1 and 2 now account for 86% of total value.
That means that our investment teams are spending much more time on origination.
And rather than waiting for the next bank auction, they're approaching companies directly and initiating bilateral discussions.
This approach is leading to good quality new investments.
In fact, both Ponroy and Lampenwelt are great examples of what I mean, and I'm quietly confident that they will be good assets for 3i.
Now what about Action? The company continues to surpass all normal expectations.
Action has really brought home to me the power of compounding.
Whether you look at sales, number of stores or EBITDA, the returns this company generates off a larger and larger base are exceptional.
When you combine all these positive factors with strong like-for-likes and sector-leading cash generation, you benefit from an outstanding returns on capital.
And I don't think we're anywhere near the peak for Action.
Although it's increasing the number of stores it opens every year, it is barely scratching the surface of how big it can become.

As you can see from this chart, store densities in Holland suggest that there's considerable whitespace opportunity in just France and Germany alone, and that's before we even consider the Rest of Europe.
As I've said before, an Action store appeals to customers wherever we have opened them.

Action is part of that very exclusive set of retailers that have one format that works across borders in different retail environments and is, therefore, are capable of achieving very significant scale.
Now at 3i, we have a small but very brainy strategy team.
And when they're not helping Julia sell our debt business, I ask them to look at things for me.
Earlier this year, I asked them to think of themselves as specialist fund managers, focusing on retail stocks and to come up with a 5 or 6 stocks they would have in their top bucket.
After lots of late nights and too much coffee and chocolate, they came up with this analysis.

They have picked Inditex, Dollarama, Five Below, XXL and B&M, a real mix of shapes and sizes, but if you're holding this portfolio, you probably wouldn't be too concerned by the current challenges in the High Street.
As you can see, these companies produce good metrics across all the important KPIs.
But the really interesting thing is, if you transpose Action's numbers onto this slide, you get a good perspective on the relative quality of the Action growth story.
And none of these 5 stocks has anything like the whitespace potential of Action.
I really enjoy being on the Action board.
It has a first-class executive team and a very wise Chairman in Adrian Bellamy.
Expansion on this scale produces its own type of challenges, which are really fascinating.
And the board is very involved in helping management maintain these strong growth rates while trying to avoid any high-speed problems.
And by the way, the Action compounding effect I mentioned earlier is very material for 3i.
Okay, enough about Action for today, except to say that I look forward to seeing you again at our day with Action management on the 30th of May.
Now let's turn to Infrastructure, where the market backdrop is no different.

There's significant dry powder and a lot of interest in this sector, which makes it all the more satisfying that our team delivered a very productive year, both expanding 3iN's portfolio and raising 2 new funds.
The team produces growing asset management income for the group as well as managing investment for 3iN, which in turn has produced very solid capital growth and dividends.

3iN is our main infrastructure investment vehicle, but we have added some discrete fund initiatives in order to capitalize on 3i's broader network and capabilities and to strengthen the overall team in Infrastructure.
These new initiatives are in their early stages, but we expect them to grow over time and build on the income contribution of Infrastructure to the group.
Apart from investing in our Infrastructure capability and adding selectively to our PE investment team, we're not considering any change in our strategic approach.

As I said right at the beginning, we will remain focused on executing our simple strategy while maintaining a disciplined approach to new investment in those sectors and geographies that we know well.
We'll also make the most of our Proprietary Capital.
That way, we can run our key winners and act more quickly and decisively when this helps secure new investment.
As you know, this is one of my favorite slides and illustrates what a powerful and efficient cash machine 3i has become.

We're getting better at finding new investment opportunities at sensible prices, and we have established the right processes and portfolio to deliver plenty of cash to reinvest and to distribute to shareholders.
Today, we have proposed a material increased our additional dividend to reflect the strength of the group and the momentum we have in the business going forward.
Don't assume we'll keep up this level of increase every year, but we are a group that is certainly capable of very attractive cash distributions over time.
This is clearly a decent set of results, and I would like to thank each and every one at 3i for their contribution this year.
Many of our people have experienced harsher times, but everybody has worked really hard to secure this type of performance.
But there is no complacency at 3i.
We recognize that the macro is better but still finally balanced as well as there being potential for more political uncertainty.

Our people see the value in our processes and discipline, and as a result, have become better at finding, assessing and managing investments, and I would say our teams are as good as any in their respective markets.

As you come to expect, we remain very careful about the cost of our platform, and the Investment Committee maintains a fierce determination to resist those voices, encouraging us to pay more than a given business might be worth.
So another decent year where our all-around performance should add to that body of evidence which will help investors properly assess 3i's longer-term potential.
I'll pass over to Julia.
So as you've heard from Simon, we've had an excellent year, the strong performance from both our Private Equity and Infrastructure businesses.
We've been busy.
We've generated GBP 1 billion of proceeds from Private Equity, had a robust contribution from Infrastructure and simplified the group with the successful sale of our Debt Management business.
All in all, we finished the year with a total return of 36% and an NAV per share of 604p.
As you can see here, the biggest component of the 30% NAV increase was unrealized value growth.
Action accounted for 2/3 of the 138p, and we got strong contributions from our more recent investments that Simon has talked about.
That made up most of the rest.
The corresponding net carry payable of 16p includes the benefit of going through the hurdle on an accounting basis on Eurofund V.
I'll explain more about that in a minute.
We did have a tailwind from sterling's weakness of 30p, but our results are strong with or without that FX benefit.
Finally, the 24p of dividends is made up of last year's final dividend and this year's interim, so the 604p is before the final dividend of 18.
5p that we've announced today.
Our Private Equity business had a great year, and they generated a gross investment return of GBP 1.
That's a 43% return on opening portfolio value, and I'll talk about the main drivers of that in a minute.
It was a very good year for realizations, with 12 full disposals and a number of refinancings and partial realizations, generating GBP 982 million of proceeds.

The uplift to sale of 5%, which excludes refinancings, reflects Mayborn and Amor being valued an imminent sale basis last year, along with the proceeds of quoted sales where we don't normally expect a material uplift.
Needless to say, the GBP 49 million loss on Agent Provocateur also affected this measure.
The closing Private Equity portfolio value was GBP 4,8 billion.
As well as the unrealized value growth, we made good progress on new investment.
The GBP 478 million you can see here includes our new investments in Schlemmer, BoConcept and Ponroy Sant as well as the funding for our existing U.
investments, Q Holding, to make their own investments in Degania.
As you've already heard, that unrealized value growth of GBP 1.
3 billion is underpinned by strong earnings growth.
The earnings growth of our top 20 investments, which account for 91% of the Private Equity portfolio value, are shown here.
Of course, Action is part of the greater than 30% bar, but that bar also includes another 4 investments.
17 of these 20 investments have positive earnings growth.
Now before I get into the usual slide on valuations, I'd like to give you some more detail about what we've done to update Action's valuation methodology.
You've seen from Simon's presentation that we think there's still plenty of upside in our investment case.
That presents a problem, the so-called nice problem to have, when we think about how we arrive at the fair value of Action in our books today.
We have to balance Action's exceptional performance and execution, its potential for significant further growth and the inherent risk in continuing to execute at this velocity.
We moved our valuation basis to run rate earnings instead of the last 12 months, or LTM, in march 2013.
The relentless consistency of Action's still rollout gave us the confidence to effectively pro forma in 12 months of new stores opened in the year.
Until now, we've used the run rate earnings to the preceding quarter.
That means, for example, using earnings to the 31st of December for a 31st of March valuation.
Every year since we made the change, Action has outperformed expectations.
That doesn't mean we can go as far as moving the valuation to DCF basis that some people are talking about.
But to recognize our competence in the performance and execution, we're now using earnings that are as close to our period-end as we can.
That means we based this evaluation on Action's earnings to the end of March 2017.
Since the third-party interest in our investment in June last year when we stepped up our valuation to GBP 1.
5 billion, we have let the multiple fall as Action's earnings have grown.
Now that we've had another year of excellent performance, we've had another look at the multiple, and we've set it to 16x post discount at the 31st of March.
As a result, Action's total value growth in the year was GBP 911 million.
And just over 3/4 of that was down to earnings growth, which is a large part of the GBP 827 million performance category for the whole portfolio, which you can see here.
Other material contributors to that performance category are ATESTEO, Euro-Diesel and Audley.
Excluding Action, there was a modest decline in the average multiples we used from 10.
We continue to apply our policy of adjusting multiples down relative to their concept if we think that markets have got ahead of our longer-term view.
14 out of 22 investments were adjusted that way.
The DCF category is dominated by our investment in Scandlines, and the increase that you can see here reflects our view that the competing fixed link will be delayed by another 2 years.
Our strong portfolio performance is also reflected in our carry payable and receivable, which we calculate assuming that all investments were sold at their balance sheet value.

As I mentioned at the half year, the excellent performance of Action and also Scandlines meant that Eurofund V went through the carrying receivable hurdle earlier this year, and that's almost all of the GBP 275 million that you can see here.

The carry payable of GBP 431 million is a product of the same excellent performance, and it also includes the accrual for the proportion of the carry receivable that will also be paid out to the participating investment teams.
Now I always make the point that the carry accrued is only paid out when the hurdle has been met on a cash-to-cash basis and then only when cash proceeds are actually received.
We went through the cash hurdle on schemes covering our investments made in 2010, '11 and '12 as a result of the Amor disposal.
That's the main reason for the step-up in cash we paid out this year to GBP 127 million.
Now it's clear that the excellent performance in Private Equity is the biggest contributor to our capital returns.
Infrastructure complements and diversifies that because they are the principal contributor to our income returns.
And the steps we've taken to grow the Infrastructure business, which Simon has talked about, should enhance that contribution.
We reinforced our support for this business and our belief in our team's ability to originate and manage good investments in the sector by standing behind 3iN's capital raise in June.
We invested GBP 131 million to maintain our 34% shareholding in 3iN.
That was a sound decision.
We, our team, have already deployed the capital raise in 6 new investments, and 3iN's share price has increased by 15% since the capital raise.
As a result, 3iN had a very good year, and that's reflected in our GBP 87 million of gross investment return.
You can also see here that our Infrastructure business is a significant contributor to our recurring fee income and cash income.
As I mentioned, the new initiatives 3i have announced should increase their contribution further.
And this is all the more important following our sale of the Debt Management business, which we completed on the 3rd of March 2017.
Selling that business will put pressure on our operating cash profit metric.
However, with the fundamental reshaping of the cost base, good progress in Private Equity and new initiatives in Infrastructure, we will keep it as a measure to reinforce our cost discipline.
That discipline remains relevant as we make incremental investment in new people in both Private Equity and Infrastructure to support investment activity and new initiatives.
Operating costs were GBP 117 million in the financial year 2017 without Debt Management.
GBP 63 million of this was incurred in the second half, and we expect our cost in financial year 2018 to be about double that second half expense.
In March, we took a further step in derisking the balance sheet with the repayment of our 331 million Eurobond.
Gross debt is now only GBP 575 million, with an annual interest cost of GBP 35 million, which is down by about GBP 15 million.
We closed the year with net cash of GBP 419 million, but as you know, most of this is now reserved for the recently announced investments in Lampenwelt, Hans Anders and Formel D.
Altogether, they account about EUR 500 million of investment, which is a good start to the year.
And with liquidity of GBP 1.
3 billion, we are well-funded for this new investment and distributions to shareholders.
We've announced a final dividend of 18.
5p, subject to shareholder approval.
5p is made up of the final base dividend of 8p and an additional dividend of 10.
That additional dividend takes account of the balance sheet strength, our outlook for realizations and investments and also recognizes that this has been an excellent year.

So this has been another good year for 3i, and our results have been underpinned by strategic progress in reshaping the business, excellent performance from Private Equity and a very good year for the Infrastructure team.
Thank you, and we'll now take questions.
Charles Murphy, Panmure Gordon.
Eurofund V comes to an end at the end of -- technically at the end of 2018.

How does -- what opportunities are there for you to extend that the bit further? And how does that affect how you think about Action and Scandlines? Why don't I take the first 2, and Julia can come back to the third because she did touch on in her presentation.
I mean, we've had an unusually strong start I would say to the liquidity of investments it's a bit like catching a bus, and so we have signed quite a few deals in a short space of time.
There's outlook the no guarantee that the rest of your will continue at that pace.
And I would expect it to moderate and for us to be more careful.
But I do think we will invest more money this year than we have previously and get closer to our sort of run rate of investment around GBP 700 million, GBP 750 million, if you like.
In terms of realizations, it's early in the year.

There are things moving forward, but I would again expect between realizations and refis, we'll get closer to our normal level, which is around the GBP 750 million, GBP 800 million type level if markets remain conducive to that.
There's a number of things going through.
I think of the order of about GBP 100 million is sort of coming in over the recent weeks.
It's that sort of things in smaller, smaller initiatives.
And there are 1 or 2 big things beginning to move along in terms of realizations.
Chris Brown from JPMorgan.
Just a quick question about post year-end events.
I mean, clearly, there's been a lot of investment.
You've got the dividend to come out.
Has there been much realization since the 31st of March? Arun from Macquarie.
Can just I ask, you sort of have the map of Action and you sort of looked at the whitespaces.

What gives you so much confidence of the whitespace probably France and Germany's almost alike in terms of revenue potential? Or even if you extend that across Europe, what giving the whitespace or same in terms of property as you would see in sort of the Holland or the old places Action did so well? Perhaps you could also talk a little bit about how when the board is looking at Action and the fact it's 30% of NAV, how do you think about -- in terms sort of risk versus order of that situation? And then on the DCF, I said what we're trying to balance is fantastic performance to date, big potential for future growth, but also there's inherent risk in sort of rolling out the way they're doing the execution that we've got.
And for that reason, when we wouldn't move it to a DCF basis in our books.
DCF is a very good preference point, especially to the extent people get concerned about the multiple that we're applying, that gives a sort of confidence in how we're looking at that.
I think what we try to do is to give you as much visibility of how we're valuing it.
So to give you all the components the multiple we use, you'll also find in the press release, we're giving you the sensitivities.
So 1 turn on the multiple will be GBP 135 million on our value, so you can measure it from that perspective.
But I think DCF is definitely got its place, and it's definitely good preference point.
But I don't imagine is moving to that method anytime soon.
Daniel Garrod from Barclays.
A couple of questions from me.
First is on earnings growth trajectory.
Julia, I think last year you sort of commented on experiencing a sort of trough in earnings growth profile and the expectation that it becoming resurgent from there.
You've got a slide where you're showing sort of, obviously the Action asset growing more than 30% but about GBP 650 million of value, also growing more than 30%.

So did you see that being sustained, the sort of improvement in earnings momentum? Can you give any color around those sort of 4 assets that you detailed as being in that sort of GBP 650 million? What are they? And what's the sort of sustainability there? Second question was around the multiple of Action.

How -- it actually continues to grow more than 30% a year, how you think about the interplay between revaluing it up to 18x, again growing into the multiple or maintaining at 16x? We'll have Morgan Stanley do that for us.
If there are no more questions, thanks very much for coming.
Have a good day.
We'll have Morgan Stanley do that for us.
So as you've heard from Simon, we've had an excellent year with strong performance from both our Private Equity and Infrastructure businesses.
We've been busy.
We've generated GBP 1 billion of proceeds from Private Equity, had a robust contribution from Infrastructure and simplified the group with the successful sale of our Debt Management business.
All in all, we finished the year with a total return of 36% and an NAV per share of 604p.
As you can see here, the biggest component of our -- of the 30% NAV increase was unrealized value growth.
Action accounted for 2/3 of the 138p.
And we got strong contributions from our more recent investments that Simon has talked about.
That made up most of the rest.
The corresponding net carry payable of 16p includes the benefit of going through the hurdle on an accounting basis on Eurofund V.
I'll explain more about that in a minute.
We did have a tailwind from sterling's weakness of 30p, but our results are strong with or without that FX benefit.
Finally, the 24p of dividends is made up of last year's final dividend and this year's interim, so the 604p is before the final dividend of 18.
5p that we've announced today.
Our Private Equity business had a great year, and they generated a gross investment return of GBP 1.
That's a 43% return on opening portfolio value, and I'll talk about the main drivers of that in a minute.
It was a very good year for realizations with 12 full disposals and a number of refinancings and partial realizations, generating GBP 982 million of proceeds.

The uplift to sale of 5%, which excludes refinancings, reflects Mayborn and Amor being valued on an imminent-sale basis last year, along with the proceeds of quoted sales where we don't normally expect a material uplift.
Needless to say the GBP 49 million loss on Agent Provocateur also affected this measure.
The closing Private Equity portfolio value was GBP 4.
As well as the unrealized value growth, we made good progress on new investments.
The GBP 478 million you can see here includes our new investments in Schlemmer, BoConcept and Ponroy Sant; as well as the funding for our existing U.
investment, Q Holding, to make them -- to make their own investment in Degania.
As you've already heard, that unrealized value growth of GBP 1.
3 billion is underpinned by strong earnings growth.
The earnings growth of our top 20 investments, which account for 91% of the Private Equity portfolio value, are shown here.
Of course, Action is part of the "greater than 30%" bar, but that bar also includes another 4 investments.
17 of these 20 investments have positive earnings growth.
Now before I get on to the usual slide on valuations, I'd like to give you some more detail about what we've done to update Action's valuation methodology.
You've seen from Simon's presentation that we think there's still plenty of upside in our investment case.
That presents a problem, a so-called nice problem to have, when we think about how we arrive at the fair value of Action in our books today.
We have to balance Action's exceptional performance and execution, its potential for significant further growth and the inherent risk in continuing to execute at this velocity.
We moved our valuation basis to run rate earnings instead of the last 12 months or LTM in March 2013.
The relentless consistency of Action store rollout gave us the confidence to effectively pro forma in 12 months of new stores opened in the year.
Until now, we've used the run rate earnings to the preceding quarter.
That means, for example, using earnings to the 31st of December for a 31st of March valuation.
Every year since we made the change, Action has outperformed expectations.

That doesn't mean we can go as far as moving the valuation to a DCF basis that some people are talking about, but to recognize our competence in the performance and execution, we're now using earnings that are as close to our period end as we can.
That means we based this evaluation on Action's earnings to the end of March 2017.
Since the third-party interest in our investment in June last year when we stepped up our valuation to GBP 1.
5 billion, we have let the multiple fall, as Action's earnings have grown.
Now that we've had another year of excellent performance, we've had another look at the multiple, and we've set it to 16x post discount at the 31st of March.
As a result, Action's total value growth in the year was GBP 911 million.
And just over 3/4 of that was down to earnings growth, which is a large part of the GBP 827 million performance category for the whole portfolio, which you can see here.
Other material contributors to that performance category are ATESTEO, EURO-DIESEL and Audley.
Excluding Action, there was a modest decline in the average multiples we used from 10.
We continue to apply our policy of adjusting multiples down relative to their concepts if we think that markets have got ahead of our longer-term view.
14 out of 22 investments were adjusted that way.
The DCF category is dominated by our investment in Scandlines.
And the increase that you can see here reflects our view that the competing fixed link will be delayed by another 2 years.
Our strong portfolio performance is also reflected in our carry payable and receivable, which we calculate assuming that all investments were sold at their balance sheet value.

As I mentioned at the half year, the excellent performance of Action and also Scandlines meant that Eurofund V went through the carry receivable hurdle earlier this year, and that's almost all of the GBP 275 million that you can see here.
The carry payable of GBP 431 million is a product of the same excellent performance.
And it also includes the accrual for the proportion of the carry receivable that will also be paid out to the participating investment teams.
I always make the point that the carry accrued is only paid out when the hurdle has been met on a cash-to-cash basis and then only when cash proceeds are actually received.
We went through the cash hurdle on schemes covering our investments made in 2010, '11 and '12 as a result of the Amor disposal.
That's the main reason for the step-up in cash we paid out this year to GBP 127 million.
Now it's clear that the excellent performance from Private Equity is the biggest contributor to our capital returns.
Infrastructure complements and diversifies that because they are the principal contributor to our income returns.
And the steps we've taken to grow the Infrastructure business, which Simon has talked about, should enhance that contribution.
We reinforced our support for this business and our belief in our team's ability to originate and manage good investments in the sector by standing behind 3iN's capital raise in June.
We invested GBP 131 million to maintain our 34% shareholding in 3iN.
That was a sound decision.
We -- our team have already deployed the capital raise in 6 new investments.
And 3iN's share price has increased by 15% since the capital raise.
As a result, 3iN had a very good year, and that's reflected in our GBP 87 million of gross investment return.
You can also see here that our Infrastructure business is a significant contributor to our recurring fee income and cash income.
As I mentioned, the new initiatives we have announced should increase their contribution further.
And this is all the more important following our sale of the Debt Management business, which we completed on the 3rd of March 2017.
Selling that business will put pressure on our operating cash profit metric.
However, with the fundamental reshaping of the cost base, good progress in Private Equity and new initiatives in Infrastructure, we will keep it as a measure to reinforce our cost discipline.
That discipline remains relevant as we make incremental investments in new people in both Private Equity and Infrastructure to support investment activity and new initiatives.
Operating costs were GBP 117 million in the financial year 2017 without Debt Management.
GBP 63 million of this was incurred in the second half, and we expect our costs in financial year 2018 to be about double that second half expense.
In March, we took a further step in derisking the balance sheet with the repayment of our EUR 331 million bond.
Gross debt is now only GBP 575 million, with an annual interest cost of GBP 35 million which is down by about GBP 15 million.
We closed the year with net cash of GBP 419 million, but as you know, most of this is now reserved for the recently announced investments in Lampenwelt, Hans Anders and Formel D.
Altogether, they account for about EUR 500 million of investment, which is a good start to the year.
And with liquidity of GBP 1.
3 billion, we are well funded for these new investments and distributions to shareholders.
We've announced a final dividend of 18.
5p, subject to shareholder approval.
5p is made up of the final base dividend of 8p and an additional dividend of 10.
That additional dividend takes account of the balance sheet strength, our outlook for realizations and investments; and also recognizes that this has been an excellent year.
So it has been another good year for 3i.
And our results have been underpinned by strategic progress in reshaping the business, excellent performance from Private Equity and a very good year for the Infrastructure team.
Thank you, and we'll now take questions.
Good morning, everyone.
Welcome to 3i's results for the year till 31st of March 2017.
As anticipated and most of you will have seen, it's been another strong year for 3i with good results across-the-board, and we have a clear and consistent strategy.
So how did we do over the last 12 months? We closed the year with a 36% return on equity, an NAV of 604p and an increased dividend of 26.
5p for the year.
Both Private Equity and Infrastructure performed well with good levels of new investment and strong portfolio performances.
And we completed the sale of our Debt Management division in March.
The sale simplifies the group and focuses our people and resources on 2 high-quality businesses.
Realizations for the year were very strong with almost GBP 1 billion from Private Equity and a further GBP 270 million from the sale of Debt Management.
3i is now performing as it should, and the approach we've taken over the last 5 years has transformed the group on all key KPIs.
Today's results are built on the sound fundamentals that we have put in place.

And the numbers don't tell the full story: The portfolio value number is considerably larger, but just as importantly, our portfolio today is made up of a smaller set of stronger, cleaner companies with much better earnings and value momentum.
So I've broken my presentation down into 4 parts, with 1 part being Action, but I'd like to start with Private Equity.
We still have a dry powder issue in this sector, and it's even bigger today than this time last year.
Most of this dry powder is in the mega funds, but those of us in the midmarket still have to maintain the discipline we have demonstrated over the last 5 years.
And we've got to continue looking for opportunities away from broad-based auctions, as we successfully did this year.
Our PE team had a great year.
They delivered a 43% return; a good level of exciting, new investments; as well as GBP 1 billion of realizations, so a good harvest but some quality seed sown for the future.
Earnings and value growth have both accelerated across our Private Equity portfolio, with our larger Bucket 1 investments continuing to make a major contribution.
The performance from our '13, '16 vintage has been particularly strong, and we have seen much less value reduction this year.
Our '13, '16 vintage is still a relatively immature portfolio, and yet it kicked in a 29% return for the year.
Of course, there are 1 or 2 weak spots, but in general we have seen really solid growth right across the portfolio.
At the interims, I mentioned the problems of Agent Provocateur, where accounting irregularities had concealed the true financial position of the company and its lack of liquidity.
As you know, we were not able to sort out the problems, and the company went into an administration process in March.
This resulted in a GBP 49 million write-off for 3i.
Moving on, our investments since 2013 are performing well, with the '13, '16 vintage already at 1.
And the new investments of the last 12 months, BoConcept, Schlemmer, Ponroy Sant, are already making a promising contribution.
The investments we've made since financial year '13, including the ones we've recently announced, now total about GBP 2 billion.
These new assets will underpin significant gains going forward, especially if we beat our minimum 2x target.
And we've entered this year with strong new investment momentum with the purchase of Lampenwelt, Hans Anders and Formel D.
These 3 new investments are all in our sweet spot: 2 disruptive retailers and a B2B German service business focused on the automotive sector.
It's been another strong year of realizations and refinancings.
As I said a minute ago, the makeup of our Private Equity portfolio has been transformed by careful purchases and by the sale of many of our weaker legacy assets.
We are now down to 37 companies.
That's a net reduction of close to 100 over that 5-year period.
And Buckets 1 and 2 now account for 86% of total value.

That means that our investment teams are spending much more time on origination, and rather than waiting for the next bank auction, they're approaching companies directly and initiating bilateral discussions.
This approach is leading to good-quality, new investments.
In fact, both Ponroy and Lampenwelt are great examples of what I mean, and I'm quietly confident that they will both be strong assets for 3i.
Now what about Action? The company continues to surpass all normal expectations.
Action has really brought home to me the power of compounding.
Whether you look at sales, number of stores or EBITDA, the returns this company generates off a larger and larger base are exceptional.
When you combine all these positive factors with strong like-for-likes and sector-leading cash generation, you benefit from an outstanding returns on capital.
And I don't think we're anywhere near the peak for Action.
Although it's increasing the number of stores it opens every year, it is barely scratching the surface of how big it can become.

As you can see from this chart, store densities in Holland suggest that there is considerable white space opportunity in just France and Germany alone, and that's before we even consider the rest of Europe.
As I have said before, an Action store appeals to customers wherever we have opened them.
Action is part of that very exclusive set of retailers that have one format that works across borders in different retail environments and is therefore capable of achieving very significant scale.
Now at 3i we have a small but very brainy strategy team.
And when they're not helping Julia sell our debt business, I ask them to look at things for me.
Earlier this year, I asked them to think of themselves as specialist fund managers focusing on retail stocks and to come up with the 5 or 6 stocks they would have in their top bucket.
After lots of late nights and too much coffee and chocolate, they came up with this analysis.

They have picked Inditex, Dollarama, Five Below, XXL and B&M, a real mix of shapes and sizes, but if you're holding this portfolio, you probably wouldn't be too concerned by the current challenges in the high street.

As you can see, these companies produce good metrics across all the important KPIs, but the really interesting thing is, if you transpose Action's numbers onto this slide, you get a good perspective on the relative quality of the Action growth story.
And none of these 5 stocks has anything like the white space potential of Action.
I really enjoy being on the Action board.
It has a first-class executive team and a very wise Chairman in Adrian Bellamy.

Expansion on this scale produces its own type of challenges which are really fascinating, and the board is very involved in helping management maintain these strong growth rates while trying to avoid any high-speed problems.
And by the way, the Action compounding effect I mentioned earlier is very material for 3i.
Okay, enough about Action for today, except to say that I look forward to seeing you again at our day with Action management on the 30th of May.
Now let's turn to Infrastructure, where the market backdrop is no different.

There's significant dry powder and a lot of interest in this sector, which makes it all the more satisfying that our team delivered a very productive year both expanding 3iN's portfolio and raising 2 new funds.
The team produces growing asset management income for the group, as well as managing investment for 3iN, which in turn has produced very solid capital growth and dividends.

3iN is our main Infrastructure investment vehicle, but we have added some discrete fund initiatives in order to capitalize on 3i's broader network and capabilities and to strengthen the overall team in Infrastructure.
These new initiatives are in their early stages, but we expect them to grow over time and build on the income contribution of Infrastructure to the group.
Apart from investing in our Infrastructure capability and adding selectively to our PE investment team, we're not considering any change in our strategic approach.

As I said right at the beginning, we will remain focused on executing our simple strategy while maintaining a disciplined approach to new investment in those sectors and geographies that we know well.
We will also make the most of our proprietary capital.
That way, we can run our key winners and act more quickly and decisively when this helps secure new investment.
As you know, this is one of my favorite slides and illustrates what a powerful and efficient cash machine 3i has become.

We're getting better at finding new investment opportunities at sensible prices, and we have established the right processes and portfolio to deliver plenty of cash to reinvest and to distribute to shareholders.
Today, we have proposed a material increase to our additional dividend to reflect the strength of the group and the momentum we have in the business going forward.
Don't assume we'll keep up this level of increase every year, but we are a group that is certainly capable of very attractive cash distributions over time.
This is clearly a decent set of results, and I would like to thank each and every one at 3i for their contribution this year.
Many of our people have experienced harsher times, but everybody has worked really hard to secure this type of performance.
But there is no complacency at 3i.
We recognize that the macro is better but still finely balanced as well as there being potential for more political uncertainty.
Our people see the value in our processes and discipline and, as a result, have become better at finding, assessing and managing investments.
And I would say our teams are as good as any in their respective markets.
As you come to expect, we remain very careful about the costs of our platform.
And the Investment Committee remain -- maintains a fierce determination to resist those voices encouraging us to pay more than a given business might be worth.
So another decent year where our all-around performance should add to that body of evidence which will help investors properly assess 3i's longer-term potential.
I'll pass over to Julia.
There is an opportunity to extend that with the agreements with the LPs for another year, so till the end of '19.
We obviously haven't come to any view about that yet, but that's an important decision for next year.
[ That's right ].
I mean, yes, you're right.
We did signal that -- well, I mean this -- by about this time last year, we had quite a lot lower growth in the portfolio ex Action.
I think, at that time, that was particularly the impact of some of the weaker assets that we've talked about previously, so the Dynatects of this world and some of the retailers.

But what we're seeing now in the portfolio ex Action is the benefit of the new investments that we've done coming through their first phase of ownership and starting to really flow through into the earnings growth.
So we've talked -- I'm not going to name all of the companies that are in the different bars, but we've talked about the good earnings growth that we se in the likes of Audley with a strong U.
performance but also a growing U.
For example, ATESTEO, you've seen, has done a refinancing this year.
So that's also performing strongly.
So the average ex Action is always going to go up and down a little bit, especially when you've got a smaller number of companies.
So it's going to be very idiosyncratic to what's happening in a particular period, but I think what we're trying to show today is our confidence in the portfolio ex Action.
And then clearly, we have this fantastic asset on top of that as well.
On the multiple, I mean, we're content where we are in the valuation today.
As I said, we're trying to balance a number of factors, but we continue to keep it under review.
The business is obviously performing extremely well.

And you saw from the slide that Simon put up the potential for future growth, so I wouldn't view the 16x as fixed, but I wouldn't try and formula in some sort of rate of improvement or increase in that.
Chris Brown from JPMorgan.
Just a quick question about post-year-end events.
I mean clearly there's been a lot of investment.
You've got a dividend to come out.
Has there been much from the realization front since 31st of March? Okay, if there are no more questions.
Thanks very much for coming.
Have a good day.
The other question I had was on what industries you're looking at in terms of forward investments.

Any particular thing that sort of -- industrial subsector that pops to mind? And then on the DCF, I said what we're trying to balance is fantastic performance to date, big potential for future growth, but also there is inherent risk in sort of rolling out in the way they're doing and the execution that we've got.
And for that reason, we wouldn't move it to a DCF basis in our books.
DCF is a very good reference point, especially to the extent people get concerned about the multiple that we're applying.
That gives us sort of confidence in how we're looking at that.
I think what we try to do is to give you as much visibility of how we're valuing it.
So to give you all of the components: The multiple we use, you will also find in the press release.
We've given you a sensitivity.
So one turn on the multiple would be GBP 135 million on our value.
And so you can measure it from that perspective, but I think DCF has definitely got its place.
And it's definitely a good reference point, but I don't imagine us moving to that method anytime soon.
Philip? There's a number of things going through.
I think of the order of about GBP 100 million is sort of coming in over the recent weeks.
It's that sort of thing in smaller initiatives.
And there are 1 or 2 big things beginning to move along in terms of realizations.
Adedapo Oguntade from Morgan Stanley.
Just 3 questions here.
So one, in terms of your investment for FY '18, it is very close to EUR 500 million.
What's your guidance [indiscernible] for the rest of the year? Two, also looking at your PE assets, it is down to 37 assets and 3 quoted holdings at any -- at the moment.
The last few years, you've had a situation of net -- pretty much net realizations -- or realizations have been up of your investments.

Going forward, what should we expect? And then the last question, this comes to Action: Given your long-term growth potential in Action and the earnings performance as well as the enormous white space available in Europe, do you think it will be better to apply this year? [indiscernible].
Arun Melmane, Macquarie.
Can just I ask? You sort of had a map of Action, and you sort of looked at the white spaces.

What gives you so much confidence that the white space in probably France and Germany is almost alike in terms of revenue potential? Or even if you extend that across Europe, why do you think the white spaces are same in terms of property as you would see in sort of the Holland or the old places that Action did so well in? We look at a variety of things.
You know that automotive often features prominently.
I think I mentioned disruptive retailing is another sector we're looking very closely at.
We've had a bit of a leaner time on, if you like, B2B businesses like [indiscernible].
We're looking harder at a number of those.
There's 1 or 2 interesting opportunities in the states.
I don't know if they will happen, but we're certainly looking at a bunch of things.
So it's the same themes that we're planning to do.
There's no change in that.

Do you have a question? And perhaps you could also talk a little bit about how -- when the board is looking at Action and the fact it was 30% of NAV, how do you think about in terms of the sort of risk versus reward of that situation? Well, I mean, we consider that position carefully.
We debate it within the Investment Committee.
We debate it within the board.
There are some voices that said, if we could have 100% of our assets in Action, we should.
And there are others who are more cautious about the weighting, but I think we're a long way from where we'll be uncomfortable with how much we own of Action.
Charles Murphy, Panmure Gordon.
Eurofund V comes to an end at the end of -- potentially it comes to the end at the end of 2018.

How does -- what opportunities are there for you to extend that a bit further? And how does that affect how you think about Action and Scandlines? I think, if you step back and look at the information that we have, what's occurred really is this year was a very busy year in terms of realizations early on.
So a lot of that realization occurred in the first half.
And it's tidied up, on top of the previous 4 years, the portfolio considerably.

And therefore, what we're seeing is our teams devoting much, much more of their time to origination and therefore the [ WIP ] bucket, as we call it, being much fuller; and the ability for us to look across quite a good population of assets and to determine the ones that -- which we wish to pursue.

And that's not only about the investment thesis in the business but how we think we'll do in competition with others if there is competition and whether ultimately we'll be able to buy it at a price that we're comfortable with.
So there's quite a lot of judgments into how you manage that [ WIP ] down.
But it's really starting from the fact that, with a smaller, more manageable portfolio that has got less things going wrong with it, we can spend a lot more time originating.
And therefore, we're getting into a better rhythm in terms of investments, and it gives us the position to make choices over what we do, which is very important.
Chris? Why don't I take the first two? And Julia can come back to the third because she did touch on it in her presentation.
I mean we've had an unusually strong start, I would say, to the rapidity of investments.
And it's a bit like catching a bus, isn't it? And so we have signed quite a few deals in a short space of time.
There's absolutely no guarantee that the rest of the year will continue at that pace.

And I would expect it to moderate and for us to be more careful, but I do think we will invest more money this year than we have previously; and get closer to our sort of run rate of investment of around GBP 700 million, GBP 750 million, if you like.
In terms of realizations, it's early in the year.

There are things moving forward, but I would again expect, between realizations and refis, we'll get closer to our normal level which is around the GBP 750 million, GBP 800 million type level if markets remain conducive to that.

I mean you don't get absolute complete uniformity across store performance, but in some of these new countries and certainly in parts of France, we experienced better store economics than we experienced in Holland.
And in certain parts of Germany, we experienced less-good economics than we -- per store than we experienced in Holland.

But we find that, as the knowledge about Action and the brand becomes greater, as it has done very quickly in France because we've been able to open more stores more quickly, the economics move up to the Holland economics and even surpass them.
And we suspect the same will be true in Germany as the brand awareness builds up over time.
Austria is probably ahead of Holland, as another example to that mix in terms of store economics.
Daniel Garrod from Barclays.
A couple of questions from me.
First is on earnings growth trajectory.
Julia, I think, last year, you sort of commented on experiencing a sort of trough in earnings growth profile and your expectation of it becoming resurgent from there.
You've got a slide where you're showing sort of obviously the Action asset growing more than 30% but about GBP 650 million of value also growing more than 30%.

So did you see that being sustained, the sort of improvement in earnings momentum? Can you give any color around those sort of 4 assets that you detailed as being in that sort of GBP 650 million? What are they? And what's the sort of sustainability there? Second question was around the multiple of Action.

How -- if Action continues to grow more than 30% a year, how do you think about the interplay between revaluing it up to 18x again, growing into the multiple; or maintaining at 16x? It's Philip Middleton from Merrill's.

Can you say a little bit more about what you see happening in investments? Because if I were to criticize what you've been doing until fairly recently, the net investment rate is relatively slow compared to where it needed to be on a steady-state basis.
It seems to be kind of more steady state now.

Is that something you think is sustainable as you redeploy stuff in that area? How do you see the investment landscape, the opportunity set? And just more generally, how do you feel about the sort of outtrade at the moment? Well, I mean, we consider that position carefully.
We debate it within the Investment Committee.
We debate it within the board.
There are some voices that said, if we could have 100% of our assets in Action, we should.
And there are others who are more cautious about the weighting.
But I think we're a long way from where we'll be uncomfortable with how much we own of Action.
Good morning, everyone.
Welcome to 3i's results for the year to 31st of March 2017.
